The Japanese, usually the first in world to taste Beaujolais because of the time difference (eight hours ahead of France), will have to wait until Nov. 22 before raising Beaujolais in a ``kampai'' (cheers). The Tokyo government has suspended cargo flights into Japan for the next week as a security measure for a series of enthronement rituals for newly crowned Emperor Akihito. Philippe Girard, owner of Le Lutin, near the Arc de Triomphe, lives and breathes by the Beaujolais tradition, even bottling it himself after buying it by the barrel. ``I spent six hours washing 70 bottles yesterday,'' Girard said. ``I take it seriously. The proof is that while I was bottling I didn't drink a single drop. And then, at one past midnight, clack! - I offered a glass, on the house, to every customer here. Now that's tradition.'' A widespread and highly orchestrated advertising blitz heralds Beaujolais' arrival each year. ``It's the biggest commercial publicity operation ever invented in the world,'' said Girard. ``It's big business.'' But there is nevertheless a genuine eagerness surrounding its arrival. ``It's like a nationwide festival, a second July 14th,'' said wine merchant Patrice Marcoue, referring to national celebrations marking the French Revolution. Marcoue, who owns the Caves Mermoz wine cellar in Paris' chic St. Honore district, was delighted with Beaujolais 1990. ``Like the last two years, it is superb,'' he said. ``It's fruity, low in alcohol and rolls on the tongue.'' Other oenophiles are describing this year's vintage in Gallic sensual terms: ``racy,'' ``tender,'' ``full-bodied'' and ``well-formed''. The wine is named after the Beaujolais region in eastern France near the Swiss border, where 8,900 acres of vineyards yield the unassuming wine with a worldwide following. ``It's not a noble wine,'' said Marcoue. ``It goes well with sausage.'' Yet more than half of the 75 million bottles produced this year will be exported to 80 countries, led by Germany, Britain, Japan and the United States, according to the Interprofessional Union of Beaujolais. American wine lovers almost missed Beaujolais this year because of the presence of the banned fungicide procymidone. Washington and Paris haggled briefly before agreeing on the exports. The wine costs $4 to $7 per bottle in France but a whopping $27 per airlifted bottle in Tokyo. Prices in the Japanese capital tend to sink to about $8 for later arrivals. The ``very good'' vintages are this year, 1985 and 1989. 1987 was considered average, and 1984 below par. Bistros and restaurants across France prepared for their annual deluge of longtime clientele and old friends wanting to taste the wine on its first day.

DOC.HEAD: Some High Schools Question Honor Society Standards
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Christienson in 18th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Complaining that the selection process too often puts personality ahead of grades, some high schools around the country are dropping or considering eliminating their National Honor Society chapters. Hampshire Regional High School last week joined those that have withdrawn from the 22,000-chapter NHS, a program that high school students with a ``B'' average have listed on their college appliations for the past 70 years. The school complained that entrance requirements of character, leadership and service are too subjective ``Too often selection becomes a matter of personality,'' said Deborah Niswonger, chairwoman of the school board that oversees 645-student Hampshire High. She said the non-scholastic criteria rule out too many ``serious students.'' At the urging of teachers, including the NHS adviser, the board voted to install its own honor society, with grades the only criteria. ``Our faculty really cares about kids and not just one kind of kid,'' Niswonger said. Hampshire was the only school in the past year to quit the society, said Dale Hawley, director of student activities for the National Association of Secondary School Principals. The association has overseen the NHS since a group of high school principals in Pittsburgh started the student recognition group in 1920. Although schools have wide latitude in using the selection criteria, they cannot base their decision soley on academics, Hawley said. ``We are looking for the total child, who is outstanding both in and out of the classroom,'' he said. And deportment counts. ``Local faculty councils tolerate different levels of behavior,'' Hawley said. ``But there are a lot of smart people, who may be working hard, but not chosen, because they have not demonstrated strong character.'' It's those criteria that moved Hampshire and other schools to opt out of the society. Cony High School in Augusta, Maine, hasn't had an NHS chapter for at least seven years and ``hasn't missed it,'' said Principal Charles Adams. ``People felt the issues of leadership, character, service, and whatever were too difficult to quantify,'' he said. Instead, the top 10 percent of each class at the 1,000-student school are ``Cony Scholars'' and get a pin and a gold cord at graduation. Roger Lonbaker, principal at T. F. Riggs High School in Pierre, S.D., said, ``If I was a betting man I'd bet there isn't a school that has a National Honor Society chapter that hasn't at some point in time considered changing.'' His 550-student school will continued in the organization ``until we really find it is too frustrating,'' Lonbaker said. The move to buck the NHS at Hampshire High began after a parent wanted to know why a child had been rejected. The five-member faculty selection committee had no written records and said it couldn't recall why. Hawley said national guidelines call for secret elections with no explanation for why students are rejected. There is no opportunity for appeal. The student president of Hampshire's NHS chapter said she was disappointed to see it go. ``I just feel they are taking away an honor,'' said Amy Christienson. ``It's a distinguished group and people in the school know that.'' But Aaron Domina, another NHS member, said he supported the move. ``The way it is now, there are people who have high averages, who aren't honored,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Van Gogh Drawing Sets World Record Price at Christie's
DOC.TEXT: An ink image of summer fields, sketched by Vincent van Gogh with a reed he cut from the banks of a French canal, sold at auction for $8.6 million - the highest price ever paid for a drawing. ``Garden of Flowers'' was sold Wednesday to an anonymous bidder at Christie's auction of modern and Impressionist art. The bid topped the auction house's pre-sale estimate of $5 million to $7 million. The sale of the van Gogh came in the midst of what art experts say is a slumping art market. The previous record for a drawing was for a Raphael sold at Christie's London in 1984 for $4.77 million. Van Gogh drew the work in 1888 with a reed cut by the banks of one of the canals near Arles in the south of France. At the time, he needed to save money on the more expensive oil and canvas supplies. In a letter to his brother, Theo, the artist wrote about the energetic ink strokes he used to draw a field and houses in Arles: ``I have just sent off three big drawings, and the little cottage done vertically is, I think, the best.'' The rest of Christie's auction Wednesday was further proof of the softening art market. Many of the finest works of the late 19th and early 20th centuries sold below the pre-sale estimates - or not at all. One surprises was the failure to sell van Gogh's oil ``Vase with Cornflowers and Poppies,'' which was estimated to be worth $12 million to $16 million. The highest bid was about $9 million, below the minimum price. ``The grim reaper has taken his toll,'' said Christie's president Christopher Burge. ``Areas of the market that have been pushed to extraordinary heights have been eliminated. ... We're seeing speculators disappearing and other traditional collectors reappearing.'' The highest price of the evening was paid for Fernand Leger's oil ``Houses Beneath the Trees,'' which sold for $9.9 million to an unidentified American dealer. The estimated pre-sale price was $10 million to $12 million. Of 47 works offered, 15 failed to sell because they didn't meet the confidential minimum price set before the auction. Of the 32 works that sold, 17 matched or surpassed the pre-sale price estimates, Christie's said. The total sale for Wednesday night was $92.3 million.

DOC.HEAD: Pipeline to Carry Canadian Gas to Northeast
DOC.TEXT: A new $583 million pipeline linking the Northeast to Canadian natural gas fields could start trimming the region's dependence on imported oil within as little as a year, its developers say. After four years of contentious debate among environmentalists, homeowners and rival energy suppliers, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission on Wednesday unanimously approved the Iroquois pipeline project. ``Canada is going to play a role in our natural gas supply in the future and I think the Iroquois pipeline is going to be an integral part of that,'' said FERC board member Jerry Langdon. Ultimately, tight energy supplies in New England, New York and New Jersey outweighed the concerns of pipeline opponents. They ranged from wildcat oil drillers in the Southwest to psychologist Dr. Joyce Brothers, whose Hudson Valley estate in New York would be crossed by the line. Nearly half of New England's primary energy needs are now met by oil. The region, for example, uses oil to generate nearly a third of its electricity, compared to only 2.8 percent nationwide, according to Iroquois. Existing gas pipelines to the Northeast from U.S. gas fields have been running at capacity for years. FERC is considering many applications to expand existing pipelines but Iroquois is the only totally new line proposed for the region. Robert J. Reid, president of the Iroquois Gas Transmission System, a consortium of U.S. and Canadian gas companies and utilities based in Shelton, Conn., said the consortium hopes to have gas flowing to New York and New England by November 1991 and to complete the line by January 1992. The pipeline will extend 370 miles from the St. Lawrence River through the woodlands of upstate New York, beneath the Hudson River, into affluent sections of western Connecticut and across Long Island Sound to Long Island. It is designed to deliver 575 million cubic feet of gas daily, or enough to meet the energy needs of 1.5 million homes. Some of the gas will go toward electricity generation rather than home heating and industrial uses. TransCanada Pipelines Ltd., one of Iroquois' several owners, estimated the new line will generate $1 billion per year in exports for Canada. Canada has been supplying natural gas to the United States since the 1960s, but mostly in the West and Midwest.
DOC.HEAD: AIDS Panelists Differ on Time Spent to Weigh Steroids Treatment
DOC.TEXT: Members of a scientific panel that drafted guidelines for adding steroids to the treatment of a killer pneumonia in people with AIDS disagree over whether they took too long to come up with teir findings. ``In retrospect, it should have happened more quickly,'' Paul Meier, professor of statistics at the University of Chicago and vice chairman of the 17-member panel, said Wednesday. However, Dr. Henry Masure, the panel's chairman and chief of critical care at the National Institutes of Health, called the three months for the review ``a relatively short period.'' ``I don't think it will ever get much faster,'' he said. Since steroids weaken the immune system, ``the whole concept of giving steroids to someone with AIDS is very novel and controversial.'' AIDS activists had charged that the panel - organized by the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases and the University of California at San Diego - took too long. The broad outline of a consensus on the steroid issue was reached May 15, but it wasn't until late August that the panelists agreed on technical details, such as who should get the therapy and in what doses. On Oct. 10, the institute sent an alert to 2,600 physicians informing them that recent studies had found benefits among some patients with pneumocycstis carinii pneumonia whose treatment was supplemented with steroids. Dr. Samuel Bozzette, assistant professor of medicine at the University of California at San Diego and a panel member, said that ``in a perfect system, it could have been shorter, but it was not an unreasonable amount of time.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Airliner Hijacked On Domestic Flight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CORRECT that Swedes, and not Finns, reversed policy by returning hijackers, SUBS 3 grafs for last graf pvs.
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet man who claimed he had a bomb hijacked an Aeroflot passenger jet on a domestic flight and forced its crew to fly to Helsinki, where he surrendered to police on Thursday, national radio reported. None of the 66 passengers or six crew members aboard were hurt, the report said. The hijacked aircraft landed at 5:30 a.m. Police Chief Commissioner Kauko Karhuviita said the Tupolev aircraft had been en route to Moscow from Leningrad when the hijacker threatened to blow it up. ``The hijacker wanted to fly to Stockholm but the plane landed here. The situation is under control now,'' Karhuviita said in a radio interview. ``All the passengers are out of the plane and we are holding the hijacker ... It seems he will want to apply for political asylum,'' Karhuviita said. Three Soviet planes have been hijacked to Finland this year. The government extradited two hijackers and refused political asylum for a third, who is in police custoday. Three planes have been hijacked to Sweden, where authorities returned two to the Soviets and allowed one to stay. Finland's practice has always been to return hijackers to the Soviet Union. Sweden previously allowed hijackers to stay. The return of two men this year reflected Swedish recognition of human rights gains in the Soviet Union and a desire to deter other hijackers.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Blocks Ventilation Standards That He Calls Deadly
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer for an anti-smoking group has blocked the adoption of national ventilation standards that he said could have caused thousands of deaths from second-hand cigarette smoke in public buildings. The proposal ``misrepresents the available scientific evidence, misleading engineers, developers and building code authorities into believing that they can ... permit `moderate amounts of smoking' while avoiding significant adverse health effects'' from second-hand smoke, attorney Richard Daynard wrote in an appeal to the American National Standards Institute in New York. The standards institute said Wednesday it sustained Daynard's appeal and did not adopt the standards. Daynard charged that the proposal reflected the aims of the tobacco industry, which had sought to soften ventilation requirements in buildings where smoking is allowed. ``The tobacco industry almost succeeded in pulling off a tremendous coup,'' said Daynard, chairman of the Tobacco Products Liability Project in Boston. ``They were using the standards to cast doubt on the evidence that environmental tobacco smoke causes disease.'' The Tobacco Institute has been sending employers a letter that says, in part, ``Where ventilation is adequate and ventilation systems are properly maintained, tobacco smoke is not a problem.'' The letter bases that conclusion on the proposed ventilation standards. Brennan Dawson, a spokeswoman for the Tobacco Institute in Washington, denied that the institute had tried to influence the standards, and she dismissed Daynard's concerns. ``Daynard would have us with a smoke-free society,'' she said. ``His position has always been that you cannot protect people from anything. Daynard is really out in left field on this issue.'' The dispute over the standards represents a major battle over smoking that took place almost entirely outside the public's view, Daynard said. ``It's an interesting glimpse into a hidden government which nobody elected and was not appointed by anyone we elected, but sets the standards which govern the way we live, the air we breathe,'' he said. The standards were written by a committee appointed by the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air Conditioning Engineers in Atlanta. ASHRAE then submitted the standards for adoption by the American National Standards Institute, a private group that establishes a wide variety of industrial and consumer standards. Its standards are often written into law. The institute's adoption of the ventilation standards would have enabled employers to defend themselves against charges they were endangering employees by allowing smoking in their buildings, Daynard said. He said it is now likely the standards will be changed to reflect concerns about the toxic effects of cigarette smoke. That could force many employers to ban smoking or face liability for the harm that tobacco smoke causes, Daynard said. The Environmental Protection Agency and the National Research Council have estimated that second-hand smoke causes 3,800 deaths in nonsmoking Americans each year. A study presented earlier this year by Stanton Glantz and William Parmley of the University of California at San Francisco estimated that passive smoking causes 32,000 heart disease deaths in nonsmokers each year and 53,000 deaths overall. The chairman of the ASHRAE committee that drafted the standards, John Janssen, a Honeywell engineer in Minneapolis, denied that the tobacco industry influenced the standards. ``They aren't all that interested,'' he said. Janssen said the committee included three nonvoting members who have done business with the tobacco industry, including a consultant hired by the Tobacco Institute to represent industry concerns. One voting member also reviews grants for the Center for Indoor Air Research, a tobacco-industry supported organization in Linthicum, Md. Members of anti-smoking groups did not regularly participate in the deliberations, Janssen said.

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll Rises to 13
DOC.TEXT: The death toll in the country's worst massacre rose to 13 today when police found human remains in the debris of a house the killer set ablaze before opening fire on his neighbors. The remains were believed to be those of two 11-year-old girls missing in the 23-hour siege that ended Wednesday the South Island seaside hamlet of Aramoana. Discovery of the two bodies raised to 13 the number of people slain by 33-year-old David Gray before police killed him in a shootout. Two children were wounded by Gray, who wiped out nearly half of Aramoana's population. Gray began his killing spree Tuesday night by setting a neighbor's house on fire, then opening fire on people who arrived to try to extinguish the blaze. The motive for his actions remains unclear. Police kept the town cordoned off today except for forensic experts, government officials and journalists. Gray, who holed up in his home before fleeing to a house on the edge of town, used high-powered rifles to shoot neighbors and keep police from reaching victims scattered on the lawn of his house and a nearby street. Detective Chief Inspector Peter Robinson told a news conference today that after police riddled with tear gas and shot the house to which Gray had fled, he emerged shouting ``Kill me, Kill me'' and firing a rifle from his hip. Fatally wounded, the gunman remained ``very active'' and criticized police for not finishing him off. ``He was quite possessed,'' Robinson said. ``He was extremely strong and very hyped up.'' The village lies on a point in an area of steep hillsides and sandy marsh about 20 miles north of Dunedin on the island's southeastern coast. It comprises just five streets and was home to about 25 people before the massacre. Most of the houses are vacation homes, not fully occupied this time of year. Among those killed were a couple and one of their two children, with their 4-year-old son hospitalized with a stomach wound. They were visiting for the day to work on their boat, according to the couple's nephew. A man who lived in the house Gray torched also was shot dead, and his daughter and a friend's daughter, both 11, were missing and presumed dead in the fire. The man's 9-year-old daughter was recovering from a gunshot wound. A psychiatrist and four parents helped console children at the 143-student primary school in nearby Port Chester, where the students included two 6-year-olds who were killed and the two missing girls. The unemployed Gray, who had an obsession with guns, was reported upset over the recent death of his mother. Some neighbors also pointed to a long-simmering dispute between Gray and the victim whose house he burned.

DOC.HEAD: Ambassador: Kuwaiti Resistance Smuggled Out Computer Records
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Kuwaiti officials say resistance fighters have smuggled out computer records on Kuwait's entire pre-invasion population, helping frustrate Iraqi efforts to erase all traces of their society. The 25 computer discs are said to contain the names and fingerprints of the entire population before Iraq's assault. They are in New York, and Kuwaiti officials want the United Nations to take custody of a set until the current crisis is over, the ambassador of Kuwait's government-in-exile, Mohammad A. Abulhasan, said Wednesday. ``We have discovered from the first two weeks of the Iraqi aggression that there is a deliberate plan for changing the demographic status of Kuwait by destroying records,'' he said. Abulhasan began circulating the text of a proposed resolution on Wednesday which would call on U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to take possession of a copy of the tapes for safekeeping. U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering said the proposal for the United Nations to take possession of the records ``seems to us a very good idea.'' One mainframe computer had all Kuwait's demographic records, Abulhasan said. ``Armed with that fact, we were able through the resistance movement to get out these records, which are electronic discs,'' he said. The records were hidden during the first week of the occupation, Abulhasan said. ``Fifteen days ago, we managed to get them out of Kuwait.'' Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and later annexed the oil-rich emirate. Kuwait's government-in-exile and the U.N. Security Council are concerned over Iraq's attempt to convert occupied Kuwait into a province of Iraq and to move 150,000 Iraqis into buildings vacated by fleeing Kuwaitis. Exiled Kuwaitis accuse the Baghdad government of trying to repopulate their country with supporters of President Saddam Hussein. The underground movement salvaged information on all 1.75 million residents of Kuwait, Abulhasan said. He said the information was current with names, addresses and fingerprints. The records will help ``to differentiate between the Kuwaitis and the non-Kuwaitis'' when the crisis is over and might be the basis for compensation claims, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Shakes Sumatra, Thailand And Malaysia
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake jolted the northern part of Indonesia's Sumatra Island and shook high-rise buildings in Thailand and Malaysia today, but officials said no casualties or damage were reported. The quake caused momentary panic during the morning rush hour in the North Sumatra capital of Medan, police there reported. It struck at 9:34 a.m. and was measured at 6.2 on the Richter scale by monitors in Indonesia and Malaysia and at 6.9 by seismological agencies in Thailand and the United States. Monitors put its location in the Andaman Sea, between Sumatra and the peninsula on which Malaysia and southern Thailand are located. In Bangkok, Thailand's Meteorological Department received reports that tremors were felt in high-rise buildings in Phuket and nearby Songkhla province as well as in Bangkok, about 430 miles north of Phuket. In Kuala Lumpur, the tremors sent office workers scurrying down to the street from many high-rise buildings. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one number means the ground motion is 10 times greater. A magnitude 6 can cause severe damage in populated areas, while a magnitude 7 means a major quake capable of widespread, heavy damage.

DOC.HEAD: Wiper Inventor Ready to Take on Other Automakers in Patent Suits
DOC.TEXT: The inventor of the intermittent windshield wiper says he's ready to take on nearly two dozen other automakers after accepting a $10.2 million settlement with Ford Motor Co. for infringing on his patents. ``Maybe I got to first base,'' Robert Kearns, 63, of Houston, said after agreeing to the settlement Wednesday. Intermittent wipers, now standard or optional equipment on nearly all cars sold in the United States, automatically start and stop at intervals. Kearns is claiming in separate lawsuits that 19 automakers infringed on his patents for the intermittent wipers. The inventor patented the device in 1967 and shopped them around to automakers. He started the lawsuits 12 years ago. ``I don't think the goal was the magnitude of the money,'' Kearns said. ``What I saw as my role was to defend the patent system. If I don't go further, there really isn't a patent system.'' Chrysler Corp. may be the next defendant up for trial, but a spokesman indicated the automaker may settle. ``Because of the Ford settlement, we're encouraged that we will probably be able to reach agreement with Mr. Kearns without extended litigation,'' said Tom Houston. Originally, Kearns sought $141 million from Ford. In July, a jury ordered Ford to pay $5.2 million, plus interest, for patent infringement, for a total of $8.5 million to $11.5 million. Kearns appealed the award; the settlement came before the appeal could be decided. ``We're pleased to be done with the litigation,'' said Ford attorney Malcolm Wheeler. ``We still believe that if we had another shot at it, the patents would have been held invalid.'' Bill Durkee, one of Kearns' attorneys, said Ford ``got away with more than they should. They made a profit from their infringement.'' Ford Motor Co. dealers have sold an estimated 20 million Ford, Lincoln and Mercury cars with intermittent wipers. After legal defense costs, the settlement nets Kearns 33 cents per car. If the Ford settlement pattern were followed with Chrysler's estimated 13 million cars with intermittent wipers, it would work out to about $4.3 million without legal fees. Durkee said Chrysler probably would be the next legal target. Durkee said Chrysler has agreed not to contest the validity of Kearns' patents, an argument that took up time in the Ford trial. Kearns had claimed he installed a set of intermittent wipers on a Ford and took it to the automaker. Kearns, a professor at Wayne State University in Detroit at the time, said he was led to believe Ford would buy his invention by the number of questions engineers asked. When that failed to happen, he sued. Kearns said he plans to pay off some legal debts and, perhaps, buy a house in Texas. And he'll continue the legal battles to protect his patent. ``They (lawyers) are running a business,'' he said. ``I'm running a cause.''

DOC.HEAD: Celebrities Say: Butt Out For Smokeout
DOC.TEXT: Broadway's Carol Channing said Cupid and fear of smelling like a sewer led her to quit smoking. Hockey star Rod Gilbert said he gave up cigarettes after getting bopped by his big brother. And Broadway actress and singer Karen Akers, who performed in ``Grand Hotel,'' summed up the depth of her anti-smoking convictions this way: ``I even want my ex-husband to quit.'' Stars from television, stage, sports, music and politics turned out Wednesday at American Cancer Society offices in New York to promote today's Great American Smokeout and say why they kicked the habit or never started. The Smokeout, sponsored by the American Cancer Society, is held the third Thursday in November to get smokers to quit. This is the 14th annual Smokeout. ``When I was 30 and doing eight shows a day, I smoked three packs a day,'' Channing said. ``I couldn't get into a bathtub without an ashtray, a match and a cigarette.'' A warning from her doctor got her thinking about quitting, but, she said, Cupid deserves the real credit. ``I met my future husband and he didn't smoke. ... I didn't want to smell like an old sewer around somebody I was stuck on.'' Lung surgeon Dr. Bill Cahan of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center told the crowd that Sammy Davis Jr., Yul Brynner and Leonard Bernstein couldn't attend because they are dead from smoking. ``I see the end result of smoking all too often,'' Cahan said. ``As a matter of fact, I've named my surgery room `Marlboro Country.''' Gilbert said at age 12 he stole a pack of cigarettes from his older brother. When he found out, Gilbert said, ``He took me upstairs to the bathroom and hit me on the head with his fist ... and then said, `Get up, I'm going to hit you again.''' Gilbert left cigarettes alone until he opened a restaurant after retirement from hockey. ``I guess I felt deprived from the time I was 12,'' he said. He quit two years ago after having some polyps removed. Rapper LL Cool J never was and never will be a smoker. ``Smoking is the pits. It's terrible. It's garbage. I hate it. Get rid of them,'' Cool J said before punching the giant cigarette box off the stage and into a sound man. Smoking causes lung cancer, heart disease and respiratory disease, scientists say. The surgeon general has warned of the risks of smoking and the addictive nature of nicotine.

DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Sylvester Stallone's sister says it bothers her that people think the ``Rocky'' and ``Rambo'' star is dimwitted and self-absorbed. ``People think he is really a jerk,'' ToniAn Stallone said in a taping of the ``Geraldo'' show, which airs Friday. ``It's kind of sad in a way, because he really struggles against that. I think, now that he's getting older, he would like to be more respected.'' Miss Stallone said her brother went to college in Switzerland and attended the University of Miami. ``I'm proud of him and when I was little, growing up - there's a big age difference between us - he was my hero,'' she said. Appearing with Miss Stallone on the show were Cher's sister, Georganne LaPiere, Barbra Streisand's sister, Roslyn Kind, and Jerry Hall's sister, Rosy Hall.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against major foreign currencies today in early European trading. Gold prices were lower. Dealers said the dollar moved higher following remarks by the French economics minister, Pierre Beregovoy, that he expects a meeting of the Group of Seven industrialized countries finance ministers in the ``coming weeks'' to discuss the dollar's weakness, The statement was interpreted as a sign of France's growing irritation over the dollar's decline, traders said. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.25 yen to a closing 129.30 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 129.20 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Wednesday: -1.4780 German marks, up from 1.4715 -1.2505 Swiss francs, up from 1.2460 -4.9825 French francs, up from 4.9585 -1.6613 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6593 -1,113.50 Italian lire, up from 1,109.00 -1.1612 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1640 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9600, compared with $1.9615 late Wednesday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $378.50 per ounce at midmorning, from $384.45 bid per ounce late Wednesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $378.65, down from $384.40 late Wednesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $4.43 to close at a bid $379.03. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.17 a troy ounce, from Wednesday's $4.21.

DOC.HEAD: Hall of Fame Reconsidering Eligibility Requirements
DOC.TEXT: Is there a movement under way to keep Pete Rose out of the Hall of Fame? Some members of a committee recently formed to review the Hall's eligibility guidelines certainly think so. One committee member called the action taken by the Hall of Fame ``a little suspicious,'' and another said it's a ``thinly veiled attempt to keep Rose out.'' William Guilfoile, the Hall's associate director, said a nine-member panel of baseball executives and writers will meet in December or January to look at the way the writers' and veterans' selection committees choose Hall of Famers. The timing of the move raised suspicions among the Baseball Writers' Association of America, whose 450 members elect players to the Hall. Rose, the game's all-time hit leader, is eligible for election in 1992, five years after his last game as a player. ``We've been voting since 1935 and there have never been questions about the way we've been conducting our elections,'' Jack Lang, executive secretary of the BWAA, said Wednesday. ``Suddenly, a year before Pete Rose comes up for election, they want to review our process. It makes us a little suspicious.'' Guilfoile said the panel was not being convened exclusively to consider the Rose case. But ``if someone on the committee wants to discuss it, I'm sure they will be able to,'' he said. Sportswriter Frank Dolson of The Philadelphia Inquirer, selected by the sportswriters' group to serve on the committee, disagreed, saying the committee is ``just a thinly veiled attempt to keep Rose out.'' ``He's eligible in '92, nd you have to ask yourself how it would look if they have to give a plaque to someone who's been banned from the game,'' Dolson said. ``What they'll probably do is make it impossible for us to vote on someone who's banned from baseball.'' Rose is serving a prison term in Marion, Ill., for cheating on his taxes and has been banned from the game for life for gambling. Nothing in the current rules excludes him from being elected to the Hall of Fame, Guilfoile said. Rose set several records in a 24-year career with Cincinnati, Montreal and Philadelphia, including most hits (4,256), most singles (3,215), most games (3,562) and most seasons with 200 or more hits (10). He was considered a shoo-in for the Hall until 1989, when then-commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti banned him from the game.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Promises Soviets Emergency Supplies If Needed This Winter
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that Germany is ready to send the Soviets emergency supplies in case of a food crisis, and a newspaper said Washington is drawing up plans to provide food and medical aid. There is concern that the Soviet Union could face serious shortages of food and other essentials this winter, causing extreme hardship and possibly provoking civil unrest. Kohl, in a speech to Parliament, said Eastern European nations also could face severe problems this winter and that he would like wealthy industrial states to be ready to help out. The German leader said that in his talks last weekend with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, he promised that Germany would assist the Soviet Union financially ``to the best of our powers.'' He said Germany will be sending a group of ``high-ranking experts'' to advise the Soviets as they attempt the transition from a socialist command economy to a free-market system. Kohl noted that Germany has already promised massive amounts of assistance for the Soviets - so far about $19.5 billion. He promised that Germany will send emergency shipments of food to the Soviet Union ``in case of acute supply crises.'' The chancellor said that in his talks with President Bush this Sunday at Kohl's home in Oggersheim, he will urge that all Western industrial nations be ready to help out the economically embattled former Soviet bloc. ``I will discuss with President Bush how the Western industrial lands can effectively and jointly support the reform processes'' in Eastern Europe, ``especially in view of the severe winter standing before the reform states,'' said Kohl. Britain's leading business daily, the Financial Times, said today that the United States already has made plans to aid the Soviets. The Times, without revealing its sources, said that reports this week that Moscow and Leningrad may have to introduce food rationing before Christmas heightened White House concern about internal instability in the Soviet Union. The paper said U.S. officials have spoken with allies about the possibility of international humanitarian aid such as food, medicine and clothing this winter, but that the means of coordinating the effort remains unresolved. In his speech, Kohl appealed for people who were East Germans until last month the have patience with the huge presence of Red Army troops that are to be pulled out over the next few years. ``We want the Soviet soldiers and their families to feel good during their remaining time here,'' said Kohl. There has been growing intolerance for the troops among Germans in the eastern part of the country. In addition, there are reports of rising crime and desertion among the Soviet soldiers The Soviets have agreed to withdraw their army in eastern Germany by 1994.

DOC.HEAD: Cool in Pacific Northwest; Unseasonably Warm Elsewhere
DOC.TEXT: Practically the entire nation had clear skies and looked for unseasonably high temperatures today as a high-pressure front move warm air east from the Plains. Except for some clouds and fog over Oregon and Washington, skies were generally clear across the continental United States today. Several inches of snow were expected in the mountains in Washington tonight, and rain was forecast for central California and Nevada. But elsewhere the forecast was for sunny skies and temperatures as much as 30 degrees above normal. Highs were expected to be in the 70s across most of the East Coast and Midwest, the 80s across the South and Southwest, the 60s in the Northeast, and the 50s and 60s in the Pacific Northwest. The high temperature for the nation Thursday was 90 at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Strike-Bound Newspaper Reportedly Hiring Drivers as `Bait'
DOC.TEXT: Two workers hired as Daily News drivers say they were really brought in as ``bait'' to get film of strikers attacking them. The two, who have since quit, said they and others were given video and still cameras and sent out to deliver papers and collect money from vendors - and be attacked by union members. ``We were bait,'' said Jim McCully of Clarksville, Tenn. ``The bottom line was that we were supposed to be cheese for rats.'' He and a man from Lexington, Ky., who asked not to be identified, said in today's The New York Times they answered an ad in a Kentucky newspaper promising a ``prestigious security position.'' But after they got to the New York area, they learned the real nature of the jobs, they said. McCully said he and others were told by a representative of Securex, the Kentucky security firm that recruited them: ``Your job is to get documentation on film of union members breaking your necks.'' Securex general counsel Bill Crabtree refused to discuss any connection between the firm and the Daily News. ``We have hired vendors from places around the country,'' said Daily News spokeswoman Lisa G. Robinson. ``We told them to avoid confrontation, not to carry weapons.'' She would not discuss Daily News security operations. The strike, which began Oct. 25, has been marked by dozens of reports of violence. The Daily News has reported damage to 76 of its trucks, and police say 39 vendors have reported being threatened or having their newspapers taken.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinians March, Fly Flags on Independence Day
DOC.TEXT: Palestinians flew their outlawed national flag from rooftops today and marched through villages chanting anti-Israeli slogans, defiantly celebrating the second anniversary of their declaration of independence. Army curfews covered most of the Gaza Strip and more than half of the West Bank, confining more than 1 million Palestinians to their homes. The army closed all schools and declared the Gaza Strip and all West Bank cities sealed military areas to keep journalists out. For the past two days, soldiers have fired tear gas and rubber bullets to break up marches and demonstrations that were held early in anticipation of the curfews. They also reportedly carried out widespread arrests of activists. The underground leadership of the nearly 3-year-old Palestinian uprising called for three days of celebrations, starting today. They mark the declaration of independence issued Nov. 15, 1988 by the parliament-in-exile of the Palestine Liberation Organization. In the West Bank village of Tamoun, nationalist songs sounded from a loudspeaker in the main square. ``We will challenge the army and its tanks with our war of the knive and the war of the street,'' one lyric said. Twelve masked activists wearing black and khaki uniforms marched through the village. They brandished knives, unfurled Palestinian flags and sprayed graffiti. The pro-PLO leadership of the uprising allowed shops to stay open all day during the celebrations, giving respite to a population worn down by the numerous general strikes that are part of the intefadeh, or uprising. Many cars flew balloons in the Palestinian national colors, army radio said. In Bethlehem, one of the few West Bank towns not under curfew, Palestinian flags fluttered from rooftops. Near the Church of the Nativity, where tradition says Jesus was born, shoppers crowded the outdoor market, taking advantage of all-day shopping. The independence declaration, which implied recognition of Israel, gave Palestinians in the occupied lands a psychological boost but brought few changes in their daily lives. The declaration was recognized by Arab and many Third World countries but rejected by Israel and Western nations. Army radio reported that in the past week, troops raided more than 400 West Bank villages and arrested scores of Palestinians seen as potential inciters. An army official said the report was exaggerated. ``Certainly, there was an effort to go into many villages over the past couple of months to look for wanted people,'' said the official, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``But I don't know anything about the army going into 400 villages,'' he said. The official said the army viewed widespread curfews as the most effective way of preventing violence and insisted they were not collective punishment. ``Curfews are not intended to wear down the population. That type of claim could have been made two years ago, but that is not at all the case today,'' he said. Troops dynamited three homes in Gaza's Bureij refugee camp of Palestinians suspected of participating in the stoning death of an Israeli soldier in the fall. The demolitions brought to 15 the number of houses destroyed as punishment for the soldiers' killing. During the uprising, the army has destroyed or sealed more than 500 Palestinian homes to punish uprising suspects. Western countries and international organizations have condemned the tactic as a human rights violation. At least 773 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the uprising, which began Dec. 8, 1987. Fifty-two Israelis have died in the violence. In addition, 299 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaboration.

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Says He Planned Attempt on Gorbachev's Life for Two Years
DOC.TEXT: The man who tried to shoot at Soviet leaders during last week's Revolution Day parade had been planning to kill President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for more than two years, Soviet news reports said today. Alexander A. Shmonov, a 38-year-old unemployed man from Leningrad, was charged with attempted terrorism in the Nov. 7 shooting on Red Square. Police say Shmonov managed to fire two shots, but was prevented by police from targeting Gorbachev and other Soviet leaders, who were observing the traditional military parade from atop Lenin's Mausoleum. No one was hurt. Col. Pyotr Sokolov, a top KGB investigator, told the newspaper Glasnost that a body search of Shmonov turned up a note confirming that Gorbachev was his intended victim. ``The note was prepared in advance in case of his death during the assassination attempt,'' Sokolov was quoted as saying in a Tass news agency report of the interview. ``In the note, Shmonov explicitly set out his criminal intentions as regards to the Soviet president.'' According to Glasnost, the shooting took place just 46 yards from the mausoleum. Police said an officer had noticed Shmonov pulling out a hunting rifle and aim at the Soviet leaders on the mausoleum. The officer forced the gun barrel skyward before Shmonov fired the two shots. He was then grabbed by more security men. ``Shmonov said he had been preparing this assassination attempt for more than two years,'' Sokolov told the newspaper. ``During that time, he acquired an imported double-barreled hunting rifle and practiced rapid firing.'' Another newspaper, Rabochaya Trybuna, said Shmonov had a hunting license and bought the weapon legally for $1,600. ``He went to a public library to read about the correct way to prepare a cartridge and asked some questions of hunters who were in the store,'' the newspaper said. ``To carry the gun into Red Square, he sawed off the butt and fixed a kind of pocket made of rubbery material inside his jacket,'' the report said, quoting an official in the state prosecutor's office. The newspaper said Shmonov, who is being held in a KGB investigation ward, arrived in Moscow on Nov. 6 and rented an apartment. ``The owner told him it wouldn't be easy to get into Red Square, so he spent the night reading newspapers describing meeting places for people participating in the parade,'' the newspaper said. Sgt. Andrei Mylnikov, the policeman who subdued Shmonov during the shooting, said in an interview with Moscow News on Wednesday that the gunman told investigators: ``I wanted to kill Gorbachev.'' Shmonov joined a delegation from the Bauman region during the parade marking the 73rd anniversary of the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution. The shooting took place five minutes after Gorbachev, Yeltsin and other officials returned to the mausoleum after marching with pro-Communist demonstrators. The last reported attempt to assassinate a Soviet leader was in 1969, when a Red Army officer tried to kill party chief Leonid Brezhnev. The gunman, Lt. Viktor Ilyin, missed and killed a chauffeur and wounded three other people. He spent 21 years in a psychiatric hospital and was released in February.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS MYRTLE BEACH, S.C.-dated 4th item in rdp to CORRECT spelling of accommodations in lead.
DOC.TEXT: Mickey Spillane has written a special potboiler for South Carolina troops in Saudi Arabia, and those who solve the mystery have a chance to win free air travel or hotel accommodations. ``This little story is just a way to keep the guys reminded of Myrtle Beach,'' said the author, a World War II fighter pilot and resident of nearby Murrells Inlet. The mystery contest designed to entertain members of the 354th Tactical Air Force, based at Myrtle Beach Air Force Base, features eight weekly installments with clues leading to the whereabouts of a former South Carolina beauty queen after a fictional kidnapping. The story will be sent to military officials via facsimile machine for distribution to the aspiring pulp-fiction detectives. Those who put together the clues qualify for a grand prize of two round-trip air tickets and several runner-up prizes of hotel accommodations. ``Once they get home, they'll be able to go on a vacation or take a trip to visit their parents, whatever they want,'' said Maj. John Elrod, who came up with the idea.

DOC.HEAD: Local Officials Appeal for Government Help in Typhoon-Hit Areas
DOC.TEXT: Local officials today appealed for help in areas ravaged by Typhoon Mike which killed more than 140 people as it swept across the central Philippine islands. Cebu, the country's second major port city, remained without drinking water, telephones and electricity two days after the storm struck, said Sen. John Osmena, who returned from the stricken area 350 miles southeast of Manila. Nearly 50 passenger, cargo and Philippine navy ships sank during the storm, most of them in Cebu's port. Typhoon Mike's ferocious winds also blew a Panamanian cargo ship, causing it to slam into the Mactan bridge and making it unpassable to truckloads of supplies in and out of the city. ``It's like we were hit by an atomic bomb,'' Osmena said after returning to Manila. ``There is not a single electric pole nor tree still standing up. Everything was blown down.'' Osmena complained that there has been no help from the central government despite President Corazon Aquino's declaration of a state of calamity in Cebu and other provinces. ``I don't know what that declaration means,'' Osmena told private radio DZXL. ``Up to now, we don't know what she has done for us. This is the problem with this government. It dilly-dallys a lot about everything.'' He said there is a food shortage in Cebu province and water is being rationed. Queues for gasoline and fuel were half a mile long, he added. In nearby Negros Occidental, Cabinet members met with businessmen who urged the government to supply the province with fuel to salvage the prawn industry that was damaged by the typhoon. The typhoon destroyed $1.6 million worth of prawn ponds and infrastructure needed by the industry, the island's second largest.

DOC.HEAD: Catholic Bishop Cancels TV Shows After Priesthood Sex Reports
DOC.TEXT: Catholic officials have canceled plans to allow a TV station to broadcast holiday church services following the station's broadcast of a controversial report on sex in the priesthood. Bishop Louis E. Gelineau of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Providence said the three-part series ``Love in the Rectory'' was offensive and an injustice to Rhode Island's nearly 500 priests. The report by WPRI-TV included an interview with a former priest who said he was not celibate and eventually married a former nun. It also discussed cases involving priests convicted of having sex with children. Galineau said he was canceling plans to have WPRI broadcast Thanksgiving and Christmas services at which he was to say Mass. ``I must now re-evaluate the official relationship between ourselves and your station,'' he said in a letter to Robert Finke, the station's vice president and general manager. He also demanded an on-air apology. The station, which said it received dozens of letters praising and criticizing last week's series, issued a statement during Tuesday's evening news program that offered a partial apology. ``If viewers were offended by the frankness of the series or its title, we apologize, but Channel 12 felt the issue was one that needed to be addressed,'' evening news anchorwoman Karen Adams said. ``We felt it was necessary to run the story,'' Finke added in an interview Wednesday. But Galineau complained that the series was packaged in a ``provocative way'' designed to boost ratings. ``I cannot ignore the fact this this is `sweeps week' and the obvious connection between increased viewership and advertising rates for the evening newscasts,'' he wrote. Sweeps week is a period when competition for TV ratings is particularly fierce.

DOC.HEAD: Police Break Up Marijuana Ring Using Toll-Free Number
DOC.TEXT: Police say they have arrested a man known as the ``pope of pot'' whose drug ring sold about $40,000 worth of marijuana a day through a toll-free number: 1-800-WANT-POT. Michael Cesar, 48, was arrested Wednesday with seven alleged accomplices after narcotics officers raided an apartment, said police spokesman Scott Bloch. During the raid, police confiscated at least 7 pounds of marijuana and $3,000 in cash, Bloch said. Cesar, alleged head of the drug ring, said he belongs to an organization called ``The Church of Realized Fantasies,'' Bloch said. The operation, which took in $40,000 a day in marijuana sales, received orders by telephone through the toll-free number, Bloch said. Callers were directed to certain streetcorners in lower Manhattan, to which couriers were then dispatched on bicycles to deliver the order, he said. The eight arrested are all charged with conspiracy to sell marijuana and criminal possession of marijuana, Bloch said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Airliner Hijacked to Finland; Two Americans Aboard
DOC.TEXT: A man who claimed he had a bomb hijacked a Soviet airliner to Finland today and surrendered without incident to authorities. Most of the passengers slept through the ordeal. It was at least the seventh time a Soviet jet was commandeered to Scandinavia this year by young Soviet men trying to flee their country. Finnish police said the 31-year-old hijacker, who turned out to be unarmed, offered no resistance at Helsinki Airport and asked for political asylum. None of the Aeroflot jet's 65 passengers or six crew members was injured. Two Americans were among the 15 Westerners aboard the plane. ``Everything was very quiet when we left Leningrad at 5 a.m. and I had no idea we had been hijacked until I saw flashing lights and police cars outside on the runway,'' said Jack McLaughlin, a businessman from Boston. ``I did see a young fella in red sneakers going up and down the aisle a couple of times, but he looked no different from any normal passenger,'' said Charles Erven of Racine, Wis. ``Most people were asleep anyway, so we didn't really know what was going on until after we landed,'' he said. Police said the Soviet man hijacked the twin-engine Tupolev 134 while on a flight from Leningrad to Moscow, threatening to explode ``a plastic bomb.'' Criminal Police Inspector Pertti Lehtonen said in an interview that the hijacker had demanded to go to Stockholm, Sweden. It was not immediately clear why the plane landed in Helsinki instead at 5:30 a.m. Lehtonen said the Western passengers had been heading for Moscow to make international flight connections. Substitute flights were arranged in Helsinki and most of the non-Soviet passengers had left by midday. The Americans were heading for Prague. ``We were very fortunate ... I guess things could have turned out really differently,'' Erven said. Lehtonen said the Soviet passengers and crew members would take the Tupolev to Moscow after police questioned them. Erven and McLaughlin said they did not know about the repeated hijackings of planes to Finland and Sweden this year by young men trying to flee the Soviet Union. ``I was in a rush and would not have taken the train in any case,'' McLaughlin said.

DOC.HEAD: Firefighters Aided By Lighter Winds, Cooler Temperatures
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters hoped lighter winds and lower temperatures would linger long enough to help them battle a 34,000-acre timber and grass fire near the Missouri River. About two dozen hunters fled their backcountry camps late Tuesday when the wind-whipped fire raged through the remote Gates of the Mountains Wilderness and adjacent Beartooth Game Range in western Montana. Lorraine Parrish, a spokeswoman at the Interagency Dispatch Center near Helena, said the wind died down unexpectedly Wednesday, and snow was falling on some areas of the fire. The fire broke out late Tuesday in the rugged Big Belt Mountains about 35 miles northeast of Helena. Officials said record-high temperatures, extremely dry conditions and winds as high as 30 mph helped the fire spread before the situation improved Wednesday. Gov. Stan Stephens on Wednesday called out the National Guard to help the 400 firefighters and support personnel fight the blaze. The cause hasn't been pinpointed, but officials think the blaze may have started in a hunting camp. Lewis and Clark County authorities said all the hunters known to have been in the area were accounted for, and no injuries had been reported. Several hunters at the Elkhorn Creek campsite had no time to leave and spent several hours lying in a creek, waiting for the flames to pass. Others fled on horseback, leaving behind most of their belongings, and spent the night trying to keep ahead of the blaze. ``We had a big fire going behind us to lighten things up,'' said hunter Gary Phillipe. ``That baby, it was like a full moon.'' Butch Hestekin of Great Falls said a wall of flames ``just whipped across the tops of the trees'' at his hunting camp. In the rush to save their lives, Hestekin's hunting party abandoned five pickups and all their belongings. ``The cinders were falling on us,'' said Lynn Dumas, another hunter. ``We had five minutes' warning - just about enough time to saddle a horse.'' At least 30 homes were evacuated east of Wolf Creek, and the fire got within about two miles of the small town of Craig, which is protected by the Missouri River.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Said to be Confident on Eve of Parliamentary Address
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is prepared for a political battle when he addresses the legislature on Friday, but is confident his views will prevail, the leader of Italy's Communist Party says. Achille Occhetto, who met for 2{ hours with the Soviet leader, said today that Gorbachev was candid about the problems, both economic and political, facing the country and predicted that the next 18 months would be crucial to the program of perestroika, as Gorbachev's reform program is called. On Wednesday, angry members of the national legislature abandoned the agenda set by the Supreme Soviet's Presidium and took to the floor with demands that Gorbachev report to them on his attempts to hold the country together and his recent meeting with Russian Federation President Boris N. Yeltsin. After 362 legislators out of 378 present voted in support of the demand, Gorbachev agreed to address the Supreme Soviet on Friday, Tass said. ``I feel Gorbachev is self-confident and ready for political battle,'' Occhetto told reporters. ``I feel he will be the master of the situation.'' Occhetto said that Gorbachev told him that the next 18 months would be extremely important for his economic and political reforms and play ``a decisive role in the future of the country.'' Tass, in a political commentary, said Friday's speech was tantamount to a ``moment of truth'' and that Gorbachev would most likely offer specific remedies to put new life into the moribund economy. ``Will Gorbachev justify the expectations?'' the official news agency said. ``The most radical-minded critics express doubt on that score, pointing out that Gorbachev - a consumate master at subtle multi-option moves - lacks resoluteness when hard decisions need to be made.'' On the other hand, Tass said, Gorbachev is making some headway in his reform program given the many vital tasks that he must perform, including time- consuming foreign affairs and domestic disputes with the restive republics.

DOC.HEAD: Risk from Tainted Transfusion High, Low for Health Care Workers
DOC.TEXT: The risk to health care workers exposed to AIDS through cuts is low but nine of 10 people who receive AIDS-tained blood through transfusions will become infected by the deadly virus, two studies say. The studies compare the minuscule amount transmitted through a needle puncture to the relatively high amount of the AIDS virus found in blood transfusions. In one study, researchers found that 90 percent of 124 people who received tainted transfusions became infected with HIV, the AIDS virus. Within three years, 13 percent developed AIDS, researchers said. In a second study, scientists reported that health care workers had a 0.56 percent chance of infection after they were injured and exposed to the AIDS virus. The studies are published in today's Annals of Internal Medicine. As of October, 154,917 Americans had contracted AIDS. Of those, 3,826, or 2.4 percent, were infected through transfusions. Three of 37 health care workers infected through occupational exposure have developed the disease, said the federal Centers for Disease Control. For up to four years, researchers tracked recipients of blood later found tainted by the AIDS virus. Of the 111 who became infected, nine have developed AIDS. Three died. Almost half received transfusions for surgery. ``It's important not to have any illusions about how infectious HIV is. If it's there (in the transfusion), you'll get it,'' said the study's lead author, Dr. Elizabeth Donegan of the University of California at San Francisco. Today, experts estimate one in 150,000 units of blood is contaminated with AIDS. The risk to health-care workers is much smaller, according to the second study. Of the 1,344 National Institutes of Health workers reporting 179 cuts or punctures over six years, only one became infected, said the study by NIH and Johns Hopkins University. The study said 243 workers were exposed to the AIDS virus, usually through splashes of patient fluids to the mouth or eyes. None has shown signs of infection. ``There is a risk, but you have to keep that risk in perspective,'' said the study's lead author, Dr. David Henderson of the NIH. Health care workers who have begun wearing gloves, masks and gowns for certain procedures should continue to do so, Henderson said. And while health care officials may find the low risk reassuring, they should not make light of those workers who fear the risk. ``While the risk is small, there is some risk and the risk is real,'' said AIDS researcher Dr. Robert Klein, co-author of an editorial accompanying the two studies.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Says Bush to Be `Tried' Next Month
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said today it will try President Bush for ``inhuman policies and planning aggression against the people of Iraq.'' The trial will begin Dec. 10 in Algiers in an Arab court, the official Iraqi News Agency said. The agency quoted the secretary-general of the Arab Jurists Federation, Shibeeb al-Maliky, as saying the proceedings would be held in accordance with rules used by the Nuremberg courts that tried Nazi war criminals. ``Mr. al-Maliky added that the court would listen to Iraqi, Arab and international witnesses with regard to charges against Bush,'' INA said in a dispatch late Wednesday. The verdict will be relayed to U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar and international groups concerned with human rights, the agency said. Officials in Baghdad announced in September that they would put Bush on trial for alleged human rights violations after Western leaders said President Saddam Hussein should be tried for war crimes. The trial was postponed twice. Officials said they had difficulty trying to organize sufficient witnesses and jurists to hold the trial in Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Bureau Chiefs Named in Arizona, New Mexico
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press has appointed new bureau chiefs in Arizona and New Mexico. Charlotte Porter will head the Phoenix bureau and Dale Leach the Albuquerque bureau. The appointments were announced Wednesday by AP President Louis D. Boccardi. In Phoenix, Ms. Porter succeeds Gavin Scott, who is retiring. In Albuquerque, Leach succeeds Mark Mittelstadt, who has been named chief of bureau for New Jersey. Ms. Porter, 36, joined the AP in Minneapolis in 1976. She worked in the Sioux Falls and Pierre, S.D., bureaus before transferring in 1979 to the General Desk at AP's New York headquarters. She was named news editor in Atlanta in 1988, and in 1989 was appointed assistant chief of bureau there. Ms. Porter grew up in Lenoir, N.C., and is a graduate of Macalester College in St. Paul, Minn. Leach, 39, joined the AP in Columbus in 1981. He was appointed news editor there in 1984 and assistant chief of bureau in 1988. Before joining the AP, he worked for the Beavercreek Daily News in Dayton, Ohio, and the Springfield Newspapers Inc., in Springfield, Ohio, his hometown. He is a graduate of Ohio State University.

DOC.HEAD: Bail Revoked for Interior Secretary's Son on Rape Charge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs, editing throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The son of Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. was ordered held without bail on a rape charge today after prosecutors alleged he was a danger to society. The $2,500 bond set for Robert Jeffrey Lujan, 28, following his arrest Wednesday night was revoked by Alexandria Judge Daniel O'Flaherty. Prosecutor Randy Sengel argued that the younger Lujan should not be free on bond because he was a danger to society. Sengel said police have evidence Lujan broke into a woman's apartment while armed and raped her. According to a police report, he was armed with a shotgun. Lujan did not enter a plea to the charge. O`Flaherty scheduled a preliminary hearing for Friday. Lujan's parents have said their son denied the allegation, according to Steve Goldstein, chief spokesman for the Interior Department. ``Their son has told them that it (the sex) was consentual,'' Goldstein said late Wednesday. ``Mr. Lujan has determined that he will not interfere with the due process of the law. He hasn't even been down to the jail this evening because he does not want to give any sense of impropriety.'' Robert Mains, a police communications supervisor, said the victim alleges the attack occurred about 4:30 a.m. Sunday in the same high rise building where Lujan lives with his parents. Goldstein confirmed local television reports that the unidentified victim told police she was raped after she awoke to find a man burglarizing her home. His parents ``are quite concerned,'' Goldstein said. ``It's difficult because he's secretary of the interior, but he's still a parent.'' ``It's a personal matter, and the secretary plans to go on with business as usual,'' Goldstein said.

DOC.HEAD: Plan to Charge Some Soviet Rail Passengers Hard Currency Scrapped
DOC.TEXT: A government commission today ordered the Railroad Ministry to cancel a plan that would have charged passengers hard currency, rather than rubles, for train trips out of the country. The new pay schedule had been scheduled to begin today. The policy would have been a hardship for many Soviets because the official exchange rate makes it difficult for them to afford hard currency. The government's Foreign Economic Commission, part of the Council of Ministers, said the plan was ``unfounded'' and told the railroad minister to rescind it. A Tass report on the development gave no further explanation. The dispute between the two government bodies is another sign of the growing dissension in the Kremlin. The Railroad Ministry had said it would take the step because it had to pay foreign companies in hard currency for using their railways. It said it had no foreign currency of its own to pay the bills, so it was forced to ask passengers to pay in hard currency. At the same time, the state airline Aeroflot is considering accepting only hard currency for trips abroad.

DOC.HEAD: Archbishop Calls Gulf War `Lesser of Two Evils'
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: War against Iraq could be a lesser evil than allowing Saddam Hussein to get away with his aggression against Kuwait, the Archbishop of Canterbury said today. ``The world faces a very somber situation,'' the archbishop, Robert Runcie, told the General Synod of the state Church of England. ``If it comes to war in the gulf crisis, non-combatants will most certainly be killed and maimed and bereaved ... we must set aside romantic ideas of a surgical strike,'' said Runcie, who was a tank officer decorated for bravery in World War II. He said the economic sanctions on Iraq must be given time to work. But, he added, ``despite all the horrors and misery that war would certainly involve, we have to face the fact that it could be the lesser of two evils.'' ``Of one thing I am quite sure: whilst we must use every means short of war to enforce the U.N. policy, it would be foolish to rule out the use of force in the last resort.'' The archbishop, spiritual head of the Church of England and leader of the world's 70 million Anglicans, was a Scots Guards officer when he led a tank unit across the Rhine and into the German heartland in 1945. He won the coveted Military Cross for rescuing one of his crewmen who was trapped in a burning tank, and the next day he blew up a German gun emplacement which had knocked out five tanks. In his presidential address to the synod's regular November session, Runcie acknowledged that some members of the synod of 574 bishops, clergy and laity disagreed over whether military action against Iraq was justifiable. ``Though war is only rarely just, it can be justifiable,'' he said. He said that threatening Saddam with a war crimes trial, as Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has done, would not encourage him to leave Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Baker to Meet African Foreign Ministers, Shevardnadze
Desk: Sub 4th graf, In Brussels, to reflect Baker has taken off.
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III is beginning a new round of consultations with other nations as the Bush administration tries to solidify support for its toughening stand against Iraq. Baker will meet over the weekend with the foreign ministers of three African countries as well as Romania and Finland. All are members of the U.N. Security Council, where the administration intends to seek approval to use force to liberate Kuwait if peaceful approaches fail. The secretary told reporters at the White House on Wednesday that his aim is to build ``an appropriate political and military foundation'' to use force against Iraq. Many countries that share U.S. disapproval of the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait are reluctant to go to war until diplomacy is given every chance to work. In Brussels, where he headed today, Baker will meet on Friday with the 12-nation European Community, which is providing aid to countries whose economies are suffering because of their adherence to a trade embargo against Iraq. Last week, on a trip to the Persian Gulf and Europe, Baker lined up the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France to go along with the resolution. As permanent members of the Security Council they could have killed it with their veto. The three African countries Baker is soliciting are Ethiopia, Ivory Coast and Zaire. Enlisting them to support the United States would give the toughened American stance broader approval among neutral and Third World nations. Baker will meet with the African foreign ministers in Geneva on Saturday. He then will fly to Paris and meet with the foreign ministers of Romania and Finland. On Sunday, he will hold nother session with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd. From Monday through Thursday next week, Baker will assist President Bush at a 34-nation summit in Paris, where a landmark treaty to reduce NATO and Warsaw Pact tanks and other non-nuclear weapons will be signed. After accompanying Bush to Saudi Arabia and Egypt, Baker will then go to Colombia the following weekend to confer with President Cesar Gaviria. Colombia also is a member of the Security Council this month. At his news conference Wednesday, Baker said the administration had not decided to use force, but wanted that ``hypothetical'' option to be credible in hopes of persuading Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to give up Kuwait. Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Bahrain, Egypt, Turkey and the exiled government of Kuwait all assured Baker during his recent eight-day trip to the Persian Gulf and Europe that they would not oppose the resolution. In the meantime, King Hassan of Morocco is trying to organize an Arab summit to head off war with diplomacy. ``We are in favor of any diplomatic approaches that can move us in the direction of a political and peaceful'' settlement, Baker said. ``But we are not in favor of diplomatic approaches that call for partial solutions.'' Baker was referring to the longstanding U.S. demand that Iraq withdraw its troops unconditionally from Kuwait before any discussion on related issues are held. Saudi Arabia, a key U.S. ally against Saddam, has taken the same position with regard to an Arab summit.

DOC.HEAD: Religious Violence in Capital Injures at Least 12
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE injured toll, ADD Punjab violence, quotes; CORRECTS to at least six dead Wednesday. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DEL1
DOC.TEXT: Police fired bullets and tear gas today to quell rioting Hindus and Moslems who fought each other with knives, stones and glass bottles. At least 12 people were injured, police said. A day earlier, the wave of religious violence sweeping the nation touched the capital for the first time when armed Sikh and Moslem mobs attacked Hindus and pillaged their houses, killing at least six people, police said. Also Wednesday, Sikh separatists in Punjab state shot and killed seven bus passengers after hijacking the vehicle at gunpoint, police said today. More than 385 people, mostly Moslems, have been killed nationwide in the religious violence sweeping India over the past month. No deaths were reported in violence today in two predominantly Hindu neighborhoods of the capital. In another part of the New Delhi, Sikh youths stoned buses and Hindu-owned shops. In Sadar Bazaar, a middle-class neighborhood and the flashpoint of Wednesday's violence, Moslems set fire to a Hindu's bicycle repair shop today, residents said on condition of anonymity. Hindu mobs retaliated by setting fire to a monument at a Moslem saint's grave and two nearby Moslem houses, other residents said. No one was injured in the incidents, but enraged residents hurled stones, soda water bottles and waved knives and daggers at each other. Police fired into the air and used tear gas to disperse the mobs, police said. ``We have now learned how to live. They (the Hindus) have removed the fear of death from our hearts,'' said Zahid Hussain, a meat exporter, speaking on the terrace of his two-story house. On the street below, a car had been smashed, its seats and stereo ripped out. Shattered glass and bricks carpeted the road. Deputy Commissioner of Police Bhimsen Bhassi said six people were wounded in the police firing and five people were injured in the stone throwing. Earlier, police used bamboo canes to disperse Hindu residents who defied a curfew and came out of their houses to hurl stones and soda water bottles. At least one person, a middle-aged Hindu man, was seen bleeding from the head after police lashed out with their canes to disperse the crowd. In Tilak Nagar, 10 miles southwest of Sadar Bazaar, Sikh students hurled stones at buses and Hindu-owned shops after their principal made an anti-Hindu speech today, a police official said. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the mob of about 800 youths damaged eight buses and six shops in Tilak Nagar, a predominantly Hindu middle-class neighborhood. Wednesday's trouble began when about 15,000 Sikhs and Moslems held a meeting in a mosque to express solidarity of India's minorities against rising fundamentalism by part of the Hindu majority. Hindus comprise 82 percent of India's 880 million people. Moslems make up 12 percent, while Sikhs are about 2 percent. Most of the rest are Christians or Buddhists. It is the first time in recent memory that Sikhs and Moslems have banded together against Hindus. The Sikh religion has roots in Hinduism and Islam. Bhassi said many of the Moslems and Sikhs at Wednesday's meeting were armed with knives, daggers, swords and pistols and they later attacked Hindus living near the mosque. He said two Hindus and one Moslem died of stab wounds, two Moslems died of bullet wounds and a Hindu police officer died after being hit on the head with a stone. Press Trust of India put the toll at seven but gave no details. At least 25 people, including seven policemen, were injured. Clashes between Hindus and Moslems peaked two weeks ago when Hindus stormed a mosque in Ayodhya. Hindus want to build a temple on the site, which they claim is the birthplace of Lord Rama, a popular Hindu god. In Punjab, four Sikhs in a jeep blocked the bus near the village of Katora, said regional Senior Superintendent of Police Anil Sharma. They then forced the motorist to drive the bus off the main road and opened fire on the passengers. Sikh militants have been fighting for an independent nation in Punjab since 1983, blaming Hindus for discrimination. At least 2,770 people have died in the separatist campaign this year.

DOC.HEAD: Suspect In Gainesville Slayings Sentenced In Beating of Grandmother
DOC.TEXT: Gainesville murder suspect Edward Lewis Humphrey was sentenced today to the maximum 22 months for beating his grandmother after his lawyer said no private psychiatric hospital could be found for him. Circuit Judge Theron Yawn said last week he was inclined to order a mental commitment rather than prison for Humphrey. But Public Defender J.R. Russo said today that some hospitals rejected Humphrey outright and the only ones that would admit him would charge $600 to $1,000 a day, more than the family could afford. Humphrey, 19, nodded when his 79-year-old grandmother blew him as kiss as he entered the courtroom but was generally oblivious to the proceedings. He mostly stared off into space as the judge imposed the maximum prison term, to be served, at least at the start, in the prison system's psychiatric facility. Humphrey, a sometime University of Florida student with a history of mental problems, has been labeled a suspect in the slayings of five students near the campus in Gainesville during the last week in August. But he has not been charged in those cases. Humphrey has been jailed on $1 million bond since the beating Aug. 30. His grandmother, Elna Hlavaty, told a deputy that night that her grandson had beaten and chowill go toward electricity generation rather than home heating and industrial uses. TransCanada Pipelines Ltd., one of Iroquois' several owners, estimated the new line will generate $1 billion per year in exports for Canada. Canada has been supplying natural gas to the United States since the 1960s, but mostly in the West and Midwest.

DOC.HEAD: Sandra Day O'Connor: Progress in Sexual Equality but `We're Not There Yet'
DOC.TEXT: Sexual barriers in America are coming down slowly but surely, even though there is still a long way to go, Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor says. ``We will have a female president some day,'' O'Connor said. ``But we're not there yet.'' ``As society sees what women can do, and as women see what women can do, there will be more women out there doing things, and we'll all be better off for it,'' O'Connor told students Wednesday at Washington University in St. Louis. As more women enter fields such as law, medicine and olitics, more women will become influential members of society, she said. ``Power is the ability to do. It is in this sense that women can become increasingly powerful,'' said O'Connor, the first woman to serve on the U.S. Supreme Court. There are still too few women judges, O'Connor said. She cited figures showing that less than 10 percent of federal judicial officers and state appeals judges are women. Women make up 20 percent of all lawyers, but are only 6 percent of law firm partners and 11 percent of tenured law professors, she said. O'Connor gave the keynote address at a conference, sponsored by the Monticello College Foundation and Washington University, titled: ``Women in power; is the view different?''

DOC.HEAD: National League of Cities to Consider Moving 1991 Convention
DOC.TEXT: The National League of Cities will consider moving its 1991 convention from Phoenix because the state does not have a paid holiday honoring Martin Luther King Jr., league officials said. The league's board will decide whether to move its convention during a meeting Dec. 1 in Houston, said Don Borut, the league's executive director. Last week, Arizona voters rejected two propositions that would have created a statewide paid King Day. As a result, the National Football League has threatened to pull the 1993 Super Bowl out of the state.
