The National League of Cities' board voted in 1987 to hold the 1991 convention in Phoenix, but with the condition that the decision would be reconsidered if Arizona did not create a paid King holiday. ``I was advised that we have a very long and uphill road to climb'' to keep the convention, said Phoenix Mayor Paul Johnson. Johnson blamed rival cities that are interested in having the event for the movement to pull the convention from Phoenix. Larry Hilliard, vice president of the Phoenix & the Valley of the Sun Convention and Visitors Bureau, said Wednesday, ``It has not been canceled and we're still maintaining a dialogue with the National League of Cities. The convention is expected to draw 10,000 visitors and to generate $6.9 million in revenues, Hilliard said. Johnson said he and City Council members will lobby board members by phone and at the Houston convention, stressing that Phoenix has a paid King holiday.

DOC.HEAD: Governors Say Suspension Law May Not Help Drug War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 13th graf pvs, Both states, with additional quotes.
DOC.TEXT: A new law requiring states to suspend the driver's licenses of all convicted drug offenders or lose some federal highway funds may not help the war on drugs, an official of the National Governors' Association says. There is no data proving that mandatory license suspensions, imposed first in New Jersey, prompts people to turn away from drugs, said Nolan Jones, staff director for the association's justice and public safety committee. ``It sounds like a good idea, but let's see if it's working'' before forcing every state to enact similar rules, Jones said. The measure, included in the fiscal 1991 transportation appropriations bill, applies to all states and all illegal drugs, including the 10 states where possession of small amounts of marijuana has been decriminalized but is still considered an infraction of the law. The legislation drew little attention when it was approved during a flurry of activity Oct. 27 as Congress rushed to leave town. President Bush signed it into law Nov. 5. The bill calls for withholding 5 percent of federal highway funds starting Oct. 1, 1993 from states that fail to require six-month driver's license suspensions for everyone convicted of any drug offense. The cut would increase to 10 percent on Oct. 1, 1995. ``Numerous states have driver's license revocation laws, but they don't go as far as this calls for,'' Jones said in an interview. ``That points to why we are against the whole issue of mandates when looking at this sort of problem.'' About half the states allow suspension of drug offenders' licenses, but only four require such suspensions for drivers of all ages and only New Jersey has a six-month minimum, according to the American Legislative Exchange Council. The minimum is four months in Georgia and three months in Colorado and Pennsylvania. The legislation does have a way out for states that want all their federal highway funds but don't want to require license suspensions: their legislatures must vote specifically against requiring the suspensions and their governors must go on record in agreement with that position. ``This forces the states to be accountable,'' said a Bush administration source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``We're not going to force you, but if you don't want to do it, you'll have to be public about it.'' In states where they can't agree - for example, the governor wants to suspend licenses but at least one chamber of the state legislature does not - the federal highway funds would be cut. The measure's sponsor, Rep. Gerald B.H. Solomon, R-N.Y., said his main targets were New York and California, which have decriminalized minor marijuana possession. Both states also have splits in party control: In California, the Democrats control the legislature and the governor is a Republican; in New York, the governor is a Democrat and his party controls the state assembly while Republicans control the state senate. Arnold S. Trebach, president of the Drug Policy Foundation and an American University professor of public affairs, said the measure ``is only one of many passed during recent anti-drug war hysteria that is creating a police state in America in the name of controlling drugs.'' ``People are soon going to realize that what their legislators have created for them under the drug laws is an absolutely intolerable situation,'' said Trebach, whose foundation urges treating drug abuse as a medical issue, not a law enforcement problem. Solomon said he pushed the measure to crack down on casual drug users. ``Seventy-five percent of the drug purchases in America are done by casual drug users, and that's white, upper-middle-class Americans that drive their Pontiac Firebirds into the ghetto and buy these killer drugs,'' Solomon said. ``You don't see the murders take place out in the suburbs, but it's the casual drug user who supplies the demand for these drugs,'' he said. ``If you do away with the demand for drugs, then the drugs will dry up in this country. ... When it starts to affect their livelihoods, maybe then they'll stop using these drugs.'' The license suspensions won't necessarily affect their livelihoods, however, because they could receive limited permits enabling them to continue commuting to work, Solomon said. The money at stake is substantial. The Federal Highway Administration will distribute some $12.3 billion to the states this year. Of that total, California will get the biggest slice, some $1.1 billion. New York will get $666 million.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Reported in Central Oklahoma
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to update with comments from chief geologist, no connection to New Madrid fault, and to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: A minor earthquake shook pictures off walls in two central Oklahoma communities early today but experts said there was no connection with a potential major quake on the New Madrid Fault. The Oklahoma Geological Survey said the quake registered 3.6 on the Richter scale of ground movement. A quake of magnitude 3.5 can cause slight damage. A quake of magnitude 2 is the smallest normally felt by humans. The National Weather Service said it had received reports of a tremor about 5:45 a.m. that was felt in Rush Springs, about 40 miles southwest of Oklahoma City, and Lindsay, about 28 miles south of Oklahoma City. The geological survey said the quake was centered 5 miles north of Lindsay. ``Police departments in those areas indicate that pictures fell from walls, objects were knocked off tables and out of cabinets and many residents were awakened,'' the weather service said in a statement. Geological survey director Charles Mankin said earthquakes are common in Oklahoma, with a couple a week detected by sensitive seismographs. ``We rarely record them as high as 3.6,'' he said. ``But a small earthquake in that area is not unusual.'' Larry Thompson of KBLP radio in Lindsay said the station was flooded with calls after the tremor was felt. At the police department, dispatcher Lois Knapp said the shaking lasted about two seconds. ``This police department is cement and brick and rock, and it moved,'' she said. There has been increased concern about a Midwestern earthquake since a New Mexico climatologist projected that there could be a major one in early December along the New Madrid Fault, which runs from Cairo, Ill., to Marked Tree, Ark. The projection, based on the fact that tidal forces will be particularly strong early next month, is disputed by most scientists. Mankin said there was no link between today's quake and the New Madrid Fault. ``Most of the earthquakes in Oklahoma we have not been able to relate to faults,`` Mankin said. ``They're very shallow earthquakes and we know they're from some ground adjustment, obviously, but we can't relate them to some fault.'' In 1811-1812, a series of quakes estimated at up to 8 on the Richter scale struck the New Madrid Fault, ringing church bells in Washington, D.C., more than 850 miles away. Jim Lawson, chief geophysicist at the geological survey, said earlier this week that even if a major quake occurred along the New Madrid Fault, its effect in Oklahoma would be negligible.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Saudi Forces Begin Exercise in Persian Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads thruout to UPDATE with amphibious landing exercise beginning. Edits to trim. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Saudi forces today began a six-day amphibious exercise in the Persian Gulf, codenamed ``Imminent Thunder'' and involving 1,000 U.S. Marines, 1,100 aircraft and 16 ships. Iraq has termed the exercise a ``provocative act'' because it is being held close to occupied Kuwait. Also today, Syria and Egypt rejected a proposed Arab summit on the Persian Gulf crisis, effectively killing chances for the gathering that Morocco's king said was possibly the last chance for peace. Presidents Hafez Assad of Syria and Hosni Mubarak of Egypt became the latest Arab leaders to join Saudi Arabia in rejecting the summit. They said they were doing so because Baghdad insisted upon keeping Kuwait. Saudi Arabia said on Wednesday it would not participate in the summit unless Baghdad promised beforehand to leave Kuwait, which it invaded Aug. 2. In other developments: -Two American diplomats arrived in Amman, Jordan, on today's regularly scheduled flight from Baghdad. The State Department said on Wednesday two Americans were to leave Iraq, but did not release their identities or further details. ``I'm not a hostage,'' said one, who was carrying an orange bag that looked like a diplomatic pouch. Two other Americans arrived from Iraq on Wednesday. -Hundreds of America's most powerful tanks began rolling into the Saudi desert, adding more power to the growing U.S. deployment in Saudi Arabia as Washington seeks U.N. authorization to wage war on Iraq. -A poll sponsored by an arms-control group found that most Americans oppose going to war without a congressional declaration and nearly half prefer to give a U.N.-ordered embargo on trade with Iraq more time. -The state Iraqi News Agency announced that President Bush will go ``on trial'' in absentia next month in Algeria for ``inhuman policies and planning aggression against the people of Iraq.'' The trial will begin Dec. 10 in Algiers in an international court of justice, INA said. It quoted the secretary-general of the Arab Jurists Federation, Shibeeb al-Maliky, as saying the trial would be held in accordance with rules used by the Nuremberg courts that tried Nazi war criminals. The exact location of Imminent Thunder was not revealed because of military policy, and a news blackout was imposed for the initial phases of the operation. No live ammuniton will be fired in the operation. But it will involve the largest use of aircraft in a single training exercise since U.S. forces were deployed in the region in August. There have been three previous amphibious exercises in the Persian Gulf, but they were believed to have been held further south. The Washington Times reported on Wednesday that Imminent Thunder would be held 10 miles from Kuwait. Iraq called that a provocation. The first of several hundred khaki-colored M1A1 Abrams tanks, to be repainted in desert camouflage, rolled off a ship in Saudi Arabia on Wednesday night. The tanks will replace M1 tanks in all front-line Army units in the country, with better protection from chemical and biological warfare, a larger gun and thicker armor. They will face Iraq's Soviet-made tanks. ``The M1 is better than anything the Iraqis have,'' said Army spokesman Maj. Douglas Bidle, 38, of Arlington Heights, Ill. ``The M1 gave us an edge. This is a better tank, so obviously this is an even better edge.'' Jane's Defense Weekly reported last month that 350 M1s would be swapped for M1A1s. The Pentagon has said all tanks will be switched by the end of the year. About 230,000 U.S. troops have massed in the region, joined by about 100,000 soldiers from more than two dozen other nations standing up to Iraq. The Iraqi foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, on Wednesday accused the United States of seeking to dominate the world oil market. ``The main U.S. objective in the region is to control oil wells and dictate oil policies,'' the official Iraqi News Agency quoted Aziz as saying. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Tuesday that a worldwide recession could result if Iraq is permitted to gain control of the Persian Gulf's vast oil reserves. Last week, Baker won qualified support from the Soviet Union, China, and France for a U.N. resolution authorizing the use of force to drive Iraqi forces from Kuwait. They are permanent members of the Security Council with Britain and the United States, and as such could veto any resolution. Chinese diplomatic sources said last week the Chinese foreign minister, visiting Baghdad, told Iraqi officials China would not veto a resolution authorizing force. But today, the Chinese Foreign Ministry said it had not told Baghdad how it would vote. It said the issue was not even raised. It was not clear whether the Chinese government was simply unwilling to show its hand, in keeping with its usual policy, or whether the diplomatic sources were incorrect. Some congressional Democrats are counseling Bush to give international sanctions as much as 18 months before considering an attack. The new poll, sponsored by The Professionals' Coalition for Nuclear Arms Control, indicates most Americans are opposed to going to war even if the standoff has not changed by January. It found that 62 percent of the 1,020 people interviewed approve of Bush's handling of the crisis, but that 71 percent think Congress must approve sending U.S. troops into battle. The national telephone survey found that 44 percent favor continuing the economic sanctions even if the situation remains unresolved by February. Fourteen percent favored a U.S. withdrawal. Thirty-eight percent believe the United States should attack Iraq. The survey, conducted Friday through Tuesday, had a margin of error of 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Bishops Modify Document On Early America To Include Abuses.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material, editing throughout.
DOC.TEXT: A summary of the Christian heritage in America was modified by U.S. Roman Catholic bishops today to recognize abuses that occurred in the early days. The document, ``Heritage and Hope: Evangelization in America,'' was drawn up to mark next year's 500th anniversary of Christopher Columbus' landing on these shores. Archbishop Edward A. McCarthy of Miami, head of a committee that drafted the pastoral letter commemorating the coming of Europeans to America, said it has undergone major revisions. It deals with concerns of ``native Americans, Hispanics, blacks, Asians,'' he said, adding that putting it together has been a ``learning experience.'' ``We do not glorify every act of the church,'' he said. ``We do not excuse our mistakes.'' But the document also brings out Christianity's positive contributions in early America. McCarthy said it is urgent that the positive side be heard in marking the anniversary. He told the annual meeting of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops: ``Already strong forces have gathered to characterize Christianity in the ugliest terms while the reality of the church's commitment in the Americas is unparalleled in the annals of human history. ``For good or bad, our history is as it was, but the future opens before us and beckons us to bring Christ into generations born and unborn.'' The bishops yesterday adopted their first comprehensive guidelines on human sexuality, calling it a ``wonderful gift'' and emphasizing chaste disciplines to nurture it. ``We do not fear sexuality, we embrace it,'' the bishops said in both lauding that universal human endowment and reaffirming traditional church restraints in expressing it. In the 185-page assessment of sexuality, approved Wednesday to guide education on the subject, the National Conference of Catholic Bishops added: ``We are dealing with a divine gift, a primal dimension of each person, a mysterious blend of spirit and body, which shares in God's own creative love and life .... ``What we fear at times is our own inability to think as highly of the gift as does the God who made us sexual human beings.'' While maintaining long-established church disapproval of premarital and extramarital sexual intercourse, the document does so in gentle, reasoned tones, and somewhat tempers past strictures against homosexuality. ``Such an orientation, because not freely chosen, is not sinful,'' said an amendment added in a motion by Cardinal Joseph Bernardin of Chicago and several others. It came after Bishop Raymond W. Lessard of Savannah, Ga., sought unsuccessfully to insert a 1986 Vatican declaration calling homosexuality a ``strong tendency'' toward `intrinsic moral evil'' and an ``objective disorder.'' Archbishop John R. Quinn of San Francisco called that a philosophical analysis that has been misunderstood as meaning such people were ``intrinsically disordered and bad.'' ``Every human being has some disordered tendency,'' such as toward anger and greed, Quinn said. The Vatican statement was put in a footnote, along with an explanation that it was not meant to demean individuals. It has caused ``untold damage,'' pushing ``many over the brink to confront the church head-on,'' said Auxiliary Bishop Peter A. Rosazza of Hartford, Conn. Another flurry erupted over the document's reiteration of the church ban on contraception. Surveys indicate that a large proportion of Catholics reject the ban. Bishop Kenneth E. Untener of Saginaw, Mich., noting that dissenters are asked to prayerfully reconsider, said they might respond: ``We will if you will.'' He said the Holy Spirit acts through people, the sense of the faithful, and the bishops had better listen to them to maintain the church's credibility. ``If we don't, it will cause great damage to the church at large,'' he said. Several bishops sharply criticized the guidelines, saying parents had not been widely consulted and predicting that many would pull their children out of Catholic schools because of them.

DOC.HEAD: Four Blacks Killed, Two Children Wounded in South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Four black adults were killed and two children wounded today when gunmen fired on a family sleeping in a minibus at a violence-torn squatter camp near Johannesburg, police said. The assailants used AK-47 assault rifles in the pre-dawn attack at the Zonkwezizwe squatter camp southeast of Johannesburg, police said. Three women and a man were killed, and a 4-year-old child and 8-month-old baby were seriously wounded. Police gave no motive for the attack, but 16 people, including the latest victims, have been killed in factional fighting at the camp in the past week. Authorities did not say why the people were sleeping in the minibus, but the squatter camp is overcrowded and shelter is in short supply. More than 800 blacks have died in factional fighting outside Johannesburg since August. Most of the violence has been between supporters of the African National Congress led by Nelson Mandela and Zulus who back the Inkatha Freedom Party. Both sides oppose apartheid, but differ over tactics and plans for a future South Africa. Police also said authorities found the body of a black man who had been stabbed to death in Wembezi, northwest of Durban.

DOC.HEAD: Egypt, Syria Nix Idea of Arab Summit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Kuwait rejecting summit, CORRECTS that summit proposed Sunday, ADDS Soviet diplomat in Rabat, background. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Syria, Egypt and Kuwait today joined Saudi Arabia in rejecting a proposed Arab summit on the Persian Gulf crisis, effectively killing efforts to bring Arab leaders together to avert war. Presidents Hafez Assad of Syria and Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said Baghdad's insistence on keeping Kuwait made it necessary for them to reject the meeting. The Kuwaiti government - exiled in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia - also voiced its objections to the meeting today because of Iraq's refusal to withdraw. The summit was proposed Sunday by King Hassan II of Morocco, who called it a ``last chance'' for peace. ``Presidents Assad and Mubarak expressed their regret over Iraq's rejection of any political settlement that aims at restoring the situation in Kuwait to what it was prior to Aug. 2,'' said a statement released by Assad's spokesman. Both Syria and Egypt have contributed troops to the 300,000-strong U.S.-led multinational force confronting Iraq, which invaded and annexed Kuwait Aug. 2. On Wednesday, the Saudi foreign minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, said the only way a summit could succeed would be for Iraq to agree in advance to withdraw from Kuwait. Iraq has made clear it would not make such a promise. The Soviet Union sent high-level envoys to the Middle East this week, among efforts to promote the summit. Before leaving Rabat, Morocco, today after a three-day visit, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Vladimir Petrovsky said: ``The essential is to act quickly for a peaceful solution. It's not too late, but time is pressing.'' The Kuwaiti and Saudi government have said that an Arab solution has already been proposed - by an Arab League summit in August that ended in disarray. At that meeting, 12 of the 21 League members voted to condemn Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and approve the dispatch of foreign forces o defend Saudi Arabia. Iraq, Libya and the PLO voted against the resolution. Jordan, Sudan and Mauritania had reservations, and Algeria and Yemen abstained. Tunis was not present.

DOC.HEAD: Pilot Error Suspected in Zurich Plane Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 13th pvs, `Debris was...' to UPDATE with identity of American victims. Pickup 14th pvs, `A team...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos ZUR2,3
DOC.TEXT: Pilot error is suspected in the crash of an Italian jetliner trying to land at Zurich's international airport, killing all 46 people aboard, including six Americans, authorities said today. The Alitalia DC-9, arriving on a 50-minute flight from Milan, skimmed treetops before its fiery crash into a wooded hillside on Wednesday night, five miles short of Kloten airport, police said. Josef Meier, a spokesman for Swiss air traffic control authorities, told a news conference that witness accounts suggested several causes for the crash and that no possible theories, including terrorism, were being ruled out. But Meier said radar data ``suggest the pilot misjudged his altitude.'' He said the plane was flying about 1,000 feet below the normal altitude during the landing approach. He said the plane was not yet within reach of an airport radar beacon enabling it to lock onto a landing path. Radio contact was normal until two minutes before the crash and controllers received no distress signal, officials said. The Swiss Federal Meteorological Office said visibility at the time of the crash was good - up to 10 miles, with light rain and light winds. Investigators reported finding one of the two flight recorders, or ``black boxes,'' which track flight data and cockpit conversations and hoped to learn more about the crash's cause from them. About 300 police and rescuers worked at the muddy crash site today, salvaging wreckage and retrieving charred bodies for identification. Officials said all 40 passengers and six Italian crew members were killed. In Rome, a preliminary count by the airline said six U.S. citizens were among the dead, but the passenger list it released gave only last names and first initials without nationalities. The jet cut a swath into the forest and broke up on impact, witnesses said. Smoking pieces of wreckage, covered with firefighting foam, were strewn around a muddy hillside. ``The plane was burning like a volcano,'' said Hanni Steffen, a resident and medic who rushed to the crash site. Debris was strewn over an area of 50 by 120 yards, police said. Alitalia identified the American victims as Karel Forman, Stephen Ritter, John Stuckey, Paul Vaughan, William Briggs and Jerry Bass. It had no further information. Three of the Americans worked for the Mobil Corp. in Macedon, N.Y.: Briggs, 52, of Newark; Forman, 32, of Clifton Springs, N.Y.; and Vaughan, 38, of Fairport, N.Y. The company provided their ages and hometowns. A team of Italian investigators sent by Interior Minister Vincenzo Scotti arrived early today to help in the inquiry. At Linate Airport in Milan, where the flight originated, officials set up a crisis unit to provide information and take calls from worried families and friends. Alitalia said the DC-9 was built in 1974 and was last inspected Nov. 4. Flight commander Raffaele Liberta, 47, was a 20-year Alitalia veteran who had flown more than 10,000 hours during his career. The last major crash involving an Italian airliner occurred Oct. 15, 1987, when an ATR-42 turboprop of the carrier ATI, an Alitalia subsidiary, crashed near Como on a flight from Milan to Cologne, Germany, killing 37.

DOC.HEAD: China to Veto Seoul's Bid to Join U.N., Report Says
DOC.TEXT: China has conveyed through the United States that it will veto any attempt by South Korea to gain separate membership in the United Nations, a newspaper reported today. The Joongang Daily News said in a Washington-datelined story that the United States, acting on a South Korean request, had asked if the Beijing government would block an effort by Seoul to join the world body this year. South Korea and its rival, Communist North Korea, currently hold observer status in the 159-member world body. South Korea has no diplomatic relations with China, which is closely allied with North Korea. North Korea opposes separate U.N. membership for the two Korean states, claiming such a measure would perpetuate the division of the peninsula. Instead, it has proposed that both Koreas share a single U.N. seat with revolving representation. Since improving ties with the Soviet Union and China, South Korean officials have said they would stand a better chance of joining the United Nations. They have indicated they would apply for U.N. membership this year. The Soviet Union and China have veto powers as permanent members of the U.N. Security Council. South Korea established formal diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union Oct. 30. Last month, it signed an accord to exchange trade offices with China.

DOC.HEAD: Fadlallah Renews Call for Hostage Release
DOC.TEXT: Lebanon's most influential Shiite Moslem cleric renewed his appeal today for the release of all hostages held in Lebanon, calling their detention inhumane. Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, spiritual mentor of the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, spoke to reporters after meeting the relatives of four Iranians missing in Lebanon. The fundamentalist Hezbollah is believed to be the umbrella for the Shiite extremist factions holding most of the 13 Western hostages in Lebanon, including six Americans. Fadlallah made several such statements in the past that appeared to have had no immediate impact on the kidnappers, despite the weight of his religious position. However, when a group calling itself The Organization of Islamic Dawn released former American hostages Robert Polhill and Frank Reed in April, it said its reasons included the ``behests of senior religious leaders.'' The longest-held hostage is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who was abducted March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Exile Sentenced to 12 Years in Bombing of Former Chilean Diplomat
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge today sentenced Jose Dionisio Suarez Esquivel to 12 years in prison for conspiring to assassinate onetime Chilean Ambassador Orlando Letelier. Suarez admitted in September that he gave a blasting cap to former Chilean intelligence agent Michael V. Townley, who allegedly masterminded the assassination. Letelier and an associate, Ronni Moffitt, were killed Sept. 21, 1976, when a bomb exploded beneath his car on Embassy Row. Letelier, Chile's ambassador to Washington from 1971 to 1973, was an outspoken critic of the right-wing military government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet. Defense attorney Paul Goldberger asked the judge to ``show some leniency'' in sentencing Suarez, noting that he has a wife and an infant son. ``This is not the type of case in which the parole board would give him an early parole,'' Goldberger said. But U.S. District Judge Aubrey Robinson Jr. said the victims should be remembered. ``I could not forget them,'' Robinson said. ``Don't think his (Letelier's family didn't love him any less. I also could nt forget Ronni Moffit and her husband.'' Under a plea agreement approved by Robinson, Suarez, 51, faced a maximum 12 years in prison for his role in the crime. Under the agreement, authorities dropped charges against Elizabeth Gongora Suarez, his wife, of concealing a fugitive, officials said. Goldberger argued that Townley, the alleged mastermind behind the plot, received only 10 years, and former Chilean army Maj. Armando Fernandez Larios received just seven years. Goldberger told the court it would not be fair to give Suarez more time than the others. Fernandez defected from Chile in 1987 and pleaded guilty to being an accessory after the fact in the conspiracy. Fernandez implicated two of his superiors in the Chilean intelligence agency and Pinochet in the coverup of the Chilean military's involvement in the crime. The two Chilean military officials have been charged with participating in the killing but the Chilean government has refused to extradite the men. Pinochet remains head of the Chilean army and military courts have jurisdiction over the two officials, Gen. Juan Manuel Contreras Sepulveda and retired Lt. Col. Pedro Espinoza Bravo, the former head of the Chilean intelligence agency. Outside the courtroom, Goldberger said ``the appropriate sentence would have been no more than Townley got.'' However, he added that Robinson was a fair judge who merely decided on the maximum prison term.

DOC.HEAD: NATO and Warsaw Pact Reach Tentative Agreement on Non-Nuclear Treaty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 1 graf at end with current weapons levels.
DOC.TEXT: NATO and Warsaw Pact negotiators reached tentative agreement today on reducing non-nuclear weapons in Europe, diplomats said. Hungary's chief negotiator, Ambassador Istvan Gyarmati, said the last minor disagreements were worked out at a plenary meeting of the 22 nations belonging to the two military alliances. Other diplomats, who spoke on condition of anonymity, also said a tentative agreement had been reached. The treaty allows each side to keep 20,000 battle tanks. It also limits each to 30,000 armored combat vehicles, 20,000 pieces of artillery, 6,800 combat aircraft and 2,000 attack helicopters. With the treaty scheduled for signing in Paris on Monday - the first day of the 34-nation Conference on Security and European Cooperation - diplomats at the Vienna talks had been under pressure to reach agreement. U.S. officials said in Washington on Wednesday that substantive questions remained, including verification that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and Warsaw Pact actually were destroying tanks, anti-aircraft guns and other non-nuclear weaponry. But negotiators in Vienna said the issues were relatively minor, and U.S. officials predicted the treaty would be ready for signing on Monday. Gyarmati said negotiating teams had sent copies of the draft agreement to their capitals, and senior officials there had until later today to register objections. After that, the treaty would be considered final. Chief negotiators were scheduled to initial copies Sunday before the accord is signed a day later. According to the treaty, in January 1989 the Warsaw Pact had 51,500 tanks and Nato had about 16,400; the Warsaw Pact had about 22,400 armored combat vehicles, NATO 4,100; the Pact had 43,400 pieces of artillery and NATO had 14,400. In addition, the Warsaw Pact had 3,700 helicopters and Nato had 2,400.

DOC.HEAD: Nigerians Bomb Buchanan, Rebels Say Several Killed, U.S. Ship Destroyed
DOC.TEXT: Nigerian jets from a West African task force bombed Liberia's rebel-held port of Buchanan, and the rebels said several people were killed and a U.S. relief ship destroyed. Nigerian Ambassador Joshua Iroha, the chief political representative of a five-nation West African army in Liberia, confirmed Wednesday's bombing. He said the raid was to stop weapons shipments to rebels led by Charles Taylor. The task force ``is not obliged to tell anyone when it is carrying out military operations, and whoever was at the port of Buchanan when the bombing was carried out was just unlucky,'' Iroha said in an interview. ``There are more weapons in the containers at the port of Buchanan than food ... any international relief organization that wants to help Liberians must use the free port of Monrovia,'' he said at his base in Freetown. The U.S. ship was carrying relief supplies of food. It was not immediately known how many people were aboard the ship or what happened to them. The West Africans have forced Taylor's rebels out of Monrovia, where there are between 150,000 and 200,000 civilians. Most people in Liberia are behind the lines of Taylor's guerrillas, and Buchanan has the largest concentration of civilians after Monrovia. Humanitarian organizations like the U.S. Catholic Relief Services and the Belgian branch of Doctors without Borders have been working on both sides to aid people dying of starvation, disease and, lately, from the West African bombing raids. Three warring Liberian armies have killed about 10,000 civilians since rebels invaded from Ivory Coast on Dec. 23. More than half of the population of 2.3 million has fled the country or is displaced inside Liberia. It was not possible to get independent confirmation of the casualties in Wednesday's bombing.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Rocks Philippines
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake shook Manila and the Philippines' northern province Thursday, but there were no immediate reports of damage or casualties. The quake measured 5.2 on the Richter scale, according to Leo Bautista, a spokesman of the Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology. She said the epicenter was about 31 miles northeast of Manila. An earthquake that measured 7.7 on the Richter scale on the same fault line, the Philippine fault line, killed nearly 1,700 people and caused widespread destruction in the northern Philippines in July. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one digit means the ground motion is 10 times greater. A magnitude of 6 can cause severe damage in populated areas.

DOC.HEAD: Six Die of Cholera in North Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Six people have died of cholera in north Lebanon and 35 others have been hospitalized with symptoms of the deadly intestinal disease, health authorities said Thursday. The Islamic Hospital in Tripoli, the provincial capital of north Lebanon, said the deaths occurred this week and were caused by leaking sewage that contaminated wells in Tripoli and two nearby villages. ``The sewage system in the north is so old and has been leaking in several parts,'' said a hospital spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Health Ministry in Beirut sent a team to Tripoli to follow up the cases. At least eight people died of cholera in north Lebanon in September. The spread of the disease at that time was also attributed to leaking sewage.

DOC.HEAD: Polls Show Thatcher Challenger May Boost Conservatives
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Thatcher in House of Commons. Pickup 4th, `Heseltine who...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Thatcher Woes, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Two opinion polls published today indicate the general public prefers Michael Heseltine over Margaret Thatcher, but the prime minister said that after 11 years in office she is not intimidated by his challenge. Speaking in the House of Commons, Mrs. Thatcher attacked Heseltine's proposals for education funding and expressed confidence that she would win the leadership vote on Tuesday. If she does, she remains prime minister; if Heseltine does, he takes over the top job. Paddy Ashdown, leader of the small Liberal Democratic party, teased the prime minister by holding up a 5-year-old newspaper interview headlined: ``Maggie: I'll Go in Five Years.'' ``What made her change her mind?'' Ashdown asked. Mrs. Thatcher said: ``I confess that that wasn't the foremost thought in my mind at this present time. ... After three general election victories, leading the only party with clear policies, resolutely carried out, I intend to continue.'' Heseltine, a former defense secretary, is the first serious challenger to Mrs. Thatcher since she became Conservative Party leader in 1975 and prime minister in 1979. Zeroing in on Heseltine's proposal that the national government assume the costs of education, she said that would ``either mean a huge increase in income tax, or a substantial reduction in monies available for other services.'' Two opinion polls published in newspapers today showed that Heseltine was more popular than Mrs. Thatcher with the general public. However, one poll, published in The Guardian newspaper, showed that Mrs. Thatcher is still the overwhelming favorite of Conservative Party voters. Heseltine, who submitted his nomination papers to party officials this morning, argues he is more likely to lead the Conservatives to victory in the next general election, which must be held by mid-1992. A poll of 1,084 people published in The Independent newspaper showed the Conservatives trailing Labor by 14 percentage points with Mrs. Thatcher at the helm. But, when the poll asked how people would vote if Heseltine were Conservative leader, the gap shrank to five points. The poll, conducted Wednesday by National Opinion Polls, had a margin of error of plus or minus three percent. The Guardian, which polled 1,446 people, found that Heseltine was favored when respondents of all political stripes were questioned, but that Mrs. Thatcher came out ahead when only Conservatives were asked. Heseltine was the first choice of 29 percent of the whole sample, four points ahead of Mrs. Thatcher. Among Conservatives, however, Mrs. Thatcher was chosen by 59 percent to Heseltine's 18 percent. ``The poll underlines the cruel choice facing Tory MPs,'' the Guardian reported. ``If they vote to keep Mrs. Thatcher, they will persevere with a leader who among the electorate attracts much the greater hostility of any contender. If they ditch her, they will deeply disappoint many committed supporters.'' The margin of error for the poll, conducted last weekend by International Communication Marketing Research Ltd., was not reported. A third poll of 240 of the 373 Conservative lawmakers, taken between Monday and today by Press Association, the British news agency, found that Heseltine faces defeat Tuesday. Press Association forecast that Mrs. Thatcher would win 53.3 percent of the vote and Heseltine would get 19.2 percent. But 27.5 percent of the Members of Parliament questioned refused to reveal their positions.

DOC.HEAD: Premier Calls for Emergency Measures to Deal With Grain Surplus
DOC.TEXT: Premier Li Peng has called for emergency measures to handle grain overflowing storage spaces after China's record harvest, an official report said Thursday. Li urged ``the mobilization of all social forces,'' and suggested building new permanent storage facilities, putting up temporary grain storage tents, and renting warehouses and empty buildings from other enterprises. The official Chinese media have reported for months that mountains of grain have been left out to rot throughout the country. Official statistics indicate that 30 million to 40 million tons of grain, representing 7 percent to 9 percent of this year's harvest, is unsheltered because of a severe shortage of granaries and other storage space. ``At the moment, the lack of granaries is a glaring problem. The grain departments alone cannot solve this problem,'' a report on the front page of the People's Daily paraphrased Li as telling local officials at a national conference on grain production in Beijing on Wednesday. Li also said farmers should be encouraged to find ways of storing their own grain. More than half of China's granaries are over 20 years old. The government says it plans to build new grain depots capable of storing 25 million tons of grain over the next five years. Already this year, the state has allocated $126 million to build granaries to store 8 million tons of grain, official reports said. Storage is only one problem created by the bumper crop, which is expected to top 462 million tons. China's largest previous grain harvest was 407 million tons in 1984. Farmers also are confronting low prices, and in some cases no buyers, for their grain. Chinese farmers can sell their harvest on the free market after meeting a state-set quota. But two consecutive years of bumper harvests have caused free market grain prices to drop. The state has raised its purchasing price for grain, but not enough to cover the rising costs of fertilizer and other outlays. To help make up for the drop in the market price, the state this fall started buying grain in excess of the quota at a slightly higher price than it paid for grain due to the state.

DOC.HEAD: Student Leaders Meet With Government, Plan Sit-In
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the 250,000 high school students who marched this week for a better education today demanded the government immediately spend millions of dollars in an emergency fund on the overcrowded school system. Education Minister Lionel Jospin met with a delegation of 20 students representing the two main moderate and leftist organizations that have emerged in four weeks of protests. Delegates said before the talks started that $1 billion that Premier Michel Rocard earmarked on Wednesday from the 1990 budget wouldn't be enough. Leaders of the moderate Federation Independant des Lyceens said they would ask for an additional $777 million during the talks. Another organization led by the Communist Party's youth movement also declared a higher sum would be necessary. Both groups basically seek more teachers, smaller classes, more innovative education and better security at schools in tough neighborhoods where crime and drugs are growing problems. A march on Monday by 250,000 students in Paris and the provinces deteriorated into widespread vandalism in the capital. Several hundred members of youth gangs exploited the crowd on the Left Bank to break windows, loot shops and burn or otherwise damage 190 cars. At least 140 police officers were injured in rock and tear-gas battles with the rioters. Special courts on Wednesday jailed or fined 53 youths arrested during the incident. Though Jospin and President Francois Mitterrand promised Monday to take steps to meet student demands, their leaders have vowed to keep up pressure until concrete measures are approved. The students plan to stage what they hope will be a peaceful sit-in Friday before the National Asssembly. They had earlier planned a march, but changed their tactics after Monday's rioting. The marches and accompanying violence are putting pressure on Rocard's government, which already faces a no-confidence test next week over plans to reform social security. His quick cash injection, targeted specifically at high schools, will add an extra $444 million dollars to this year's $20 billion budget deficit. The students won broad public support as accounts emerged of graffiti-scarred high schools with holes in the roofs, exposed wires, shortages of desks, violence against teachers and pupils, extortion, and drug use. The marches began last month after a student was raped in a lavatory in the gritty Paris suburb of St. Ouen. Most of the nearly daily protests have been peaceful.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls in Business Leaders to Discuss Nation's Economy
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with meeting ended and comments from a participant; picks up 5th graf pvs, The White...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush met today with leaders of some of the nation's largest corporations and banks as part of a series of private sessions to help him gauge whether the economy is in a recession. The president is trying to decide what steps he might be able to take to help soften the impact of the current slowdown, said a White House official. The official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said today's meeting follows a meeting on Wednesday between the president and bank regulators and administration economic officials. John G. Medlin Jr., president and chief executive officer of the First Wachovia Corp., said that the group of executives gave Bush a generally gloomy assessment of the economy with many expressing the belief that the country has either slipped into a recession or is on the verge of a downturn. Medlin said that Bush gave no indications of what the administration may be proposing in an effort to lessen the severity of any downturn and spent most of the session listening to what the business executives had to say in describing economic conditions. ``The president just listened. He didn't give us his views,'' Medlin said. ``He was very sincerely looking for views out in the real world.'' The White House officials said that Bush likely will hold another meeting with executives on Friday. The White House refused to release a list of those meeting with Bush, saying the sessions were private. ``It's an opportunity for the president to hear them (the business leaders). These are listening sessions,'' the official said. The sessions are an outgrowth of a meeting Bush had over the weekend at the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md., with Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, chief White House economist Michael Boskin, Budget Director Richard Darman and Vice President Dan Quayle. The president, at a news conference last Thursday, said he was ``concerned about an economic slowdown in the economy.'' ``I want to be sure that, to the degree a president can do something to soften the blow or to stimulate economic growth, that he tries to do it,'' Bush said at the time. White House officials today referred to those news conference remarks when asked about the series of meetings. Today's session is ``one of a series of private meetings the president is having to discuss the status of the economy with inside and outside experts,'' the White House official said. ``He likes to keep in touch,'' the official added. Although administration officials have not used the word ``recession'' to describe the current slowdown, many private economists have suggested that the economy may already be in a recession - or at least teetering on the edge of one. And Boskin, chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers, has offered far gloomier assessments of economy's condition in private meetings than in his public appearances, administration sources said.

DOC.HEAD: Nuclear Test Detonated After Protesters Arrested
DOC.TEXT: Four protesters were charged with misdemeanor trespassing after being caught on the Nevada Test Site minutes before a British nuclear weapon was to be detonated deep beneath the desert floor. The four were released on their own recognizance after an appearance Wednesday before U.S. Magistrate Lawrence Leavitt. Scientists detonated the nuclear after a delay of more than two hours, which government officials attributed both to technical problems and the search for the infiltrators near ground zero. The device, with an explosive punch up to 12 times the force of the World War II atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima, was detonated at 11:17 a.m. Wednesday after the four were removed by security officers. ``We're very pleased with the success of the protest,'' said Junior Bridge, a spokeswoman for the Greenpeace environmental organization. It was the second time in three years that anti-nuclear activists have infiltrated the sprawling secret desert site to delay a nuclear test. Motion from the blast was felt at Las Vegas City Hall, about 105 miles away, and atop the city's highrise hotels. It measured 5.1 on the Richter scale at the National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo. Energy Department officials rejected Greenpeace claims that the four protesters were near ground zero until they popped into view of cameras monitoring the blast site during a technical hold in the countdown six minutes before detonation. The nuclear device was buried 1,900 feet deep in a shaft filled with concrete. DOE spokesman Jim Boyer said intruders could be nearly on ground zero and the blast would ``just shake them up a lot.'' But Energy Department spokesman Chris West has said that someone standing on ground zero could receive a jolt from the blast strong enough to break their legs. All British nuclear tests are conducted in Nevada under a mutual defense treaty with the United States. Wednesday's test was the eighth this year at the Nevada site and the 707th since testing began there in 1951. The last previous test was Oct. 12.

DOC.HEAD: Warming Of Lake May Preview Greenhouse Effects In Canadian Lakes Region
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For use after 6 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: Increased forest fires, less snow, warmer lakes and fewer trout in Ontario may give a glimpse of what will happen if the Earth warms as a result of the greenhouse effect, Canadian researchers say. Scientists at the Canadian Department of Fisheries and Oceans report Friday in the journal Science that lakes monitored for more than 20 years in northwestern Ontario have been slowly changing as temperatures rise, snowfall declines and fires ravage nearby forests. D. W. Schindler, leader of the group, said the study does not claim that the changes are due to the greenhouse effect, but that the changes could be a preview of what is to come if the Earth does warm up. ``This is by no means the only period that has warmed for a prolonged time or at the rate that we're seeing,'' said Schindler. ``Our point is...to show what increasing warming and drying, which we would see with a greenhouse effect, would do to lakes and their watersheds.'' The greenhouse effect refers to global warming that is caused when the atmosphere is enriched with carbon dioxide and some other manmade gases that affect the movement of solar radiation and heat. The so-called greenhouse gases allow sunlight to pass through the atmosphere and strike the Earth. But the gases can prevent heat from radiating back out into space, thus trapping thermal energy about the planet. An increase in carbon dioxide is related to the burning of fossil fuels, such as coal and oil. The Canadian study shows that snowfall and other precipitation has decreased since the mid-1970s in the lakes in the Ontario study area. As a result, water runoff into the lakes has declined and this, in turn, has affected the lake chemistry. The waters have become clearer. Drier weather has led to more forest fires, some burning over millions of acres in the watershed feeding the lakes. This also changed the chemistry of the lakes and caused an increase in evaporation by allowing winds to more directly blow on the lakes. Schindler said air and water temperatures have increased, on the average, about 3.6 degrees during the study period. Snow, which once blanketed the area from fall to spring, now is sparse, with midwinter melts occurring most years. The lakes also lose their ice cover about 20 days earlier in the spring, said Schindler. This allows the lakes to absorb more solar radiation in the spring and thus warm up sooner and reach a higher temperature. Plant life has increased and changed in the lakes, due to the clearer water and warmer temperatures. This could provide more food for some fish and small organisms, but the warmer water may also cause major shifts in the types of fish, said Schindler. ``We may have increased productivity from the lakes, but there may be some pretty dramatic species changes,'' he said. ``What may be good trout lakes now may become good bass lakes. But we would have to stock them because the bass would not invade naturally.'' Schindler emphasized that his group is only reporting the observed effects of temperature and precipitation changes, not guessing on what is causing it. ``I'm not going to speculate if this is due to increases in carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases, or if it is a natural phenomenon at this point,'' he said. But Schindler said that the study does show that the changes brought about by the greenhouse effect will be many, varied and not altogether predictable. ``Our record indicates that it will not be a simplistic response,'' he said. Schindler was on the staff of the Department of Fisheries and Oceans when the study was conducted, but is now a researcher at the University of Alberta in Edmonton. Science, which published the study, is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Group Seeks Bad Ads
DOC.TEXT: If you've noticed any unfair, deceptive or misleading advertisements in the past year, national consumer groups want to know. Nominees are being sought for the annual Harlan Page Hubbard Awards, bestowed by a coalition of consumer organizations for what they consider to be the worst abuses of the advertising trade. The ``winners'' will be announced Dec. 10 in a variety of categories. Nominations should be sent to Hubbard Awards, 1875 Connecticut Ave., N.W., Suite 300, Washington, D.C., 20009-5728. Nominations should include an original copy of printed ads, along with the name and date of the publication and a description of why the ad is unfair or misleading. Broadcast commercials should be taped and sent in along with a written description of the station and time of broadcast and why they are misleading. Nominations are especially being sought in the categories of airlines, alcoholic beverages, automobiles, energy and the environment, financial services, food, telephones and toys. The awards are given annually by a coalition including the Action for Children's Television, Aviation Consumer Action Project, Center for Science in the Public Interest, Coalition on Smoking or Health, National Consumer's League, National Council on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence, National Women's Health Network and Safe Energy Communications Council. Hubbard, for whom the awards are named, was a 19th century advertising pioneer who specialized in promoting patent medicines for a variety of illnesses.

DOC.HEAD: `Blue Planet' Displays Astronaut's-Eye-View of a Threatened Earth
With AM-Space Shuttle, Bjt; AM-Shuttle Movie-List
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Burtt in 9th graf cq.
DOC.TEXT: Earth's beauty, and environmental threats to its survival, are vividly displayed in ``Blue Planet,'' a $5 million giant-screen movie filmed by astronauts aboard seven space shuttle flights. The 42-minute film is opening this month at IMAX and OMNIMAX theaters in 14 U.S. and Canadian cities. It will be shown in at least 11 other cities during the next four months before being shown internationally next spring. ``We hope the audience will come out of the film feeling concerned about protecting the Earth. It's our only home,'' said Graeme Ferguson, producer of ``Blue Planet'' and co-founder of IMAX Systems Corp. of Toronto. The movie gives viewers ``a real good feel for the perspective shuttle crew members have from low Earth orbit,'' said astronaut James Buchli, 45, a Marine colonel who helped shoot the film during Discovery's March 1989 mission. ``It's hard not to appreciate the grandeur of our Earth from that perch,'' Buchli said by phone from Johnson Space Center in Texas. ``You have a powerful feling of how insignificant each of us is with respect to the world as a whole.'' The camera used to make ``Blue Planet'' was invented in 1967. IMAX film has a frame size 10 times larger than conventional 35mm movie film, providing intense detail and a wide-field view that can be projected onto a giant screen. ``Blue Planet'' depicts the natural and human forces that shape Earth's environment, using IMAX and still photography from space and a variety of film shot on the planet's surface and beneath the sea. From space, the movie shows peaceful, almost alien scenes of volcanoes, eerie lightning flashes, puffy thunderclouds and giant swirling hurricanes. Then the film moves to the ground, capturing the violence of those natural processes with help from a powerful sound system. The movie was directed by four-time Oscar-winning sound designer Ben Burtt, who did sound effects for the ``Stars Wars'' trilogy and ``Indiana Jones'' films. The main message of ``Blue Planet'' deals with human damage to the environment: topsoil from farms washing down the Mississippi and Yangtze rivers, destruction of Madagascar forests, vast stretches of city lights gobbling energy, and a pall of smoke obscuring the Amazon Basin as rain forest goes up in flames. The space scenes in ``Blue Planet'' were shot during seven shuttle flights between 1984 and April. Ferguson, 61, also produced ``The Dream is Alive,'' the 1985 film that has been seen by more than 25 million people worldwide and was the first to use IMAX cameras aboard shuttles. He co-produced ``Hail Columbia!'' the 1982 IMAX film about the first shuttle mission. An IMAX camera wasn't aboard that flight. Lockheed Corp. paid most of the $5 million cost of ``Blue Planet.'' Other sponsors were the Smithsonian Institution's National Air and Space Museum, IMAX Systems and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Ferguson said the next IMAX film is a bit less cosmic: a 90-minute feature on the Rolling Stones' concert tour.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Takes New Aim At Public Power Subsidies
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is preparing a plan to cut public power subsidies but expects strong opposition from beneficiaries of the low-cost energy, lawmakers say. The proposals explore selling public power to the highest bidder, as well as including a surcharge to bring prices up to market levels in areas where the subsidized power is sold below cost. ``Auctioning off federal power at market rates is a radical, radical notion,'' said Paul Reiten, an energy expert for Sen. Mark Hatfield, R-Ore. ``For instance, Southern California could come in and outbid the Northwest ... and leave the Northwest with a power shortage.'' The Office of Budget and Management, offering suggestions for President Bush's new National Energy Strategy, outlined the money-saving options last week in recommendations to the Energy Department. OMB and DOE officials declined comment on the plan, but the American Public Power Association provided a copy of the memo to The Associated Press. It was confirmed by aides to Hatfield. ``This proposal eliminates multibillion dollar energy consumption subsidies at a time when DOE is expanding energy conservation subsidies,'' the OMB memo said. The agency acknowledged the plan would ``not be accepted by interest groups receiving the subsidies. The beneficiaries have a well-organized and strong nationwide constituency and are represented by powerful lobbying organizations.'' Presidents Reagan and Bush previously have recommended saving money by raising interest rates or speeding up debt payments for the nation's five public power marketing administrations. The biggest, the Bonneville Power Administration, provides about half the Pacific Northwest's power, serving about 8 million consumers. Hatfield said he believes the plan would boost wholesale public power rates in his region by more than 30 percent and residential rates by nearly 20 percent. ``This isn't a budget deficit measure, this is a proposal for social and economic disaster in the Pacific Northwest,'' Hatfield said. Rep. Al Swift, D-Wash., a member of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, said any federal gains through reduced subsidies would be more than offset by shortfalls in tax receipts as a result of the economic impact on the Northwest. ``It is a shortsighted, stupid, monomania idea in the mind of some troll in OMB,'' Swift said. The OMB memo said the power administrations ``provide subsidies for the well-to-do at the expense of the taxpayers in cities and poorer areas of the country.'' The below-cost sales have cost the federal treasury $4 billion since the dams were built, the agency said. BPA has the greatest installed generating capacity among the five administrations, 22,900 megawatts. But the plan also would address Western Area Power Administration, 10,400 megawatts; Southeastern Power Administration, 3,090 megawatts; Southwestern Power Administration, 2,150 megawatts; Alaska Power Administration, 108 megawatts. It takes about 1,000 megawatts to meet the energy needs of a city the size of Seattle.
