DOC.HEAD: Poll Says Two-Thirds Feel Health Care System Not Working Well
DOC.TEXT: Most Americans are disillusioned with the current health care system and favor rationing, although no one strategy has majority support, according to a survey released Thursday. The poll, conducted for Northwestern Life Insurance Company, found just 30 percent of those surveyed agreed that the country's health care system is working well, while 67 percent disagreed. More than 9 in 10 agreed that health care costs - expected to reach $650 billion for the nation this year - are rising out of control and that the country's health care system needs major changes to control costs. While more than two-thirds of those surveyed said they were confident their health care costs would be taken care of if they became seriously ill today, 60 percent worried that would not be the case in the future. Ninety-four percent said health care should be available to everyone regardless of ability to pay, but 52 percent said people who can pay should be able to buy extra care if they want it. Michael Conley, senior vice president for group insurance at the Minneapolis-based Northwestern Life, said this seeming contradiction is probably because Americans ``are still forming their values on rationing.'' But panelists who spoke after the poll results were presented said they were surprised that people think rationing is a new concept. They suggested that people have different interpretations of what it means. ``We really do ration health care now ... by limitations on access'' to health care, said John Golenski, president of the Bioethics Consultation Group Inc. of Berkeley, Calif., and an architect of Oregon's plan to revamp its Medicaid program. An estimated 31 million to 37 million Americans are uninsured. The survey focused on beliefs about rationing in general and did not ask more broadly what kind of changes in the current system people would like to see. The poll found that 85 percent agreed with at least one of six rationing concepts presented, but a majority could not agree on any one strategy. The strongest support, 44 percent, was for idea that treatments or procedures that are rationed or denied should be denied to everyone, regardless of ability to pay. Forty percent said availability of publicly funded health care should be based on the chance of success of the treatment, and 29 percent said smokers should be denied public funds for health care for treatment of illness caused by smoking. More than a quarter said children should be given priority for services and 16 percent said rationing should apply only to those using public funds. Also, half said they would trust a panel of medical professionals to make rationing decisions. The poll, conducted by Project Research Inc. of Minneapolis, involved telephone interviews with 500 adults in August and September. The margin of error was 4.5 percent, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Thrift Bailout Regulators Seek $6.8 Billion From Drexel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5-6th grafs, `FDIC and ...', with 8 grafs to UPDATE with detail from court filing. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `Drexel said...'. Version moved financial wires. PM-Drexel-S&Ls-List will move shortly.
DOC.TEXT: Thrift regulators are demanding a record $6.8 billion from Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. for alleged junk bond fraud. The collapsed investment firm says it's being made a scapegoat for the savings and loan debacle. The claims filed in federal Bankruptcy Court on Wednesday accuse Drexel and its former junk bond chief, Michael Milken, of ``plundering'' more than 40 failed thrifts through racketeering, fraud, bribery and numerous other crimes. The allegations brought by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Resolution Trust Corp. are by far the largest damages sought in the S&L crisis, which is expected to cost taxpayers more than $500 billion over 30 years. They also, for the first time, pin much of the blame for the crisis on Drexel. The 60-page court filing, released today, claims Drexel starting in 1982 ``spread a gospel of greed'' and illegally made billions of dollars by inducing S&Ls to use their federally insured deposits to buy junk bonds. ``The exposure of Drexel's and Milken's criminality destroyed the illusions surrounding junk bonds that Drexel and Milken had sought to create,'' the filing said. The agencies charged Drexel manipulated junk bond prices, arranged secret securities ``parking'' deals, ran sham transactions, bribed favored customers and controlled a network of S&L customers to sustain a fictitious market. The filing lists 41 failed thrifts with junk bond losses totaling more than $330 million and seeks $1.25 million more in damages for the lost value of current holdings. An additional 18 failed thrifts have separate non-junk bond claims. Institutions from 18 states and the District of Columbia are included. The alleged damages sought are tripled under federal antitrust and racketeering laws, for a total of $6 billion. The agencies also seek $800 million for the alleged illegal activity unrelated to junk bonds. A separate claim for more than $4.5 billion was filed on behalf of Columbia Savings and Loan Association of Los Angeles, which has not been taken over by the government. The largest claimed loss is $56.2 million by Imperial Savings Association of San Diego and the smallest $27,500 by Charter Savings Bank of Newport Beach, Calif. The filing seeks $150 million for alleged securities fraud by Drexel against Capital Bank & Trust Co. of Washington, D.C. FDIC and RTC chairman L. William Seidman said the agencies ``still have much more to do to ensure that we identify and recover all the losses caused by Drexel. The American taxpayers ... expect no less from us.'' Drexel said in a statement that it ``has become a convenient scapegoat for the S&L crisis as various agencies and branches of the government attempt to deflect their own responsibility.'' ``Regardless of the number of zeros in the claims ... Drexel intends to vigorously defend against them,'' the firm said. ``In court the conduct of regulators and others chiefly responsible for the S&L debacle will be the real issue.'' Drexel, which sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in February, already faces billions of dollars more in claims in more than 100 lawsuits filed by investors, shareholders and former clients. Milken has pleaded guilty to securities violations and is awaiting sentencing next week. The FDIC insures deposits for the nation's savings and loans. Resolution Trust oversees the thrift bailout and has taken over more than 100 failed S&Ls. Drexel handled most of the $15 billion in junk bonds bought by thrifts. But the junk bond market collapsed about a year ago, devastating the securities' value. The claims are far larger than a $1.1 billion racketeering lawsuit filed by the government against Lincoln Savings and Loan head Charles Keating and others. But the FDIC and Resolution Trust are not expected to get anything near $6.8 billion. Lawyers for Drexel and those who have sued the company are negotiating a fixed amount to be set aside to settle more than 100 lawsuits and the federal claims. In addition, Drexel's assets, not counting the value of its junk bond portfolio and certain stock investments, total only about $3 billion, against $2.85 billion in liabilities. Drexel and Milken have denied any role in the S&L collapse, and a March 1989 report by the congressional General Accounting Office concluded that junk bonds had not contributed to the S&L crisis. But the S&L industry was criticized for dealing in junk bonds, which offer high yields at high risk. Under last year's federal thrift bailout bill, savings and loans must sell their junk bond holdings by 1994. The FDIC and RTC alleged among other things that Drexel made misrepresentations about the bonds and gave payoffs to managers of some S&Ls. Drexel also allegedly engaged in anticompetitive practices and threatened companies that did not retain Drexel as an investment banker.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Convicted in Fatal Arsenic Poisoning
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf, `Moore, who...' with 2 grafs to restore dropped quotation marks, recast. Picks up 16th graf pvs, `Defense attorneys...'.
DOC.TEXT: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. (AP) - A woman found guilty of murdering a former boyfriend by spoon-feeding him food laced with arsenic ``just loves people'' and shouldn't be put to death, her daughter told a jury today. Blanche Taylor Moore, 57, was convicted Wednesday in the death of Raymond Reid in 1986. As Mrs. Moore's sentencing hearing got under way this morning, Vanessa Woods said her mother cared for Ms. Woods' premature baby when it was born several years ago ``like its mother.'' ``My mother is just the same today as she always is,'' she said. ``She just loves people.'' Mrs. Moore also is charged with murder in the poisoning of her first husband in 1973 and with assault for allegedly poisoning her current husband after their honeymoon last year. No trial dates have been set in those cases. Another character witness at the hearing, jailer Carolyn Hinshaw, told jurors today that she and Mrs. Moore get down on her knees every morning and evening and pray during in the 1{ years Mrs. Moore has been in jail. ``All I knew about her is what I read in the paper,'' Mrs. Hinshaw said. ``She wasn't there very long before her concerns for other people became very evident.'' The only options before the jury were life in prison or death, which is carried out by injection or gas in North Carolina. The only woman executed in the United States in the last 15 years was also a North Carolina woman convicted of fatally poisoning a boyfriend with arsenic. Velma Barfield was put to death in 1984. The jury convicted Mrs. Moore on Wednesday after six hours of deliberations over two days. Prosecutors said Mrs. Moore killed Reid to gain part of his estate, feeding him spiked, home-cooked food while he lay dying from arsenic poisoning in the hospital. His symptoms had been mistakenly diagnosed as a rare nerve and muscle disease. Mrs. Moore testified last week that she is lovingly cared for the three men she is accused of poisoning. ``I know arsenic was found in these three people, but I know that I didn't do it,'' she said. ``I've never physically harmed other people.'' Mrs. Moore's estranged husband, the Rev. Dwight Moore, who was hospitalized for arsenic poisoning last year, told a newspaper Wednesday that he was against execution. ``I would be more at peace with a life sentence than the death penalty,'' Moore told the Roanoke (Va.) Times & World-News. Moore, who is living on disability and had to resign from his position at the Carolina United Methodist Church of Christ near Burlington because of the effects of the poisoning, said he had been confident that Mrs. Moore would be found guilty. ``I felt the jury could have made the decision walking down the hall to the jury room,'' he said. Defense attorneys tried to blame an acquaintance of Mrs. Moore's, Garvin Thomas, who is now dead. They produced a rambling, five-page letter in which he allegedly confessed to the crimes, but handwriting experts differed on whether Mrs. Moore or Thomas could have written the letter. Officials exhumed five bodies while investigating the case, including those of Mrs. Moore's father, a former mother-in-law of hers and a former co-worker. They found arsenic in the remains of Mrs. Moore's father, but she was not charged in his death.

DOC.HEAD: ABC Morning Show Gets Highest Ratings in Four Years
DOC.TEXT: ABC's ``Good Morning America'' last week had its largest audience in more than four years and won the ratings race for network morning shows for the 45th consecutive week. A.C. Nielsen Co. estimates on Thursday showed ABC's program won easily over NBC's ``Today,'' averaging a 5.2 rating to a 3.5. ``CBS This Morning'' had a 2.6 rating. Each ratings point represents 931,000 homes. Ratings were up for ``Good Morning'' and ``Today.'' NBC's once-dominant show fell behind ``Good Morning'' in January after the much-publicized replacement of co-anchor Jane Pauley by Deborah Norville. Last week's ratings for ``Good Morning America'' were the show's highest since the week that ended April 21, 1986, ABC said. The show also had a 5.2 rating then, but a ratings point at that time represented 859,000 homes.

DOC.HEAD: Business Inventories Grow Amid Concern About Further Production Cuts
DOC.TEXT: Business inventories grew 0.5 percent in September, the government said Thursday, leading some analysts to express concern the buildup could lead to further production cuts and loss of jobs. Economist Evelina Tainer of the First National Bank of Chicago noted that industrial production in October already dropped 0.8 percent, its sharpest cutback in nine months. ``It's consistent with the idea that the economy is sliding into a recession and growth will be negative in the fourth quarter,'' she said. Analysts said the inventory level itself had not reached a dangerous level although continued vigilance was needed to prevent an even deeper reduction in output. The Commerce Department said inventories held on shelves and backlots in September totaled a seasonally adjusted $811.5 billion, up from $807.5 billion the previous month. But the accumulation slowed from a 0.7 percent gain in both July and August, the largest increases since an 0.8 percent advance in July 1989. Business sales dipped 0.5 percent to a seasonally adjusted $548.7 billion, down from $551.5 billion a month earlier. It was the first decline in sales since a 0.4 percent drop in July and the largest since a 1.0 percent decrease last April. August sales had jumped 2.1 percent. The ratio of inventories to sales edged up to 1.48 from a 1.46 level in August. The ratio means it would take 1.48 months to exhaust the backlog of goods at the September sales pace. Still, the ratio was down from its recent peak of 1.54 in July 1989 and economist Michael P. Niemira of Mitsubishi Bank in New York said businesses are now able to react more rapidly to economic developments and avoid serious buildups. The ratio reached a high of 1.74 in January 1982 during the last recession. ``I think you'll see inventories coming down, but coming down coincident with a slowdown in sales,'' Niemira said, noting that retail purchases last month slowed to a 0.1 percent increase from a 1.3 percent advance in September. In both months, however, the sales gains were fueled by high gasoline prices, rather than volume. When the gasoline component was excluded, retail sales actually fell 0.1 percent last month while rising just 0.9 percent in September. All categories posted inventory gains - manufacturers, up 0.6 percent, and wholesalers and retailers, up 0.4 percent each. At the same time, manufacturers' sales fell 0.7 percent while wholesalers posted a 1.8 percent decline. Sales at the retail level jumped 1.3 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Exile Sentenced in Death of Former Chilean Diplomat
DOC.TEXT: A Cuban-born man who pleaded guilty to conspiracy in the 1976 assassination of former Chilean Ambassador Orlando Letelier was sentenced Thursday to 12 years in prison. U.S. District Judge Aubrey Robinson Jr. called the deaths of Letelier and an aide, Ronni Moffitt, a ``cold, ruthless act of terrorism'' before sentencing Jose Dionisio Suarez Esquivel to the maximum prison term allowed under a plea agreement. Suarez, a member of the Cuban National Movement, was described by his attorney as an anti-Castro Cuban. ``In all his political zeal, he turned to one of the few countries in the world'' that could have given him freedom, Robinson said referring to Suarez's move to the United States. But ``he chose not to be as free'' as everyone else, the judge said. Letelier and Moffitt were killed here Sept. 21, 1976, when a bomb exploded beneath the former ambassador's car. Letelier, Chile's ambassador to Washington from 1971 to 1973, was an outspoken critic of the right-wing military government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet. Suarez, who had been a fugitive for a dozen years, in September admitted giving a blasting cap to former Chilean intelligence agent Michael V. Townley, who allegedly masterminded the assassination. In exchange for Suarez's plea, authorities agreed to drop charges of concealing a fugitive against his wife, Elizabeth Gongora Suarez, officials said. Suarez, 51, will be eligible for parole after serving nine years. Two other people have been convicted in connection with the bombing. Townley was sentenced to 10 years, while former Chilean army Maj. Armando Fernandez Larios received seven years. Fernandez defected from Chile in 1987 and pleaded guilty to an accessory after the fact. He implicated two of his superiors and Pinochet in the coverup of the Chilean military's involvement in the crime. The two Chilean military officials have been charged with participating in the murder, but the Chilean government has refused to extradite them.

DOC.HEAD: Social Workers Say Parents Shouldn't Spank Children
DOC.TEXT: Slapping or spanking children only encourages them to think violence is an acceptable form of behavior, says a social workers' group. The National Association of Social Workers, which previously opposed corporal punishment in schools, has passed a resolution rejecting physical punishment for children in the home. Since the policy was passed in August, the Silver Spring, Md.-based group with 130,000 members has been promoting its resolution nationwide. ``Beating a child, whipping a child, spanking a child is really not a rational way of teaching a child how to change his or her behavior,'' said Isadora Hare, staff director of the group's Commission on Education. ``What you do is breed resentment in the child and anger towards you which is going to come out in more undesirable behavior. What is important is to teach a child why behavior is unacceptable.'' The no spanking policy and alternative means of child discipline is being discussed the group's annual meeting this week in Boston. Nineteen states ban corporal punishment in schools, Hare said. But dissuading parents from hitting their children will be tough in a country where such discipline is widespread, largely because of religious beliefs, she said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS SAN DIEGO-dated 3rd item in rdp to UPDATE with bird found.
DOC.TEXT: Fred the cockatoo from the Robert Blake TV series ``Baretta'' was found this morning, a day and a half after being stolen from the San Diego Wild Animal Park, officials said. The missing cockatoo was one of three that portrayed Blake's pet during the 1970s series, in which the actor played a streetwise police officer. Police spokesman Bill Robinson said that Scott Forester and Johnny Martinez told police they spotted the bird in the middle of a road this morning, less than a mile from the Wild Animal Park. Forester and Marintez returned the bird, which appeared unscathed, to the park. The winner of a Patsy - the animal equivalent of an Academy Award - Fred had been performing in shows at the park for the last six years. The 30-year-old bird was taken from a holding cage kept in the rear area of the park's bird show theater sometime between Tuesday evening and Wednesday morning, when the theft was discovered, Robinson said. Park spokesman Tom Hanscom said Fred was the only bird taken among 40 in the holding cages. The cockatoo is owned by Ray Berwick and Associates of Westlake Village, which contracts with the Wild Animal Park to provide trained animals for the park's show. The company provided the cockatoos for the ``Baretta'' series and brought Fred to the Wild Animal Park, an affiliate of the San Diego Zoo, in 1984, Hanscom said. Because of Fred's training and star status, the bird had an estimated value of $15,000. Typically, sulfur crested cockatoos can be obtained for about $2,000. Hanscom said Fred can talk in simple phrases, coughs, and laughs.

DOC.TEXT: Here are lists of savings and loans the government regulators allege were defrauded by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The lists consist of 41 failed thrifts with junk bond losses, 18 failed thrifts with other claims against Drexel and a separate claim on behalf of Columbia Savings and Loan Association, which has not been taken over by the government. The claims were filed by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Resolution Trust Corp. in U.S. Bankruptcy Court late Wednesday and released publicly Thursday. For the junk bond losses, the list contains the thrift name, location, size of losses and total current junk bond holdings at cost. The additional claims list the alleged wrongdoing and amount of claim. The list does not reflect the total $6.8 billion being sought against Drexel. That includes the cost of junk bonds still held by the S&Ls, damages for defaulted bonds, insurance damages to be paid to S&Ls, tripled damages under federal racketeering and antitrust laws, and other claims. The agencies noted that the data on some of the thrifts may be incomplete because of difficulty obtaining complete records.
