Westwood Savings and Loan Association, Los Angeles, securities fraud, breach of fiduciary duty, $96,002.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Invokes Powers For Military Construction In Persian Gulf
DOC.TEXT: President Bush invoked emergency powers Thursday authorizing the Pentagon to undertake military construction projects in the Persian Gulf without advance approval from Congress. Without the waiver, the Pentagon would have had to go through a lengthy process of requesting authorization from Congress for each construction project and then seeking an appropriation from lawmakers to finance it. ``Operational requirements do not permit such an extended process for construction of much-needed facilities,'' Bush said in a letter to leaders of the House and Senate. Bush said his action will enable Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney ``to undertake military construction projects that he deems necessary to respond to the threat caused by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.'' Bush granted the waiver in an executive order under the authority of the National Emergencies Act.

DOC.HEAD: Gainesville Slayings Figure Sentenced in Beating of Grandmother
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager identified as a suspect in the slayings of five Gainesville college students was sentenced Thursday to 22 months in a prison mental hospital for beating his elderly grandmother. Edward Lewis Humphrey, who has a history of mental problems, also faces an assault charge in Gainesville and a 1988 attempted rape and burglary case in Indian River County. Public Defender J.R. Russo told Circuit Judge Theron Yawn that he could find no public treatment center willing to accept the 19-year-old University of Florida student. Private psychiatric hospitals wanted $600 to $1,000 per day to treat him, more than his family could afford, Russo said. Hospitals run by the universities of Florida, Miami and South Florida refused to accept Humphrey for private commitment, partially because of his notoriety, Russo said. Humphrey was convicted Oct. 10 on a charge of battery on a person over age 65. The judge imposed the maximum prison term and recommended to the state prison system that Humphrey serve it in the Corrections Mental Health Institution at Florida State Hospital in Chattahoochee. ``I look at it as a psychiatric care sentence,'' Russo said, adding that he doesn't think Humphrey will serve any of his time in a regular prison. Humphrey has been labeled a suspect in the slayings of five students, some of them mutilated, near the University of Florida campus in Gainesville during the last week in August. But he has not been charged in those cases. He had been jailed in lieu of $1 million bond since the beating Aug. 30 at his home in Indialantic, two days after the last two bodies were discovered in Gainesville. Humphrey's grandmother, Elna Hlavaty told a deputy that night that her grandson had beaten and choked her. But at the trial, she testified she had fallen and hurt herself in the dark. Russo had argued for probation with temporary commitment to a mental hospital, but the judge said he wanted a sentence somewhere between probation and prison. Humphrey's family reacted angrily to the sentence, with his 79-year-old grandmother calling it a ``charade of justice.'' ``It should have been thrown out. I was never beaten,'' she said. ``That boy has done nothing wrong.'' ``Any hope Ed had of being a normal person has been washed away,'' said Humphrey's 22-year-old brother, George, choking back tears. ``It's sad to see Ed sacrificed,'' George Humphrey said. Edward Humphrey nodded when his grandmother blew him a kiss as he entered the courtroom but generally appeared oblivious to the proceedings and mostly stared off into space. The judge also placed Humphrey on probation for 14 months after his prison term with the condition that he continue psychiatric treatment if needed. Humphrey was to transferred to an Orlando hospital for a psychiatric evaluation and then to the state prison system's mental health hospital within the next three days, Russo said.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Singer Michael Jackson is negotiating a new contract with CBS Records that would beat anything else out there. Jackson sent attorney Bertram Fields to New York this week to team up with his contract negotiator, Allen Grubman. The pop singer is asking CBS for a special production deal and royalties of more than $2.50 per album. Jackson requested an advance against royalties of more than $18 million per album. Pop music royalties generally range from $1 to $1.50 per album, including publishing royalties. Jackson also is seeking his own recording label, the Los Angeles Times reported Thursday. The newspaper said Jackson wants a guarantee that his deal outpaces that of any other pop singer, including his sister, Janet Jackson, who is renegotiating a contract with A&M Records. CBS Records spokesman Bob Altshuler declined comment on the negotiations. --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - Country singer Roseanne Cash says Americans suffer from a ``cultural malaise'' that values money over artistic creativity. ``We are becoming so heavily identified with that dollars and cents mentality that we are numbing ourselves to the better half of our nature,'' Cash told a national panel evaluating music education in schools. She was one of 17 music professionals, educators and students who addressed the panel from the National Commission on Music Education. The panel will forward its recommendations about music education to Congress and President Bush next year. --- PARIS (AP) - Actress Debra Winger couldn't shake the desert after filming ``The Sheltering Sky'' in the Sahara. She put on a pack and traveled for three weeks in the west-central African country of Niger. ``Only then could I face coming home. I had the desert inside of me,'' she said Wednesday at a screening of the movie, due to open in the United States in December. Based on Paul Bowles' best-selling novel by the same name, the film stars Winger and John Malkovich as Kit and Port Moresby, sophisticated New York artists who go into the African desert to save their failing marriage. Director Bernardo Bertolucci admits his cast and crew went through an ordeal to make the film. He said the cast and crew of 120 battled desert heat and flooding caused by the first rain in the region in two years. The storms swept away roads and bridges, stranding equipment trucks, the cast, crew and even Bertolucci himself. ``It was a hard movie to make. The sweat isn't makeup, it's real sweat,'' he said. ``The dust is real dust and the flies are real flies.'' Bertolucci aid he was attracted to ``The Sheltering Sky,'' which became something of a cult book when published in 1949, because ``after `The Last Emperor,' I was really interested in doing something that didn't have a lot of actors and a lot of costumes.'' --- MINNEAPOLIS (AP) - Sound problems plagued a Billy Joel concert, and the arena gave refunds to people who complained. The $23.50 ticket price was returned to 142 people who complained during Joel's show at the Target Center, which opened last month. Sound technicians checked into the complaints, found a couple of dead spots, and corrected the problems, said Frank Russo, center executive director. Some concertgoers in the affected sections were relocated to unsold seats or private suites at Tuesday's performance, said Nancy Bindas, director of marketing for the center. --- LANSING, Mich. (AP) - The law caught up to fugitive rocker Bob Baldori in Toronto, but his lawer says the arrest was cordial with officers asking for autographs and serenading him with his 1967 hit, ``Who Do You Love?'' The FBI said the 47-year-old musician was arrested Wednesday by immigration authorities and was expected to be sent back to Michigan this weekend. Baldori, known as ``Boogie Bob,'' has been a federal fugitive since February when he disappeared before his arraignment on drug charges. Authorities seized 88 pounds of marijuana Jan. 16 from his home near Lansing. His lawyer, Mark Fox, said Baldori and his girlfriend were returning to their Toronto apartment when they were met by police and immigration officials. ``There were about eight officers and most of them wanted his autograph. Then they sang to him. They broke into `Who Do You Love?''' he said. The song is a Bo Diddly classic. In 1967, Baldori and a band called The Woolies recorded the song, which made the charts and was the group's only hit. --- MADRID, Spain (AP) - Argentine writer Adolfo Bioy Casares on Thursday was awarded the 15th Miguel de Cervantes Prize, considered the Nobel prize of literature in Spanish. ``I am overwhelmed with happiness and a bit flustered,'' the 76-year-old Bioy Casares said after the announcement. ``Literature has been the most important part of my life.'' He was in Madrid for a seminar on his work. The prize, with a $129,000 award, is given by the Spanish Culture Ministry. Bioy Casares first won acclaim for his 1940 novel ``The Invention of Morel,'' which formed the basis for Alain Robbe-Grillet's 1961 film ``Last Year at Marienbad.'' Also in the 1940s, he used the pseudonym Honorio Bustos Domecq to publish two collections of short stories with fellow Argentine Jorge Luis Borges, who later received the Cervantes prize. The first, ``Anthology of Fantastic Literature,'' was a compilation of what later became known as magic realism.

DOC.HEAD: Changes in Eastern Europe Seen Driving Down World Food, Oil Prices
DOC.TEXT: Changes in the Soviet Union and eastern Europe will drive down prices for food and energy worldwide, members of an international panel of experts predicted Thursday. Increased grain production will mean the end of the common farm policy that has helped keep prices high in the 12 western governments of the European Community and elsewhere, said L. Alan Winters of the University of Birmingham in Britain. The panel's report foresaw that the biggest food price effect from the end of the Communist system would come in grain and dairy products, because of the increased production expected. A 20 percent rise in eastern European milk production would be equivalent to the same increase in the 12 European Community countries, it said. ``Worldwide price reductions of at least 10 percent (for) wheat and 9 percent (for) coarse grains would be necessary to absorb the additional output,'' the panel added. Coarse grains are normally fed to farm animals. The Soviet Union produces large quantities of oil and coal; Poland is also a big coal producer. Winters saw world supplies increasing as eastern European factories become more efficient and use less energy, and as new drilling methods increase Soviet oil production. ``World oil prices could tumble, perhaps by as much as one-fifth, squeezing high-cost producers such as (Britain), Mexico and Texas and reducing OPEC's market power,'' the report said. OPEC is the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. `Similarly, increases in East European output of coal and gas will put downward pressure on world prices, even allowing for some output reductions for environmental reasons, such as in East Germany,'' it added. Members of the panel came from Britain, Switzerland, Italy, Sweden, Norway and Belgium. It was organized by the Centre for Economic Policy Research in London. The center is a network based on European universities. Its report, the first of an annual series, was titled ``Monitoring European Integration - The Impact of Eastern Europe.'' Portes aid it was presented last week to authorities of the European Community. He presented it to reporters Thursday under the auspices of the Brookings Institution, a major private research group.

DOC.HEAD: Commander Salutes Forces Defending Freedom as Pilgrims
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of U.S. forces in the Middle East, saluted American troops on Wednesday for defending freedom just as the Pilgrims did in 1620. In a Thanksgiving message released eight days early, he said the Americans defending Saudi Arabia in Operation Desert Shield have shown the same courage as the Pilgrims who celebrated the first Thanksgiving. The operation, he said, has become ``a symbol of freedom around the world.'' Here is the text of Schwarzkopf's message: ``In 1620 a group of courageous and determined men and women traveled halfway around the world to restore their freedoms and return to peaceful, just lives. Three hundred seventy years later, another group of courageous Americans has again traveled halfway around the world to the Arabian Gulf region to defend those same eternal principles. ``As we take a brief respite from our important mission in order to celebrate a harvest of blessings, I want all of you to know that you have the country's deepest gratitude for the superb job you are doing making Desert Shield a symbol of freedom around the world. ``For those of you deployed away from home, this will not be a traditional Thanksgiving; but for everyone it will certainly be a meaningful one, as each of you does your part to defend the ideals that Americans have held so dear for generations. I salute and thank everyone associated with Desert Shield for giving so much to the country.''

DOC.BYLINE: Post-Communist Army Trimmed Dramatically, To Become Defensive Force ^By DRUSILLA MENAKER
DOC.TEXT: Poland's post-Communist army has been trimmed by 100,000 soldiers and will be nearly halved to transform it into the defensive force of a neutral country, the Defense Ministry announced Thursday. Meanwhile, troops are being reoriented to defend the eastern border with the Soviet Union as well as the western frontier as they had before, officials said at a news conference. Military officials of the old regime are being replaced, with 62 percent of the Defense Ministry administration changed since Solidarity took over the government last year, the officials said. They said any military role of the Warsaw Pact already has been ``frozen.'' ``We hope that military power will never again be the weightiest argument in European or world politics,'' said Vice Adm. Piotr Kolodziejczyk, the defense minister who in July replaced the longtime Communist defense chief, Gen. Florian Siwicki. Poland always maintained the largest army in the Warsaw Pact after the Soviet Union. Now it will undergo a thorough transformation as it shifts to a defensive orientation and sheds its political role, Kolodziejczyk told reporters at his first news conference as defense minister. Troops will number 305,000 by the end of December, down from more than 400,000 in 1988, he said. Planners have started intensive work on a new military model, dubbed ``Armed Forces '90,'' that envisions an army of 230,000 to 250,000 highly mobile, well-trained, well-armed troops. Poland's defense will no longer be focused only on its western border, the officials said. However, permanent redeployment of divisions to the eastern border is too expensive now, although it will be considered if budgets allow in the future. Kolodziejczyk said it would take no more than a day to move troops to eastern Poland, adding ``despite the absence of people in uniform in those regions, we care about assuring security and people should be assured.'' He rejected claims from candidates in Poland's Nov. 25 presidential election that democratic change has been too slow in the military. He said 56 generals will have left by Jan. 1, when there will be a total of 88, compared with 188 in 1984 and 96 in Poland's last independent army on the eve of World War II in 1939. Deputy Defense Minister Janusz Onyszkiewicz, a civilian formerly known as the spokesman for the long-banned Solidarity movement, predicted that two military groups will exist after the demise of the Warsaw Pact: NATO and the Soviet Union - or at least the Russian republic. Poland will be a ``neutral'' country, not aligned with either, he said. ``Poland will remain neutral in the sense that ... it does not plan in the future to join NATO or to get into some kind of military alliance with the Soviet Union which would make it impossible for Poland to keep close to both the West and the East,'' he said. Onyszkiewicz said the Warsaw Pact's military role has essentially ended. ``At the moment, these institutions do not function. They are completely frozen, and our armed forces are under absolute control of the Polish command and the Polish political authorities,'' he said. Poland sees the Warsaw Pact having a brief second life as a consultative body. ``We think it is something relatively short-termed, and this pact is of a transitional character, but we think it can fill a certain political void which otherwise would be created in Central Europe,'' Onyszkiewicz said.

DOC.HEAD: First Lady To Read Excerpts Of Book To Czechoslovakian Children
With AM-Bush Trip, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush, accompanying the president on an eight-day trip to Europe and the Persian Gulf, will introduce Czechoslovakian children to a book she ghost-wrote for the family dog, Millie. Mrs. Bush will read to students at the Prague Middle School from ``Millie's Book.'' The book is a tongue-in-cheek insider's view of life in the White House as seen trough a dog's eyes. Mrs. Bush's schedule in Paris, Prague, Germany, Cairo and Saudi Arabia also includes time with the wives of heads of state and visits to literary and cultural spots. She will get a taste of Saudi Arabian segregation of the sexes, dining separately with the king's wife while their husbands eat in another room. On the first day of the trip Saturday, Mrs. Bush will join the wife of Czechoslovakian President Vaclav Havel, Olga, for several events in Prague. In addition to the visit to the middle school, the first ladies will stop at a hospital for the mentally disabled, and take a walking tour of the Charles Bridge, a pedestrian bridge with a famous view. The Bushes travel then to Ludwigshafen, Germany, where Mrs. Bush will have tea on Sunday with the wife of Chancellor Helmut Kohl, while their husbands hold talks. In Paris, where Bush will attend the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, Mrs. Bush on Monday will join the spouses of the other leaders participating in the 34-nation conference. The spouses will tour the historical Trianon Palace and attend a luncheon hosted by Daniele Mitterrand, wife of the president. On Tuesday they will tour the Picasso exhibit at the Grand Palais Museum and attend a luncheon hosted by Michele Rocard, wife of Prime Minister Michel Rocard, and visit the Institute Pasteur which is conducting AIDS research. The president and Mrs. Bush will travel to Saudi Arabia on Wednesday and will spend Thursday, Thanksgiving Day, with the U.S. troops sent by Bush to stand against the army of Iraq's President Saddam Hussein. Mrs. Bush will have dinner in Jeddah on Wednesday night with Princess Jawhara, the most recent of the three wives King Fahd is known to have had. The president and the king will dine separately for a working dinner. Women in Saudi Arabia are not permitted to take part in affairs of state. The Bushes will stop in Cairo before returning home next Friday. Mrs. Bush is expected to accompany the wife of Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, Suzanne, to a library and a school for blind children.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers: Most Cystic Fibrosis Occurs When Key Protein Misplaced ^Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EST, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Most cystic fibrosis cases occur because cells single out and block a crucial protein when it is misformed, suggests a study that boosts prospects for developing treatment. Scientists had already linked cystic fibrosis to a malfunction on the surface of cells. But the finding that the malformed protein simply never shows up on the surface where it belongs ``was a big surprise to us,'' said researcher Alan Smith. The finding supports the idea that cystic fibrosis may be treatable by having patients inhale an aerosol to deliver the protein into its proper place, he said. Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder that affects about 30,000 children and young adults in the United States. Their lungs produce a thick, sticky mucus that sets the stage for fatal lung infections. Mucus elsewhere interferes with digestion. The abnormal mucus appears because cells cannot expel charged particles called chloride ions, while they absorb other particles called sodium ions too rapidly. That results from defects in the gene that tells cells how to make a protein called cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator, or CFTR. The genetic defects lead to faulty versions of CFTR. The new study suggests that most cases of cystic fibrosis occur because these versions never reach their proper place on the cell surface. The work is reported in Friday's issue of the journal Cell by Smith and colleagues at the Genzyme Corp. of Framingham, Mass. ``It's a beautiful piece of work'' that ``allowed them to make an important new hypothesis'' about what causes cystic fibrosis, commented Dr. Michael Welsh of the University of Iowa College of Medicine in Iowa City and the Howard Hughes Medical Institute. The work was done in monkey cells, and the hypothesis should now be tested in cells from cystic fibrosis patients and healthy people, he said. For the research, scientists injected cells in the laboratory with genetic material that carried specific mutations, some of which mimicked defects in the CFTR gene that cause cystic fibrosis. The mutation responsible for about 70 percent of cystic fibrosis cases led to a version of CFTR that was incompletely processed by the cell, scientists found. Normally, the cell adds carbohydrates to the backbone of the CFTR protein. That is a two-step process, but the defective version of CFTR completed only the first step, Smith said. Apparently it was recognized as abnormal by some sort of ``quality control mechanism,'' he said in a telephone interview. The abnormal protein failed to continue on to take up its normal position on the surface of the cell, he said. Genzyme scientists are studing the possibility of treating cystic fibrosis by replacing the missing CFTR at the cell surface, he said. ``This finding very much encourages us,'' he said. The idea would be to use a virus or some other targeting system to deliver normal CFTR to lung cells, he said. That strategy had been discussed before, along with others such as delivering normal CFTR genes to the cells, noted Robert Beall, the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation's executive vice president for medical affairs. The new work suggests that protein replacement ``may be a very important option,'' he said. Smith said that the absence of CFTR at the cell surface does not cause all cases of cystic fibrosis. The study found that two very rare genetic mutations that cause the disease do not keep CFTR from getting to the surface, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Charter Flight to Evacuate Americans from Kuwait
With AM-US-Gulf
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 Americans and their foreign-born family members are expected to leave Kuwait on Sunday aboard a U.S.-chartered Iraqi Airways flight, the State Department said Thursday. Most are women and children who have been eligible to leave for some time but decided only recently to do so, said deputy spokesman Richard Boucher. Iraq has forbidden American men to leave Iraq and Kuwait except for those with Arab ancestry. More than 100 American men have been taken to military and industrial installations to deter a possible U.S. attack on Iraq. After leaving Kuwait, the plane is scheduled to stop in Baghdad before proceeding to London. It was not clear when the Americans and their family members would arrive in the United States. Earlier charter flights have taken more than 2,000 Americans out of Iraq and Kuwait. According to U.S. estimates, there are fewer than 1,000 Americans left in the two countries. Some Americans, responding to an Iraqi invitation, are making plans for holiday visits to family members trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. The State Department is opposed to such travel, saying the safety of the visiting Americans cannot be assured.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors May Be Wrongly Evaluating Patients' Heart Risks
DOC.TEXT: Doctors may be giving bad advice about the dangers of heart disease by not considering the interaction of risk factors such as high blood pressure, high cholesterol and smoking, a doctor said Thursday. ``Based on single factor determinations, they may be needlessly alarming or falsely reassuring patients,'' said Dr. William B. Kannel of Boston University. Kannel is one of the principal investigators with the Framingham Heart Study, a 40-year-long study of 5,209 people in Framingham, Mass., 25 miles west of Boston. The study has provided the information researchers use to determine how much an elevated cholesterol level, for example, or hypertension, increases a person's risk of heart disease. Kannel and the American Heart Association announced the development of a ``risk factor prediction kit'' that will enable doctors to better estimate patients' heart disease risks. The kit, based on the Framingham data, allows doctors to calculate the heart disease or stroke risk associated with a given combination of risk factors, Kannel said. ``We need a more efficient profile to pick out the ones who are truly in jeopardy,'' Kannel said at the heart association's annual meeting. He said 30 percent to 40 percent of Americans, for example, have cholesterol levels high enough to require treatment. Many of those might not have substantially increased heart-disease risks, however, Kannel said. A patient with mildly high cholesterol and no other risk factors may have only one-tenth the increased risk of a patient with the same cholesterol level who also has high blood pressure, is overweight and smokes, Kannel said. ``The problem everybody hasn't fully appreciated is that the risk varies over a 10-fold range'' for each single risk factor, depending upon what other risk factors are found in combination with it, he said. The major controllable risk factors for heart disease are cigarette smoking, high blood pressure and high cholesterol, the heart association says. Other risk factors can't be changed. Increasing age raises the risk as does a family history of heart disease. And men have substantially higher risks than women. The risk factor prediction kit takes into account age, sex, cholesterol, blood pressure, smoking and the level of high-density lipoproteins, the so-called good cholesterol. It shows, for example, that a 60-year-old man whose only risk factor is an elevated cholesterol level of 240 has a 13 percent chance of having a heart attack during the next 10 years. If his blood pressure is high, that risk could jump to 18 percent or 20 percent, and if he smokes it would be even higher. The risk factor prediction kit, which is intended for use by doctors, will be followed by a similar kit intended to give patients some idea of their risks so they can decide whether to see a doctor for a better evaluation. ``Feeling well is no guarantee against a heart attack,'' Kannel said. ``One in five men have heart attacks before age 60, and one in three of them aren't going to make it out of the room,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pilot Error, Technical Failure Possible Causes of Alitalia Crash
DOC.TEXT: Pilot error and technical failure were cited Thursday as possible causes of the crash of an Alitalia DC-9 jetliner that killed all 46 people aboard when it slammed into a wooded hillside. Seven Americans were identified Thursday as being among the 40 passengers killed when Flight AZ404 from Milan crashed late Wednesday five miles outside Zurich's international airport. Six Italian crew members also died. Pope John Paul II sent a message of condolence to the victims' families. Bodies remained trapped inside the fire-gutted wreckage 24 hours after the crash. Police said identification could take weeks as most victims were burned beyond recognition. White sheets concealed human remains scattered among charred plane wreckage and scorched tree stumps on the rain-soaked ground Thursday. A notepad that survived the inferno lay open among the debris. The green, red and white Alitalia emblem was still visible through ashes covering the jetliner's tail, which was lying upside down. Rain hampered efforts to retrieve the victims and inspect the wreckage. Eugen Thomann, a Zurich police official, said it appeared all victims were killed on impact. Zurich airport spokesman Andreas Meier said witness accounts suggested several causes for the crash. But he said radar data indicated ``the pilot misjudged his altitude.'' He said the plane was flying about 1,000 feet below the normal altitude during the landing approach. Alitalia officials told Italian television that failure of the plane's electronic navigation system was also a possibility. Meier said terrorism was being considered, but stressed there were no indications the airplane was the target of an attack. Most of the passengers on the late-evening flight linking two financial centers were probably businessmen and people on personal visits, rather than tourists, he said. Investigators found both the aircraft's flight recorders, or ``black boxes.'' One recorder tracks flight data and the other tapes cockpit conversations. Meanwhile, Italian government investigators arrived to assist in the inquiry. Witnesses in villages near the scene of the crash said something appeared wrong with the approaching aircraft. ``I ran outside because the plane was so loud,'' said one resident, who insisted on anonymity. ``Then I saw that the plane was flying unusually low and seemed to be swaying.'' Other witnesses said the pilot seemed to rev the plane's engine just before the crash. ``It sounded like a sudden roar,'' one villager said. ``But then there was a thud and it turned deathly quiet.'' There were also accounts of fire and ``apparent explosions'' before the plane went down, but officials were unable to confirm those accounts. ``I shudder every time I think how near the village the plane crashed,'' said a shocked woman in Stadel, about half a mile from the crash site. The two-engine jetliner was on schedule on its 50-minute flight from Milan. The Swiss Meteorological Office said visibility at the time of the crash was good, with light wind and light rain. Josef Meier (cq), a spokesman for Swiss air traffic control authorities, told reporters radar records showed the plane was horizontally on course but flying about 990 feet below the correct altitude. Traffic was heavy at the time and controllers did not continuously monitor the jet's height, he said, adding that this was normal procedure. Radio contact was normal until two minutes before the crash and controllers received no distress signal, officials said. They said the investigation could take months. Alitalia said the DC-9 was built in 1974 and was last inspected on Nov. 4. The flight commander Raffaele Liberta, 47, was a 20-year Alitalia veteran who had flown more than 10,000 hours. The U.S. embassy in Bern identified the American victims as Karol Forman, Paul Vaughan and William Briggs of New York state; John Stuckey and Jerry Bass of North Carolina; Robert Anderson, an American resident of Switzerland, and Stephen Ritter, for whom they had no further information.

DOC.HEAD: Challenger Wins Congressional Seat
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. Jim Bates, who was reprimanded by the House for the alleged sexual harassment of staff members, has been defeated for re-election, the county Registrar of Voters said Thursday. Republican Randy ``Duke'' Cunningham, a former Navy pilot, received 50,335 votes, or 46.3 percent, to Bates' 48,676 votes, or 44.8 percent. The results of the election had been delayed while local officials counted thousands of absentee ballots. Authorities said about 200 absentee ballots remained outstanding and would not affect the outcome. Bates, 49, the only Democratic congressman south of Los Angeles, has declined to concede defeat. He was reprimanded by the House ethics committee, stemming from complaints by two female staffers in September 1988 that he sexually harassed them. The current election was the first time he faced voters since the committee's decision. During the campaign, Bates said the reprimand was an old issue. If voters were concerned about it, he said, they would have thrown him out in the June primary.

DOC.HEAD: Thief Who Took Bibles Sentenced to Jail
DOC.TEXT: Wayne Johnson said he wanted the perfect Christmas gift for his religious friends when he took five Bibles from a store. Now he'll be spending Christmas in jail. Johnson, 34, pleaded guilty Wednesday to shoplifting for taking five $12.95 Bibles from a Waldenbooks store and has been sentenced to two years in prison. Assistant District Attorney Ricky Raven said an off-duty police officer who was working security at the store Tuesday night noticed an odd bulge in Johnson's clothes and followed him outside. Johnson, who has been in and out of the Harris County Jail on five separate misdemeanor theft cases since 1985, was arrested in front of the store. Defense attorney Ken Goode said his client wanted to present the Bibles as gifts. ``He said that's how he does his Christmas shopping: He steals,'' Goode said.

DOC.HEAD: GOP National Committee Cutting Staff 25 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The Republican National Committee is cutting its staff 25 percent, a reduction party officials say is normal for the start of a non-election year. ``We gear up in the even years and we gear down in the odd years,'' said Mary Matalin, RNC executive director. The committee has about 270 fulltime employees. B.J. Cooper, communications director for the committee, said a comparable staff reduction occurred four years ago, after the 1986 midterm elections. Matalin and Cooper denied published reports the cutbacks were forced by a disappointing fund-raising year or were ordered by White House Chief of Staff John Sununu. ``We're 100 percent supportive of their effort to shift gears,'' said Ed Rogers, White House political director. ``There was no instruction to do anything out of here; it's part of a longstanding plan. The White House was informed of it on an FYI basis the day before yesterday.'' The RNC had an operating budget for 1990 of $26 million and raised more than enough to cover it. At the Democratic National Committee, spokeswoman Ginny Terzano said no immediate cutbacks are planned. But the DNC is a much leaner operation with only 100 fulltime employees. The Democrats raised just over $10 million in 1990, including a record $2.7 million Wednesday night at the party's annual gala.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev to Face `Moment of Truth' Before Legislature
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev will be ready for political battle when he addresses the legislature Friday and is confident his views will prevail, said an Italian leader who met the Soviet president Thursday. The official Tass news agency, in a commentary, said Gorbachev would face a ``moment of truth'' when he speaks to lawmakers on the crumbling economy and on campaigns by separatist-minded republics. Gorbachev agreed to address the legislators after lawmakers, angered by the slow pace of reform, demanded a report on the state of the union. They similarly wanted a report on Gorbachev's weekend meeting with Russian Federation President Boris N. Yeltsin. Yeltsin also will speak to the national legislature Friday, Tass said. Achille Occhetto, leader of the Italian Communist Pary, met in Moscow with Gorbachev on Thursday and said Gorbachev was candid about the country's economic and political problems. Gorbachev predicted that the next 18 months would be crucial to his political and economic reforms, Occhetto said. During that time, the country will be trying to switch from a centrally planned to a market economy. Soviet economists have predicted unemployment and inflation will worsen during the transition. Some goods have disappeared from stores and prices have risen fast, squeezing retirees and other people with fixed incomes. In many cases, food is being rationed. ``I feel Gorbachev is self-confident and ready for political battle,'' Occhetto said at a news conference. ``I feel he will be the master of the situation.'' Soviet television said Thursday that Gorbachev would speak to the legislature about the ``sharply worsening'' conditions in the country. According to Tass, legislators at the Supreme Soviet became rebellious Wednesday and refused to discuss bills ``suggested from above'' until a new treaty on relations between the Kremlin and the republics is concluded. Many of the country's 15 republics, especially Russia, are disregarding laws passed by the national legislature and decrees adopted by Gorbachev and the Council of Ministers, or Soviet Cabinet. The legislature of Russia on Thursday heard a report on the economic and political situation in the republic from government leaders, Tass said. It said the session was held behind closed doors, and no details were released. A day earlier, the Russian government said a Soviet decision to lift price controls on ``luxury goods'' would not be implemented in the republic. The Moscow City Council seconded the Russian government's action. One prominent Soviet politician said the military might have to be called in to restore order. ``If the constitution is trampled upon and some forces - separatists or other anti-socialist associations - attempt to dismember this country or change its social system by force or other anti-constitutional means, the armed forces can be used,'' Marshal Sergei Akhromeyev, a member of the national legislature and Gorbachev adviser, wrote in the daily Sovietskaya Rossiya. Moldavia's leaders also balked at freeing prices. Deputy Premier Konstantin Tampiza told the Moldavian Parliament the measure was ``not even worth discussing, let alone ratifying'' until action is coordinated with other republics, Tass said. The Central Asian republic of Kazakhstan similarly decided to defy the Kremlin. Its Parliament said the resolution freeing prices would have no effect in the republic, the independent news agency Interfax reported. ``Prices are rising, but wages stay the same,'' said deputy Lev Trybnikov. ``It's not a market, but downright robbery.'' The leaders of all Soviet republics were invited to attend Gorbachev's speech, but one republic declined the invitation. The Estonian News Agency said Arnold Ruutel, president of the Estonian republic, would not attend because ``the Soviet constitution is not valid on Estonian territory.'' Battles were also raging within the Kremlin. A national government commission ordered the Railroad Ministry to cancel plans to stop accepting rubles as payment for trips abroad. The ministry had said passengers leaving the country would have to pay in foreign currency starting. The government's foreign economic commission, part of the Council of Ministers, told the railroad minister to rescind it. Tass said the confrontations were part of the ``progressing paralysis of power.'' The news agency said Gorbachev's speech was expected to include specific proposals to reverse the deteriorating situation in the country. ``Will Gorbachev justify the expectations?'' Tass asked. ``The most radical-minded critics express doubt on that score, pointing out that Gorbachev - a master at subtle multi-option moves - lacks resoluteness when hard decisions need to be made.'' But, the news agency said, Gorbachev supporters in the Supreme Soviet blame his heavy workload for delays in reaching accord with the restive republics. ``He tries to reduce to the minimum even major visits abroad and makes them mainly over weekends, leaving weekdays for tackling domestic problems,'' Tass said. Such visits are essential, it said, because ``Gorbachev remains the Soviet Union's only politician with whom Western leaders agree to do business.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Begins Ethics Hearings into Keating Five
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts graf 5, Bennett said, with further from Bennett statement. This should stand for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Ethics Committee today opened politically-charged hearings into links between five senators and the owner of a failed savings and loan and the panel's chairman bluntly told the lawmakers that many people believe ``you sold your office.'' Four of the so-called Keating Five looked on as Sen. Howell Heflin said, ``many of our fellow citizens apparently believe that your services were bought by Charles Keating, that you were bribed, that you sold your office, that you traded your honor and your good names for contributions and other benefits.'' Sens. John McCain, a Republican from Arizona, and Democrats John Glenn of Ohio, Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan and Dennis DeConcini of Arizona each listened intently as Heflin spoke in his gravely Southern accent. Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., who is undergoing prostate cancer treatment, did not attend. All five deny any wrongdoing. Committee counsel Robert Bennett jostled a boxed puzzle before the committee members as he began his opening statement, saying he would provide them with a picture that later pieces of evidence would fill in. Bennett said Cranston, DeConcini and Riegle ``were important players'' in helping Keating in his ``all-out war'' with federal regulators. He said McCain and Glenn played lesser roles. Bennett said he did not contend it was improper for the senators to hold meetings with federal regulators, but that it was up to the panel to decide whether their actions were improper. He said ``there can be no doubt'' that the intent of each of the five senators was to help Keating when they met with federal regulators in 1987. The five senators received a total of $1.3 million in campaign contributions or donations to their favored causes from Keating and his associates. All contacted federal regulators on behalf of Keating at a time when the government was considering whether to seize the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, an Irvine, Calif.-based thrift institution. The thrift later collapsed at an estimated cost to the taxpayers of $2 billion. Heflin told the five they would have the chance to say whether the donations ``influenced your actions in any way.'' He said lawmakers' activities legitimately include helping their constituents and overseeing government institutions and added that there is room for disagreement about conclusions in the case. Bennett said the evidence will be clear despite the refusal of Keating to answer questions during the Senate inquiry. Keating has been indicted in California on state securities fraud charges and is awaiting trial. ``One could ask the question, `If Mr. Keating were here, would you believe what he had to say anyway?''' Bennett said. The five senators have become a symbol of the massive savings industry collapse, and the outcome of the ethics hearings could intensify the political ramifications of what so far has been a bipartisan scandal. In addition, the case has highlighted a political system that gives lawmakers great latitude in contacting federal regulators on behalf of constituents, at the same time they are dependent on campaign contributions to mount their political campaigns. The hearings stemmed from a complaint last year by the citizens group Common Cause. ``It's not just the five senators but the whole Senate whose integrity and credibility is on the line,'' said Fred Werthheimer, the organization's leader. Heflin and others on the panel said the case should not create a standard that bars members of Congress from intervening with federal agencies on behalf of constituents or campaign contributors. ``A standard of conduct which would preclude members of Congress from intervening on behalf of individuals who happened to have contributed to or raised funds for their campaign is nonsensical and unworkable under existing law,'' said Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H. Sen. Trent Lott, R-Miss., another member of the committee, complained that panel has taken too long with the case. ``We should have already taken certain ... actions,'' he said. Heflin, D-Ala., defended the panel's decision to hold the hearings against charges of partisanship. ``On all the votes taken by the committee ... not one was divided along partisan lines,'' he said. With documents stacked several inches high on a table covered with green felt, Heflin framed the issue that the ethics panel will have to grapple with: ``The allegation in this case, that an individual used his wealth to get preferential treatment from government officials in the performance of their official duties, raises questions which are as old as history, and issues that bear on the balance of power among the branches of the federal government. The committee could vote to rebuke any of the five or recommend a more serious punishment to the full Senate. Each senator has denied any connection between Keating's money and their meetings with regulators. The basic issue is whether any violated Senate rules against exerting improper influence in return for compensation. All except Riegle attended an April 2, 1987, meeting with Ed Gray, then the top thrift regulator. All five attended another meeting a week later with San Francisco-based bank examiners who revealed that potential criminal actions by Lincoln were involved. McCain's top aide, Chris Koch, said McCain would make the case that he ended his friendship with Keating on March 24, 1987, when Keating asked the senator to negotiate with regulators on his behalf. ``There's no smoking gun on Don Riegle,'' the Michigan senator's lawyer, Thomas Green, said before the hearing. He contended that Riegle's meeting with regulators was unrelated to a fund-raising effort Keating directed for Riegle. DeConcini wrote a letter to about 5,000 supporters this week denying wrongdoing. ``You may hear derogatory statements about me and my office, but I can assure you that I have not betrayed my public trust, nor do I intend to be intimidated from assisting constituents in their dealings with our government,'' DeConcini said. Glenn has said in the past that he had no discussions on behalf of Lincoln after the 1987 meeting when regulators said criminal charges were possible. Cranston's spokesman, Murray Flander, said Cranston contends, ``I pocketed no money, I broke no law, I violated no Senate rule. Those are undisputed facts.''

DOC.HEAD: Berlin Government Collapses Over Raid on Squatters
DOC.TEXT: The city's coalition government collapsed Thursday in a dispute over a violent police crackdown on hundreds of leftist squatters living in abandoned buildings. The environmental Greens party said it was bolting the two-party coalition led by Social Democrat Mayor Walter Momper. The Greens say they were outraged by the massive police crackdown over a three-day period that led to a series of violent clashes, resulting in more than 260 injuries and about 450 arrests since Monday. Gerd Poppe, a Greens candidate for the Bundestag, the lower house of the German parliament, said ``the unbelievable police presence'' triggered the violence. But Momper and other officials blamed the leftists, veteran radicals from former West Berlin's anarchist scene who are adept at making firebombs and staging urban guerrilla attacks. Hundreds have moved into rundown, vacant tenements in former East Berlin. Berliners will elect a new city government on Dec. 2, when elections will also be held to elect a united German government. Momper likely would govern with a minority until then. The Greens move is seen as largely a symbolic gesture of protest. City officials began evicting leftist radicals on Monday. A huge protest turned into a rock-throwing spree that resulted in 160 injuries and 20 arrests. On Wednesday, police moved into Mainzer Street, where radicals were living in 12 large tenement buildings. Police, bolstered by crack paramilitary troops from the federal border patrol, rolled in Wednesday morning with armored personnel carriers and bulldozers and evicted the radicals. The radicals responded with firebombs and rocks. About 325 people were reported arrested and more than 100 were injured. Tens of thousands of people marched through Berlin on Wednesday night to protest the raid and the lack of affordable housing in Berlin. Later, some protesters began throwing rocks and firebombs at police. Police said about 100 people were arrested. The crackdown on squatters in Berlin triggered sympathy protests in other cities Wednesday night. Police reported a rash of window smashings and other vandalism, along with graffiti expressing sympathy for the squatters, in the cities of Cologne, Wuppertal, Duesseldorf and Muenster during the night. Affordable housing has long been a problem in wealthy western Germany, where people who make lower-than-average wages often have a difficult time finding adequate housing. Germany has one of the highest standards of living in the world. Many of eastern Berlin's squatters are Westerners who have taken advantage of the general laxness of government and law enforcement in the eastern side of the city since East Germans overthrew their Communist rulers last year. Momper on Wednesday accused the conservative federal government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl of neglecting Berlin's housing problem, made worse as West Germany assumed responsibility for decayed housing in the east. Also Thursday, the government said it planned to send more police into former East Germany to curb growing violence at soccer games. The clashes, which began after unification Oct. 3, came after years of relatively peaceful league matches disturbed only by occasional rightist ``skinheads'' in the west. Earlier this month, however, police shot and killed a soccer fan during one rampage in Leipzig. Last weekend, riots erupted in two eastern German cities after league matches. Chief of Staff, Rudolf Seiters, did not say how troops would be dispatched to try to maintain order, but the disappearance of the German-German frontier has freed up hundreds of specially trained border guards for other law enforcement duties.

DOC.HEAD: Warsaw Pact to Stop Existing as Military Organization in July
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet-led Warsaw Pact will stop functioning as a military alliance next July, a Hungarian Foreign Ministry official said Thursday. ``There is now consensus to end the six-nation organization's military functions July 1,'' said the official, Istvan Koermendi. ``This includes ending the multilateral agreements on the basis of which the pact functioned.'' The pact, which began to crumble with last year's democratic changes in Eastern Europe, has lost any real role as a counterweight to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Poland's Deputy Defense Minister Janusz Onyszkiewicz said in Warsaw that the ``common position'' of Poland, Czechoslovakia and Hungary was to work toward abolition of the pact's joint military command and staff. ``At the moment, these institutions do not function,'' Onyszkiewicz said. ``They are completely frozen, and our armed forces are under absolute control of the Polish command and the Polish political authorities.'' But he said at a news conference that no date had been set to disband the alliance: ``This does not mean ... a verdict on the Warsaw Pact has been issued, that it will be dissolved within the next few months.'' Onyszkiewicz said a date could be fixed at an upcoming pact summit. Koermendi said top leaders from the pact nations would probably meet in Budapest before the end of the year, possibly in early December. Hungarian officials had earlier said in private that the pact would disband as a military alliance by next summer, describing its future role as a loose political forum. But Koermendi appeared to be the first Warsaw Pact official to publicly announce a date for the end of its military role. He first mentioned July 1 on Wednesday, to Parliament's foreign relations committee, and then again in an interview Thursday. The pact, formed in 1955 in the early years of the Cold War, menaced the West into the late 1980s. Originally comprised of the Soviet Union, Albania, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary, Poland and Romania, it was reduced to seven nations after Albania withdrew in 1968 following the pact invasion of Czechoslovakia and a long ideological feud with Moscow. The unification of the Germanys left only six member nations that often advocate positions closer to the West than Moscow. The 16-nation NATO and the Warsaw Pact formally plan to end their adversarial relationship next week, at a 34-nation summit of the Conference on European Security and Cooperation. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Wednesday the 22 countries belonging to the two alliances will sign a ``non-aggression declaration which will, in a sense, bury the Cold War hatchet.'' Another treaty to be signed in Paris reduces non-nuclear forces in Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Villagers' Vote Was for the Birds
DOC.TEXT: Residents of the village of Koliganek cast their votes last week for a bunch of turkeys - a whole plane full of them. The villagers have been declared the winners of a contest sponsored by the Bristol Bay Native Association to encourage Bristol Bay region voters to go to the polls. The winning village was to receive $500 worth of turkeys. Seventy of Koliganek's 87 registered voters, or 80.5 percent, participated in the Nov. 6 elections, said native association Director Terry Hoefferle. The village is about 70 miles north of Dillingham on the Nushagak River and 275 miles southwest of Anchorage. The native association plans to fly a plane filled with up to 80 turkeys to the village by Thanksgiving. Native leaders, at the urging of elections officials, have promised to give the turkeys to the village leaders for distribution to all, not just to those who voted. No buying votes in this village.

DOC.HEAD: Food Rationing Sweeps Soviet Union; Western Aid Possible
With AM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Leningrad's City Council voted Thursday to join the growing list of Soviet cities rationing food, while the United States and other Western nations considered sending emergency aid. Starting Dec. 1, Leningrad will ration meat, poultry, butter, flour and other staples for the first time since the Nazis blockaded it during World War II. Rationing also had been under debate in Moscow's City Council, but it decided Thursday to delay taking action. As the country's economic crisis deepens, the list of cities rationing food, and the number of goods they restrict, has been increasing rapidly. Ration coupons are now in use in many cities across Russia and the Ukraine. Meat, sugar and vodka are the mostly commonly restricted items. Eggs, butter and flour are also rationed in some areas. In Kharkov, a Ukrainian city of 1.6 million people, demonstrators blocked streets this week to protest rationing and the lack of basic foods in state stores, the government newspaper Izvestia said Thursday. No starvation, or even chronic hunger, has been reported. But as the country moves toward a market economy, goods have disappeared from state stores and prices in private farmers' markets have risen fast, squeezing retirees and other people with fixed incomes. In a public opinion poll published Wednesday in the weekly Moscow News, 62 percent of those questioned said they ``fear hunger will begin in the Soviet Union in the next few months.'' The survey was conducted in October by the All-Union Center for Study of Public Opinion, one of the nation's most respected pollsters. It queried 1,356 people in 11 regions. No margin of error was given. In Germany, Chancellor Helmut Kohl said Thursday his country was ready to send emergency supplies, if needed. He also said he would urge all Western industrial nations to prepare to help the Soviet Union and Eastern European countries, ``especially in view of the severe winter'' looming. In Washington, officials said the U.S. government was considering airlifting food and medical supplies to the Soviet Union. Leningrad Mayor Anatoly Sobchak, one of the nation's leading reformist politicians, pushed hard for his city's rationing program. Without it, he warned Monday, the city of nearly 5 million people could face hunger and civil unrest this winter. In recent weeks, Leningrad residents have had to stand in two-and three-hour lines for bread. Many other necessities - including eggs, sugar, cheese and sausage - have virtually disappeared from stores, according to Maxim Korzhov, a Leningrad journalist covering the city council session. ``People here are upset and worried about food,'' Korzhov said. ``The atmosphere is tense.'' Hunger is an intensely emotional and politically volatile subject in Leningrad because of the 1941-1944 siege, when an estimated 600,000 people died, many from starvation. Korzhov said public support for rationing increased after stores throughout the city ran out of bread on Nov. 5 and 6, when residents stocked up for the Nov. 7 holiday, the 73rd anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution. For decades, bread has been cheap, wholesome and plentiful throughout the Soviet Union, ensuring that even the poorest segments of the population - students, pensioners and the disabled - would not go hungry. This year, bread has periodically become scarce in many cities, including Moscow. The Soviet Union's food problem stems not only from inadequate harvests, but also from inefficient transportation, packaging and distribution. By some estimates, 15 percent to 20 percent of many crops is lost to spillage, spoilage and theft. Food supplies to big cities, particularly in the north, also have been disrupted this year by the country's political fragmentation. Some of the most fertile republics, including Armenia, Georgia and the Baltic states, have stopped shipping meat, dairy products, citrus or other items outside their borders. The Leningrad Soviet, or city council, voted 296 to 10 with 68 abstentions to allot each resident a monthly ration of 2.6 pounds of meat, 1.1 pounds of poultry, and 2.2 pounds of sausage. In addition, each person will be allocated 10 eggs, 1.1 pounds of butter, 2.2 pounds of dry cereal or pasta, 1.1 pounds of flour and 11 ounces of vegetable oil. Leningrad, the nation's second-largest city, already issues coupons for 4.4 pounds of sugar, two bottles of vodka and two bottles of wine per person. Those rations will remain in effect. Residents will be able to buy their allotments at state subsidized prices, which are quite low: $4.5 to $6.50 for every 2.2 pounds of meat, $2 for 10 eggs, $6.50 for 2.2 pounds of butter. If Leningrad residents want more than their rationed amounts, they will have to pay market prices, which are often 10 times higher. The city council voted to remove price restrictions on food sold in state stores without ration coupons.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Keating-Senators, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is background information about the Senate Ethics Committee's hearings on the ``Keating Five'' senators. The five intervened with federal banking regulators on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr., former head of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan. They also received $1.3 million in political donations for their campaigns and causes from Keating and his associates. The five are: Republican John McCain of Arizona and Democrats Alan Cranston of California, Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona and John Glenn of Ohio. All have denied that the contributions influenced their intervention, and say their discussions with federal regulators on Keating's behalf amounted to routine help for a constituent. Keating and three top executives of his companies have been indicted in California on state securities fraud charges. All four are out on bail pending trial. All the senators except Riegle met on April 2, 1987, with Edwin J. Gray, the top thrift regulator at the time. Gray said DeConcini offered a deal on behalf of Keating that the other senators supported. The senators vehemently denied that the offer was made. A week later, all five senators met with San Francisco-based regulators who told the lawmakers that criminal referrals in the case would be made to the Justice Department. Here are key details about the conduct of each senator:
DOC.HEAD: John Glenn
DOC.TEXT: The three-term senator attended both the April 2 and April 9 meetings, but said he had no further contacts with regulators after April 9, 1987. He told regulators at the April 9 hearing, according to a transcript, ``To be blunt, you should charge them or get off their backs.'' Keating and associates raised $34,000 in campaign contributions for Glenn and contributed another $200,000 to a political action committee supporting the senator's views. Glenn is up for re-election in 1992.
DOC.HEAD: Alan Cranston
DOC.TEXT: Cranston has announced he will not run for a fifth term in 1992 because of prostate cancer, and did not seek re-election as majority whip this week. Cranston received $850,000 for three voter registration projects he supported and $39,000 in campaign contributions from Keating and his associates. Cranston continued to intervene with banking officials up until the time Lincoln was seized by the government in April 1989. He said the continuing contacts were made to encourage regulators to approve a sale of Lincoln rather than take control of the thrift. In October 1987, Cranston wrote a memo to Keating that mentioned both the donations and the senator's intervention for the thrift owner.
DOC.HEAD: Dennis DeConcini
DOC.TEXT: Documents show the three-term Democrat, facing re-election in 1994, assisted Keating in his bid to have Gray removed from the examination of Lincoln. DeConcini maintained his contacts with the regulators until the takeover, pushing for a sale of Lincoln rather than a takeover. Shortly after the federal government filed a fraud and racketeering suit in September 1989 against Keating and American Continental Corp., Lincoln's parent company, DeConcini said he was returning the $48,100 he received in contributions from Keating and associates. He said there was a ``serious possibility that money from Lincoln Savings may have been illegally funneled into a number of political campaigns.''
DOC.HEAD: John McCain
DOC.TEXT: The only Republican among the five, the second Arizona senator in the case says he and Keating became close friends after becoming acquainted in 1981. McCain said he ended his relationship with Keating in March 1987, shortly before the two meetings with regulators. McCain said the break occurred after he refused to negotiate with regulators on Keating's behalf. The senator received $112,000 in campaign contributions from Keating and associates, and said he would return the money if it was found to have been diverted from Lincoln. From 1984 through 1986, McCain flew on Keating's airplanes for vacation trips to the Bahamas. In May and June 1989, the senator paid back $13,433 for the cost of the flights. Also, McCain's wife and father-in-law invested in a shopping center that was managed by subsidiaries of Keating's company. McCain said he was not involved in the investment. Now serving his first Senate term, McCain faces re-election in 1992.
DOC.HEAD: Donald W. Riegle Jr.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Banking Committee chairman acknowledged suggesting to Gray that he meet with senators unhappy over Lincoln's treatment by regulators. But he denied setting up the April 2 meeting, which he did not attend, or the April 9 meeting. Documents revealed that in the two months before Riegle's April 1987 meeting with regulators, there was an extensive fund-raising operation for the senator led by Keating, with assistance from DeConcini. Riegle, who raised $78,250 from Keating and associates, said he returned the money after learning the contributions had come from individuals with a direct business affiliation with American Continental, Keating's main company. Riegle has served in the Senate since 1976 and faces re-election in 1994.

DOC.HEAD: Alydar, Runnerup in Memorable Triple Crown Races, Destroyed
DOC.TEXT: Alydar the horse that ran second to Affirmed in memorable 1978 Triple Crown races and became an influential sire, was destroyed Thursday at Calumet Farms after breaking his injured right leg. The 15-year-old Alydar, who sired such champions as Alysheba, Easy Goer and Turkoman, kicked his stall door late Tuesday and underwent surgery Wednesday. Dr. Larry Bramlage, who helped operate on the chestnut stallion, said Thursday: ``It was either maintain him in a tranquilized state ... or wean him out of the sling. Fifteen minutes after it was off, he slipped and fell, breaking his right femur.'' The second injury was to the same leg. The horse was buried at the farm, where he had stood at stud since 1979. Alydar and Affirmed began their epic duel in their 2-year-old season and the rivalry culminated in the Kentucky Derby, Preakness and Belmont Stakes. Affirmed won all three races by a total of less than three lengths. Alydar had quite a few notable victories, including the Florida Derby, Blue Grass Stakes and Arlington Stakes.

DOC.HEAD: NATO And Warsaw pact Negotiators Agree on Non-Nuclear Arms Treaty
With AM-Arms Control, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: NATO and Warsaw Pact negotiators reached agreement Thursday on a treaty cutting non-nuclear weapons in Europe, ending decades of Cold War discord between the military alliances. Senior diplomats said negotiators from the 22 nations comprising both alliances, had agreed on a final text for the most sweeping weapons accord in history and had sent the treaty to their capitals for approval. Last-minute objections from home were not expected. The 70-page, English text was to be translated into the five other official languages for initialing Sunday by delegation heads, the officials said. The texts were to be formally signed a day later by heads of states gathered in Paris for the 34-nation Conference on Security and European cooperation. The Monday deadline had put the Vienna negotiators under the gun. ``We actually had consensus on the big issues since the beginning of October,'' said Hungary's chief negotiator, Ambassador Istvan Gyarmati. ``But some relatively minor details needed ironing out.'' The treaty covers an area from the Atlantic Ocean to the Ural mountains in the Soviet Union. It sets ceilings on non-nuclear weapons systems, regulates troop movements, and permits mutual inspections to verify that the terms of the treaty are not being contravened. Negotiators originally had also sought agreement on troop reductions, but participants agreed to suspend that track so the treaty could be ready for signing at the Paris summit. Delegates were to reconvene in Vienna Nov. 29 to discuss cuts in personnel. But a formal pledge in September by Germany to maintain no more than 375,000 troops after unification on Oct. 3 eased fears of the Soviet Union, which lost millions of people during World War II. Delegates in Vienna said the issue of troop cuts had become relatively unimportant. ``The importance of numbers of soldiers declines if they don't have a gun to fire,'' said a negotiator with one nation in the 16-member North Atlantic Treaty Organization. He spoke on condition of anonymity. The treaty limits each side to 20,000 main battle tanks; 30,000 armored combat vehicles; 20,000 pieces of artillery; 6,800 combat aircraft and 2,000 attack helicopters. Those ceiling were agreed on earlier, and a negotiator from a Warsaw Pact country said last-minute differences were relatively arcane. ``There were things like a clearer definition of the southern Leningrad (military) district,'' another delegate said on condition of anonymity. The negotiations, formally known as the Conventional Force Europe talks began March 9, 1989, after NATO and the Warsaw Pact decided to scrap earier negotiations aimed at cutting conventional troops and arms in Central Europe. Those talks were a victim of the Cold War; little substantive progress was reached in 17 years of wrangling over a wide range of issues, including existing troop strengths and means of verification. NATO figures published two months before the new talks began listed the following figures for the two military alliances. Main battle tanks: Warsaw Pact, 51,500; NATO, 16,424. Armored combat vehicles: Warsaw Pact, 22,400; NATO, 4,153. Artillery: Warsaw Pact, 43,400; NATO, 14,458. Helicopters: Warsaw Pact, 3,700; NATO, 2,419. Combat Aircraft: Warsaw Pact, 8,250; NATO, 3,977. But at the new talks the two sides decided to concentrate on target strengths and ignore how many soldiers and weapons each side had in an effort to avoid past deadlocks. Soviet political and economic reforms, which fed warming superpower relations in the past year, gave the current talks even more impetus and led to the swift progress that had eluded previous attempts to limit weapons. The end of Communist rule in Moscow's former European satellites this year also hastened the Vienna negotiations, with former Soviet vassal states acting with increasing independence. Hungarian officials said Thursday that the Warsaw Pact - reduced to six members with the unification of Germany - would cease its military activities by July.

DOC.HEAD: One Missing, One Injured in Explosion at Ammonia Plant
DOC.TEXT: A chemical plant explosion seriously injured one worker Thursday and may have blown another into the Missouri River, authorities said. The blast at Nutra-Flo Chemical Co. occurred as two workers welded atop a silo-like storage tank, fire officials said. The tank was about a third full of anhydrous ammonia, a toxic fertilizer. ``We believe the ignition source was a torch used on the top to weld a ladder,'' said Fire Chief Bob Hamilton. One man fell from the tank and was hospitalized in serious condition. The other welder was missing. Welding rods that officials believe had been used by the missing worker were found along the river about 100 feet away. Rescuers searched the river for the worker.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs Clean Air Law
With AM-Clean Air-Glance
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, saying every American ``deserves to breathe clean air,'' on Thursday signed an extensive overhaul of the nation's anti-pollution law to curb acid rain, urban smog and toxic chemicals. Susan Merrow, president of the Sierra Club, described the Clean Air Act of 1990 as ``a breath of fresh air after a 10-year smog alert.'' Bush said the bill, which updates and tightens federal air pollution standards for the first time since 1977, was ``simply the most significant air pollution legislation in our nation's history.'' ``This bill means cleaner cars, cleaner power plants, cleaner factories, and cleaner fuels. And it means a cleaner America,'' Bush said at a packed White House ceremony. The goal of the legislation is to cut acid rain pollutants by half, sharply reduce urban smog and eliminate most of the toxic chemical emissions from industrial plants by the turn of the century. The cost of adhering to the regulations is expected to be as much as $25 billion a year. Environmental groups temporarily put aside their differences with the president on other issues to praise his effort on clean air. But they said the effectiveness of the legislation would require aggressive implementation and enforcement by the federal government. Richard Ayers, chairman of the National Clean Air Coalition, called the legislation ``cause for celebration and hope.'' But Ruth Caplan, executive director of Environmental Action, said Bush's signature marked ``only the first step toward cleaning up our air. There are dozens of provisions that must be implemented through regulation.'' Industry representatives, facing large compliance costs, were more muted in their approval. ``While business supports the act's clean air objectives, its costs to American consumers and workers cannot be sugarcoated,'' said William D. Fay, administrator of the Clean Air Working Group, a coalition of 2,000 businesses and trade associations. Bush's signature capped a decade-long debate over anti-pollution rules. The legislation was the product of 16 months of intensive wrangling among administration and congressional negotiators over myriad technical provisions. The new law requires tougher emission controls on cars, and requires service stations to sell cleaner-burning gas. It mandates new equipment in thousands of businesses and factories to capture smog-causing pollutants and toxic chemicals. It also requires coal-burning power plants to cut in half sulfur dioxide emissions, which cause acid rain. Some of the new requirements will begin to be phased in within a few years, but most won't be fully in place until the end of the decade. Some cities with the worst smog problems have as long as 15 to 20 years to meet federal air requirements. Bush, fulfilling a campaign promise, proposed in July 1989 a broad rewrite of the clean air laws. Earlier efforts to revamp the laws had been blocked by strong opposition from economic and regional interests and the Reagan administration. ``No American should have to drive out of town to breathe clean air,'' Bush said. ``Every city in America should have clean air. With this legislation I firmly believe we will. Every American expects and deserves to breathe clean air.'' But while some environmentalists praised the president for the clean air legislation, others were harshly critical of his opposition to designating Antarctica a wilderness preserve. Such action would bar mineral and oil explorations. The Alliance for Antarctica urged the United States to change its position as a multination conference began in Antarctica.

DOC.HEAD: Diabetes Increases as Nation's Population Ages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release 5 p.m. EST, time set by source
DOC.HEAD: With AM-CDC-Diabetes List
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The number of people with diabetes rose 17 percent in the United States during 1980-87, an increase federal health researchers attributed Thursday to the aging of America. The largest increase was among white males, though diabetes remains most prevalent among black females, the Centers for Disease Control said in its weekly report. In a related report by the CDC, a study of diabetes in 1988-89 found that it was most prevalent in Eastern states, with the highest rate in the District of Columbia. Diabetes was least prevalent in Montana. The 38-state study of prevalence by race and sex found that during the seven-year period the number of white males with diabetes mellitus, the most common form of the condition, increased 33 percent - from 2.1 million to 2.8 million. The increase among black females was 24 percent and black males 16 percent; white females remained unchanged. Minorities continue to be more susceptible to diabetes, the CDC said. In 1987, for example, the prevalence among black females was more than twice that among white females - 50.9 cases per 1,000 black females compared with 23.4 per 1,000 white females. Prevalence among black males was about one-third higher than for white males, the CDC said. For the nation as a whole, the CDC said, diabetes increased from 5.8 million people in 1980 to 6.8 million people in 1987. The CDC's estimates were based on self-reported cases, which health officials believe is about half the total cases. The report was based on a household survey of 120,000 U.S. residents who were asked if anyone in the family had diabetes during the previous 12 months. ``Most of it (the increase) is explained by the aging of the U.S.,'' said David Olson, a statistician with the Atlanta-based CDC's Center for Chronic Disease Prevention and Health Promotion, which prepared the report. ``Now there's a higher proportion of people with greater age,'' Olson said. ``With increased age there is a higher frequency of diabetes.'' Olson said health officials are not sure why diabetes occurs more among minority groups, though some believe it is because blacks, Hispanics and Indians tend to have less access to preventive medicine. Dr. Jeff Newman, an epidemiologist at the CDC's chronic disease branch, said the higher incidence of diabetes among minorities probably explained the regional differences in the state-by-state study. ``The states that have large proportions of these groups do have a higher prevalence,'' he said. Newman said the state study was primarily for help in planning local prevention programs, and he cautioned against drawing any conclusions about anything in the states themselves that might be increasing the risk of diabetes. The District of Columbia showed the highest prevalence, with 8.7 cases per 100 people. Other states with more than six cases per 100 included Michigan, with 7.1; Hawaii, 6.4; Alabama, 6.2; South Carolina, 6.1; and West Virginia, 6.1. Montana had the lowest prevalence, with 2.8 cases per 100 people. Other states with fewer than four per 100 included Minnesota, with 3.2; Maryland, 36; Oklahoma, 3.6; South Dakota, 3.8; Utah, 3.8; Arizona, 3.9, and Nebraska, 3.9. The CDC said that in 1987, costs associated with medical care and lost productivity due to diabetes amounted to $20.4 billion. ``Based on the increase in the number of people with (diabetes mellitus), the substantial economic and health care burden ... is expected to increase,'' the CDC report said.

DOC.HEAD: US Concerned About Shift Of Soviet Tanks To Siberia
DOC.TEXT: As the most sweeping arms reduction treaty in history awaited President Bush's signature, U.S. officials on Thursday registered concern about the transfer of thousands of Soviet tanks to Siberia from Eastern Europe. The officials stressed that the tanks and other equipment shifted east of the Ural Mountains could not be excluded from the cutbacks required by the Conventional Forces in Europe treaty. But they said the Soviets had given assurances that some of the weapons were destroyed and most of the rest would be put to the torch. The treaty is to be signed on Monday in Paris by Bush, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the leaders of 20 other NATO and Warsaw Pact countries. It is the most ambitious arms control accord in history and was aimed at reducing Cold War tensions between East and West. Even before the treaty's conclusion the Soviets under Gorbachev undertook major reductions in Eastern and Central Europe. The treaty makes many of these cutbacks legally binding. With the signing deadline only four days away, U.S. officials said some details still had to be ironed out. They mostly concern procedures to verify that the reductions in tanks, anti-aircraft artillery, armored personnel carriers, aircraft and helicopters are carried out. Diplomats in Vienna said, however, that negotiators for the two military alliances had reached tentative agreement on treaty terms. The treaty will allow NATO and the Warsaw Pact each to keep 20,000 battle tanks, 30,000 armored combat vehicles, 20,000 pieces of artillery, 6,800 combat aircraft and 2,000 attack helicopters. The cutbacks are far deeper on the Warsaw Pact side, and in that sense represents a triumph for the Bush administration. But the transfer of Soviet tanks and other arms east of the Ural Mountains - beyond the 2.5 million square miles covered by the treaty - drew attention here even though the main U.S. goals had been accomplished. ``This is not a new issue,'' a senior U.S. official told reporters at the White House. ``We have made it clear to the Soviet Union from the beginning that since the treaty deals only with Europe, we wanted to ensure there would be no buildup in the Soviet Union east of the Urals that would circumvent the treaty.'' At the same time, the official said, the Bush administration had put pressure on the Soviets to withdraw their forces from Eastern Europe. As a result, tanks and other weapons were pulled back to Siberia.
