That positions them beyond the area where East-West tensions were high and where the United States wanted Soviet weapons held to a minimum. On Sunday, the day before the treaty signing, the two alliances will exchange information about the size of their non-nuclear arsenals assigned to Europe. Then, over 40 months, they will be obliged to destroy all weapons above the ceilings set by the treaty. The restriction applies to material assigned to the European arsenal that may have been moved elsewhere, including the tanks in Siberia and tanks and other non-nuclear weapons the United States has sent to the Persian Gulf in a military buildup designed to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. ``Obviously, we are concerned about movements to the East of the Urals,'' said the senior official, whose identity was shielded under White House briefing rules. ``The Soviet Union has assured us that some of the equipment has already been destroyed and that much of the rest will be destroyed.'' The treaty will establish inspection procedures and other ways of monitoring the cutbacks are carried out. The official acknowledged that Soviet territory east of the Ural Mountains would not be covered. But he said the United States had other detection means of making sure the Soviets do not store tanks and other arms in excess of treaty ceilings.

DOC.HEAD: Son Of Interior Secretary Charged With Rape, Held Without Bail
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with comments from defense lawyer. EDITS throughout to tighten
DOC.TEXT: The son of Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. was ordered held without bail Thursday on a charge of raping a woman whose apartment he was accused of entering while armed with a shotgun. Prosecutor Randy Sengel argued during a brief court hearing that Robert Jeffrey Lujan, 28, posed a danger to society and should not be allowed to remain free on bond. Sengel also said Lujan, known as Jeff, had been convicted in 1983 on a federal charge of cocaine possession. Alexandria Judge Daniel O'Flaherty revoked the $2,000 bond on which Lujan had been released several hours after his arrest Wednesday night. The judge scheduled a preliminary hearing for Friday. Lujan, who did not enter a plea, is charged with raping a 48-year-old woman who lives in the same high-rise apartment building where he resides with his parents, police said. The woman told police she was awakened about 4:30 a.m. Sunday by a man carrying a shotgun, authorities said. There was no sign of forced entry into the woman's apartment, according to the police report. Defense lawyer Robert Stanley Powell said Jeff Lujan was invited to the woman's apartment for a drink on Saturday night and the two had sex. ``They had both been drinking. They met up in the elevator and she invited him in for a drink,'' Powell said. ``The only issue here is one of consent.'' Interior Department spokesman Steve Goldstein said Lujan was with his parents at their apartment when he was arrested at 8 p.m. Wednesday. The younger Lujan, a house painter, had recently moved back into his parents' apartment in this Washington suburb, Goldstein said. Lujan kept to his normal schedule Thursday. Goldstein said the secretary didn't go to the jail Wednesday night or to Thursday's hearing because he didn't want to be seen as trying to influence the outcome of the case. ``It is difficult for the Lujans,'' Goldstein said. ``Any other parents would have the opportunity to plead for their child. The secretary recognizes that he is not any other parent.'' The Lujans ``love their son and they are going to stand by him,'' Goldstein said. Jeff Lujan, one of the secretary's four children, was sentenced in 1983 to an unspecified term as a youthful offender for possession of cocaine and use of a telephone in a drug transaction in New Mexico. At the time, his father was a Republican congressman from the state. He served was imprisoned for several months at a federal facility in Englewood, Colo., Goldstein said. He originally had been charged with two counts each of cocaine possession and trafficking, but pleaded guilty to the two possession charges under a deal with federal prosecutors. His lawyer said Jeff Lujan also was convicted in 1987 of driving while intoxicated and driving with a suspended license and served a one-year prison term. At the time of the 1983 sentencing, Lujan said his son was being treated for ``a big alcohol problem'' that came to light when he was arrested on the drug charges.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon to Sell Tank Ammunition, Equipment to Egypt
DOC.TEXT: The Defense Department said Thursday it notified Congress of a $281 million sale of tank ammunition to Egypt. Up to 136,000 rounds of 120mm ammunition will be used by Egypt for the new M-1A1 main battle tanks it is building with the United States. Some ammunition components also will be jointly produced in Egypt, the Pentagon said. The Pentagon also said it was selling to Egypt 40 U.S.-made M-88A1 Recovery Vehicles, whic are tracked armored vehicles used to haul disabled tanks from the battlefield. The deal is worth $70 million.

DOC.HEAD: Mubarak, Assad Reject Summit, Blame Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Presidents Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and Hafez Assad of Syria on Thursday effectively killed efforts to bring Arab leaders together in an emergency summit aimed at averting war in the Persian Gulf. The two leaders said they rejected King Hassan of Morocco's call for a summit because Iraq insisted on holding onto Kuwait. On Wednesday, Saudi Arabia said it would not participate unless Baghdad promised beforehand that it would leave Kuwait. Hassan proposed the summit Sunday as a possible ``last chance'' for peace. Mubarak, returning Thursday from a visit to Libya and Syria, stressed that ``no one wants war,'' and he said he would continue to make every effort to find a peaceful solution to the crisis rather than ``open the doors of hell.'' The Egyptian leader also said he had asked President Bush to wait for three months before turning to military action to force Iraq out of Kuwait. He did not say when he made the request. In Damascus, a statement released by Assad's office said the two presidents ``expressed their regret for Iraq's rejection of any political settlement that aims at restoring the situation in Kuwait to what it was prior to Aug. 2.'' Both Egypt and Syria have contributed to Arab forces among the U.S.-led multinational force confronting Iraq, which numbers about 300,000. Assad and Mubarak's statement effectively killed any chance of the summit taking place, despite the fact the fact that a few Arab League members, including Sudan and the Palestine Liberation Organization, had agreed to Morocco's proposal. Kuwait's government-in-exile also rejected the idea Thursday. Egypt's Middle East News Agency said Mubarak told editors traveling with him that he would ``undertake every possible effort'' to find a peaceful solution to the crisis. Hassan's proposal had raised interest in Moscow, and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev sent envoys to the region to sound out leaders on the idea. But Mubarak's chief political aide, Osama el-Baz, said after a meeting Thursday in Cairo with Soviet envoy Alexander Bologonov that the possibility of a peaceful solution is ``getting smaller every day.'' Iraq itself has said it would attend a summit on condition that earlier Arab League calls for its withdrawal from Kuwait be scrapped. Twelve Arab League members, including Egypt and the gulf states, voted at a summit in August to condemn the invasion of Kuwait and approve the dispatch of foreign forces to defend Saudi Arabia. Iraq, Libya and the PLO voted against the resolution. Jordan, Sudan and Mauritania had reservations, and Algeria and Yemen abstained. Tunis was not present.

DOC.HEAD: Again Americans Try to Butt Out During Great American Smokeout
DOC.TEXT: A classical music radio station asked its listeners to ``bust your butt for Bernstein,'' in honor of the late conductor, a heavy smoker who died last month, and folks with smokes nationwide tried to stop their tokes Thursday. As part of the 14th annual Great American Smokeout, the first 50 listeners to call New York City station WNCN-FM and pledge to quit for the day received a compact disc of ``Leonard Bernstein's Greatest Hits.'' Anti-smoking advocates maintain that the effort to get people to kick the habit for a day has seen such romantic images as the Marlboro man and teen-age rebels fall into history's ashtray. ``It's a day of celebration,'' Surgeon General Antonia Novello said in Washington. ``Because it's a time when smokers can realize that the road to good health begins with one smoke-free day, and then one more, and one more ...'' It also was a day for rallies and other events from coast to coast. The American Cancer Society again estimated that 18 million smokers - more than one-third of the smoking population - would attempt to quit at least for the day. Of that number last year, 5 million made it through the day and 3 million managed not to smoke for four days or more, Ms. Novello said. The surgeon general has called for a smokeless society by the year 2000. And in recent years numerous cities and counties have enacted restrictive smoking laws. Taboo, too, is smoking on domestic airline flights. ``You're more socially acceptable if you're a heroin addict,'' complained Patty Prickett, a California environmentalist who's tried to quit smoking six times but still consumes two packs a day. Anti-smoking advocates and smokers' rights activists staged separate rallies about an hour apart Thursday on opposite sides of the Ohio Statehouse in Columbus. Neither session drew large crowds. Anti-smoking groups objected to the Philip Morris Co.'s sponsorship of a national tour of the Bill of Rights, which is going on display Monday in Boston. ``Here you have Philip Morris, which is literally a drug-pushing organization, profiting from drug addiction, wrapping itself in the Bill of Rights,'' Ed Sweda, head of the Boston-based Group Against Smoking Pollution, said in testimony before a Massachusetts legislative committee. Philip Morris is running an extensive advertising campaign and transporting an original copy of the Bill of Rights to all 50 states to highlight the 200th anniversary of the document's ratification. Female doctors wearing lab coats and stethoscopes and health advocates in tennis whites planned to picket Thursday night at Madison Square Garden to protest Virginia Slims' sponsorship of the women's tennis tournament there. In North Carolina, the nation's largest producer of flue-cured tobacco, the Great American Smokeout constitutes the Great American Fizzle year after year. ``It's always been our position that the American Cancer Society should be spending its money on cancer research and cancer treatments rather than public relations stunts,'' said Maura Payne, a spokeswoman with R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. in Winston-Salem. ``I think a lot of other states approach tobacco differently than we do,'' said Lisa Poovey, a spokeswoman for the North Carolina chapter of the American Cancer Society in Raleigh. ``I hear of some of the things the happen in other states, particularly with anti-smoking groups, and think, `Gee, we'd get mobbed if we did that here.' ``It's been our practice in North Carolina to approach smoking as a pro-health issue and not an anti-smoking issue.'' One Raleigh radio station gave out ``cold turkeys'' as a way of promoting the smokeout. And in Charlotte, a smokeout supporter dressed as an old-fashioned cigarette girl was taking cigarettes rather than dispensing them. Smokers who handed over their cigarettes got a balloon, gum or some other item in exchange. For some die-hards, however, all the hoopla was a drag. George Follman, vice president of a hang glider and windsurfing company in Newport Beach, Calif., has smoked for 20 years. He's even smoked while hang gliding. He quit a decade ago, but returned to it after a 1981 accident while riding an ultralight airplane. He crashed in a rice paddy but was unhurt. The first thing he did when rescuers came: Borrow a cigarette. His plans for the Great American Smokeout? ``I intend to smoke my brains out,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Announces Germany Will Send Emergency Supplies to Soviets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with U.S. officials disclosing aid plans for Soviet Union, Britain announcing new aid, ADDS background on European Community concern, minor editing. Pickup graf 13 pvs, `I will...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl said Thursday that Germany will send emergency supplies to the Soviet Union in case of a food crisis this winter. In Washington, U.S. officials said the Bush administration is also developing contingency plans to provide emergency food and medicine to the Soviet Union to tide it through the winter. The announcements came on the same day that Leningrad's City Council voted to begin widescale food rationing on Dec. 1 - for the first time since the Nazi siege in World War II. Kohl spoke during a special session of Parliament in which he summarized his talks last weekend with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The opposition convened the session to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis. The chancellor told legislators that during talks with Gorbachev on Friday he promised that Germany would assist the Soviet Union financially ``to the best of our powers.'' The talks followed the signing of a far-reaching cooperation and non-aggression treaty between the two countries. Specifically, he said, Germany would send emergency shipments of food to the Soviet Union ``in case of acute supply crises.'' Concern has grown that the Soviet Union could face serious shortages of food and other essentials this winter, causing extreme hardship and possibly provoking civil unrest. European Commission President Jacques Delors earlier this week said the fear of famine in the Soviet Union is one of the European Community's biggest concerns. A European source said it will be one of the main topics at an EC summit in Rome on Dec. 13-14. In Oxford, England, Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd announced Thursday that Britain will provide $39 million worth of expertise to the Soviet Union over the next two years. He said help would be given in the areas of food distribution and agriculture, energy, small business formation, and financial services. The Foreign Office also said a similar fund for Eastern Europe will be doubled to $58.5 million in fiscal 1991-2. U.S. officials said they are considering using U.S. emergency disaster programs to help the Soviets, airlifting food and medicine, and dispatching technicians to help solve transportation problems. There is no decision yet to go ahead, the officials stressed. President Bush is expected to discuss the situation with Gorbachev next week during a 34-nation summit meeting in Paris. The U.S. officials said their plans for emergency aid were prompted in large measure by fear that internal strife may escalate in the Soviet Union. ``It's a tense moment, and it's anyone's guess whether there is going to be some out-and-out confrontation,'' one official said on condition of anonymity. Kohl also said Germany would send a group of high-ranking experts to advise the Soviets during the transition from a centrally planned socialist economy to a free-market system. He noted that Germany has already pledged $19.5 billion in assistance to the Soviet Union. Kohl added that Eastern Europe cold also face severe shortages this winter, and urged wealthy industrial states to be ready to help out. He said he would raise the subject of aid during a meeting Sunday with Bush in Oggersheim, in southwest Germany. ``I will discuss with President Bush how the Western industrial lands can effectively and jointly support the reform processes (in Eastern Europe), especially in view of the severe winter,'' he said. Kohl also appealed to residents of what used to be East Germany to be patient with the large number of Soviet troops still deployed there. Under an agreement last summer that cleared the way for German unification, the troops are to stay until 1994. ``We want the Soviet soldiers and their families to feel good during their remaining time here,'' Kohl said. Intolerance has been growing toward the Red Army troops amid reports of rising crime and desertion among the Soviet soldiers. During the debate on the gulf crisis, members of the governing coalition urged greater support for the U.S. position on ending the conflict. ``Has one so quickly forgotten the solidarity the United States showed toward German unity?'' asked Michaela Geiger, a member of the Christian Social Union, the conservative Bavarian sister-party of Kohl's Christian Democrats. The opposition Social Democrats, led by former chancellor Willy Brandt, proposed a resolution calling for maintaining international political and economic pressure on Iraq, but disavowing any use of force. The proposal was sent to committee for study.

DOC.HEAD: Bears Can Be Saved Despite `Public Relations Problem,' Official Says
DOC.TEXT: America's dwindling grizzly bear population suffers from ``a public relations problem'' but can be saved from extinction by concerted federal and state efforts, a government bear expert said Thursday. ``Certainly we can do it,'' said Christopher Servheen, coordinator of grizzly bear recovery for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. Timber and livestock groups have been cool to the recovery program, he said, largely because ``grizzly bears have a public relations problem - they are big, they are dangerous and they are direct competitors with man.'' But Servheen, of Missoula, Mont., told reporters after a meeting designed to gather public comment on the recovery program that the criticism will not block efforts to save the bears. The grizzlies went on the endangered species list in 1975 and the government is required to fight to save them. ``There's no question that we are going to recover bears,'' he said. ``What we're interested in now is public comment on how we plan to do that.'' The grizzly bear - Ursus arctos horribilis - once roamed western North America from the Arctic Circle into northern Mexico. The U.S. population was once estimated at 50,000 to 100,000. But the number of grizzlies in the United States has shrunk drastically. Fewer than 1,000 remain. The main reason for the decline, according to federal officials, is the shooting of bears for furs, sport, predator control and fear. Another is loss of habitat to farming, grazing, human settlements and water projects. The government has no intention of placing bears in areas where they don't live now, Servheen said. Grizzlies live in Yellowstone, the Northern Continental Divide area of Montana, the Cabinet-Yaak area of Montana, the Selkirks vicinity of Idaho and Washington and the Northern Cascades area of Washington. Bears also might be living in the Bitterroot Mountains of Idaho and the San Juan Mountains of Colorado, but none has been sighted lately. One female was recently brought into the Yellowstone area where scientists are concerned about expanding the genetic pool, Servheen said, adding that the service would like to take in three more. The service plans to keep gathering public comment on its plan until February and produce a final version next spring. It will decide then whether to start full-scale recovery operations in the North Cascades and Bitterroot vicinities and whether to consider such action in the San Juan Mountains. The 151-page plan envisions differing specific goals for each of the ecosystems involved. In Yellowstone, for example, the objectives are 15 females with cubs over a six-year average with the animals spread out over 15 of the 18 ``bear management units'' and annual known bear deaths not to exceed a total of seven or two adult females. Grizzlies are one of three types of bears found on this continent. The others are the North American black bear and the polar bear. Kodiak bears, close relatives of grizzlies, are found on three islands off Alaska.

DOC.HEAD: Violence Increases in Rebel Protest Movement, Army Enters Fray
DOC.TEXT: Former Contra rebels exchanged gunfire with police and holed up in churches in several towns Thursday in a fast-rising wave of violence that has left four police officers dead and 23 people wounded. Police in Managua arrested a former Contra leader believed to be involved in directing the violent rebellion that began Oct. 31 in southeastern Nicaragua. Aristides Sanchez Herdocia, a right-wing hard-liner, was political adviser to the now-disbanded, U.S.-backed Nicaraguan resistance and a former member of its directorate. An Interior Ministry spokeswoman who demanded anonymity said police who raided Sanchez's office early Thursday found ``a great quantity of weapons and hand grenades'' and had other evidence ``involving him in the commission of grave crimes.'' The casualties occurred late Wednesday in Sebaco, 50 miles north of Managua, during a shootout between ex-Contra rebels and police. It was the most violent incident yet in a series of protests that appeared to be converging on the capital. Camouflaged army units with machine guns and rocket launchers were called in late Wednesday to rout the rebels. It was the first time the Sandinista People's Army has been deployed to try to quell the two-week protest. The demobilized rebels, their supporters and the mayors of 16 towns in the region are demanding aid and land promised to the former Contras as part of their agreement to lay down arms after a decade of war against the former Sandinista government. They are also demanding that President Violeta Chamorro, who defeated the Sandinistas in a February election, fire her Sandinista army chief and two ministers. Mrs. Chamorro and Interior Minister Carlos Hurtado maintained this week that there were ``dark forces'' manipulating the rebels for political purposes. This was a veiled reference to Mrs. Chamorro's vice president, Virgilio Godoy. Godoy, whose relations with Mrs. Chamorro have been severely strained, has denied any behind-the-scenes involvement in what he called ``a beautiful civic protest.'' The government said Wednesday it had already distributed land to most of the 20,000 Contras, who completed their demobilization in late June. Sebaco is an important junction connecting large towns in northeastern Nicaragua with the Panamerican highway, the most important north-south artery in Central America. Regional police chief Sergio Gomez said the violence in Sebaco began after about 300 rebel protesters placed boulders and trash across the Panamerican Highway late Wednesday. He said police tried for more than three hours to persuade the former rebels to clear the road. An Interior Ministry communique said the talks were conducted in the presence of representatives of Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo and the Organization of American States' regional mission. Gomez said police began throwing tear gas at the blockade when the negotiations failed. The protesters responded by throwing two hand grenades and then opened fire with combat weapons. Four police officers were killed and 16 wounded in the ensuing shootout. Seven civilians also were wounded, Gomez said. He said an undetermined number of the former rebels fled west of the town and army units were called in. The 200 soldiers gained control of the town Thursday, while additional army units chased the rebels through the brush. An army intelligence source said an estimated 500 former Contras had also gathered in the area around Waslala, a town in northern Nicaragua near the Honduran border. Also Thursday, radio stations reported that demobilized Contras were holed up in a church and the city hall building in Granada, Nicaragua's second-largest city, 30 miles southeast of Managua. Another group had taken over a church, telephone building, bank and other public offices in Nagarote, 30 miles northwest of Managua.

DOC.HEAD: Bishops' Head Tells Bush Offensive Now Could Violate Church Principles
With AM-Catholic Bishops
DOC.TEXT: The head of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops on Thursday told President Bush that a military offensive against Iraq at this point could violate the church's ``just war'' standards. In a letter delivered to the White House, Archbishop Daniel E. Pilarczyk of Cincinnati wrote: ``Because of the serious moral and human factors involved, we ask you ... to intensify the determined and creative pursuit of a peaceful solution that seeks to bring justice to the region without resort to war.'' The letter was dispatched after a closed-door discussion of issue at the annual meeting of U.S. bishops here. Citing the church's age-old criteria of ``just war'' - that its probable gains outweigh the resulting costs in lives, that civilian areas not be targeted, and that war be a last resort - Pilarczyk said: ``I fear that, in this situation, moving beyond the deployment of military forces in an effort to deter Iraqi aggression to the undertaking of offensive military action could well violate these criteria, especially the principles of proportionality and last resort.'' Repeating earlier condemnation by the annual meeting of bishops here of Iraq's aggression, hostage-taking and violation of human rights and support for peaceful pressure on Iraq, Pilarczyk wrote: ``We urge our government and our allies to continue to pursue the course of peaceful pressure and not to resort to war.'' He said that considering the ``dangers and human costs which could be the result of war in the Persian Gulf'' the nation ``needs to continue to assess and discuss the ethical dimensions of this difficult situation.''

DOC.HEAD: Scottish Man Has Nose for Spirits
DOC.TEXT: Evan Cattanach's job with a whisky maker in the Scottish Highlands is nothing to sniff at. A $1 million insurance policy his employer took out on him during a U.S. visit is proof of his value as a ``noser'' - the man who ensures quality control by sniffing batches of the liquor. Cardhu is a small distillery, but the 166-year-old company produces more than 1 million bottles of its single-malt alcohol a year. Laboratory testing can determine a liquor's content, but it is Cattanach's nose that determines whether each twice-monthly batch of Cardhu will be saved for 12-year aging. ``You can do tests. But the brain tells you it's Cardhu,'' said Cattanach, 55. ``I put a few drops on my hands. The alcohol evaporates when I rub my hands together. It leaves behind the subtle character flavor - the maltiness and earthiness.'' Worldwide, about 150 people have jobs like Cattanach's. Cardhu took out the Lloyd's of London policy on Cattanach's nose for his two-week American trip, scheduled to end next week with a tour of a Kentucky distillery. During a visit to Los Angeles, Cattanach found Cardhu's $25-a-bottle whisky served at a barbecue rib eatery. But to his dismay, he said diners were ``sloshing ice in everything.''

DOC.HEAD: Palestinians Mark Second Anniversary of Independence Declaration
With AM-City of Fear, Bjt
LaserColor JRL103
DOC.TEXT: Palestinians celebrated the second anniversary of their declaration of independence with fireworks and parades Thursday, spurning Israeli efforts to squelch festivities. Most clashes between police and demonstrators were minor. A 4-year-old Palestinian boy was killed when struck in the head by a stone, apparently thrown by Arabs, the army and Arab reports said. The army reinforced patrols and imposed curfews on all of the occupied Gaza Strip and most of the West Bank, confining more than 1 million Palestinians to their homes. The areas were closed to journalists. Israeli troops were drawn into cat-and-mouse chases with Palestinian youths who held military-style parades, unfurled outlawed Palestinian flags and distributed sweets to children in a traditional gesture. After darkness fell, the bangs of firecrackers were heard in Jerusalem and dozens of villages and refugee camps. Palestinians lighted torches and released balloons from their roofs. A half-dozen minor skirmishes were reported in Jerusalem between Palestinians and police. Several ended in showers of police tear gas and rubber bullets. Jerusalem police spokesman Aharon Elhayani said three Palestinians were caught with bullhorns in the city ress Writer= NEW YORK (AP) - Best-selling author Bret Easton Ellis blasted Simon & Schuster on Thursday for the publisher's 11th-hour decision to ax his new novel about a serial killer who mutilates women, saying it smacks of censorship. ``If all this had been brought up 11 months ago, I would not say that,'' Ellis said. ``But when it comes this late in the game and it seems that it was done just because Marvin Davis does not respond to this kind of fiction, then it is censorship.'' Ellis was referring to the head of Paramount Communications Inc., Simon & Schuster's parent company. The publishing house announced Wednesday it would not print Ellis' third novel, ``American Psycho.'' Simon & Schuster spokeswoman Barbara Reno said the company would not comment on Ellis' charges. Chairman Richard E. Snyder told The Washington Post he was not pressured by Paramount. He said he learned of the violent contents of the book only recently and said editors who bought it made ``an incorrect decision.'' ``It was I who decided we should not put our name on this book. It's a matter of taste,'' Snyder said. He said Paramount agreed with his decision. ``I think it would have been a matter of taste if this had been raised or discussed 12 months ago when the final draft was first handed in, not after jackets were printed up, the book typeset, 250 bound galleys made,'' said Ellis, whose previous novels, ``Less Than Zero'' and ``The Rules of Attraction,'' were also published by Simon & Schuster. ``American Psycho'' had a January publication date and was scheduled to be shipped to stores next month. Ellis' book, which includes graphic passages of women being dismembered and cannibalized, was criticized recently in Spy and Time magazines. ``My response to both those pieces was that they verged on the hysterical, mostly because the reviewers concentrated on 40 or less pages of a 400-page novel, concentrating on 10 percent of the book while ignoring the other 90.'' ``I think it distorted what the book is really about and in some strange way gave the impression that I was endorsing this kind of violence, which if you read the book is clearly not the case,'' said the 26-year-old author. Ellis said Simon & Schuster's action means the end of their relationship. ``It's kind of sad. I've been with them since 1984 and I'm very close friends with my editor there. But I don't think there is any chance I would ever publish another book there again.'' Ellis' publicist, Amanda Urban, said she is negotiating with several other publishers who expressed interest in the book. She would not elaborate. Urban said Ellis gets to keep his advance. A source involved with the contract, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the advance was $300,000.

DOC.HEAD: Warm Weather From Rockies To The Great Lakes
DOC.TEXT: Unseasonably warm weather expanded across the central United States on Thursday with record highs from Colorado to northern Michigan. Rain and snow were scattered over the Northwest. In more typical November weather, a storm was headed for Alaska. Heavy rain fell on parts of the Hawaiian Islands. Temperatures reached as high as the 80s in the Plains and the Midwest. A reading of 78 degrees in North Platte, Neb., tied a record on the books since 1887. Pueblo, Colo., tied a record high of 80 degrees that has stood since 1894. The 61-degree reading in Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., toppled a record set in 1918, the National Weather Service said. Other record highs were: 63, Alpena, Mich.; 75, Colorado Springs, Colo.; 69, a tie, Dubuque, Iowa; 53, Duluth, Minn.; 65, Eau Claire, Wis.; 69, Flint, Mich.; 68, tie, Grand Rapids, Mich.; 64, Green Bay, Wis.; 67, tie, Jackson, Mich.; 69, La Crosse, Wis.; 68, Lansing, Mich.; 68, Madison, Wis.; 69, tie, Milwaukee, Wis.; 72, tie, Moline, Ill.; 69, tie, Rockford, Ill.; 70, tie, South Bend, Ind.; and 65, tie, Traverse City, Mich. ``It's wonderful. It's the kind of weather I'd take all the time if they'd give it to me,'' said Deann Beard, who barbecued hot dogs with her daughter at Boom Island Park in Minneapolis, which had a record high Wednesday of 71. The normal Nov. 14 temperature in Minneapolis is 42. Ten days before the record high the city had 3 inches of snow. ``We've had multiple Indian summers,'' weather service meteorologist Jim Mathews said in Minneapolis. ``If you had told me in October that we'd have 70s in November, I'd have said you were crazy.'' Rain was scattered over southwestern North Dakota at midday and over the northern coast of Washington state. Snow showers were scattered over the Montana Rockies. Strong, gusty wind blew across Wyoming between Cheyenne and Laramie during the morning. During the afternoon, high wind blew across parts of Texas, Kansas, Missouri and Indiana. Wind gusted to nearly 50 mph at Emporia, Kan., around midday. A winter storm watch was posted through Friday across sections of northern and interior Alaska, with blizzard conditions expected over the western Arctic Coast. Locally heavy rain caused minor flooding in the islands of Hawaii after more than 8 inches of rain fell in 24 hours at Mountainview and other locations near Hilo. Thursday's low for the Lower 48 states was 12 in Gunnison, Colo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 29 degrees at Yellowstone National Park, Wyo., to 86 at Harlingen, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Former Klan Leader Sought in Florida Sexual Assault Arrested in Canada
DOC.TEXT: A former Florida Ku Klux Klan leader sought in his home state for the sexual battery of a 16-year-old girl has been arrested for panhandling in Canada, authorities said. Donald Spivey was arrested Wednesday in the community of Spences Bridge, about 120 miles northeast of Vancouver, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police said. A Canadian immigration adjudicator scheduled a closed hearing Friday to determine whether Spivey should be deported to the United States for entering Canada illegally, said Rob Johnston, Vancouver-area immigration manager. Spivey allegedly used the name William O'Shea when he entered Canada on Oct. 24 at Osoyoos, about 160 miles east of Vancouver, said Spences Bridge Constable Ray Watson. Watson said that when he checked Spivey's fingerprints with the FBI, he learned he was wanted in Florida. Spivey, 41, recently was Grand Dragon of a Florida KKK group, said Lynne Breidenbach, a spokeswoman for the Polk County sheriff's office in Lakeland, Fla. A warrant for Spivey's arrest was issued April 18, charging him with sexual battery, she said. The warrant set bail at $500,000.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Considering Change In Milk Pricing Formula
DOC.TEXT: A proposal to change the butterfat formula used in determining milk prices paid to farmers is under consideration, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. Daniel D. Haley, administrator of the department's Agricultural Marketing Service, said the proposed change is based on the unanimous wishes of major sectors of the dairy industry that testified a national hearing on July 31 in Alexandria, Va. The proposal, if adopted, would reduce the value of butterfat in the pricing formula used under all federal milk marketing orders. ``Paying dairy farmers less for the butterfat in the milk they sell to processors will recognize the lowered value of butterfat in today's marketplace caused by consumers' changing preferences,'' Haley said. Currently, butterfat in milk is given a value according to a ``butterfat differential'' based on a fat content of 3.5 percent. Milk with a higher percentage of butterfat gets a higher prices, and milk with a lower percentage gets a lower price. The differentials are gauged in increments of one-tenth of 1 percent. Haley said the new formula would benefit milk wholesalers, or ``handlers,'' under federal milk marketing orders. The handlers now are paying farmers one price for the butterfat in their milk but can only sell surplus butterfat to butter plants at a lower price. Under the new formula, handlers would pay less for the butterfat, but would increase the value of skim milk. Haley said the overall net income to dairy farmers will remain the same. But use of the new formula is contingent on milk producers approving the plan, he said. Producer approval will be determined through six federal marketing order referendums. The federal marketing orders are a system used to set minimum prices for milk that dealers must pay farmers. Although the orders do not set retail milk prices, the minimums specified at the farm are felt throughout the marketing chain. Officials said details of the proposed pricing formula will be published in the Federal Register, the government's rule-making document, on Nov. 19. The agency said copies of the proposal are available from any federal milk marketing order office or from: AMS, USDA, Dairy Division, Order Formulation Branch, Room 2968, P.O. Box 96456, Washington, D.C. 20090-6456. Telephone 202 447-6273.

DOC.HEAD: Inquiry Told that Soviet Bloc Knew of Secret Network
DOC.TEXT: An Italian official told a parliamentary inquiry on Thursday that the Soviet bloc learned years ago about a network of secret resistance groups in Europe reportedly set up with NATO and CIA aid. The Western public is only learning now about the anti-communist network. Adm. Fulvio Martini, chief of military intelligence service, testified on the opening day of the inquiry that the other side found out about the operation through its own spies. ``They surely knew about Gladio for a simple reason, because of an espionage operation that had a certain importance in a NATO country,'' Martini said, without going into specifics. Martini is in charge of Operation Gladio, the Italian branch of the guerrilla network established at the dawn of the Cold War in case of a Soviet invasion. Gladio is Italian for the double-edged swords used by Roman gladiators. Premier Giulio Andreotti revealed the existance of the group last month, many European governments have admitted similar organizations were formed in their countries - sometimes with CIA help. Several groups were later put under North Atlantic Treaty Organization command. The Parliamentary Committee on Massacres is examining whether Operation Gladio was linked to right-wing terrorism. Martini strongly denied that it was. The admiral did not say exactly when the Soviets learned about the guerrilla network. He told the commission that Warsaw Pact members themselves had a form of Operation Gladio. He identified it as Spetnas - an acronym for Spetsialnovo Naznacheniye, or special forces. But he said that unlike Gladio, it relied not on civilians but on military forces who could form ``a kind of Fifth Column'' in case of Western invasion. In Poland, Deputy Defense Minister Janusz Onyskiewicz said that ``we did not prepare for a guerrilla fight in case of invasion by our country by the NATO army.'' He is a civilian appointed by the post-Communist government. Revelation of the European networks has prompted an outcry in Italy. Some politicians and news media speculated Gladio may have been behind a series of unresolved terrorist bombings that occurred from 1969 through the early 1980s, when the Italian Communists came to the brink of power. Most of the attacks were blamed on right-wing groups. Martini admitted under questioning that Gladio documents mentioned defending against ``internal subversion'' as well as foreign invasion. But he denied any ``gladiators'' were involved in illegal conspiracies. ``The structure and national breakdown of Gladio ... would be of very little use for a coup or other internal subversion,'' he said. Of a total of 622 ``gladiators,'' 70 percent were based above the Po River near Italy's northern borders, he said. ``Not one of the 622 was ever involved in any conspiracies or plots,'' he said. He said Operation Gladio was ``frozen'' a month ago on Andreotti's orders, but that authorities had let it decline for years because of the reduced Soviet threat. Some members were apparently being recruited even in recent years, however. The Italian newsweekly Europeo on Thursday published what it said was a partial list of Gladio members. Among them were a 22-year-old and a 23-year-old. Members of the commission said they were told the list was genuine. In Britain, The Guardian newspaper quoted Gen. Sir Anthony Farrar-Hockley, a former commander of NATO forces in northern Europe, as saying a British group was formed to resist an invasion by Communist forces. ``The original plan was to establish a network to arm guerrillas from the civil populace while conventional forces were occupied elsewhere,'' he was quoted as saying. The network is said to also have had branches in Germany, France, Belgium, the Netherlands, Denmark, Norway, Austria, Spain, Greece and Portugal. In Italy, the resistance group was set up through a 1956 accord between Italian secret services and the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency, Martini and parliamentary deputies said Thursday. It came under NATO coordination three years later. Among questions raised by Gladio is what happened to some of its 139 arms caches hidden around Italy. Martini said the contents of two of them were stolen. The hearing Thursday was closed to the public but reporters were allowed to follow the proceedings on closed-circuit television. The broadcast was interrupted five times when the commission decided that certain testimony involved state secrets.

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Leak Prompts Evacauation of McDonnell Douglas Workers
DOC.TEXT: A leak of noxious sulfur dioxide Thursday forced the evacuation of 1,500 McDonnell Douglas workers and sent 40 people to the hospital with minor breathing problems, officials said. The chemical, which can burn the eyes and throat, started leaking at 9:45 a.m. from the valve of a 150-gallon drum between two buildings at the sprawling aerospace plant, said fire spokesman Hank Zavaleta. Firefighters evacuated people from the buildings while a hazardous materials team cleaned up the area. Forty workers were taken to hospitals for observation or treatment of minor inhalation problems, said McDonnell Douglas spokesman Warren Lamb. There were no serious injuries. The leak's cause was not immediately known. The sulfur dioxide was used to treat wastewater from metal finishing to make the water safe enough to dispose.

DOC.HEAD: Public Citizen Issues `Clarification' Letter to Company
DOC.TEXT: The private group Public Citizen on Thursday issued what it described as a clarification of a recent critical report on the insurance industry, saying it did not mean to imply that the American International Group was in danger of insolvency. In a letter to AIG Chairman Maurice R. Greenberg, Public Citizen President Joan Claybrook also reiterated that Public Citizen finds no need for policyholders to switch companies because of the findings in its report. AIG released the letter, along with a statement describing the Public Citizen report as ``irresponsible'' and objecting to ``any suggestion ... that its financial condition was to any degree imperiled or impaired.'' It said the consumer group had ``acknowledged ... that any such suggestion in the report was neither intended nor accurate.'' Public Citizen has previously acknowledged that it was mistaken in saying in the report that the property and casualty surpluses of Aetna and the ITT Hartford insurance group had declined. Public Citizen spokesman Bob Dreyfuss said the letter to AIG, however, did not acknowledge any error. ``We didn't make any additional changes or corrections or retractions at all in the report,'' he said. ``It was really a simple clarification.'' The report, issued on Oct. 15, said that five of the nation's top 20 property and casualty companies would be subject to possible insolvency in the event of a severe economic downturn. It said none of the companies was on the edge of insolvency but ``the underlying weakness in their financial condition is clearly evident.'' The five were Aetna, AIG, Hartford, Liberty Mutual and United States Fidelity & Guaranty. The study said they each triggered four of six factors that, by Public Citizen's analysis, would make them vulnerable to insolvency in an economic downturn. One of the tests was whether they held less in surplus in 1982 than in 1972. Aetna and Hartford were both listed in this category, but the group said a later re-calculation showed that their surpluses had actually increased during the decade. Consequently, it said, they should not have been on the list. In response to a question at a news conference when the report was released, Ms. Claybrook said she would not advise people holding policies with any of the companies to change to another insurer. Instead, she said, they should write to their companies and urge corrective action. In her letter to Greenberg, Ms. Claybrook said, ``AIG has objected to references to it in the report. Public Citizen did not suggest, or intend to imply, that AIG's financial condition is such that it is in danger of becoming insolvent, nor did we intend to cast doubt upon AIG's ability to meet its obligations. As Public Citizen explicitly stated when the report was released, it finds no need for policyholders to switch companies and does not dispute the ratings that AIG has received from Moody's, Standard and Poor's and A.M. Best.'' AIG's statement said it had previously received and still holds the highest rating provided by each of these organizations.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Alcohol, Tobacco Firms Should Pay for Counter Ads
DOC.TEXT: Congress should require the alcohol and tobacco industries to pay for advertising to discourage teenage use of the ``gateway'' substances, a national panel said Thursday. The National Commission on Drug-Free Schools said the campaign is needed because, while schoolchildren have curbed their use of cocaine, marijuana and other illegal drugs, they stubbornly resist calls to abstain from drinking and smoking. The panel suggested in a report that Congress enact a ban on advertising and promotion of either or both of these products if the industries fail to stop targeting youth by 1992. The report presents final conclusions of the 26-member commission, co-chaired by Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos and William Bennett, the outgoing director of the National Drug Control Policy, on the problems of drugs in the nation's school. The key finding, after nationwide field hearings involving more than 1,700 witnesses, was that while prevention efforts have had some impact on the use of illegal controlled drugs, there has not been the same success in discouraging use of alcohol and tobacco. ``For the past year, our commission has talked to hundreds of students, teachers, and prevention specialists, and all of them agree that alcohol is the drug of choice for young people,'' said Rep. Michael DeWine, R-Ohio, a commission member. ``Most of the kids don't realized that alcohol and tobacco are often gateways to other drug use,'' he added. The report, authorized as part of the Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1988, said illegal drug use decreased from 1981, when 66 percent of seniors acknowledged use of an illicit drug, to a 51 percent rate in 1989. Marijuana use within the previous 30 days among high school seniors declined from 37 percent in 1978 to 17 percent in 1989. Cocaine use within the previous 30 days among high school seniors declined from a high of 6.7 percent in 1985 to a low of 2.8 percent in 1989. Alcohol use within the previous 30 days among high school seniors declined from 72 percent in 1978 to 60 percent in 1989. The report said children as young as third-graders have used alcohol and tobacco. Data from recent national surveys of high school seniors indicate that about 19 percent reported having smoked cigarettes and about 9 percent reported having drunk alcoholic beverages by the sixth grade. About 3.3 percent of these students reported having been drunk by the sixth grade. ``Alcohol and tobacco pose serious health hazards to young people,'' said the report. ``Alcohol-related traffic accidents are the leading cause of death among young people.'' Among its recommendations, it said, ``the amount of funds from the alcohol and tobacco industries should be sufficient to develop and operate a substantial public education program to balance the messages that have the effect of encouraging young people to drink and smoke.'' ``The counter-advertising campaigns could serve as remedial education for young people who have been influenced to use these drugs by exposure to advertising and promotion from these industries over the years.''

DOC.HEAD: Atlanta: Omni Hotel.
DOC.TEXT: The network said the FBI agents had no warrant and acted over the objections of a CNN attorney. It said it was demanding the tapes be returned. In Washington, FBI spokesman Scott Nelson confirmed authorities obtained some CNN tapes without a subpoena. ``We were made aware of the tapes and merely picked them up for analysis,'' Nelson said. The network said the Turner Security official called the FBI because agents had told him they were looking for ``stolen government property.'' The network said the material was not stolen.

DOC.HEAD: Wellstone Doesn't Hide Dislike For New Colleague
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last two grafs with comments from Helms
DOC.TEXT: Sen.-elect Paul Wellstone has made it clear that the Senate tradition of sidestepping personal attacks on fellow senators will not affect his antagonism toward his new colleague Jesse Helms. Wellstone, a liberal Democrat from Minnesota, said he has been an opponent of the conservative North Carolina Republican since he first heard Helms while studying at the University of North Carolina in the 1960s. ``I have detested him since I was 19, and moreover I think he won against Harvey Gantt on a blatantly racist campaign. Period. It's true,'' Wellstone said at a news conference Thursday. Helms won re-election last week by narrowly defeating Gantt, a black. ``I didn't come here to Washington to start talking differently than I did in Minnesota.'' Wellstone could be serving on at least one committee with Helms, a possibility that Wellstone acknowledged would be ``interesting.'' One of Wellstone's top priorities is a seat on the Agriculture Committee. Helms is the panel's former chairman and now its No. 2 Republican. ``I think people in Minnesota expect me to come to the United States Senate and every single time it's appropriate on the floor of the Senate or wherever to take on Jesse Helms and present a very different kind of vision of politics,'' Wellstone said. Helms, who has never met Wellstone, responded Thursday: ``I hope that he will prove to be somewhat more stable. ... Otherwise he's going to have a difficult time in the Senate.'' Helms bristled at Wellstone remarks that Helms had ``minimized'' the assassination of President Kennedy in 1963. ``He went off the deep end,'' Helms said of Wellstone.

DOC.HEAD: Groups Plan To Appeal Iroquois Decision
DOC.TEXT: Opponents of the Iroquois gas pipeline said Thursday they will appeal a federal agency's decision to approve the 370-mile pipeline. At least four groups planned to challenge the project by questioning the procedures used by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. The commission's approval cleared the way for construction to begin on the $583 million pipeline from upstate New York, through western Connecticut and under Long Island Sound to Long Island. The line will bring Canadian natural gas to utilities and gas companies in New England, New York and New Jersey. Backers of the project say it will reduce dependence on Mideast oil and provide a clean-burning energy alternative for heating and electricity. Leading the opposition are domestic gas and oil prospectors and suppliers who say the project has been given an unfair competitive advantage over U.S. energy sources. A citizens' group opposes the decision on environmental grounds and because of the disruption it may cause to property owners in its path.

DOC.HEAD: West African Task Force Jets Bomb Liberian Port
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to CORRECT that raid was Wednessday, confirmation was Thursday. Picks up 4th graf, `The State...'
DOC.TEXT: Warplanes of the West African task force in Liberia bombed the rebel-held port of Buchanan, and the insurgents said people were killed. Rebels also claimed the Nigerian jets destroyed an American ship carrying relief food in Wednesday's attack, but State Department officials in Washington denied it. The officials said Thursday that one of two U.S.-owned Liberian flag vessels at Buchanan sustained minor damage to a foremast. The other was not damaged. The State Department said there reportedly were two Liberian casualties, but gave no details. It said no American citizens were involved. The U.S. government expressed its concern about the incident to task force headquarters in Monrovia, the Liberian capital, the officials said. The task force was sent to enforce peace in Liberia. The U.S. Catholic Relief Services and the Belgian branch of Doctors without Borders are among the humanitarian organizations that have been striving throughout Liberia to help people dying of starvation, disease andin task force bombing raids. Joshua Iroha, the Nigerian ambassador ande chief political representative of the five-nation West African army in Liberia, said Wednesday's air raid was aimed at stopping weapons being shipped to rebels led by Charles Taylor. Iroha said in an interview at his base in Freetown, the capital of Sierra Leone, that the task force ``is not obliged to tell anyone when it is carrying out military operations, and whoever was at the port of Buchanan when the bombing was carried out was just unlucky. ``There are more weapons in the containers at the port of Buchanan than food ... Any international relief organization that wants to help Liberians must use the free port of Monrovia.'' The West Africans have forced Taylor's rebels from the capital, where 150,000 to 200,000 civilians remain. Most people in Liberia are behind the lines of Taylor's guerrillas. After Monrovia, Buchanan has the largest concentration of civilians. About 10,000 civilians have been killed since rebels invaded from Ivory Coast on Dec. 23. More than half of Liberia's 2.3 million people have fled the country or have been displaced inside Liberia.
Panel Opens `Keating Five' Hearing, Told Senators Helped S&L Owner
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 6th graf: ``Keating contributed,'' to raise higher the $1.3 million in contributions; INSERTS 14th graf: ``Glenn arranged,'' to note lunch
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Ethics Committee opened trial-like public hearings Thursday on the ``Keating Five'' with the panel's lawyer declaring the lawmakers helped the owner of a failing savings and loan fight an ``all-out war'' with federal regulators. The senators also heard committee chairman Howell Heflin say many Americans believe ``that you were bribed, that you sold your office, that you traded your honor and your good names for contributions and other benefits.'' Special counsel Robert S. Bennett, said in his opening statement that Sens. Alan Cranston and Dennis DeConcini ``were important players'' in Charles J. Keating Jr.'s strategy to stave off federal rules and that Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr. ``played a much greater role'' than he now contends. Speaking in a packed hearing room, Bennett said Sens. John McCain and John Glenn played lesser roles. The lawyer spoke for about five hours Thursday, and will resume Friday morning. Before Bennett spoke, the chairman of the six-senator committee, Alabama Democrat Heflin, somberly told the subjects of the inquiry: ``Many of our fellow citizens apparently believe that your services were bought by Charles Keating, that you were bribed, that you sold your office, that you traded your honor and your good names for contributions and other benefits.'' Keating contributed $1.3 million to campaigns of, and causes favored by, the five senators. While Bennett denied his role was prosecutorial, Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark. testily told him, ``You're beginning to reach personal conclusions and deciding what is relevant and what is not relevant.'' Bennett responded ``It's less my conclusion and more the objective evidence.'' In his detailed comments, Bennett told the panel: -Despite Riegle's statements that he doesn't remember such events, Keating offered to host a fund-raiser for Riegle at the businessman's Detroit hotel; the senator set arrangements in motion for an April 2, 1987, meeting between the four other senators and the former top thrift regulator, and Riegle hid from his own aides his role in arranging that meeting and the fund-raising purpose o a trip to Keating's Phoenix-based company. -Cranston continued to contact federal regulators even though former Arizona Gov. Bruce Babbitt told the senator that Keating was ``a crook.'' -Evidence shows that DeConcini offered a deal on behalf of Keating to former top thrift regulator Edwin J. Gray, despite DeConcini's denial of a quid pro quo. Three other senators at the meeting refused to ``say flatly'' that DeConcini's version was correct. -On Glenn, the lawyer ``knew of no evidence'' linking Keating's contributions to intervention by the Ohio senator. -Glenn arranged and attended a lunch between Keating and then-House Speaker Jim Wright in January 1988 to discuss S&L problems. Some time after the meeting, a Keating aide sent Glenn a thank you note, saying ``Speaker Wright's interest was fantastic.'' -On McCain: ``Was there anything improper about Sen. McCain's conduct? The evidence discovered by the special counsel suggests not.'' Four of the five senators were present for the opening of the hearing in the Senate Hart Office Building. Cranston, who said last week that he will undergo treatment for prostate cancer, was not there. The committee could vote to rebuke any of the five or to recommend a more serious punishment to the full Senate, or to take no action against any of them. All have denied wrongdoing. While Keating was enlisting the five senators and other lawmakers as soldiers in his battle, he was liberally doling out political contributions, Bennett said. It is the committee's role, he said, to determine whether that money was driving the senators to intervene with regulators on Keating's behalf - or whether they were providing normal constituent service. Bennett said, ``I will give you many instances where acts and money were discussed at the same time and indeed hundreds of thousands of dollars in the case of Sen. Cranston passed in an office in this building.'' The lawyer held up jumbled pieces of a jigsaw puzzle and promised to piece together evidence in the case just as someone would complete the puzzle. The committee members and Bennett repeatedly described the hearings as a fact-finding effort to determine whether the five senators helped Keating because of the $1.3 million they received from the former thrift operator and his associates. All five senators have contended they were helping Keating as they would anyone - whether a contributor or not - who complained of unfair treatment by federal regulators. For months, the news media have reported that Bennett recommended to the committee of three Democrats and three Republicans that McCain, R-Ariz. and Glenn, D-Ohio, be dismissed from the case; and that the investigation be intensified against Cranston, D-Calif., DeConcini, D-Ariz. and Riegle, D-Mich. In the mid-1980s, when Keating was fighting a rule by regulators limiting risky thrift investments, he enlisted the support of the five senators and many others. Placing his hand on stacks of documents Bennett said, ``It is clear from the paper and testimony that Cranston and DeConcini were important players in Keating's strategy.'' Riegle, Bennett said, told the committee he played a ``minor and largely passive'' role in helping Keating fight the regulators. But he said there was ``substantial evidence Riegle played a much greater role than he now recalls.'' Bennett said McCain and Glenn did not play such large roles in organizing the meetings with regulators in April 1987, ``nor did they play meaningful roles following the meetings.'' Bennett also appeared to back previous statements by Gray, the former chief thrift regulator, that the senators had offered Gray a dealon behalf of Keating. ``The regulators were asked to withdraw a regulation (limiting risky investments by thrifts) at the request of a single company and the company would do certain things in return,'' Bennett said. Gray has testified an offer was made at the April 2, 1987, meeting he held with all of the senators except Riegle. According to Gray, DeConcini made the offer, but DeConcini, Cranston, McCain and Glenn all denied such a quid pro quo was offered.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam, Ortega Talk of Revolution Around World
DOC.TEXT: Former President Daniel Ortega of Nicaragua held talks with Saddam Hussein on Third World revolutionary efforts to resist U.S. influence, Baghdad television said Thursday. The Iraqi leader said his seizure of Kuwait on Aug. 2 was a victory for all Third World countries because it was important to show that ``arrogant powers cannot violate small nations,'' the television quoted him as saying. It did not elaborate. Ortega, who headed Nicaragua's leftist Sandinista administration, said he flew to Baghdad on Wednesday to express solidarity with Hussein and the Iraqi people, according to the report. It said the two men had a ``profound discussion'' covering the problems of liberation movements in Third World countries trying to combat U.S. hegemony. Saddam expressed his desire to settle the Persian Gulf crisis through dialogue and in conjunction with other regional disputes, especially the Arab-Israeli conflict. The United States and many other nations opposing Iraq reject the linkage. Ortega was quoted as telling Saddam that the struggle for freedom and independence in Latin America would continue, despite changes in the international climate. The United States supported the Contra rebels who fought Ortega's government in the 1980s. Ortega was defeated in February elections by a U.S.-backed coalition.

DOC.HEAD: VP's Wife, Marilyn Quayle, Visits Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: Marilyn Quayle, wife of Vice President Dan Quayle, met Thursday with officials to discuss Soviet preparations for natural calamities and industrial accidents, the official news agency Tass said. Mrs. Quayle toured an emergency medical center and met with Deputy Prime Minister Vitaly Doguzhiyev, chairman of a Soviet government committee on emergencies. She is visiting the Soviet Union as co-leader of a delegation from the Office of U.S. Foreign Disaster Assistance. The purpose of the visit is to foster cooperation between Soviet and U.S. disaster response organizations.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Smash Ring Linked to $43 Million Hidden Drug Treasure
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with 15 suspects charged in court Thursday, minor editing. ADDS background, quotes and byline. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Federal authorities said Thursday they had smashed a 30-member cocaine-smuggling ring whose leader buried $43 million in drug money on a farm in Puerto Rico. The case caused a sensation last spring when it was disclosed that residents of the Vega Baja coastal area had unearthed barrels filled with $10, $20 and $100 bills and kept their windfall secret for weeks. In all, residents made off with $11 million, which they put in their bank accounts and bought everything from VCRs to luxury homes before the authorities stepped in, according to the FBI. In a statement Thursday, the FBI said it had arrested or issued warrants for 30 alleged members of the drug ring that amassed the buried treasure in drug-running operations from Colombia since 1985. Fifteen suspects were charged Thursday in U.S. District Court in San Juan and four others were already in jails in Puerto Rico and New York, said FBI spokeswoman Juana Arriazola. Another suspect arrested Thursday in New York was awaiting extradition, and two others were charged in Puerto Rico on Wednesday, she said. Among the eight suspects still at large were reputed drug kingpin Ramon Torres Gonzalez, on whose farm the cash-filled barrels were hidden, and Iris Janet Concepcion Perez, alleged co-leader of the drug ring, the FBI said. All 30 are accused under a 27-count federal indictment with criminal enterprise and conspiracy to import and distribute controlled substances. The indictment was returned Nov. 1 by a federal grand jury in Puerto Rico. If convicted, the suspects face a minimum penalty of 60 years in prison and a maximum sentence of life in prison, as well as a fine of up to $10 million. U.S. Magistrate Jesus Castellano released seven of the defendants who came into court Thursday on bail totaling $625,000 and jailed the others without bail. He set a court hearing for Nov. 21. The indictment alleges that Torres and his drug organization had imported and distributed more than 4.5 tons of Colombian cocaine into Puerto Rico and the United States since 1985. William Mitchell, head of the San Juan office of the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration, said most of the cocaine was shipped to Puerto Rico by way of neighboring Dominican Republic. ``Some (cocaine) was for the local market, but the majority went to the states, principally New York and Philadelphia,'' he said. The drug ring amassed a fortune, of which $43 million in cash was buried in 22 plastic drums on Torres' 9.7-acre farm in Vega Baja, about 35 miles east of San Juan, authorities said. The FBI got involved in the case in April after authorities learned that local residents had been using large amounts of cash to buy houses, cars, VCRs, motorcycles, boats and jewelry. Residents took $11 million of the money before Torres allegedly removed and hid the remaining $32 million, which has not been found, the FBI said. The FBI said it had confiscated $4.5 million in cash and property purchased with the stolen money. None of the residents were arrested.

DOC.HEAD: Mass Anti-Government Demonstrations Convulse Romania
LaserPhoto XBUC2
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of Romanians rallied against the government Thursday, turning an anniversary of the first major protest against Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu into a denunciation of his successors. The rallies across Romania continued late Thursday night. They were sparked by the protest three years ago in this southern Transylvanian town. But they were fueled by unrest over government reforms that have tripled food prices, and by resentment over President Ion Iliescu's having served as a Communist official years ago under Ceausescu. Demonstrators also took to the streets of the capital Bucharest, Timisoara, Constanta, Ploiesti, Iasi and Sibiu, demanding Iliescu's resignation. In Bucharest, up to 50,000 demonstrators converged on Palace Square, where protesters died in last year's uprising, and marched to government headquarters. The protesters, including many students, shouted anti-Iliescu slogans and jeered the price increases. Thousands remained on the streets Thursday night and about 300 demonstrators blocked traffic on the main boulevard. More than 50,000 people rallied in the western city of Timisoara, site of the massacre that spurred the revolution. The center of Ploiesti, 38 miles north of Bucharest, was also blocked by demonstrators late Thursday night. But the focus of the rallies was Brasov, where thousands of workers marched through the city center to commemorate the Nov. 15, 1987 riot against Ceausescu. Three years ago in Brasov, a man set himself afire on a hilltop to protest Ceausescu's rule. Workers and others later attacked and ransacked city hall. The dread Securitate secret police suppressed the rallies. Scores of people accused of instigating the protests were arrested, tortured and jailed. At Thursday's rally, former dissident Doina Cornea, among the first to support the 1987 protests, joined crowds calling for Iliescu's resignation. ``We do not need hypocritical, violent demagogues,'' Cornea told demonstrators. Sorin Rosca said the newly established Civic Alliance opposition group would organize committees nationwide to seek out remaining Securitate agents and publish names. ``We are not dealing with the Communist phantom, but with a neo-Communist reality,'' he told the crowd. Iliescu promised gradual reforms and social protection after he won a landslide victory in May elections. But many Romanians accuse him and his National Salvation Front government of allowing old-regime officials to remain in the bureaucracy and of personally harboring Communist tendencies. Both president and government insist they have shed their Communist past.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Thatcher Vows to Stay on; Heseltine Says He Would Heal Rift
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher pledged Thursday to stay on in office, while fellow Conservative Michael Heseltine, the man who seeks to oust her, said he can unify their party's ``deep divide.'' They traded campaign rhetoric on the day Heseltine formally submitted his bid for leadership of the Conservative Party and the government. Heseltine, once Mrs. Thatcher's defense secretary, will stand against her in a ballot Tuesday of the 372 Conservative legislators. It marks the first serious challenge to her leadership since she took office 11 years ago. ``After three general election victories, leading the only party with clear policies, resolutely carried out, I intend to continue,'' she declared in the House of Commons. She was responding to an opposition lawmaker who held up a 5-year-old newspaper in which he said she'd promised to quit in 1990. Mrs. Thatcher also attacked a Heseltine proposal on education, saying it would ``either mean a huge increase in income tax, or a substantial reduction in monies available for other services.'' Heseltine has suggested education should be paid for by the national government, not through the unpopular new per-capita tax on property dubbed the poll tax. He said Thursday he would review the tax. The self-made millionaire said in an interview that he was inspired to make his challenge by former Deputy Prime Minister Geoffrey Howe's scathing attack on Mrs. Thatcher in the House of Commons Tuesday. ``After Geoffrey made the speech, you couldn't say `Go on, business as usual,''' Heseltine told Independent Television. ``There was a deep divide . ... We have to find a way of unifying the party. ... I think I could do it.'' He said that despite what Mrs. Thatcher achieved in the 1980s, a growing number of people felt it was time to ``ask questions about the 1990s, and it will need a new voice, a new language, a new approach.'' Earlier, he was heckled at a meeting of Conservative Party workers in Paisley, Scotland, but by apparent outsiders, who carried ``Socialist Worker'' placards. Heseltine snapped at them, ``You will never solve Scotland's problems if your only contribution to the debate is a loud mouth and an empty mind.'' A poll of 240 Conservative lawmakers conducted Monday to Thursday by Press Association, the British news agency, found Heseltine facing a defeat. It reported Mrs. Thatcher winning 53.3 percent of the vote and Heseltine 19.2 percent. But 27.5 percent refused to reveal where they stood. Heseltine needs 159 votes in the first secret ballot to force a runoff, and says 100 lawmakers have pledged him support. Mrs. Thatcher needs 214 votes to win outright. The Guardian newspaper published a poll of 1,446 people indicating Mrs. Thatcher was still the overwhelming favorite of Conservative Party voters. A poll of 1,084 people published in The Independent newspaper had Conservatives running closer to the opposition Labor Party with Heseltine as leader. The poll indicated the Tories now trailed Labor by 14 percentage points. When the poll asked how people would vote with Heseltine as Conservative leader, the gap shrank to five points. Much of Mrs. Thatcher's crisis is rooted in her party's 16-month lag behind the Labor Party in opinion polls, mainly because of high inflation, high interest rates and the poll tax. Division in her Cabinet over her attitude toward Europe's moves toward economic integration helped precipitate the crisis in the party as it looks nervously toward a general election which must be held by mid-1992. Heseltine left Mrs. Thatcher's Cabinet in 1986 in a Europe-related dispute.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Saudi Forces Start `Imminent Thunder' Exercise in Gulf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with six grafs to UPDATE with general location of exercise, quotes. Picks up graf 6th pvs, `No live...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto Staffing
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Saudi Arabian forces Thursday began a six-day amphibious exercise in the Persian Gulf codenamed ``Imminent Thunder.'' Iraq called it a ``provocative act'' because it was close to Kuwait. The exercise involved 1,000 U.S. Marines, 1,100 aircraft and 16 ships, including the aircraft carrier USS Midway, which arrived in the region earlier this month. It was the largest use of aircraft in a single training exercise since American forces began being deployed in the region under Operation Desert Shield in early August. There have been three previous amphibious exercises in the gulf since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Iraq, but they were believed to have been held farther south. While the exact location of Immninent Thunder was not revealed under military policy and a news blackout was imposed for the initial phases, a Pentagon spokesman said the exercise is centered in eastern Saudi Arabia, about 100 miles from Kuwait. ``It is not right next to the Kuwaiti border,'' Lt. Cmdr. Edward Lundquist said late Thursday in Washington. Press reports have said the exercise would be 10 miles from the Iraqi-Kuwaiti border. No live ammunition will be fired in Imminent Thunder. The exercise was not intended to provoke the Iraqis, said U.S. Navy spokesman Cmdr. J.D. Van Sickle. ``The purpose is to give participating forces training in oint and combined operations and to enhance amphibious warfare skills,'' he said. ``Exercise Imminent Thunder is part of our Desert Shield training.'' Military officials said there was no particular significance to the name of the operation and that its timing was not linked to any operational plans. But it is being held as the United States doubles the number of aircraft carriers in the gulf region to six and sends in 150,000 additional military personnel to join the estimated 230,000 already deployed. The entire U.S.-led multinational force arrayed against Iraq numbers more than 300,000. The exercise was launched one day after British Defense Secretary Tom King visited Saudi Arabia to discuss what reinforcements Britain might send. The British have 16,000 personnel in the region, including the 9,000-man 7th ``Desert Rats'' Armoured Division, which became operational Wednesday. King warned Iraqi President Saddam Hussein on Wednesday: ``Time is running out. We're not going to sit around forever.'' Adm. Frank B. Kelso, the chief of naval operations who was in the gulf visiting the destroyer USS O'Brien as part of an inspection tour, refused to answer questions about Imminent Thunder. ``We don't discuss details of future operations,'' Kelso said. He flew by helicopter out to the O'Brien, operating off Bahrain to help enforce U.N. trade sanctions against Iraq to force it out of Kuwait. Kelso said the additional three aircraft carriers on their way means ``fundamentally, you have doubled your firepower.'' The exercise included units of the Army, Navy, Air Force and 1,000 members of the 4th Marine Expeditionary Battalion. It also included the Royal Saudi Air Force, and naval and marine units. Training will consist of an amphibious landing in eastern Saudi Arabia with air cover and close air and naval support of ground forces. Army Sgt. 1st Class Mickey Kershaw, 37, of West Islip, N.Y., said he felt it would be better to get on with the real fighting, if there was to be any, instead of doing more training. ``It's a waste of time,'' he said of Imminent Thunder. He said he would rather fight Saddam's force now ``than do it five years from now when this guy nukes me and the family I might have.''

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Shakes Nerves in Central Oklahoma
DOC.TEXT: A small earthquake early Thursday in central Oklahoma rattled nerves and caused some minor damage. The earthquake at 5:45 a.m. shook pictures off walls and knocked objects off tables and shelves in the area of Lindsay, about 35 miles south of Oklahoma City. No serious damage or injuries were reported. ``It felt weird because you could feel the building shaking. I looked over on the wall and saw my calendar shaking,'' said Larry Thompson, program director at KBLP radio in Lindsay. The Oklahoma Geological Survey said the quake registered 3.6 on the Richter scale of ground movement and was centered 5 miles north of Lindsay. A quake of magnitude 3.5 can cause slight damage. A quake of magnitude 2 is the smallest normally felt by humans. Geologists said interest in the temblor could have been fueled by a quake projection for the New Madrid Fault in the Midwest in early December. ``There's no correlation whatsoever,'' said Charles Mankin, director of the Oklahoma Geological Survey in Norman. ``It's a completely different fault system,'' added Ken Luza, an engineering geologist at the survey. New Mexico inventor Iben Browning has said there's a 50-50 chance of a major earthquake along the New Madrid Fault, which runs from Cairo, Ill., to Marked Tree, Ark., hundreds of miles east of Oklahoma. Most geologists have denounced Browning's forecast, but the resulting controversy has kept earthquakes on the public mind throughout the Midwest. Mankin said quakes are common in Oklahoma, with a couple detected each week. ``We rarely record them as high as 3.6. But a small earthquake in that area is not unusual,'' he said.

DOC.SECOND: EDs: Tops with 20 grafs from interview; INSERTS grafs 25-27:
DOC.TEXT: ``-Iraqi President,'' defense of hostage policy by Saddam; picks up 3rd graf pvs, now 21st graf: ``President Bush;'' heavy editing subsequently to trim. Changes byline
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush Trip, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Thursday that he ordered a massive increase in U.S. military power in the Persian Gulf instead of digging in for a prolonged standoff because it is hard to keep public support for a long-term struggle. ``I think holding public opinion forever in any country is very difficult to do,'' Bush said in an interview with Cable News Network on the eve of his departure for Europe and the Persian Gulf. He was answering the question, Why had he decided on developing a huge offensive capability for the possibility of a war rather than laying preparations for a long stay in Saudi Arabia while economic sanctions crippled Iraq. Bush said he would ``not put it in terms of time'' as to how long he would wait for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. ``I don't think this matter is going to go on forever. As far as I'm concerned, it's not.'' Observing that he has probably not communicated to the public his objectives in the Persian Gulf very well, Bush pledged not to involve the country in a Vietnam-like war. ``I will not, as commander-in-chief, ever put somebody into a military situation that we do not win - ever. And there's not going to be any long drawn-out agony of Vietnam. So I reject the parallel. But I can understand why people say that.
