Because they're thinking, we don't want to have a drawn-out Vietnam.'' The president spoke only hours after the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., said Bush has been inept in explaining his Persian Gulf policy to the American people and must build a consensus for possible U.S. military action. Recent congressional criticism of Bush's decision last week to deploy an additional 200,000 U.S. troops to the gulf region to provide offensive capabilities has called into focus the absence of such a consensus, said Aspin, who supports the president's policy. Bush said has not decided yet to use military force against Saddam and wants to ``preserve all options.'' ``And one way to have a credible option is to have enough force there to fulfill one's responsibilities if one has to exercise that option. And that is what was behind my decision to move this amount of force,'' he said. He said furthermore, he wanted to send a signal to Saddam that ``we are deadly serious'' about getting Iraq out of Kuwait. ``And that message I hope will get out loud and clear to him when he sees another hundred and some thousand of the best equipped, best trained, best motivated forcs in the world up against him,'' Bush added. Even if Saddam does withdraw from Kuwait and the rulers there are restored Bush said, ``there would have to be some international guarantees'' against Saddam's chemical weapons and his attempt to develop a nuclear capability. ``I don't think the rest of the world would say this is good enough, just what they call the status quo ante, going back to where things were before the invasion,'' he said, without specifying what the guarantees should be. Asked about public opinion surveys showing that public support for his gulf policy was dwindling, Bush chalked it up in part to ``an enormous economic equation.'' He said the country is going through ``an economic slowdown ... a disproportionate increase in the price of oil that stems from what Saddam Hussein has done.'' ``And it does mean jobs,'' he added. Reiterating that his motive is also to stand against Iraq's agression, Bush said, ``If I haven't done as clear a job as I might on explainihng this, then I've got to do better in that regard, because I know in my heart of hearts that what we are doing is right.'' Bush, who has declined to say whether he would first go to Congress before undertaking a military strike, said that he recognizes Congress' constitutional right to declare war. ``And I have the right as commander in chief to fulfill my responsibilities, and I'm going to safeguard those executive powers and they have every right in the world to safeguard the powers of the Congress,'' he said. ``President Bush has proven to be an inept communicator and has failed to convey to the public why we are in Saudi Arabia,'' Aspin said. Aspin said the president seemed on Wednesday to have allayed lawmakers' concerns that he had decided to attack Iraqi forces. Now, Aspin said, ``somehow we've got to in Congress and in the country come to the consensus with how we're going to deal with the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.'' And that will require better communication from Bush, he indicated. In other gulf-related developments: -Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, interviewed by ABC News, said he was holding hostages because their presence ``may help distract anybody who may opt for war.'' Hussein called on Bush to pledge not to attack Iraq, and added, ``An open pledge of this nature, a declared statement of this nature, would be sufficient for us to allow all foreigners to leave Iraq.'' The State Department said no spokesman was available to comment on Hussein's remarks. -Bush invoked emergency powers authorizing the Pentagon to undertake military construction projects in the gulf region without advance approval from Congress. -The House Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs Committee announced that it will hold hearings on the economic impact of U.S. involvement in the Middle East on Nov. 27 and Nov. 28. Aspin made his comments at a Capitol Hill news conference in which he released an interim report card on the contributions U.S. allies and other nations have made toward the gulf effort. ``The American people won't stand for our allies sitting out the fighting while Americans are dying,'' Aspin said. His committee will hold gulf hearings sometime after the Thanksgiving holiday, he said. Aspin gave Turkey ``A-plus'' for its prompt response in shutting down the oil pipeline from Iraq that runs through Turkey to the Mediterranean Sea and for providing base facilities for U.S. military units. Egypt also received an ``A-plus'' for its troop contributions. Aspin gave a grade of ``B'' to Saudi Arabia, complaining that based on the amount of money the country has realized since the crisis, now $150 million a day from increased oil prices. Some other grades: Japan, ``C'' for its financial contribution; the Soviet Union, ``B;'' Kuwait, ``A;'' Syria, ``B-plus;'' Yemen, Libya and Sudan, all ``F.'' The Pentagon said Tuesday the gulf states have contributed $6 billion so far.

DOC.HEAD: Year After Slaying of Jesuits, Trial of Accused Has Yet to Start
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT 2 grafs after 2nd graf `The soldiers' to UPDATE with State Department comment. Picks up 3rd graf `The killings...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: A year after soldiers killed six Jesuit priests in a massacre that received world attention, the trial of those accused in the slayings has yet to start. The soldiers who pulled the triggers have confessed and are likely to go to jail. But the senior officer charged in the deaths may well go free, and the question of whether higher-ups were involved is likely to remain a mystery. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Thursday in Washington: ``This brutal crime shocked the conscience of El Salvador and the world. ... The United States insists on a full investigation and prosecution. There is no issue regarding El Salvador to which the ambassador and our embassy have devoted greater effort than the pursuit of justice in the murder of the Jesuits.'' The killings have cost El Salvador half of its $85 million in American military aid planned for 1991 and called into question a long tradition of substantial military impunity in human rights cases. So far, no officer has ever been convicted of killing civilians, though a few enlisted men have been. ``Those priests are causing us more problems dead than they did alive,'' an army colonel said, commenting privately. He is one of more than a dozen high-ranking officers who testified before Judge Ricardo Zamora, the magistrate investigating the slayings and their aftermath. The Jesuits, also professors at the Jesuit-run Central America University, were killed five days after leftist rebels launched the biggest offensive of their decade-old war against a succession of U.S.-backed governments. The radical right and much of the military considered the priests leftists for arguing that misery, injustice and repression were the causes of the civil war. Conservative forces saw the war as part of Communist expansion. The killings took place before dawn last Nov. 16. About 40 soldiers from the elite Atlacatl infantry battalion tramped across the campus, pounded on the door and smashed windows of the Jesuits' dormitory-like residence. According to statements by the soldiers, they roused the educators and marched five of them to the yard behind the building. The soldiers forced the five, including university rector Ignacio Ellacuria, to lie face down. The soldiers said in their statements that Lt. Jose Espinoza walked over to Pvt. Antonio Avalos who, along with Pvt. Oscar Amaya, stood guard over the prostrate men. ``When are you going to proceed?'' Espinoza asked Avalos. Avalos said he took that as the signal to commence. So he and Amaya fatally shot the priests in the head with their assault rifles. The sixth priest, Father Joaquin Lopez, had been wounded in his bedroom. He was finished off with four bullets when he grabbed the foot of a soldier walking past him. Elba Ramos, the Jesuits' housekeeper, and her 15-year-old daughter Celina, were murdered as they hugged each other on the floor of a small bedroom. Espinoza said he was ordered by a colonel who sent him to eliminate witnesses. Eight military men, including Col. Guillermo Benavides, are under arrest and charged with the priests' murder. Another soldier is a fugitive. Benavides did not take part in the killings but is accused of ordering them. Father Jose Maria Tojeira, the Jesuit Provincial for Central America, says the order maintains ``a hypothesis'' of guilt going beyond Benavides. He said the Jesuits suspect a group of colonels pressured Benavides to order the slayings. During 10 years of civil war, Salvadorans have suffered a wide variety of right- and left-wing violence. Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero was gunned down by suspected right-wing triggermen as he said Mass. Security forces raped and murdered three U.S. nuns and their layworker companion. Soldiers and civilian death squads have slain many common folk unknown beyond their hamlets, and Marxist rebels have carried out their own killings. Last month, the U.S. Congress, which has bankrolled a succession of Salvadoran governments, halved military aid for fiscal 1991. It said the remaining aid would be cut if those responsible for the Jesuit murders were not punished. Representative Joe Moakley, D-Mass., heads a U.S. congressional delegation monitoring the investigation. In August he said: ``Salvadoran military officers have withheld evidence, destroyed evidence, falsified evidence and repeatedly perjured themselves in testimony before the judge.'' Judicial sources say those who committed the murders likely will get the maximum 30 years in prison. The only hard evidence incriminating Benavides is the testimony of two lieutenants, among those charged with the murders. But under Salvadoran law, testimony from a defendant is inadmissable as evidence against a co-defendent. One judicial source said that if the case were to go to trial tomorrow, and if the law were respected, Benavides would be acquitted. But the Salvadoran judiciary is subject to political pressure. The slain priests' colleagues predict Benavides will be convicted simply because it is politically impossible to let him off. ``The armed forces need a scapegoat,'' said Father Rogelio Pedraz, who runs the campus publishing house and who was not at the residence the night of the massacre. He had left to pick up some laundry. Until recently, Judge Zamora had hoped to start the trial this year. Then a wrench landed in the works. Moakley on Oct. 18 revealed that U.S. Army Maj. Eric Buckland, the adviser to the Salvadoran military who originally incriminated Benavides, told FBI investigators in January that members of the Salvadoran high command knew at least 10 days before the priests were slain that Benavides intended to harm them. Col. Rene Emilio Ponce - then chief of the joint chiefs of staff and now the Defense Minister - allegedly sent an envoy, accompanied by Buckland, ``to calm down'' Benavides regarding the Jesuits. The affidavit containing that information, which Buckland later recanted and which Ponce rejects as a lie, was not made available to Moakley or Zamora until October. Zamora is planning to recall for further pre-trial testimony some of those named by the U.S. major.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Leaves For Eight-Day Trip To Middle East, Europe
DOC.NOTE: EDs; INSERTS 17th graf: ``The president,'' with invitation to congressional leaders
DOC.TEXT: President Bush leaves Friday on an eight-day trip to the Middle East and Europe, becoming the first U.S. president to visit front-line troops since Lyndon Johnson in Vietnam. Before his Thanksgiving stop in Saudi Arabia, he'll sign a historic East-West arms control agreement in Paris. The Persian Gulf crisis will dominate the tour, even while the president is in Paris attending a 34-nation European summit. Aides said Bush would seek to coordinate his gulf policies when he meets with leaders of the Soviet Union, Britain and France at the three-day Paris gathering. In particular, U.S. officials said, Bush plans to sound out these and other members of the 15-member U.N. Security Council on wording of a proposed resolution to authorize force to drive Iraq from Kuwait. Although the European summit is largely a celebration of the end of the cold war, Bush is ``more than a one-topic president,'' said a senior administration official. ``He understands the significance of what is going to go on in Paris... By the same token, I am sure he will use opportunities as they come along to discuss the gulf with others who are attending,'' said the official, briefing reporters at the White House on condition of anonymity. Secretary of State James A. Baker III flew to Europe ahead of Bush on Thursday to help lay groundwork on gulf policy. He was meeting with foreign ministers of Security Council members, including three African countries - Ethiopia, Zaire and the Ivory Coast. Before leaving Washington, Baker said that while economic sanctions against Iraq's Saddam Hussein seem to be working, ``the real question is, are they working to achieve the goal'' of Saddam's unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait. Baker and Bush will link up again on Monday in Paris at the beginning of the European summit. The centerpiece of the Paris session is a treaty sharply reducing non-nuclear forces that both NATO and the Warsaw Pact maintain in central and eastern Europe. It is the first major East-West agreement on conventional arms since the end of World War II. In his session with Gorbachev early next week, Bush is likely to discuss the condition of the troubled Soviet economy. The administration is developing contingency plans to provide emergency food and medicine to the Soviet Union to help it get through the winter, officials said. The planning is based more on concern that disorders may escalate than on food shortages, although they are severe, said the officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Bush was to leave Washington Friday evening for the trip, which will begin with a one-day state visit to Prague, Czechoslovakia, on the first anniversary of the ``Velvet Revolution'' that ended years of communist control. On Sunday, on his way to Paris, Bush will pay a five-hour visit to recently reunified Germany. He will meet with Chancellor Helmut Kohl at Kohl's home in a suburb of Ludwigshafen. After three days in Paris, Bush will begin the Middle East segment of his trip. He will visit U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf on Thanksgiving Day. The president on Thursday invited top congressional leaders from both parties to join him on Thanksgiving Day. Officials said it was not yet known whether those leaders - House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. - would make the trip. The White House will not discuss specific sites for security reasons, but Bush is expected to visit forces both on a naval vessel and in desert encampments in Saudi Arabia. It will mark the first visit of a U.S. president to front-line troops since President Johnson visited forces during a half-day visit to Vietnam in 1967. Bush will wind up the eight-day trip with a stop in Cairo, Egypt, on Friday, where he will meet with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantis Blasts off with Spy Satellite
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with more comment from NASA officials. Pick up 12th graf, `During the ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CSB2
DOC.TEXT: Atlantis lit up the sky in a rare launch in darkness Thursday as it streaked into orbit on a secret military mission that reportedly will send a satellite to spy on Iraq. The shuttle thundered from its oceanside launch pad at 6:48 p.m. EST, trailed by a 700-foot-pillar of flame. On board were five astronauts who will deploy the satellite during the flight. Mission control's Jeff Carr described the launch as ``picture perfect, absolutely no anomalies to report.'' He said the mission commander described the liftoff as ``spectacular.'' ``This was really just about as smooth a count and liftoff and early few minutes of a mission as I've ever seen,'' said NASA Administrator Richard Truly. The 100-ton spaceship was visible for miles as it rocketed into the nighttime sky. It was the fifth after-dark launch in 37 shuttle flights. It also was NASA's fifth launch for 1990 and the seventh and probably last Pentagon mission to be shrouded in secrecy. Two minutes into the flight, Atlantis' two solid fuel rockets burned out and dropped into the Atlantic Ocean. The shuttle reached an undisclosed orbit 6{ minutes later on the thrust of its three main liquid fuel engines, and all public communications with the craft were cut off. Throughout the day, high crosswinds and low clouds threatened to delay the launch, but the weather improved. The countdown also was unaffected by a last-minute problem with a unit at the launch pad used to cool the shuttle. A news blackout has been imposed on Atlantis' four-day flight, during which the astronauts will deploy a satellite that sources said is to spy on Iraq. Experts believe it is either a photographic imaging or an eavesdropping spacecraft. Atlantis carried a spy satellite into orbit during its last flight in March. The shuttle's all-military crew, commanded by Air Force Col. Richard Covey, has been waiting for months to fly this mission. The flight was scheduled for July but was delayed indefinitely when Atlantis was found during a fueling test in June to have dangerous hydrogen leaks. It was the second shuttle to be crippled by leaking hydrogen. Columbia's astronomy mission was scrubbed in May when the spaceship sprang leaks during fueling. ``We finally got there, fixed the leaks, which is again a testimony to the team,'' said launch director Bob Sieck. ``We do find problems, they do occur. But we fix them, and we'll get on with what we're supposed to do which is flying these machines safely and successfully.'' During the grounding, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration replaced Atlantis' external fuel tank, plumbing between the orbiter and tank, and valve seals. In addition, Atlantis' military cargo reportedly was modified for gathering information in the Persian Gulf. Atlantis, like Columbia, was cleared for flight during a fueling test last month. NASA set a Nov. 9 launch date for Atlantis, but the Air Force delayed that mission because of undisclosed cargo problems. That trouble quickly was resolved, clearing the way for Thursday's liftoff attempt. Also on the crew are Navy Cmdr. Frank Culbertson Jr., pilot; and Army Capt. Charles Gemar, Air Force Lt. Col. Carl Meade and Marine Col. Robert Springer, all mission specialists. The Pentagon has imposed a news blackout on the flight similar to its six previous missions. Because of the expense in maintaining secure operations, officials said this would be the last military shuttle mission to be conducted in secrecy. The Pentagon plans to use the shuttle two more times in 1991, but the cargoes in each instance will be unclassified. Military officials will rely on unmanned rockets - primarily the giant Titan 4 - to carry other payloads into orbit. So far, the Air Force has sent up three Titan 4 rockets, the most powerful unmanned launcher in the United States. The third one blasted off Monday night from Cape Canaveral. Air Force Col. Frank Stirling, who heads the Titan 4 program, said a fleet of unmanned rockets will offer greater reliability than NASA's shuttle. ``We had in a sense committed all our resources for space access to one program, the space shuttle with only four orbiters,'' Stirling said. ``With Titan we have a continuing production line with many Titans available so that if we should ever have a problem or an outage with the vehicle, we would still be able to recover and continue operations,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Agrees on Maine Environmental Fine for Shipyard
DOC.TEXT: The Navy has agreed that the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard must observe Maine environmental laws and that fines and fees for past violations will total more than $1 million, state officials said Thursday. Still pending was whether the state has the authority to collect the money from the federal government. The agreement is part of a consent decree that settles nearly all of the issues in the state's lawsuit against the Navy stemming from violations of Maine's hazardous-waste laws at the shipyard in Kittery, Maine's southernmost town. While the two sides agree on the fine total, the Navy still reserves the right to have the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals decide whether it actually has to pay, Maine Assistant Attorney General Dennis J. Harnish said. ``Certainly the decision at the 1st Circuit will have a substantial impact and this (consent decree) sets the stage for that,'' Harnish said. At stake would be civil penalties of $887,200, and total hazardous waste generator and licensing fees of $267,886, for a total of nearly $1.16 million. Officials at the Portsmouth atomic submarine-repair facility's public affairs office did not return telephone messages left Thursday. Maine filed two lawsuits in 1986 asking that the shipyard be required to clean up inactive solid waste and hazardous waste dumps, including a landfill and a mercury disposal area. The state, in the suit that originated in York County Superior Court, claimed that the Navy dumped hazardous wastes into a treatment plant that could not handle them, gave wastes to unlicensed handlers, illegally accepted wastes from other installations and expanded its waste storage yard without the state's approval. The state also charged that the shipyard was responsible for 14 oil spills and that it had not paid fees to the state for generating hazardous wastes. In November 1988, U.S. District Judge Gene Carter rejected the Navy's argument that the federal government had not waived its immunity, allowing the state to impose its fines and fees. The Navy is appealing that ruling to the 1st Circuit Court, said Harnish.

DOC.HEAD: Hindus, Moslems, Sikhs Battle in India
LaserPhoto DEL3
DOC.TEXT: Hindus battled Moslems with knives, stones and glass bottles in New Delhi on Thursday and Sikh extemists mounted other attacks in new religious and separatist fighting, police and news reports said. At least 18 people were reported killed Wednesday and Thursday in Punjab alone, the Sikh-dominated state to the north. The violence pitted the Sikh and Moslem minorities against the majority Hindus. Religious clashes sweeping India over the past month have killed more than 385 people, most of them Moslems. The fighting was sparked by a Hindu plan to take over a disputed mosque in the northern town of Ayodhya. Hindus and Moslems, inflamed by religious fighting in the capital that killed six people Wednesday, fought street battles in New Delhi's Sadar Bazaar neighborhood. Police fired bullets and tear gas to stop the rioting in the Hindu locale, and at least 12 people were wounded, witnesses said. Elsewhere in the city, Sikh youths stoned buses and Hindu-owned shops. In Punjab, police said Sikh separatists shot and killed seven bus passengers Wednesday. Eleven additional people were killed in other violence in the state Wednesday and Thursday, the United News of India news agency reported. Many of the victims were Hindus. Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar, who took office Saturday, visited Sadar Bazaar on Thursday and blamed the violence on infiltrators from Pakistan, UNI said. The government of V.P. Singh was brought down by India's religious and caste feuds. UNI also quoted intelligence reports as saying Pakistanis disguised as Sikhs had entered India to foment trouble. India has long accused Pakistan of abetting separatist revolts and religious strife here. The two countries have fought three wars. Pakistan, an Islamic nation, has denied the charges. New Delhi has offered little proof. Violence broke out in New Delhi on Wednesday after about 15,000 Moslems and Sikhs met at a mosque in Sadar Bazaar to appeal for solidarity of minority religious communities against what they called rising Hindu fundamentalism. A group broke from the meeting and attacked Hindu homes and shops. Three Moslems, two Hindus and a Hindu police officer were killed in the rioting and gunfire, according to police count. Press Trust of India said seven died. On Thursday, Hindu and Moslem mobs clashed again, defying curfew orders restricting people to their homes. Deputy Police Commissioner Bhim Sain Bassi said at least 11 people were injured, six by police bullets and five in the rioting. Witnesses said many more were injured. In Tilak Nagar, a mainly Hindu locality 10 miles southwest of Sadar Bazaar, Sikh students hurled stones at buses and Hindu-owned shops after their principal made an anti-Hindu speech Thursday, a police official said. Sikh militants have been fighting for in independent nation in Punjab since 1983, accusing the Hindu majority of discrimination. Hindus make up 82 percent of India's 880 million people, Moslems 12 percent and Sikhs 2 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Piracy Action Filed
DOC.TEXT: A group of U.S. industries formally asked the government Thursday to penalize Thailand for tolerating piracy of American movies, music, books, computer software and trademarks. An unfair trade complaint was filed with the office of the U.S. trade representative that could bring formal hearings and lead to new penalties against Thai exports to the United States. The action was brought jointly by the Recording Industry Association of America, the Motion Picture Export Association of America and the International Intellectual Property Alliance, representing more than 1,600 companies that produce and distribute motion pictures, computers and software, television programs and home videocassettes, music tapes, records and discs, books and professional journals. The industries said the Thai government ignored an October warning that the complaint would be filed unless the Thai government met their demand for measures against ``unhindered piracy'' which they say will cost them $70 million to $100 million this year. Thai Embassy Commercial Counselor Wisitsee Chintana said the October warning had been sent immediately to Bangkok and the government was doing its best to solve the problem, including drafting legislation for submission to parliament. She said she could not comment further without knowing more about the complaint. After Thai Prime Minister Chattichai Choonhavan's White House visit in June, there was some hope for a crackdwn against known Thai manufacturers turning out tens of thousands of pirated music audiocassettes daily., said Jay Berman, president of the Recording Industry Association of America. But ``obviously the Thai government does not consider the issue of sufficient importance to take action,'' he added. Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Pictur Export Association, called Thailand ''the worst offender of intellectual property rights in Asia.'' ``We regret the need to go to these lengths to get Thailand simply to enforce its existing copyright law,'' he added. ``The Thai government must be made to realize that we now have no alternative but to ask our government to close the U.S. market to important Thai exports like jewelry, textile products or blank videotape, if immediate action is not taken to stem the more than $130 million in losses our members have suffered over the last 10 years.'' According to Valenti, ``illegal copies of American movies are on sale throughout Thailand within days of their release in the United States and well before their legitimate release in Thailand. American movies are increasingly screened without license by illegal Thai cable TV systems outside of Bangkok.'' In 1989, the U.S. government put Thailand on a ``priority watch list' because of the issue and withheld duty concessions on $165 million worth of Thai exports to the United States. No further action was taken, however, and Thailand enjoyed a $1.4 billion trade surplus with America for the year.

DOC.HEAD: Ohio Court Throws Out Rap Group's Disorderly Conduct Conviction
DOC.TEXT: A state appeals court has cleared members of the rap group NWA of a disorderly conduct conviction they received after a June 1989 concert at Riverfront Coliseum. Three members of the Los Angeles-based group had been convicted in Hamilton County Municipal Court. But the 1st Ohio District Court of Appeals threw out the convictions Wednesday, ruling that the entertainers did not break the law when they asked women in the audience if they wanted to have sex. The appeals court ruled that the requests, made onstage during the concert, did not break the law because they likely did not inconvenience, annoy or alarm anyone. All five members of NWA were charged after police said their remarks were obscene. The three members involved in Wednesday's ruling - Lorenzo ``MC Ren'' Patterson, Oshea ``Ice Cube'' Jackson and Todd ``Too-Short'' Shaw - were convicted by Judge Harry McIlwain and fined $100 each. During the trial, both sides agreed that NWA asked women in the audience if they wanted to have sex with rapper Eric ``Eazy-E'' Wright. But the defense argued that language did not constitute the kind of ``fighting words'' required for a disorderly conduct conviction. H. Louis Sirkin, the group's attorney, also argued that NWA's comments were protected free speech under the First Amendment. The appeals court skipped the constitutional issues and reversed the case on the evidence. Ohio law says disorderly conduct must ``recklessly cause inconvenience, annoyance or alarm.'' ``We're thrilled,'' Jerry Heller, NWA's manager, said of the decision. Heller said NWA members are busy in a Canoga Park, Calif., studio recording two albums.

DOC.HEAD: US, Japanese Pressure Postpones Loan to Brazil
DOC.TEXT: Pressure from the United States and Japan led the World Bank to postpone $450 million in loans to Brazil, officials said Thursday. These officials, who disclosed the delay on condition that they not be identified, said the object of the postponement was to make Brazil come up with some of the $8 billion in interest it owes to commercial banks and has not paid for nearly a year and a half. Brazil's international debt totals $114 billion, the largest of any third-world country. More than $67 billion, not counting the unpaid interest, is owed to commercial banks. A large fraction of that is owed to U.S. and Japanese banks. Zelia Cardoso de Mello, Brazil's minister of Economy, was reported readying a new offer to the commercial banks. The World Bank's Board of Executive Directors, who represent the 143 owner governments, has been considering two new loans to Brazil. One, for $300 million, would got to the Brazilian government's National Bank for Economic and Social Development, to help it lend more to private business. Another loan, for $150 million, had been destined for the Brazilian government's secretariat of Science and Technology. The World Bank released a statement on Thursday saying that these two loans had been approved but James Riddleberger, a bank spokesman, said the statement was a mistake. The directors had not approved any loan to Brazil, he said. Officials explained that an objection in the closed-door directors' meeting had been raised by Japan, and the United States backed the objection. The loans may be reconsidered in a week or two in light of Brazil's talks in New York with commercial banks. The officials said the World Bank had been planning about $1 billion in loans to Brazil by the end of next March. Brazil already owes the World Bank $8.1 billion and is not seriously behind on those interest payments - new loans would not be considered if it were.

DOC.HEAD: Jailed `Bambi' Bembenek and Fiance Request Permission to Marry
DOC.TEXT: Convicted murderer Lawrencia ``Bambi'' Bembenek and her fiance, Dominic Gugilatto, have asked permission to marry, Canadian jail authorities said. The Milwaukee couple remained in jail Thursday following their arrest last month in this Canadian tourist city. They had lived and worked here after Ms. Bembenek's escape from a Wisconsin prison. Thunder Bay Jail Superintendent John Mackenzie will make a decision on the marriage request Friday morning, hours before Gugliatto is scheduled to be deported to the United States, Deputy jail superintendent Michael Coons said. If their request is approved, Ms. Bembenek and Gugliatto will be married in a large office at the maximum security jail, Coons said. Gugliatto, 35, faces charges in Wisconsin of allegedly aiding and abetting Ms. Bembenek's escape in Fond du Lac in southeastern Wisconsin. The deportation was ordered after Canadian immigration authorities determined that Gugliatto had worked in the country without authorization. A hearing to determine whether Ms. Bembenek will be deported was set for Nov. 22. Ms. Bembenek, a former model, Milwaukee police officer and Playboy club waitress, created a media sensation when she escaped from the Taycheedah Correctional Institution on July 15. Canadian police captured her and Gugliatto on Oct. 17. Ms. Bembenek, 32, was serving a life sentence for the 1981 murder of her former husband's ex-wife. Coons said the couple made the request to get married while in custody earlier this month. A husband-wife privilege that prevents spouses from being compelled to testify against each other probably would not apply in the case of Gugliatto and Ms. Bembenek because all the alleged crimes occurred before marriage, said Fond du Lac County Sheriff's Lt. Ed Sheppard.

DOC.HEAD: CDC: AIDS Risk From Medical Waste Small, But Urges Better Management
DOC.TEXT: The Centers for Disease Control said Thursday the risk of getting AIDS from contact with medical waste is relatively small, but it recommended hospitals try to reduce the amount of waste generated. The waste report was based on a study presented to Congress earlier this fall by the Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, like the CDC an arm of the Department of Health and Human Services. The report, which measured the health impact of medical waste, estimated that a maximum of four AIDS cases a year occur among health care workers who suffer injuries from needles or other sharp objects in waste from hospitals and doctors' offices. That would represent .01 percent of the 35,238 U.S. AIDS cases reported to the CDC in 1989. The study also estimated that as many as 160 hepatitis B cases a year, about .1 percent of the total, may occur because of contact with medical waste. The CDC said the risk of these diseases from medical waste is particularly small for the general public, which usually is not in contact with these materials. Federal health officials in the past have urged health care workers to take precautions, such as wearing protective clothing, when dealing with medical waste. Though the report downplayed the health risk, it and the CDC stressed the need for better management of medical waste, which comprises about .3 percent of the 158 million tons of municipal solid waste created each year in the United States. ``The most effective way of reducing medical waste is to reduce the amount of waste created, on a small scale in homes and on a large scale in health care operations,'' the CDC report said. The CDC urged more emphasis on recycling, reuse and reclamation of medical waste.

DOC.HEAD: Garbo Auctions Provide Glimpse of Her Very Private Life
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with details of sale, EDITS to conform. No pick up.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY38
DOC.TEXT: The surroundings of Greta Garbo's very private life were sold Thursday for higher than expected prices during the last of three auctions. The sales at Sotheby's brought an estimated $20.7 million, including the auction house commission. ``The family is ecstatic,'' said Ted Kurz, lawyer for the Garbo estate. He said the auction showed ``the public remembers Greta Garbo and appreciates the fact that she was a great collector and had a good eye.'' Thursday's sale had been expected to draw about $700,000 to $1 million, but brought $2.5 million. The Tuesday and Wednesday portions of ``The Greta Garbo Collection'' auction brought $18.2 million, with Renoir's 1889 portrait of his nephew fetching the highest price of any one piece - $7 million. In addition, Renoir's ``Leontine and Coco Reading'' brought $5.7 million and Bonnard's ``Corn Poppies'' sold for $3.2 million. Thursday's auction was not about great works of art; it was about the film legend herself and the elegant, serene world the actress created in her Manhattan apartment for 38 years. None of her personal articles was for sale - no slouch hats, dark glasses, Art Deco cigarette holders or turtleneck sweaters. The paintings of rose-filled vases, the gracefully carved Louis XV chairs, the pretty porcelain and enamel boxes and the morroco-bound books by Emerson, Hawthorne, Shelley, Goethe and Schiller make the life of the film legend tangible. ``This is a personal collection. It reflects totally one person's taste, vision, preference,'' Gray Reisfeld, Garbo's niece and the sole benefactor and executor of her estate, wrote in the auction catalog. Garbo died April 15. Small paintings and little porcelain boxes that were estimated to sell for $100 to $200 sold for 30 times that amount. An oil painting of a white terrier, valued at $600 to $800, sold for $17,000. An oil still life of flowers in a basket, valued between $100 and $200, sold for $3,000. The highest price paid for a painting at the sale was $170,000 for ``A Woman in White, Seated,'' an oil on canvas dated 1912 by Albert Andre. ``She was mystical and exciting and extremely gifted,'' Constance Ford said of Garbo, after placing a winning bid of $2,250 for a pottery figure of a clown. Many Garbo fans were disappointed by the auction's high prices. ``I think she would have wanted someone like me to have something, instead of the people who have all the bucks,'' said Sherry Ostrow of West Orange, N.J. Garbo bought most of her paintings, furniture and objets d'art on her legendary walks through Manhattan; in the art and antique shops she frequented, she was known as ``Mrs. Brown'' or simply ``G.G.'' She chose her own colors - mostly roses, salmons and greens - arranged her furniture and hung her paintings herself. ``She had created this refuge and was proud of it,'' Gray oran, Mrs. Reisfield's daughter and Garbo's great-niece, wrote in the auction catalog.

DOC.HEAD: Montana Firefighters Gain on Missouri River Blaze
DOC.TEXT: Helicopters made repeated water drops Thursday on a 34,000-acre wildfire nea the Missouri River in rugged mountain timber considered too dangerous for fire crews to operate on the ground. ``It's not a safe situation to try to put people in, so we're going to try to drown that stuff out,'' said Bob Krepps of the U.S. Forest Service. The aerial assault concentrated on the southern flank of the fire near the boundary between the Gates of the Mountains Wilderness and adjacent Beartooth Game Range in the western Montana Rockies. It was a cool, windy day in western Montana, with temperatures near 40 and gusts up to 30 mph. Stiff westerly winds fanned flames on the fire's eastern flank as well, and crews were sent in to battle flareups, said Dave Turner, a fire information officer at the Interagency Dispatch Center near Helena. ``That's the most remote, the furthest (area of fire) away from the fire camp'' and fire managers were considering setting up an auxiliary or ``spike camp'' to put firefighters closer to the action, Turner said. Officials expressed satisfaction Thursday at progress toward containing the unusual late-season blaze. Turner said it was 20 percent contained by Thursday afternoon. Krepps said that about 10 percent to 15 percent of the total fire area still was burning actively, while the fire had burned itself out on most of the rest of the 34,000 acres. ``We're down to the dirty stuff now of making sure things are secure,'' Krepps said in a telephone interview from the fire command post near Wolf Creek. ``We're hitting the hotter areas today; then it's going to be cleanup for the next couple of days.'' About 400 firefighters were called in to combat the blaze, which broke out Tuesday in the rugged Big Belt Mountains about 35 miles northeast of Helena. Authorities said it appeared to have started accidentally at a hunting camp. At least 30 rural homes were evacuated and about two dozen hunters fled the area Tuesday night, many on horseback. One group of hunters survived the flames by jumping into a mountain creek. Firefighters have been hampered by limited daylight and nighttime temperatures that dipped below freezing, but those same temperatures helped to limit the spread of the fire, Turner said. ``What continues to be the problem are the dry conditions,'' he said. Elsewhere, firefighters were sent home Thursday after containing a 33,000-acre grass and timber fire on the Fort Belknap Indian Reservation, about 190 miles northeast of the Missouri River fire. A skeleton crew of eight to 10 firefighters was to remain at the scene Friday, said Jim Greene, a Department of State Lands official who commanded the firefighters. The fire, which is believed to have started in a landfill near the reservation town of Lodgepole, destroyed a trailer house, a small barn and some outbuildings, and killed one cow, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: Bishops Still Striving to Assuage Difficulties About Women
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `-Approved principles ...' to CLARIFY that principles approved for more gender neutral language.
DOC.HEAD: By GEORGE W. CORNELL
DOC.TEXT: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops were told on Thursday that their long, sidetracked struggle to delineate church rights of women still is ``alive and well.'' After seven years, ``the work continues,'' said Bishop Joseph L. Imesch of Joliet, Ill., head of a committee striving to shape a pastoral letter on women that would be fair to them. Past drafts of the proposed teaching letter have been widely criticized as contradictory in asserting equal standing of women, yet reiterating that they remain ineligible for the most influential role, the priesthood. In a discussion of the difficulties with the letter at the annual meeting of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, Auxiliary Bishop Francis P. Murphy of Baltimore said: ``This is a very unhappy time.'' But he commended the continued grappling with the issue. ``It has raised the consciousness of the church in this country and thrown light on the equal or unequal experience of women in the church and society,'' he said. Action on the letter initially had been scheduled at this week's meeting of the bishops, but this was postponed in September by an administrative committee. In a closing session of their four-day meeting, the bishops also: -Approved principles for more gender neutral language in a new lectionary, the cycle of Bible readings for worship service. Terms such as ``brethren'' would be rendered ``brothers and sisters'' and ``man'' as ``people.'' Also, blanket pejorative references to ``the Jews'' become ``the Jewish authorities'' or ``leaders.'' -Modified a planned pastoral letter on the 1992 observance of the coming of Columbus and Europeans to America, to recognize abuses inflicted on American Indians and blacks. As for the pastoral letter on women, Imesch said, ``I want to erase any doubt about the future'' of the project. He said suggested changes were continuing to be received, and would be considered. Asked afterward if there was any discomfort among the bishops, one of the country's last exclusively male organizations, in trying to define the place of women, he said: ``There's a great deal of uncomfortability.'' He added that there has been much input from women in hearings across the country. But he said ``it would be a miracle'' if the drafters were able to overcome the hurdle of reconciling the principle of women's equality with church rules barring their ordination. But miracles can happen, he added. Dropping of the letter from the bishops' current agenda came after the Vatican suggested prior consultation with bishops conferences in other countries before taking action. Imesch told reporters some suggestions about the letter from Rome might or might not be accepted, adding, ``We may not accept all those locally or from Rome.'' Pope John Paul II at one point ordered no more discussion of the idea of women's ordination.

DOC.HEAD: Scholars Assail Plan To Use Court-Appointed Lawyers in Noriega Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS three grafs after 5th graf, `It's made ...' to UPDATE with Thursday developments. Pick up 6th graf, `The defense ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Scotus-Noriega
DOC.TEXT: Stripping Manuel Noriega of his fortune and forcing him to accept court-appointed lawyers would be unfair and make the U.S. judicial system look bad, some of the nation's top legal scholars say. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler has set a Friday deadline for Noriega's private attorneys to work out payment and resume working on the drug-smuggling case. Otherwise, the judge will appoint government-paid counsel for the deposed Panamanian dictator. The Criminal Justice Act, which governs such appointments, allows for only two or three relatively low-paid lawyers and a few thousand dollars for investigating the case. Noriega's current lawyers object, saying the government reneged on President Bush's pledge to give Noriega a fair trial. Some legal experts agree. ``It's made it an unfair and unbalanced prosecution,'' said Harvard University law Professor Alan Dershowitz. ``It's extremely unfair to take a case where the United States has put incredible resources and ask someone to defend it on the basis of the CJA budget.'' Cable News Network asked Supreme Court Justice Anthony M. Kennedy on Thursday to let it broadcast tape recordings of Noriega's telephone conversations with his lawyers. Network lawyers asked Kennedy to set aside a federal judge's order banning such broadcasts. Kennedy referred the matter to the full court and ordered lawyers for Noriega and the Bush administration to file responses by noon Saturday. The FBI, meanwhile, said it had obtained CNN tapes taken from an Atlanta hotel lost-and-found to see if they include portions of the material involved in the court battle. The network protested that the tapes were obtained without a warrant. The defense estimates that the Justice Department is using 25 to 30 lawyers and will spend up to $30 million to prosecute Noriega. University of Michigan law professor Yale Kamisar said the case's investigative phase is often more important than the trial in a complicated prosecution like Noriega's - and that's precisely where court-appointed lawyers are at a disadvantage. Neal Sonnett, who recently ended a term as president of the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, said the law's allowable budget makes the case ``a mismatch.'' He noted that the case already has shown it is forging new law in many areas - the U.S. invasion of Panama, Noriega's status as a prisoner of war and a head of state, the frozen accounts, and the battle over Cable News Network's broadcast of taped telephone calls. ``In a case of this magnitude, with all the issues at stake, the United States should be bending over backward to ensure Noriega has the lawyers of his choice,'' said Sonnett, who once worked on the Noriega case. William Greenhalgh, a Georgetown University law professor, said the case's prestige may allow the judge to find top-level lawyers prepared to take the case, even at a fraction of their normal rates. But he agreed that the investigative resources are inadequate, and worried that Hoeveler is insisting on a trial by Jan. 28 or shortly thereafter. ``I think it would be most unfortunate if (the judge) pushes whoever he appoints to go to trial before they're ready,'' Greenhalgh said. ``If I got appointed to it, I would be filing a huge motion for continuance.'' Another issue disturbing the experts is that Noriega's pauper status was created by the government. Soon after the invasion of Panama, the Justice Department asked foreign nations to freeze 27 bank accounts holding about $20 million in money allegedly controlled by Noriega. Hoeveler ordered that money freed in June, but prosecutors responded that the foreign governments stepped in with their own confiscation procedures, tying up the money indefinitely. Justice Department spokesmen refused to comment about court-appointment law because of its application to the case. One of the few organizations favoring the law's use in Noriega's case is the conservative Washington Legal Foundation. ``The Sixth Amendment entitles him to adequate counsel,'' said the foundation's chief counsel, Richard Samp. ``It doesn't entitle him to the best counsel he can get in the country.'' But even Samp said he has doubts about freezing Noriega's assets in the first place. ``I have qualms about any pretrial procedures in which the government takes away people's assets,'' he said. ``Noriega ought to have a chance to contest that.'' One lawyer who knows the resources the government will use is Jose Quinon, who unsuccessfully defended Colombian drug lord Carlos Lehder Rivas, now serving a life sentence. Quinon, immediate past president of the Florida Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, estimates Noriega's lawyers would need $750,000 for investigations alone, but will be lucky to get $5,000 or $10,000 under the court appointment law. ``They'll convict him not because of the evidence, but because the defense had inadequate resources,'' said Quinon. Most of the experts agreed that using court-appointed lawyers in the high-profile case will look bad in the glare of international publicity. ``This is the kind of case we should be showing the world how fair we are and what kind of criminal justice system we have,'' Quinon said. ``But this whole thing is now an embarrassment not only for the government, but the courts and society as a whole.''

DOC.HEAD: Challenger Wins California Congressional Seat
DOC.TEXT: Settling Congress' last undecided race, election officials said Thursday that Republican Randy ``Duke'' Cunningham defeated Democratic Rep. Jim Bates. A late tally of absentee ballots gave Cunningham, a former Navy pilot, a total of 50,335 votes, or 46.3 percent, to Bates' 48,676 votes, or 44.8 percent, election officials said. California now has 26 Democrat and 19 Republican representatives, a gain of one seat for the GOP. The results of the Nov. 6 election had been delayed while officials counted thousands of absentee ballots. Authorities said about 200 absentee ballots remained outstanding and would not affect the outcome. Bates, 49, the only Democratic congressman south of the Los Angeles area, had declined to concede defeat. It was his first re-election campaign since the House ethics committee reprimanded him for sexually harassing two female aides. During the campaign, Bates said the reprimand was an old issue. If voters were concerned about it, he said, they would have thrown him out in the June primary or in 1988, when harassment accusations surfaced.

DOC.HEAD: `Imminent Thunder' Begins; Chances Dashed for Arab Summit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Bush comments. Picks up 5th graf, ``Such an ...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Exercise, Bjt
LaserPhoto DHA3
DOC.TEXT: Key national leaders on Thursday rejected a proposed emergency Arab summit to resolve the Persian Gulf crisis. Despite Iraqi protests, U.S. and Saudi forces launched ``Imminent Thunder'' - a six-day amphibious exercise near Kuwait. President Bush, who leaves for Europe and the gulf Friday, said he ordered the big buildup in U.S. military power in the area instead of waiting out Iraq because it is hard to keep public support for a long-term struggle. Bush was replying to a query in an interview with Cable News Network on why he chose to develop a major offensive capability for possible war instead of planning a long stay in Saudi Arabia while economic sanctions cripple Iraq. Two more Americans arrived in Amman, Jordan, on a regularly scheduled flight from Baghdad. A U.S. Embassy spokesman said the two were U.S. diplomats, but it was unclear whether they had worked in Kuwait or Iraq. The Americans arrived along with 24 other foreigners - 22 Irish citizens, one Dutch national and one Briton. They all were medical personnel from a foreign-run hospital in Baghdad. Saddam Hussein said in an interview with ABC-TV he would release the foreign hostages he is holding as ``human shields'' in Iraq and occupied Kuwait only if Bush promises not to attack his country. ``Such an open pledge of this nature - a declared statement of this nature - would be sufficient for us to allow all foreigners to leave Iraq,'' the Iraqi president said. Iraq says it is holding hundreds of foreigners at strategic locations such as military installations to protect against attack. Saddam, interviewed in a government guest house in Baghdad, the Iraqi capital, said he regrets holding the hostages. ``This is the only decision which we have taken which rather chokes us up,'' he said. However, he again asserted that the hostages were his best protection against attack. ``The only justification for this situtation is that the presence of these people may help distract anybody who may opt for war. It may make them hesitate a little before jumping into a decision of this nature,'' he said. As for dialogue with the United States, Saddam said he was unwilling to meet Bush's demand that Iraq unconditionally withdraw from Kuwait. ``This is not dialogue. These are preconditions imposed to insure our capitulation,'' he said. ``We reject such preconditions.'' The official Iraqi News Agency announced Thursday that Bush would go ``on trial'' in absentia next month in Algeria - for ``inhuman policies and planning aggression against the people of Iraq.'' The trial will begin Dec. 10 in Algiers, INA said, in what it called an international court of justice. It said the verdict would be relayed to U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar and international groups concerned with human rights. Iraq first spoke of putting Bush on trial in September, after Western leaders said Saddam should be tried for war crimes. Presidents Hafez Assad of Syria and Hosni Mubarak of Egypt became the latest Arab leaders to reject the emergency Arab summit, which was billed by the king of Morocco as perhaps the ``last chance'' for peace. Saudi Arabia said Wednesday it would not participate in the meeting unless Baghdad promised beforehand to leave Kuwait, which it invaded Aug. 2. Iraq made it clear that no such promise was forthcoming. In a joint statement released in Damascus, Assad and Mubarak said they also rejected the idea because of Iraq's intransigence. And in Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait's government-in-exile also objected, citing Iraq's refusal to withdraw. The objections effectively killed chances for the summit. A few Arab League members, including Sudan and the Palestine Liberation Organization, had agreed to Morocco's proposal. Both Syria and Egypt have contributed troops to the 300,000-strong U.S.-led multinational force confronting Iraq. The appeal on Sunday by King Hassan II of Morocco for Arab leaders to gather provoked a flurry of diplomatic activity. Among those trying to promote the summit was the Soviet Union, which sent high-level envoys to the Middle East this week to discuss the idea. While the exact location of Imminent Thunder, which began Thursday, was not revealed, and a news blackout was imposed for the initial phases of the operation, a Pentagon spoesman said in Washington the exercise was based in eastern Saudi Arabia, about 100 miles from Kuwait. The operation involves 1,000 U.S. Marines, 1,100 aircraft and 16 ships. Iraq has termed it a ``provocative act'' because it is being held close to occupied Kuwait. There have been three previous amphibious exercises in the Persian Gulf, but they were believed to have been held farther south. On Wednesday, the Washington Times reported Imminent Thunder would be held 10 miles from Kuwait. No live ammunition will be fired in the operation, U.S. officials say. But it will involve the largest use of aircraft in a single training exercise since U.S. forces were deployed in the region in August. Imminent Thunder is not intended to provoke the Iraqis, said U.S. Navy spokesman Cmdr. J.D. Van Sickle. ``The purpose is to give participating forces training in joint and combined operations and to enhance amphibious warfare skills,'' he said. Military officials said there was no particular significance to the name of the operation and that its timing was not linked to any operational plans. The United States has doubled the number of aircraft carriers in the gulf region to six, and ordered in about 200,000 additional military personnel to join the estimated 230,000 already deployed. The multinational force arrayed against Iraq numbers more than 300,000. In other developments, Secretary of State James A. Baker III headed Thursday to Brussels, on his way to yet another round of consultations with foreign leaders. Baker was to meet Friday with the 12-nation European Community, which is providing aid to countries that have been hit hard by the trade embargo against Iraq. Over the weekend, he was to meet with the foreign ministers of three African countries as well as Romania and Finland. Elsewhere on the diplomatic front, Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati was in Iraq on Thursday, meeting with Saddam and visiting Moslem shrines. Velayati, the highest-ranking Iranian to visit Iraq since the 1979 Islamic revolution in Iran, said he had made it clear to Saddam and other senior officials that Tehran wanted Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. The two countries fought each other for nearly a decade during the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war.

DOC.HEAD: Caution Advised After Chitlins Make Atlanta Kids Sick
DOC.TEXT: Federal health officials warn those with a taste for the Southern delicacy chitterlings, pork intestines also known as chitlins, avoid touching children while preparing the dish. The warning from the federal Centers for Disease Control follows an outbreak of gastroenteritis among Atlanta area children during the 1988-89 winter holidays. Fifteen children got sick, the CDC said. The infecting organism, Yersinia enterocolitica 0:3, was transferred from raw chitterlings to the children mainly through contact with food preparers. The organism, present in many chitterlings, causes fever, diarrhea and abdominal pain, the CDC said. The CDC advises that those preparing chitterlings should carefully wash their hands before touching children or anything used by children and avoid letting children touch the raw chitterlings.

DOC.HEAD: Church Leader Asks Bush to Talk Peace
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with council voting to urge halt to military building in Persian Gulf; EDITS to conform. No pick up.
DOC.TEXT: The National Council of Churches voted Friday to urge the United States to halt its military buildup in the Persian Gulf and begin withdrawing troops from the region. The only U.S. troops that should stay are ``those which might be required and explicitly recommended by the Security Council of the United Nations,'' the church council said in a policy statement approved at its convention. ``We stand at a unique moment in human history, when all around us seemingly impregnable walls are being broken down and deep historical enmities are being healed,'' the council said. ``And yet, ironically, at such a moment our own nation seems to be poised at the brink of war in the Middle East.'' The council said President Bush and Congress should use every means to try to reach a peaceful settlement in the Persian Gulf, including direct negotiations with Iraq. The council also expressed support for the holding of a U.N. international conference aimed at reaching a comprehensive peace in the Middle East. And it reiterated its opposition to the withholding of food and medicine from Iraq, but added that it generally supports the U.N. sanctions against Iraq. The council urged Iraq to release immediately all foreigners held against their will in Kuwait or Iraq and called on Iraq to immediately withraw its troops from Kuwait. The vote came after the head of a group of Christian churches in the Middle East urged the council to launch a united effort to seek peace in the Middle East. ``Many people forget that Christianity came from the Middle East,'' said Gabriel Habib, general secretary of the Middle East Council of Churches. ``How can we say to other people, `Love each other, live in peace,' if we don't have peace'' where Christianity began. The Middle East Council is a sister group of the national council, which represents more than 42 million members of Protestant and Eastern Orthodox denominations in the United States. Habib also urged President Bush to talk directly to Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein. Bush risks taking the blame for any war if he appears unwilling to exhaust all peaceful ways to remove Iraqi troops from Kuwait, Habib said. The best route to a settlement, he said, lies with the United Nations because it involves a cooperative effort among all nations. In other business, the national council nominated a New York City minister to become the first woman to lead the council since it was founded 40 years ago. The Rev. Joan Brown Campbell, 58, was chosen by a 29-member search committee to become general secretary. She was formally nominated for the post Wednesday. An election was expected to approve the nomination Thursday or Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Workers for San Francisco Newspapers Threaten Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT they to their; INSERTS one graf after 11th graf, `Cuthbertson said ...' to ADD top scale for reporters; SUBS penultimate graf, `The last ....' to CORRECT Examiner and Chronicle both hit by strike in 1968, sted one newspaper.
DOC.TEXT: About 4,500 workers at the three largest San Francisco Bay area daily newspapers threatened to go on strike Friday for the first time since the 1960s unless their pay increase demands are met. Negotiators for the San Francisco Chronicle, San Francisco Examiner, San Jose Mercury News and unions met Thursday with a federal mediator to discuss a union demand for a 20 percent salary boost. The newspapers, which together have a daily circulation of more than 1 million, completed settlement of non-economic issues during an all-night session. About a dozen unions, representing workers from reporters to delivery drivers to press operators set a 5 p.m. Friday strike deadline last week. Union leaders Thursday asked reporters to begin withholding their bylines from stories as a show of solidarity. ``Our leverage on the newspaper is the holiday season when ad revenues are usually up,'' said Nell Chethik, chairman of the Newspaper Guild local for the Mercury News. Richard Jordan, chief negotiator for the San Francisco Newspaper Agency, which prints the Examiner and Chronicle, said: ``I'm confident we'll resolve this without a strike.'' Doug Cuthbertson, chairman of the Conference of Newspaper Unions, added, ``Time is runing short; It's going to be very tough.'' In New York, workers at the Daily News have been on strike since Oct. 25. The News brought in replacement workers and as the shutdown spread to include about 2,100 employees. The News has continued to publish since the violence-plagued strike began, using replacement workers, Newspaper Guild members who crossed picket lines and management. Most of the Bay area unions have worked without a contract since Feb. 2. Workers voted Oct. 29 to authorize a strike. The walkout deadline was set Nov. 9 after management refused to consider the union wage proposal for a 20 percent pay hike and four-day work week. Cuthbertson said the request ``was high, but you've got to start somewhere.'' Management had not made a salary proposal public but ``we won't be proposing any wage freeze either,'' Jordan said. The top scale for reporters at all three newspapers is $800 a week. Knight-Ridder, a multi-media conglomerate that owns the Mercury News, earned a profit last year of $247 million with the Pulitzer prize-winning Mercury News accounting for about 25 percent, analysts said. Revenue estimates weren't available for two San Francisco newspapers, privately held by the Hearst and Thieriot families, but the unions and an analyst with Duff & Phelps Inc. of Chicago, said both are profitable. The previous three-year contract for all three newspapers gave employees a 3 percent to 5 percent annual raise. John Hammett, a Mercury News senior vice president, said he was speaking for all three newspapers and the initial union pay increase proposal was outrageous. The morning Chronicle, weekday circulation of about 560,000, publishes jointedly with the Examiner on Sunday for a combined circulation of about 725,000. The afternoon Examiner has a weekday circulation of about 138,000. The two 125-year-old papers entered into a Joint Operating Agreement in 1965 with only the editorial departments separate. The last San Francisco newspaper strike came in 1968 when the Examiner and the Chronicle didn't publish for 55 days. The last strike at the San Jose Mercury News came in 1959 when the paper didn't publish for four months. The newspaper has a daily circulation of about 275,000 during the week and about 329,000 on Sundays.

DOC.HEAD: Holocaust Writer Adolf Rudnicki Dies
DOC.TEXT: Adolf Rudnicki, a leading Polish writer and essayist known for his complex characters and his depictions of Jews during the Holocaust, has died in Warsaw, PAP news agency reported Thursday. He was 78. Rudnicki, whose works were translated into English, French, Hebrew, German and Russian, died Wednesday. His novels include ``The Golden Windows'' and ``The Merchant of Lodz,'' which focus on the theme of Jewish suffering and resistance. Although his best known works were published after World War II, Rudnicki gained an audience in Poland in the 1930s with his novels ``The Unloved,'' a psychological study of two people in love, and ``The Rats.'' Rudnicki escaped being killed as a Jew under the Nazi occupation and survived to fight in the 1944 Warsaw Uprising. His wartime experiences permeated his work. PAP. called his ``Epoch of the Ovens,'' a series of short stories, ``one of the most explicit testimonies'' on the Holocaust, in which about 6 million Jews were killed by Hitler's Germany. According to one survey of contemporary Polish culture: ``The deepest aspect of Rudnicki's work is keeping faith with the persecuted and their fate. ... Their fate, a sort of death sentence, is shown in a biblical perspective - a chosen people and a doomed people.'' No information was immediately available on survivors or funeral arrangements.

DOC.HEAD: N.J. Governor Tells Mayors He Wants 8 Percent State Budget Cutback
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Jim Florio said Thursday he will cut 8 percent from the New Jersey budget this year instead of waiting a year. The governor said results of the Nov. 6 election in New Jersey showed him he needs to demonstrate state government will cut back immediately if a $2.8 billion tax increase is to prove palatable. Florio's fellow Democrats performed poorly or lost on Election Day, which analysts saw as a voter protest to the tax hike. The 8 percent cut will affect all 19 state departments and could include layoffs, Florio said. He would not speculate on how many layoffs could occur among the 87,000 state employees or which departments, if any, might be eliminated. ``We need to accelerate that cutting process if we're going to respond to the people's challenge,'' Florio said. ``We need to start saving money right now and not just be talking about it.'' Florio asked officials gathered for a luncheon of the New Jersey League of Municipalities to keep local spending down in conjunction with the state's effort to cut costs. Florio suggested regionalization, the combining of services provided by separate localities, as one way of cutting expenses and thus reducing property tax increases. ``Property taxes soared by 108 percent during the last decade,'' he said. ``That's intolerable. It destroys communities and drives people out of the neighborhoods they helped build.''

DOC.HEAD: Hal Holbrook Stars as King Lear
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned.
DOC.TEXT: Hal Holbrook is a towering King Lear - an old man who slips in and out of sanity but who never forgets that he is king and accustomed to having every word obeyed. One doesn't see Holbrook or his portrayals of Mark Twain or Abe Lincoln in Shakespeare's ``King Lear'' on the off-Broadway Roundabout stage. One sees Lear. In the play, which opened Thursday, Holbrook's Lear sometimes pulls himself back from madness through strength of will. His hand shakes at moments of anxiety and he shouts with authority when he has lost power. But when when Cordelia is killed, he lays her down, gently smooths her hair and makes the audience share a parent's unbearable pain at the death of a beloved child. The production, directed by Gerald Freedman, doesn't have a static moment. Audience attention can't flag; somebody or something on stage is always moving. The evening's second most interesting performance is by Margery Murray as Regan. John Woodson is on target as the Earl of Kent, disguised as a hearty servant of King Lear. Ron Randell is the other unwise old father, Gloucester. Christopher McCann is a sharp-beaked, bright-eyed chicken of a person as Lear's fool, Gary Sloan properly insolent as Goneril's steward. The words explain the duplicity of Gloucester's son Edmund (John Hutton) but one doesn't feel the evil personality underneath when he's lying to his father. Edgar, the brother Edmund is trying to kill, is called too good to suspect evil. But Michael James-Reed, though he hops around effectively in Edgar's near-nude disguise as Poor Tom, plays Edgar as too much of a wimp. Gloria Biegler looks right as Cordelia - the excellent costumes are by Robert Wojewodski - but has a bit of debutante manner. Holbrook first played ``King Lear'' in May in Cleveland. The play, which opens the Roundabout's 25th anniversary season, runs here through Dec. 9. Peter Aylward, who has a small role in the production, plays Lear at Wednesday matinees.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam: Hostages to Be Released Only If Bush Pledges No Attack
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS lede and INSERTS grafs 8-13 bgng: ``On other,'' further comments on nuclear weapons, terrorism; DELETES last four grafs to trim
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein said Thursday he would release his foreign hostages only if President Bush promises not to attack his country and claimed that he needs nuclear weapons to balance what he said were Israel's. ``Such an open pledge of this nature - a declared statement of this nature - would be sufficient for us to allow all foreigners to leave Iraq,'' the Iraqi president said in an interview with ABC-TV. The Iraqi government says it is holding hundreds of foreigners at strategic locations such as military installations to protect against attack. Hundreds also have also been released intermittently the past few months, many at the request of individual envoys. Saddam, interviewed in a government guest house in Baghdad, the Iraqi capital, said he regrets holding the hostages. ``This is the only decision which we have taken which rather chokes us up,'' he said. ``Not for fear of anybody but out of this sense of respect for humanity.'' However, he again asserted that the hostages were his best protection against attack. ``The only justification for this situtation is that the presence of these people may help distract anybody who may opt for war. It may make them hesitate a little before jumping into a decision of this nature,'' he said. On other topics, Saddam was asked why he sought nuclear weapons. ``Because Israel is in possession of chemical, biological and nuclear weapons. And Israel is following a policy of expansion at the expense of the Arabs,'' he replied through an interpreter. ``So the way we see it is that peace sometimes dictates for a kind of balance to be drawn.'' Iraq has made several attempts to acquire equipment and technology useful for producing nuclear weapons. In two notable instances, U.S. and British authorities blocked a shipment of fast-acting electrical switches, and U.S. authorities seized high-temperature ovens that authorities said could have been used for nuclear devices. Though many analysts have concluded that Israel either has or could quickly produce nuclear weapons, Israel has never admitted having them and has said Israel will not be the first to introduce them into the Middle east The Arab fight against Israel also formed the basis of Saddam's defenseof sheltering two men accused of many terrorist attacks: Abu Nidal and Abu Abbas. Though the two may make ``mistakes,'' he said, ``Our view of them is different from the way we view the same mistakes made by someone whose land has not been occupied ... These are freedom fighters and not highwaymen.'' Bush has been leading the international stand against Iraq's Aug. 2 takeover of neighboring Kuwait. More than 300,000 soldiers from 26 nations, including 230,000 from the United States, have massed in the gulf region. Last week Bush ordered in another 200,000 U.S. soldiers. Asked whether he was willing to discuss the Mideast crisis with other leaders, Saddam said: ``We have been ready all along.'' As for dialogue with the United States, Saddam said he was unwilling to meet Bush's demand that Iraq unconditionally withdraw from Kuwait before any discussions. ``This is not dialogue. These are preconditions imposed to insure our capitulation,'' he said. ``We reject such preconditions.'' Asked whether his position in Kuwait is negotiable, he said, ``When I say something I mean it.'' He did not elaborate.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Loses, Then Regains Contact With Magellan; Venus Mapping Halted
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Mapping was ...' to UPDATE with mapping resumed.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: NASA lost contact with Magellan for 40 minutes Thursday, halting the spacecraft's Venus-mapping mission for most of the day as a nagging malfunction resurfaced for the third time in three months. Engineers sent new commands to the spacecraft, successfully pointing its main antenna toward Earth so it could resume its $744 million mission to make radar pictures and maps of Venus, said Steve Saunders, Magellan's chief scientist at Jet Propulsion Laboratory. Magellan normally loses contact with Earth during part of each orbit of Venus. But shortly after 9 a.m. PST, a ground tracking station failed to regain Magellan's radio signal, meaning contact was lost completely, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said in a statement. Contact was restored 40 minutes later when engineers locked onto a radio signal that gives them information about the spacecraft's health. The main, dish-shaped antenna still was pointed away from Earth by a scant 1{ degrees. The antenna must be aimed precisely at Earth so Magellan's pictures of Venus can be transmitted to Earth at a very high speed using a narrow-beam radio signal. Mapping was halted for most of the day until the new commands made Magellan point its antenna properly. Mapping resumed Thursday night. Magellan was launched from space shuttle Atlantis on May 4, 1989, and went into orbit around Venus on Aug. 10. NASA lost contact with the spacecraft for roughly 11 hours starting Aug. 16, just hours after Magellan made its first test pictures of Venus. Communications broke down for another 17 hours beginning Aug. 21. Engineers repeatedly warned they might lose touch with Magellan again, but Thursday's blackout was the first since Magellan formally started its map-making mission Sept. 15. ``I always get really worried about these things, but I know in my heart we can expect this to happen, and it's going to happen again,'' Saunders said, adding that the engineers ``deserve a lot of praise'' for restoring contact with Magellan so quickly Thursday. Engineers still haven't learned the cause of the previous radio blackouts, but a similar event probably caused Thursday's loss of contact, NASA said. However, Thursday's blackout lasted only a short time because of improvements in Magellan's safety systems that were made following the August breakdowns, NASA said. At the time of Thursday's malfunction, Magellan had orbited Venus 713 times and made pictures of the planet during 338 of those orbits, experiment representative Steve Wall said.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Driver Pleads Guilty in Wild Ride
DOC.TEXT: A replacement Greyhound bus driver who told passengers he hadn't ``killed anybody yet'' as the bus hurtled across western Montana and northern Idaho has pleaded guilty to inattentive driving. Nick F. Eisenbarth, 29, of Spokane had been scheduled to stand trial Wednesday on a charge of reckless driving, but pleaded guilty to the lesser offense in an arrangement with prosecutors. Eisenbarth was fined $300 and sentenced to two days in jail with credit for one day served. The plea bargain was reached because all the witnesses were from out of state and it would have been too expensive to bring them to Idaho for Eisenbarth's trial, said Robyn Dvorak, Kootenai County deputy prosecutor. Greyhound Lines fired Eisenbarth after learning of the incident, which occurred July 19 on a run from Missoula, Mont., to Seattle, a company official said. He was arrested after authorities were tipped off by a passenger who got off the bus in Coeur d'Alene. The bus line's 6,000 drivers went on strike March 2 over a dispute in wages and job security. Eisenbarth was hired as a replacement driver. Kootenai County sheriff's deputies spotted the bus speeding west from Coeur d'Alene. After following the bus for two miles, deputies ordered it to pull over. Frightened passengers said Eisenbarth drove at speeds up to 80 mph. The bus nearly sideswiped several tractor-trailers, tailgated slower-moving cars until they changed lanes and sped through a tight curve along Lake Coeur d'Alene at 20 mph over the posted speed limit, passengers said. Passengers also said the driver got the bus stuck in a driveway and cursed riders who complained about his driving. ``I haven't killed anybody yet,'' he was quoted as saying. During the ride, Eisenbarth said he couldn't slow down because he had to stick to his schedule, passengers told authorities. The bus arrived in Coeur d'Alene 30 minutes early, a police report said. Four of the 38 passengers complained of back and neck injuries after being tossed around during the three-hour ride.

DOC.HEAD: Mitsubishi Entering U.S. Luxury Car Market
DOC.TEXT: Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America Inc. said Thursday it's entering the American luxury car market with the Diamante sedan. The Diamante, named after the Spanish word for diamond, will be an American version of the Mitsubishi Motors' Diamante sold in Japan, spokesman Kim Custer said. The car will cost between $20,000 and $30,000, he said. The Diamante is expected in U.S. dealer showrooms in April 1991 as a 1992 model, Custer said.
