DOC.HEAD: War Powers Ambiguity Likely To Last Through This Gulf Crisis
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: When Democratic leaders looked at the prospect of an emergency session of Congress on the Persian Gulf crisis, they saw an old, intractable dilemma over warmaking power. So Congress will investigate instead of trying to legislate. A question of presidential and congressional powers that has gone unresolved for 200 years isn't about to be settled in a special session while U.S. forces are at risk against Iraq. There have been repeated attempts to amend the creaky, usually irrelevant war powers system that already is on the lawbooks, none successful. And what couldn't be done in tranquil times, when the issues were hypothetical, can hardly be accomplished in the midst of a giant military buildup in the Middle East. When congressional leaders reminded President Bush that Congress has the power to declare war, he took out his own copy of the Constitution, said he understood that, and reminded them that it also makes him commander in chief. He also said he has made no decision to take military action and would consult with them before using force. While he made no commitment to seek congressional action in advance of a response to Iraqi provocation, his assurances satisfied the Democrats, at least for the time being. So the push for a special session of Congress to debate and act on the Gulf crisis - an idea launched by Republicans - has been shelved. There will be congressional hearings on the administration's military and diplomatic policy toward Iraq. And the administration has repeated its promise of continuing consultation with House and Senate leaders. The escalated debate last week was prompted by the president's plans to nearly double the size of the U.S. force deployed in Saudi Arabia and the Gulf, reinforcements the administration said would provide an offensive capability for use if needed. That seemed to be a threat aimed at Saddam Hussein, to turn up the pressure for Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. But the message stirred concern in Congress, where Democrats like Sen. Sam Nunn of Georgia, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, said there had been a fundamental change in policy, to an offensive mission of liberating Kuwait. He said that was a casebook example of a situation in which Congress should be called upon for a declaration of war - something that has happened only five times in U.S. history. Republican Sen. Richard Lugar of Indiana took the lead in proposing a special session of Congress, which he said should act to authorize U.S. operations in a manner that would display American unity and staying power. The White House said a special session was unnecessary because there is no war and the president wants to avoid one. And the Democrats weren't enthusiastic about the idea, either. Sen. George J. Mitchell, D-Maine, the majority leader, said there should be no special session without a clearly defined purpose. Speaker of the House Thomas S. Foley said he wasn't going to put Democrats in a potentially embarrassing position. Congress already has voted its overwhelming approval to the Persian Gulf operation, in resolutions adopted in October that declare support for continued action by the president ``to deter Iraqi aggression and protect American lives and vital interests,'' in accord with United Nations decisions and with U.S. legal requirements. Mitchell said there was no way to read into the October resolutions any approval for offensive military action. They were adopted only after repeated declarations that Congress was not approving anything like the Gulf of Tonkin resolution, the 1964 measure later cited by the White House as the equivalent of a declaration of war in Vietnam. The Democratic preference is to wait while international economic sanctions take their toll on Iraq and, presumably, force Saddam to yield, it takes 18 months or more. While Republican congressional leaders say that's too long, the White House isn't talking about specific time frames, only about maintaining the pressure on Saddam Hussein. And, as Mitchell said, that doesn't take congressional approval. ``Obviously ... a president need not get a prior act of Congress to issue a threat,'' Mitchell said. He is supposed to get approval for deployment of American forces in hostilities ``or into situations where imminent involvement in hostilities is clearly indicated.'' That's the 1973 war powers law, enacted over presidential veto, opposed by every administration since. That measure requires congressional approval in order to keep U.S. forces in such circumstances for more than 90 days, but it never has been enforced. In this case, Bush advised Congress that he did not believe involvement in hostilities was imminent. That stands, although the troops involved are receiving the additional pay that goes with facing possible hostilities. Force, after all, is an administration option, ``a clear and unmistakable signal,'' according to Secretary of State James A. Baker III. The challenge to Bush is to keep the pressure on by making that worry Iraq without shaking his backing at home. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Building Blocks of Bandelier Threatened
DOC.TEXT: Caves were a cinch to carve in the soft volcanic-ash face of Bandelier, meaning these centuries-old Indian ruins are just as easily erased by fire and erosion. ``The erosion itself is starting to threaten some of the ruins in the back country, and that is unacceptable,'' said Roy Weaver, superintendent of Bandelier National Monument, the park in the Jemez Mountains 45 miles west of Santa Fe. The park boasts 3,000 to 5,000 archaeological sites dating from 1100 to 1760, including remnants of three-story pueblos that had as many as 400 rooms. But time, weather and the effects of man's encroachment are slowly eating away at Bandelier's building blocks. Outside the visitors center in Frijoles Canyon are the ruins of a village called Tyuonyi, an ellipse of dwellings around a central religious chamber, or kiva, into which people descended by ladder. Tourists may stroll through Tyuonyi on an asphalt path and peer down into the excavated kiva. They also may visit dwellings carved into the soft volcanic ash, or tuff, on the north wall of Frijoles Canyon. ``With primitive tools - like a good, hard oak stick - you could literally hack yourself a cave into the walls,'' said Bob Powers, a National Park Service archaeologist who is heading a study of Bandelier. Ladders are provided for visitors to climb into some caves. One series of ladders leads to a restored kiva cut 140 feet high in the cliff's face. Visitors may enter the kiva. Last year, 322,000 people wandered through, Weaver said. In contrast, Frijoles Canyon had a population of probably no more than 700 people at its peak, around 1300 to 1550, Powers said. Around 1550, Tyuonyi was abandoned. The reasons remain unclear. ``My gut feeling is that a combination of overhunting, overuse of natural resources, a growing population and a lot of competition from other pueblos throughout the Rio Grande Valley may have made the area not very viable economically,'' Powers said. Cochiti Pueblo, still flourishing nearby, is believed to have evolved from this settlement. A Cochiti Indian first led Swiss-born anthropologist Adolf Bandelier into cave-studded Frijoles Canyon in 1880, who called it ``the grandest thing I ever saw.'' His 150th birthday, Aug. 6, was celebrated this summer at the park, which will be 75 years old in February. Powers' crews completed their fourth year of field work here in August and return in the spring for their final year. Their findings have yet to be analyzed. ``Our major focus is to try and figure out why the big pueblos that appear in the early 1300s, why those were built,'' said Powers. ``Why did they all move in together in these big communal pueblos?'' That was a major change in their cultural habits, he said. ``One factor almost certainly is a growing population,'' he said. ``As population increases, there are not as many resources.'' The crews have been mapping the thousands of caves and other ruins that dot the monument's 32,737 acres, trying to stay ahead of the erosion that periodically sheers off pieces of the cliff. ``We have two kinds of erosion. One is visitor-induced. The other is based on previous land-management abuses,'' he said. ``This goes back over 100 years. Because of the overgrazing and the elimination of fire, the natural grasses which were quite extensive at the time have been eliminated.'' He said overgrazing stopped 60 years ago, but much of the damage already was done. ``The ground is uncovered, and erosion is occurring. We're losing in some areas a tenth of an inch (of soil) per year right now,'' he said. A management statement published last April said: ``The erosion problem must be addressed immediately or severe, irreversible damage will occur to the park's pinon-juniper ecosystems and possibly to thousands of associated archaeological sites.'' Weaver said he doesn't know what the federal budget has in store for him, so he doesn't know what crews will be able to do about erosion. Controlled burning, thinning of too-dense trees and replanting grasses all take money. Fire-suppression has caused an overproliferation of pinon and juniper, scrub trees that actually heighten fire danger, Weaver said. In 1977, a fire burned through ruins on nearby Escobas Mesa. The intense heat and firefighting efforts that included heavy equipment turned much of the ruins into dust, said Judy Miles, field director for the archaeological study. Those ruins, like Tyuonyi and the other ancient villages of Bandelier, had been made of bricks of tuff, Powers and Miles said. The tuff was created by two series of cataclysmic eruptions 1.4 million and 1.1 million years ago that formed the nearby Valles Caldera. Tuff is a mixture of frothy glass bubbles, glass shards, crystal fragments and bits of rock, said Wolf Elston, a geologist at the University of New Mexico. Heat bursts the bubbles, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Panic Attacks Keep Thousands From Malls, Off Roads
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Americans are too afraid to get into their cars, shop at the mall or even venture out of the house, worried they'll suffer a panic attack. ``It's a horrible feeling,'' said Ann, a 51-year-old Richmond real estate agent. ``I feel like I'm losing control. I feel like the world around me doesn't exist and I feel like I'm going to die.'' Ann, who asked that her last name be withheld, said the panic attacks began when she was about 8, but she was too afraid to tell anyone. ``I didn't even tell my parents,'' she said. ``We're very good at faking things. I didn't know whether I was mentally unbalanced. People with panic attacks are good liars, good excuse-makers.'' Ann had trouble going to the beauty parlor or sitting through a Sunday church service. She started avoiding the places where she had the attacks, places where she felt closed in. About 3 million people suffer from panic attacks, said Dr. William T. Riley, co-director of the Anxiety Disorders Clinic at the Medical College of Virginia. ``Most people have experienced at least one or two panic attacks in their lifetime,'' he said. ``For it to be something that we consider a disorder, that we need to treat, people need to experience about one a week.'' The symptoms often mimic a heart attack. They include chest pain, shortness of breath, dizziness, trembling and sweating, nausea and abdominal distress. The disorder is known as agoraphobia when people start avoiding places where they experience the attacks. Panic disorders seem to develop primarily in people in their 20s, Riley said. It can strike anywhere, anytime. Evidence suggests people inherit a predisposition to panic attacks. Othe factors indicate outside stress contributes to the problem. ``A lot of the people who have panic disorders had problems with separation from mom and dad early on,'' he said. ``They had difficulty with being left at the baby sitter, difficulty going to school by themselves.'' The attack can last 15 to 30 minutes, and more often than not, people can disguise the fact that they're having one. ``On the outside, all they'll usually see in these folks is that they look hotter, more sweaty. They'll shake a little bit and have some difficulty talking. ``A lot of time they can keep working or hold it together.'' The two most frequent things people with panic attacks avoid are driving and shopping malls. ``They're real afraid of being trapped and having this panic attack happen in front of a bunch of people, where they can't get out,'' Riley said. ``Malls are very crowded and there aren't a lot of exits. They're OK in a shopping center. They can get to the doors quick.'' This month, the Food and Drug Administration approved the first medication for the treatment of panic disorders. Xanax, known generically as alprazolam, had been used to treat clinical anxiety and anxiety associated with depression. The drug is manufactured by Upjohn Co. of Kalamazoo, Mich. Executives there said a biochemical malfunctioning in the brain is believed to be one of the causes of panic attacks. Xanax can block the attacks by interacting with several different systems in the brain. Patients also must learn how to control their behavior, Riley said. They learn relaxation techniques, they learn how to talk themselves out of the episode. Then, they begin to try to tackle the things they're most fearful of. ``If they're fearful of driving because they started to have these panic attacks, we start working on the drive,'' he said. ``If they're fearful of going to the mall, a first step may be nothing more than driving there, sitting in the parking lot for five minutes and going back home.'' Agoraphobics also attend support group sessions. For example, in Richmond about 700 people belong to Agoraphobics Building Independent Lives. The treatment is effective about 70 percent to 80 percent of the time, Riley said. Ann, who has been working closely with Riley, said she has gotten to the point where she can go to the grocery store, a discount store and even the beauty salon. ``I took my car through the carwash by myself two weeks ago,'' she said. ``I'm still having trouble with the interstates, because you can't get off of them until the exits.'' Her most recent assignment was to drive the interstate a little each day. ``You take a little bit at a time,'' she said. ``If you do it without anxiety, you've really done something.''

DOC.HEAD: Science Focuses on Sweet Potatoes
DOC.TEXT: Scientists are searching for ways to improve the humble sweet potato, a nutritious vegetable that may have a future beyond the Thanksgiving table - in fancy restaurants and outer space. Melvin Hall, a horticulturist at the University of Georgia's Coastal Plain Experiment Station in Tifton, said scientists in several states are trying to develop new varieties that give growers higher yields and are more resistant to insects and diseases. Sweet potatoes, a subterranean relative of morning glories, are high in carbohydrates and vitamins, and Hall believes they could appeal more to health-conscious consumers. ``A lot of time people think sweet potatoes are things you eat when you're about to starve to death,'' he said. ``We'd like to think of the sweet potato as something you can find in a fancy restaurant.'' Hall tries to develop improved varieties through genetics research. Each year, he plants 10 to 12 acres and then evaluates the results. He bakes and tastes the most promising sweet potatoes. He said it's difficult to conduct genetics research with sweet potatoes because they have six sets of chromosomes, compared to only two in humans. ``It's complicated to mathematically figure out what will happen,'' he said. ``We have to have thousands and thousands of seeds to come up with new genetic combinations that might be better than what we already have.'' Scientists in North and South Carolina, Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama are conducting similar breeding tests. Researchers in other states share information on yields and quality. Hall said scientists at Tuskegee University in Alabama are working with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration on a sweet potato for space. The sweet potato is one of the few plants that is 100 percent edible, and space travelers could eat the stems and leaves, leaving no waste. ``We don't normally think of the vines, but in some parts of the world, they're considered a delicacy,'' Hall said. The most popular variety is the Jewel, a sweet potato that has been around for at least 20 years. Scientists released the Beauregard a few years ago in Louisiana, but growers are still evaluating it. North Carolina is the nation's top producer. Louisiana is second, and Georgia, California and Texas vie for third. With the emphasis on health foods, Hall said, people are beginning to see the benefits of eating sweet potatoes, which are used in soups, souffles and ice cream. ``I think the interest in health will at least keep the consumption level stable and hopefully ... people will come to see these as not only healthy, but delightful,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Turkey Struts Its Stuff Year Round Nowadays
DOC.TEXT: Ben Franklin wanted the turkey to be our national bird, for some reason finding it more respectable than the eagle. He failed, but Americans are gobbling up turkey like never before. It now appears as sausage, ground up, as cutlets or as boned roasts, cooked into meatloaf, cut up in salads, tossed with pastas or piled onto sandwiches. Thirty years ago, 90 percent of all turkey sold in the United States was consumed in November and December, according to the National Turkey Federation. Today, health-conscious consumers are drawn to turkey's low fat content (as little as a third that of beef), and 60 percent of our turkey is eaten during the other 10 months of the year. Annual consumption has jumped from 10 pounds per person in 1980 to an estimated 19 pounds this year. At this time of year, however, it is the groaning Thanksgiving table that the turkey most often graces. Rick Rodgers, author of ``The Turkey Cookbook,'' estimates 45 million whole turkeys are eaten that one day. Rodgers offers 14 recipes for cooking the whole bird, including Texas turkey with chili powder, peppers and onions; a Bayou-style roast turkey; and an Italian version with lemon, rosemary and roasted potatoes. But he says the juciest, crispest turkey is roasted unstuffed, with herbs and aromatic vegetables placed in the cavities. November is the busiest month for the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Meat and Poultry Hot Line, with 16,000 calls last November. About half the callers talked to a person; the rest heard recorded messages on food safety, said the hot line's manager, Susan D. Templin. The privately operated Butterball Turkey Talk-Line already has ``had just a deluge of calls this year,'' said Marge Klindera, assistant supervisor. She cites a few reasons for the early calls: the popularity of turkey, troubles getting through when the line was busy last year, and a calendar Butterball is giving away. In its 10th year, the Turkey Talk-Line could receive its millionth call this season, Klindera said. It is staffed by 44 nutritionists and home economists. Some recommendations for handling turkey: - To thaw a frozen turkey, keep it refrigerated one day for each five pounds. Or place it in its wrapping in a sink and cover with cold water. Change the water every half-hour, planning on 30 minutes per pound. - Fresh turkeys should be bought only one to two days before cooking. Whole frozen turkeys will last a year frozen at zero degrees. - Wash hands, utensils, counters and sinks that have come in contact with raw turkey. ``Whenever you're handling a raw product, you need to be worried about bacteria,'' said Templin. ``Around the holiday, pople are preparing larger amounts of food, preparing ahead, putting food out for large groups. So there's a lot of areas where people can make mistakes.'' - Stuff a turkey just before it is cooked. - Do not roast turkey overnight in a low-temperature oven. Turkey should be cooked at 325 degrees or higher to prevent bacteria growth. - Remove stuffing right after cooking. Do not leave a cooked turkey at room temperature for more than two hours. - To cook a turkey ahead, cook to internal temperature of 180 degrees. Carve meat, except legs, thighs and wings. Refrigerate. Reheat in 325-degree oven. - After dinner, cut meat from bones and refrigerate meat up to four days or freeze. --- The USDA Meat and Poulty Hot Line can be reached at 800-535-4555. Within Washington, D.C., call 447-3333. In November, it operates weekdays, and 9 a.m.-5 p.m. EST on Nov. 17-18 and 8 a.m.-2 p.m. EST on Thanksgiving Day. The Butterball Turkey Talk-Line, 800-323-4848, is open weekdays 9 a.m.-9 p.m.; the weekend before Thanksgiving 9 a.m.-7 p.m.; Thanksgiving Day 7 a.m.-7 p.m.; and weekdays in December 9 a.m.-7 p.m.

DOC.HEAD: Leaping into Exercise May Leave You Hurt ^Eds: A version on sports wires as BC-Lifestyle Sports.
DOC.TEXT: Exercise is one of those good things that you can get too much of, and beginning exercisers should realize it, experts say. The new demands on their bodies may unmask hidden medical problems or break something that had been OK until they suddenly put too much stress on it, they say. Beginners often ``don't know how, they don't know how much is too much, or how to progress with it,'' said Dr. Douglas B. McKeag, professor of family practice and coordinator of sports medicine at Michigan State University. Experts say people should ease into exercise, increasing their regimen by no more than 10 percent in time or distance each week. Exercise should start with a warmup, in ``an effort not to jump start the body,'' and rip a muscle that's unprepared for maximum exertion, he said. If you want to stretch, do it slowly and gently, he said, adding that he's ``more and more convinced that stretching is less and less important.'' Similarly, a beginner can exercise too frequently, too long or too intensely. McKeag recommends every other day, t a heart rate of at least 60 percent of your maximum (the maximum is computed from the number 220 minus your age), for at least 15 minutes a day. Pushing beyond that, he said, can lead you into injuries that strike the area you use the most. Bicyclists get knee pains, runners get shin splints, tennis players get tennis elbow, swimmers get sore shoulders - they all are listed as overuse injuries, McKeag said. The doctor strongly recommends a cooldown - a slow easing off from your exercise peak. ``When major cardiac events occur as a result of exercise, it happens right after exercise,'' he said. Quitting cold sends your blood pressure bouncing like a yo-yo, as your body reacts to the changes in blood pressure that result. Another problem is that people who didn't know they had heart disease may find it when they add the stress of exercise, said Dr. William L. Haskell, professor of medicine at Stanford University School of Medicine. ``A fair number of middle aged men or older have underlying atherosclerosis not evident on a day-to-day basis,'' he said. People who most need to be aware of this have high blood pressure, high cholesterol, tobacco addiction, or a family history of heart disease, he said. If you are middle aged and don't have those risk factors, you shouldn't have a problem with an exercise program that starts slowly and progresses, Haskell said. But he still advises a visit to the doctor before starting an exercise program. A stress test, in which a patient commonly exercises on a treadmill while medical experts monitor the body's response, is a common method to identify people with increased risk. But one researcher says it's overdone. ``As a cardiologist, that's a financial boondoggle,'' said Dr. Paul E. Thompson of Miriam Hospital in Providence, R.I. Only a few people die because exercise triggered some underlying condition, he said. In a 1982 study of deaths while jogging, Thompson, an associate professor of medicine at Brown University, concluded Rhode Island was averaging one man dead for every 7,620 men who jogged per year. After eliminating the cases in which the joggers knew they had heart disease, the study found only one death for each 15,600 men. Based on those figures, the stress test may not be worth the $300 or so that it costs, he said. On the other hand, he said, pay attention to a tightness or choking feeling in your chest: It's a sign of heart trouble.

DOC.HEAD: Blood Substitute Shows Promise, Researcher Says
DOC.TEXT: A chemical cousin of Teflon is showing promise as a blood substitute in animals and may one day help stroke patients, a researcher says. ``It's chemically pretty inert - pretty non-toxic - (and) could be stored fairly easily without fear of contamination with virus or bacteria or dirt,'' said Robert A. Linsenmeier, associate professor of biomedical engineering and neurobiology and physiology at Northwestern University. The blood substitute is made of a class of chemicals called fluorocarbons. Teflon is also a fluorocarbon, a carbon-based compound in which most or all hydrogen ions have been replaced by fluorine atoms, Linsenmeier said. Different fluorocarbons have different physical properties, he said, adding that the blood substitute he and his colleagues are testing is a thick, milky fluid made by Alliance Pharmaceutical Corp. of San Diego. In stroke patients, doctors may one day be able to inject some of the artificial blood soon after the stroke and boost the oxygen supply to affected brain tissue. The findings in tests on eight cats by Linsenmeier and Thomas K. Goldstick, professor of chemical engineering and biomedical engineering, were to be presented this month by their co-researcher, Rod Braun, at the annual meeting of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers in Chicago. Now, only one form of artificial blood is approved by the Food and Drug Administration for use in humans - a fluorocarbon emulsion called Fluosol, said Gary Schaer, director of the cardiac catheterization laboratory at Rush-Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center in Chicago. But Fluosol is not effective in general transfusions, he said. It is only useful in tiny quantities to keep heart muscle supplied with oxygen during cardiac angioplasty. Schaer cautioned that any type of artificial blood still undergoing only animal tests is years away from potential use in humans. ---
DOC.HEAD: Genes May Be Key to Skin Cancer
DOC.TEXT: About 40 percent of people probably carry a genetic susceptibility to the most common forms of skin cancer no matter how fair their skin is, researchers reported. Scientists from the University of Miami and the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Miami reported in the Journal of Investigative Dermatology that there is a genetically distinct group inclined to develop skin cancer. Scientists have known for some time that too much sun can cause skin cancer, but the research team concluded a genetic predisposition in tandem with overexposure also may play a role. Dr. Howard Koh, associate professor of dermatology and medicine and public health at Boston University, was not familiar with the study but noted the importance of such research. ``Skin cancer is the No. 1 cancer in the United States estimated at up to 600,000 cases a year,'' Koh said. ``Non-melanoma skin cancer rarely kills a person but its impact on quality of life and the morbidity of it is really considerable.'' Dr. J. Richard Taylor and colleagues studied people using ultraviolet light exposure and a drug to test the body's immune response. Neither the drug nor short bursts of ultraviolet light exposure were harmful to study participants, he said. Study subjects who never had skin cancer developed a rash that showed they had the immune system cells needed to fight a cancer-causing assault. None of the volunteers who previously had cancer developed the rash, Taylor said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Nov. 19

DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge kept Eastern Airlines alive Wednesday night by allowing the carrier to withdraw $15 million from an escrow fund. The judge, however, expressed doubts the struggling carrier's recovery plans will work. Eastern's trustee, Martin R. Shugrue Jr., asked U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland to let the airline tap $30 million out of an escrow account immediately. Shugrue also said Eastern will need to get another $40 million in late December and $10 million in early January. The account presently has $273.6 million, he said. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Retail sales growth slowed to a barely perceptible 0.1 percent in October, the government said, prompting analysts to predict the holiday gift-buying season will be a bust. ``I think holiday sales are going to be pretty lousy,'' economist Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York said Wednesday. Economist Sandra Shaber of the Futures Group in Washington agreed, pointing to two months of declining sales at department and clothing stores. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Federal savings and loan regulators have filed claims for $6.8 billion against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. alleging that the firm ``plundered'' more than 40 failed thrifts through its junk bond dealings. The filing in U.S. Bankruptcy Court on Wednesday charges that the collapsed Wall Street investment bank engaged in bribery, coercion, extortion, fraud and other illegal activities that created huge losses for the savings and loans. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Resolution Trust Corp. also said they would seek to recover $750 million from Drexel and former Drexel junk-bond leader Michael Milken from two separate federal restitution funds. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Federal Communications Commission, under the gun to keep the United States in the race with Japan and Europe to develop the next generation of television, announced an ``ambitious but realistic'' test schedule to select a U.S. high-definition TV standard by mid-1993. The FCC on Wednesday said five companies will be in the running for the coveted HDTV standard, which will be the sole format to be used to provide Americans with HDTV's crystal-clear pictures and compact disc-quality sound by cable, satellite and the major commercial networks. Backers of HDTV say it could revitalize a lagging U.S. electronics industry. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Former stock speculator John A. Mulheren Jr. was sentenced to one year and one day in prison and fined $1.68 million for manipulating stock in a scheme with Ivan Boesky. Mulheren, a flamboyant and successful stock trader who was convicted in a trial that featured Boesky's first public testimony in Wall Street's insider trading scandals, was freed following Wednesday's sentencing pending appeal of the charges. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Repetitive motion disorders accounted for most of the increase last year in the nation's job-related illnesses, which were up by 43,000, the government said. There was an increase of about 32,000 new cases of repetitive trauma illnesses, such as carpal tunnel syndrome, which causes pain in wrists and forearms, the Labor Department said Wednesday. --- DETROIT (AP) - Early November sales of North American-made vehicles rose a slim 2.4 percent despite a drop in sales of gas-gulping light trucks, the automakers said. Sales of trucks, which until this year had been increasing steadily since the mid-1980s, have been falling off as gas prices rise in the wake of the Middle East crisis. The increase during the Nov. 1-10 period this year, announced Wednesday, came against a relatively weak period last year when customers shied away from showrooms featuring new 1990 models with sticker prices higher than 1989 models. --- BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) - The European Community Commission has proposed to cancel $4.3 billion in debt that 69 developing nations owe the European Community as a whole. The debt, worth 3.1 billion European currency units, is owed by African, Caribbean and Pacific nations that have special trade ties with the EC. EC Development Commissioner Manual Marin said his debt cancellation proposal ``does not cover bilateral debt,'' between the ACP and the 12 EC states but between the ACP nations and the Community as a whole. --- DETROIT (AP) - The inventor of intermittent windshield wipers has ended a 12-year-old patent-infringement lawsuit against Ford Motor Co. by accepting $10.2 million from the automaker. A Ford attorney called Wednesday's settlement ``extremely reasonable,'' adding that the agreement resolved all disputes between the company and 63-year-old inventor Robert Kearns. ---

The stock market climbed to an eight-week high Wednesday, resuming its recent rally with encouragement from falling oil prices. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 24.25 points to 2,559.65, its highest close since it stood at 2,571.29 on Sept. 18. Bonds rose modestly. The dollar touched new lows. Gold fell sharply, caught up in a general slide in commodity prices. Crude oil prices tumbled nearly $2 a barrel as traders focused on market supplies in the absence of major news from the Middle East.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwait Airways: We Can't Fly Home But We're Still Flying
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait Airways soon plans to resume service into the United States as it expands symbolic efforts to keep flying, even though occupying Iraqis have pirated most of the oil-rich emirate's jet fleet. ``It's a mini-operation,'' said Gerard Tateossian, manager of the government-owned airline's U.S. offices. ``We can still run our airline and have the Kuwaiti flag flying all over the world.'' After Iraqi troops invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, they seized the airport in Kuwait City along with 15 planes from the fleet of 23 once held by Kuwait Airways, Tateossian said. The eight jets still in the fleet are the ones that happened to be out of the country. ``Fifteen of them have been looted by aggressors, taken away to Baghdad,'' Tateossian said. ``There is no place else they can go. We have indications that there is nothing at the Kuwait airport.'' Kuwait Airways announced through newspaper advertisements Wednesday that it soon would resume service to New York, one of its key foreign destinations. ``Until we're able to welcome you to Kuwait, welcome aboard,'' the ad states. It calls the new service ``a symbol of the perseverance of Kuwait.'' ``We resumed operations already out of Cairo to the Gulf on the 18th of October,'' Tateossian said in a telephone interview. ``We will be resuming out of the United States sometime at the end of this month or the beginning of December.'' The New York flights will include twice-weekly trips from Kennedy airport to London, Bahrain and Bombay, he said. There will be an additional flight leaving once a week that goes from Kennedy to London, Cairo, Bahrain and Bombay. The flights will be handled by crews who were with the planes that escaped the invasion, as well as some workers who got out on their own, Tateossian said. Kuwait Airways said its ticketing offices in Washington, Houston, Chicago, Los Angeles and Toronto remain open. Those cities were never destinations. The state-run carrier is now an airline without a country, as its corporate offices are set up in Cairo and its hub is now Bahrain. Previous service into various African, European and Asian destinations has not been restored. Kuwait Airways hopes it can make its skeletal service turn a profit, but the U.S. manager said the most important consideration is to just show that it can still fly. ``The first operations were up to 54 percent occupancy,'' Tateossian said.

DOC.HEAD: Icahn May Seek Seats on USX Board
DOC.TEXT: TWA Chairman Carl Icahn, USX Corp.'s largest shareholder is threatening to seek seats on the giant steel and energy company's board if it ignores his latest call for restructuring. In a letter to USX Corp. Chairman Charles Corry, Icahn praised plans announced last month to transfer its steel operations into a separate company. Those plans could result in a sale of the steel division, the biggest steelmaker in the country. But Icahn called on USX to distribute the proceeds from the sale of the steel business to shareholders as a special dividend. ``My USX stock is not for sale, and I will not even consider selling it until USX supports a meaningful restructuring plan that benefits all shareholders,'' Icahn said in his letter. The letter, dated Nov. 13, was disclosed Wednesday in an Icahn filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington. A spokesman for USX, Don Herring, said the company had no comment on the matter. USX stock closed at $32.12{, up 37{ cents at the end of trading Wednesday. Icahn, a takeover strategist who runs Trans World Airlines, has been a thorn in the side of USX management for years. He had been laying low since last May, when his proposal to spin off most of the USX steel business in the form of a shareholder dividend was rejected by other stockholders. Icahn has said he considers steel a drain on USX's Marathon Oil Co. and Texas Oil and Gas Co. Icahn, who controls 13.3 percent of USX's common stock, said he was creating an independent committee to ``assist all stockholders of the company in having meaningful input'' on issues such as separating the steel and energy businesses, dividend policy and corporate governance. The committee, consisting of law, government and business professors at Harvard and Stanford universities and the University of Chicago, would seek election to the board of directors at the 1991 annual meeting ``unless the USX board adopts a meaningful restructuring plan and corporate governance changes,'' according to Icahn's five-page letter to Corry. Icahn also said the committee would seek a shareholders' list and begin canvassing USX shareholders as soon as practical about its proposals, which include the possible sale of all or part of its energy operations; and eliminating the shareholder rights plan, or ``poison pill'' defense against possible takeovers.

DOC.HEAD: Colorful Figure in Boesky Scandal Gets Prison, $1.68 Billion Fine
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge gave John A. Mulheren Jr. a 366-day prison term and a $1.68 million fine for stock manipulation, saying the former friend of famous Wall Street felon Ivan Boesky deserved incarceration. ``Anyone who tampers with the integrity of the stock market will go to prison,'' Judge Miriam Cedarbaum decreed Wednesday in pronouncing sentence on Mulheren, a flamboyant 41-year-old speculator convicted with Boesky's help. When asked for his reaction to the sentence, Mulheren responded in the same easy-going manner with which he conducted himself during his trial: ``Nobody likes to go to jail, right?'' Mulheren's prosecution received widespread attention because it featured Boesky's first public testimony in Wall Street's insider trading scandals. He was freed pending appeal of the charges. He was the only person implicated by Boesky - the ex-speculator whose admissions led to several prominent indictments - to go to trial rather than strike a plea agreement. A jury in July found Mulheren guilty of charges he helped Boesky drive up the price of Gulf & Western Inc. stock in 1985. He faced a maximum of 20 years in prison. If his conviction is upheld, it is unlikely Mulheren will serve the entire sentence because he will be eligible for parole after serving four months. Cedarbaum also gave Mulheren credit for time served in 1988 in connection with an alleged plot to shoot Boesky. Mulheren's attorney, Thomas Puccio, said he believed Mulheren was in federal custody for about two months for that incident, which later was settled with Mulheren agreeing to three years of probation. Mulheren did not address the court before sentencing. He relied on statements by Puccio, who asked for leniency because Mulheren suffered from manic depression and because of his many charitable acts. ``The most we have here is someone who momentarily strayed and committed one act on one day against a lifetime of honesty and respectability,'' Puccio said. Prosecutors had charged that Mulheren bought 75,000 Gulf & Western shares at Boesky's behest, driving the stock to $45 a share, the price at which Boesky wanted to sell about 3.5 million shares back to the company. Cedarbaum said the fine of $1.68 million represented the losses sustained by investors who bought Gulf & Western stock during the time of the manipulation. Boesky agreed in November 1986 to plead guilty to one count of lying to federal investigators and pay $100 million in fines. He was released from federal custody in April after serving two years of a three-year term. The high point of the trial came when Boesky was called as a prosecution witness against Mulheren, his former business associate and friend. Boesky admitted in testimony that he traded suitcases stuffed with cash for confidential information about imminent takeovers. Mulheren, a laid-back multimillionaire who often flew by helicopter to his trial, flouted convention in court as he had in his Wall Street career. During testimony, Mulheren wore a tennis shirt, blue jeans and boat shoes. At sentencing, Mulheren also dressed casually in an open-necked pink shirt and khaki pants. In 1988, after learning Boesky had implicated him, Mulheren was arrested leaving his Rumson, N.J., mansion carrying a loaded assault rifle and army fatigues. Police said he planned to shoot Boesky. State authorities in New Jersey last year dropped weapons possession charges against Mulheren as a part of the settlement that included probation. Mulheren's lawyers blamed the incident on his failure to take lithium prescribed to treat manic depression. Some criminal charges against Mulheren remain because the jury was unable to reach a verdict on 26 additional counts of securities fraud, mail fraud and record-keeping violations. Cedarbaum declared a mistrial on that portion of the case and the government has yet to decide whether to retry Mulheren on the pending counts. Mulheren's co-defendant, Leonard DeStefano, 34, a former trader at Mulheren's defunct firm Jamie Securities Co., was acquitted of all conspiracy and record-keeping violations charges brought against him.

DOC.HEAD: Early-November Sales Up, Despite Big Chrysler Declines
DOC.TEXT: U.S. automakers reported a 2.4 percent rise in the number of North American-made cars and trucks sold in early November, despite a big decline posted by Chrysler Corp. Within hours Wednesday of Chrysler reporting a 21.3 percent decline in its vehicle sales during the period, the struggling automaker issued a new incentive package including cash rebates on all of its minivans. It's the second time in history that's been done. Chrysler's car sales fell 9.1 percent while sales of its trucks, including the company's minivan line, plummeted 33 percent. General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co., meanwhile, said their car and truck sales during the Nov. 1-10 period rose 7.4 percent and 4.7 percent respectively, compared with the same time last year. Combined, the Big Three and the seven Japanese companies selling cars and trucks made in North America said their average daily sales rate rose to 26,817 vehicles during the period this year compared with a rate of 26,194 a day in early November last year. Car sales jumped 8 percent over a relatively weak period last year, but truck sales dropped 6.4 percent, mainly because of the sag in Chrysler sales. Chrysler spokesman Tom Jakobowski said Wednesday the truck sales declines were noted across-the-board, with no one particular vehicle suffering a significantly larger slump than others. Shortly after reporting its car and truck sales, Chrysler issued a new incentive program that included rebates on standard-wheelbase minivans. Chrysler has commanded a lion's share of the minivan market ever since it introduced its popular vehicles in late 1983. But recently, as the number of companies marketing minivans in the United States has grown, Chrysler's share of the market has shrunk. Nonetheless, the company still controls more than 45 percent of the market. Chrysler said it would offer a $1,000 discount on 1989 and 1990 models of its popular minivans between now and Dec. 16. Previously, the company offered $500 cash rebates on extra-length minivans. That incentive also was boosted to $1,000. Jakobowski said as much as 40 percent of the minivans sold during the early-November period were 1989 or 1990 models. Chrysler shut down its two minivan assembly plants for a month apiece to retool for 1991 models, which cut supplies of the newly redesigned models. Also on Wednesday, Chrysler boosted rebates on its Jeep line of sport-utility vehicles and some of its Jeep and Dodge pickup trucks. The only other time Chrysler has offered a rebate on its minivans, which were introduced in late 1983, was during a six-week period beginning in mid-December last year. Sales of the popular light trucks soared during the rebate period, but plummeted when the rebates expired. The early-November sales period last year was one of the weakest of 1989. Many consumers who had planned to buy cars in the fourth quarter of last year pushed up their purchases to the third quarter to take advantage of incentives and avoid price increases due with the 1990 models. Incentives still are in effect, but they don't have the drawing power they once had. So far this year, car and truck sales by the 10 companies have dropped 3.6 percent compared with last year, with car sales down 3.8 percent and truck sales 3.3 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Won Computer Chip Patent Says He's Done it Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Gilbert Hyatt, the engineer who was granted a patent last summer for the computer microprocessor after a 20-year battle, says he's done it again. Hyatt announced Wednesday at the Comdex Computer Show that he recently received a patent for a technology that triples the speed of one of the most widely used types of computer chips. Hyatt said his modification of Dynamic Random Access Memory chips, or DRAM, eliminates unnecessary operations in the chips to achieve the greater speed. DRAMs are among the most common types of computer chips, used in products ranging from personal computers to printers to some home electronics equipment. They temporarily store bits of data that are needed to perform various operations. By speeding them up, computers could perform calculations more quickly. That's because the speed of microprocessors, the ``brains'' of personal computers, has outpaced the ability of DRAMs to feed them data. Hyatt said he plans to license the technology to the computer industry, much like he is seeking licenses for his 1968 invention of the microprocessor. One industry analyst, Millard Phelps, of the San Francisco brokerage Hambrecht & Quist, said Hyatt's latest invention could be a major advance - provided his chips don't have too many drawbacks. ``It sure makes you wonder what is the tradeoff,'' Phelps said. Hyatt, however, said he achieved the speedup without sacrificing any other characteristics of the chips. He said he uses off-the-shelf DRAMs in his technique. Hyatt said he plans to use any royalties he receives from his two patents to help other small inventors. He said small inventors tend to get trampled by major companies and overlooked by the government. ``I hope to do my part in helping the little guy from what I learned in my 20-year fight,'' he said. Hyatt, of La Palma, Calif., fought with the U.S. Patent Office and major computer chip makers until he was granted his microprocessor patent in July. The patent award called into question the computer industry's official history, which says the microprocessor was invented by several Intel Corp. scientists. Hyatt declined to comment on the amount of royalties he was seeking on the patent, beyond calling them ``significant.'' Industry analysts estimate he could get several million dollars a year from major microprocessor makers. Hyatt has said that he sought his patent more to set history straight than for riches. He said he has earned a living by consulting to the aerospace industry while continuing to work on inventions in his home lab and seeking the patents. Despite his long ordeal with the microprocessor, Hyatt supports the cumbersome U.S. patent-granting system. ``It's to the credit of the patent system that eventually right prevails,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pan Am, UAL Sign Final Agreement On Trans-Atlantic Routes
With PM-Eastern Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Pan Am Corp. finalized its deal to sell important trans-Atlantic routes to UAL Corp. in a $400 million package that will give United Airlines a strong presence flying across two oceans. Now, United might run into troubles with the British bureaucracy as it seeks to keep flying the old Pan Am routes into Heathrow Airport, the most desirable destination in London. Some airline analysts believe the British will insist that United fly into Gatwick Airport instead. The Teamsters union at Pan Am had also voiced objections to the deal, saying the struggling carrier was not getting enough cash for the London routes. But Pan Am said the deal also involved a marketing agreement through which the rival airlines will coordinate some flights and attempt to feed passengers to one another. The two carriers signed the final papers on the deal late Wednesday night, the deadline for its completion, Pan Am spokesman Jeff Kriendler said. The airlines did immediately release details of pact as it was announced early today. The agreement was put in question over the weekend when it was announced that TWA had proposed merging with Pan Am if the arrangement with United fell through. If the papers hadn't been signed by Wednesday, the United deal could have been terminated and TWA's offer might have come into play. TWA Chairman Carl Icahn offered Pan Am securities with a face value of $300 million and $150 million in cash if it didn't sell the routes to United's parent, UAL Corp. Completing the deal marks a major expansion by UAL. United bought Pan Am's prized Pacific routes five years ago for $750 million and has since become a key airline in that part of the world. The deal, originally announced late last month, provides for UAL to acquire Pan Am's U.S.-London routes, except for those from Miami and Detroit. It also provides for UAL to buy gates, hangar and office space at San Francisco and Washington's Dulles International airport, two Boeing 747 jumbo jets and spare parts. Also Wednesday, federal transportation officials gave final approval to United's planned new routes between Chicago and Tokyo. The Department of Transportation approved the routes over the objections of American Airlines, which had sought to offer the service. Pan Am has said it will concentrate on one major European hub, Frankfurt, as well as strengthen schedules to other European cities, including Oslo, Zagreb, Hamburg, Amsterdam and Nuremberg. In addition, Pan Am has said it will increase its Miami presence by adding long-haul flights from that city to Latin America. The agreement with UAL also includes reciprocal participation in each other's frequent flier programs and coordination of their schedules at Miami, as well as to Central and South America from the West Coast.

DOC.HEAD: GM Fighting Tariff on Canadian-Built Geo Vehicles
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. is in a dispute with the U.S. Treasury Department over whether its Canadian-built Geo Tracker sport-utility vehicle or the Geo Metro subcompact car should be subject to tariffs. At issue is whether the Tracker or Metro, built at a joint GM-Suzuki Motor Co. Ltd. plant in Ingersoll, Ontario, have more than 50 percent of their value attributable to U.S. or Canadian labor. If the vehicles comply and have more than 50 percent North American content, they enter the United States without tariffs. Most of the engines and transmissions for GM's Geo line of small vehicles come from Japan. The Treasury Department said the Tracker and Metro don't comply with the North American content rule. GM disagrees, saying the content level should include the costs of borrowing money for the factory. ``It's very real and, in our case, it was borrowed from a variety of institutions in Canada and in the U.S.,'' said James Cameron, a spokesman for the CAMI Automotive Inc. joint manufacturing plant in Ingersoll. If the Tracker is classified as having less than 50 percent North American content, it would be subject to a 25 percent truck tariff and the Metro could be hit with a 2.5 percent car tariff. If the levies were applied, it could cost GM $75 million for the 29,000 Trackers and 27,000 Metros it brought into the United States from Canada during the 1990 model year, according to John Simpson, a deputy assistant secretary for the Treasury Department. Other automakers' vehicles made in Ontario contain have more than 50 percent North American content. They include the Civic made by Honda Motor Co. Ltd. in Allison, the Corolla made by Toyota Motor Corp. in Cambridge, the Ford Crown Victoria and Mercury Grand Marquis made by Ford Motor Co. in St. Thomas; and the Dodge Monaco and Eagle Premier made by Chrysler Corp. in Bramalea.

DOC.HEAD: Packaging Industry Goes Green
DOC.TEXT: The newest gadgets that box, sort, tape and buffer are on display at a packaging industry trade show that looks grass-green in its support of sound environmental policies. ``It's the environmental revolution,'' said Craig Todd, district manager of Better Packages. ``Everybody's gotten on the bandwagon.'' Better Packages isn't offering a new product at the show but is exhibiting new packaging for its old products. The Shelton, Conn., company's tape machines, which use glue rather than adhesives which don't decompose, ``just happen to be the right thing at the right time,'' Todd said. More than 55,000 people were on hand Wednesday for the packaging industry's Pack Expo, which ends Friday at McCormick Place. Dozens of this year's 900 exhibitors included environmentally sensible products, which ran from mailing envelopes made of recycled materials to packaging ``peanuts'' made nearly entirely of cornstarch. The new ``peanuts,'' manufactured by American Excelsior Co. of Arlington, Texas, will give the environmentally conscious consumer an alternative to the standard polystyrene packaging peanut, the company said. The product, called Eco-Foam, is more than 95 percent cornstarch, and the rest is a water-soluble organic polymer, said Robert Asselin of National Starch and Chemical Co. of Bridgewater N.J. It handles the peanuts' production for American Excelsior. The product dissolves in water and is safe enough to eat, said Asselin, who did just that while chatting with a reporter. American Excelsior will keep making polystyrene peanuts, said company Vice President Ken Starrett. ``We've serviced this market for about 30 years or more,'' said Starrett. ``We're not competing with ourselves, and we don't see a conflict by making both products. Eco-Foam is still the newcomer to the market.'' Some companies said thir customers aren't fully converted to the idea that environmentally sound is best. ``They'll buy it if the cost is the same and the quality's the same. But if the price is higher or the quality's affected, forget it,'' said Peter Dauphinais, whose company, Polyair Corp., introduced ``Eco-Lite'' mailing envelopes this year. The envelopes are made from 100 percent recycled paper and plastic and, while they cost the same as non-recycled, they're less strong, said Dauphinais, sales man for the Toronto company. Cantech Industries Inc., of Johnson City, Tenn., introduced a new unbleached masking tape at the show. The new tape is free of caustic chemicals used in other tape manufacture but is not quite as white as its bleached counterpart, said Cantech's Jim Petruzzi. Petruzzi said manufacturers tend to have a natural inclination toward packaging materials which are the newest and white-est of whites - a tendency that dies hard. ``You spend your whole life on making things look good, then environmental issues come up,'' said Petruzzi. ``Not that they're not good issues.''

The stock market declined broadly today, giving up some of the gains recorded in its rally since mid-October. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 9.90 to 2,549.75 in the first half hour of trading. Losers outnumbered gainers by more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 267 up, 709 down and 467 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 20.03 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Oil prices turned upward and interest rates rose in early activity in the commodity and credit markets. Analysts said that provided stock traders with an incentive to cash in some of their recent gains. The recovery in stock prices has been based to a considerable degree on expectations that the Federal Reserve will soon take new steps to relax its credit policy. Some observers believe that any likely Fed action has been largely ``discounted,'' or taken into account in advance, by the market's rise of late. Losers among the early volume leaders included Wal-Mart Stores, down ] at 29; General Motors, down \ at 39|; International Business Machines, down { at 113, and Toys R Us, down \ at 23{. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped .88 to 173.80. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .50 at 297.37. On Wednesday the Dow Jones industrial average rose 24.25 points to 2,559.65. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by almost 2 to 1 on the NYSE, with 1,001 up, 521 down and 468 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 179.31 million shares, up from 160.24 million in the previous session.

DOC.TEXT: Rupert

DOC.HEAD: Brokerage House Denies Allegations of Fraud
DOC.TEXT: Merrill Lynch & Co. officials deny allegations of fraud in selling Lomas Financial Corp. securities and said Harvard University, one of nine accusers, had access to reports Lomas was not doing well before buying. In a suit against Merrill Lynch, Harvard said the brokerage firm concealed its own $40 million stake in Texas-based Lomas while selling Lomas securities. Harvard bought $45 million of Lomas notes in May 1989, one month before Lomas announced a $200 million loss. ``Lomas' problems were not kept secret from the financial markets or the Harvard Management Co.'s managers,'' Merrill Lynch spokesman Fred Yeager said Wednesday. He said Harvard had access to all material negative developments before it purchased, and received a private placement memorandum describing Lomas' poor financial results and its intewntion to undertake restructuring transactions. He said Merrill Lynch's stake in Lomas was documented in Securities and Exchange filings one month before Harvard invested in the company. Trial of the suit by Harvard and eight other institutional investors will be held in U.S. District Court in Boston and is expected to begin in the spring.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Banks Reportedly Lending $400 Million to Soviets
DOC.TEXT: Five Japanese commercial banks have lent the Soviet Union $400 million to buy steel pipes and pay for goods imported from Japan, the economic newspaper Nihon Keizai Shimbun reported Thursday. Nihon Keizai said the loans were extended to the Soviet government-owned Soviet Bank of Foreign Economic Affairs, but did not identify the Japanese banks. It also did not report the interest rate, but said the loans would be repaid in 10 installments over five years. The Soviet Union is to use half of the money to pay for industrial materials it has bought from Japan and the rest to import 105,000 tons of seamless pipes and 80,000 tons of large-diameter steel pipes for the development of oil resources, Nihon Keizai said. An official of the Finance Ministry, who spoke on condition of anonymity, declined to confirm the report, saying, ``It is our policy not to answer on any private cases.'' Foreign Ministry officials have said Japan will not extend financial assistance to the Soviet Union until the Kremlin agrees to return a group of northern islands seized by the Soviet Union at the end of World War II.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 355.13 down 1.74 from the previous day's close.

The stock market pulled back today, giving up some of the gains recorded in its rally since mid-October. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 8.41 points to 2,551.24 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 398 up, 814 down and 515 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 45.43 million shares at midmorning. Oil prices turned upward and interest rates rose in early activity in the commodity and credit markets. Analysts said that provided stock traders with an incentive to cash in some of their recent gains. The recovery in stock prices has been based to a considerable degree on expectations that the Federal Reserve will soon take new steps to relax its credit policy. DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices rose slightly today on the Chicago Board of Trade, recovering from several sessions of double-digit losses in some active contract months. Grains were mostly lower. Soybean prices rose initially on speculation that some type of U.S.-European food aid package to the Soviet Union would result from President Bush's impending trip to Europe. Soybeans continued to face pressure, however, from a government report issued last week that found larger stocks of the crop than had been expected. DOC.HEAD: Violent Novel `American Psycho' Canceled by Publisher
Precede WASHINGTON
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to UPDATE with publisher confirming cancellation; author's publicist raises censorship question.
DOC.TEXT: Book publisher Simon & Schuster said today it will not release ``American Psycho,'' a violent new novel by critically acclaimed author Bret Easton Ellis. Chairman Richard E. Snyder released a statement saying the book, which was scheduled to be shipped to stores next month, would not handle be handled by Simon & Schuster. Ellis' publicist said the decision smacks of censorship. ```American Psycho' is not a book that Simon & Schuster is willing to publish even though Mr. Ellis is a serious author whose work Simon & Schuster has previously published,'' Snyder said. Ellis, 26, is the author of the critically praised novel ``Less Than Zero,'' which depicts a morally decadent lifestyle among children of upper-income families in Los Angeles. It was made into a movie in 1987. The statement offered no further explanation for the book's cancellation. But Snyder told The Washington Post: ``In my opinion, there was an incorrect decision'' by editors who bought the book and approved its publication. ``American Psycho,'' the story of a young, successful Wall Street businessman who can't stop killing people, was criticized for its vivid descriptions of violence against women. Ellis' publicist, Amanda Urban, said, ``Refusing to publish a book at this 11th hour, without explanation, raises the question whether there was a form of censorship going on here.'' ``What is involved here is a giant corporation responding to pre-publication controversy and strong-arming its publishing division into abandoning its own tradition of fearless publication,'' Urban said. Snyder denied he was pressured into canceling the book by the publishing house's parent company, Paramount Communications Inc. ``It was I who decided we should not put our name on this book. It's a matter of taste,'' Snyder told the Washington Post. He said Paramount agreed with his decision. ``Through the press, I became aware of this book, and then aware of its contents,'' Snyder said. ``And it was I who decided we should not put our name on this book. It's a matter of taste.'' Urban said other publishers have expressed interest in the book. She declined to give names while negotiating. She said Ellis does not have to give back his advance, which today's Wall Street Journal put at $300,000. Snyder said Martin Davis, chairman of the publishing house's parent company, Paramount Communications Inc., agreed with the decision. Ellis was quoted by The Washington Post as conceding that some scenes in his novel ``are appalling'' but added that some magazine accounts of it ``verged on the hysterical and gave a false sense of what the book is about.'' The violence is there because ``the character is crazy,'' he said. ``The book is 400 pages long, and there are less than 40 pages with the type of mayhem they quote,'' Ellis said.

DOC.HEAD: Polly Peck Furniture, Paintings to be Sold by Auctioneers
DOC.TEXT: The court-appointed administrators brought in to salvage Polly Peck International PLC said Thursday they have hired auctioneers to sell the contents of the British conglomerate's headquarters. The items to be sold by Phillips auctioneers are mostly fine furniture and paintings from Polly Peck's board, conference and waiting rooms, said one of the administrators, accountant Michael Jordan of the firm Coopers and Lybrand Deloitte. Jordan said he hoped the sale planned for February would yield more than 3 million pounds, or $6 million, which would go toward running the company. The food and electronics company, headed by Turkish Cypriot businessman Asil Nadir, was placed in the hands of the administrators in October after the price of its stock fell sharply on the stock exchange. The administrators are trying to sort out its debt of 1.3 billion pounds, or $2.5 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Unemployment Rises to Six Percent
DOC.TEXT: The British unemployment rate rose to 6.0 percent in October, according to figures released Thursday by the Department of Employment. The figures show a rise of 0.1 percent, or up 32,200 people to 1.7 million people from the previous month. The unemployment rate in the United States was 5.7 percent in October.

DOC.HEAD: State's High Court Upholds Auto Lemon Law
DOC.TEXT: Washington state's automobile-lemon law, designed to protect consumers who purchase defective new motor vehicles, was upheld today by a unanimous state Supreme Court. The law had been challenged by the Ford Motor Co., which contended it violates the equal protection and due process provisions of the state and U.S. constitutions. ``The state's interest in protecting consumers in the purchase of motor vehicles under the motor vehicles warranties law outweighs the due process considerations,'' Justice Charles Smith wrote for the court. The case stemmed from Ford's appeal to the King County Superior Court of a New Motor Vehicle Arbitration Board ruling in favor of Gary Barrett. Barrett bought a Ford Thunderbird from Mossy Ford in Bellevue in September 1985. He went to the arbitration board after the dealer was unable to repair a steering problem that caused the vehicle to pull to the left. The board ordered Ford to buy the vehicle back from Barrett. Ford conceded that the steering defect constituted a serious safety defect. But the automaker appealed, asking that Barrett's claim be denied on merits and contending the requirement that it repurchase the vehicle was unconstitutional. Superior Court Judge Patricia Aitken disagreed. She ordered Ford to pay Barrett $7,125, representing the repurchase cost less offset for use; $7,000 for Ford's failure to provide free use of a comparable loaner vehicle pending resolution of the appeal; and $1,750 for attorney's fees. In its appeal of tht decision to the state's high court, Ford contended that requiring it to pay attorney fees and a loaner-vehicle fee constituted the singling out of ``a class of litigants and subjecting them to onerous penalties as a condition of seeking redress within the court system.'' Ford also complained that if had prevailed in its superior court appeal, Barrett could not have been forced to pay attorney fees. The company said that represented denial of equal protection under the law for Ford and discouraged the filing of appeals. Smith noted, however, that the law designates two classes, manufacturers and consumers, and that the consumer class is not held liable for fees incurred in an appeal. Smith held that the separation of classes was rational. And he brushed aside Ford's argument that the law might discourage all appeals by manufacturers. He said Ford had not effectively demonstrated that the law was not rationally related to its purpose. ``Equal protection does not require that legislative efforts be perfect,'' Smith wrote, adding: ``The state's interest in (consumer protection) outweighs any deterrent effect on manufacturers.''

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Dodges Death Threat, Trustee Blasts Creditors As Reckless
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with quotes from Shugrue at news conference.
DOC.TEXT: The head of Eastern Airlines predicted today that the embattled carrier would strengthen soon and he denounced the creditors who sought to choke off its life-giving supply of cash in a bankruptcy-court brawl. ``Their actions in public and in the media are nothing short of reckless and shameful. They have set back our recovery efforts,'' Eastern trustee Martin R. Shugrue Jr. told a news conference, a day after he convinced a bankruptcy judge to release more money from a $273.6 million escrow fund to keep Eastern operating. Shugrue also said he believed that Eastern, one of the country's oldest, biggest and most troubled airlines, ``will stay on the path to profitability and will continue to maintain the support of the court.'' The airline's creditors wanted U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland to deny Eastern any more money, force it to close and auction off whatever assets remain to help pay its enormous debts. Analysts say Eastern has a total accumulated debt of some $2.5 billion. At a packed hearing that lasted nearly nine hours Wednesday night, the creditors and Eastern officials sparred over whether the airline could survive, especially in view of the nation's economic downturn and a dramatic rise in fuel prices caused by the 3-month-old Persian Gulf crisis. Burton finally ruled Eastern could have $15 million immediately, half of what it requested through late December. The judge said he'd release another $15 million if Eastern's projections were on track as of early December. Burton said he was making ``a close call'' with his ruling. He also said Eastern could revise performance estimates to account for any harm that comes from news stories written about creditor attempts to liquidate the airline. ``There's a great sense of relief,'' Eastern spokesman Jim Ashlock said Wednesday night after a judge approved the life-saving infusion. ``This was the big one.'' Eastern was taking steps today to assure its 18,000 employees that they would still be flying, at least for now. The brush with near death was the latest in a history of trauma at Eastern, which has been operating under bankruptcy court protection since March 1989 when most employees struck in a bitter dispute with management over concessions to save money. Eastern hired strike replacements and is a much smaller airline now, but it is still suffering staggering losses of about $1 million a day. In addition to the $30 million Shugrue requested for December, he also said during the hearing that the airline probably will need another $40 million in late December and an additional $10 million in January before it can turn the corner and halt losses that have come to about $1 million daily. Shugrue said Eastern will be able to repay the fund with even more cash by February. But the unsecured creditors' committee said it put no faith in his plans for resurrecting the carrier. The creditors say Eastern's plans are based on an assumption that fuel prices will drop, as well as Shugrue's contention that he will be able to take business away from his more healthy competitors through a program that offers first-class service at coach class rates. The creditors said fuel costs are likely to keep rising, but the judge faulted them for making a court filing on Tuesday that included news stories about a dramatic rise in oil prices late last week. The creditors left out subsequent news stories that showed oil falling sharply over the next couple of days. Eastern even pointed out that one of the creditors' expert witnesses has even been quoted in at least two recent news stories as saying oil prices are likely to fall. ``Your speculation and your arguments about prices may be no better than theirs,'' the judge told lawyers for the creditors, who include banks, airplane companies and labor unions. The creditors said Eastern's competitors will find ways to compete with the first-class program, and they are particularly motivated to do so as the airline industry endures hard times amid high fuel prices and a sluggish economy. Shugrue said Eastern has failed to meet his previous projections for business improvements because of the unpredictable downturn in the U.S. economy and Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August. Alan S. Boyd, chairman of the creditors' committee and chairman of airplane-maker Airbus Industrie Holdings of North America, stopped short of saying the judge's ruling will delay the inevitable death of Eastern. ``How this process will work out, God only knows,'' Boyd said, speaking to reporters outside the courthouse. The judge said in issuing his ruling that Shugrue had shown reasonable business judgment in asking for the additional money. ``I'm not sure the creditors' committee has exercised business judgment superior to that of the trustee,'' Lifland said. The hearing coincided with the release of Eastern's earnings statement for the third quarter of 1990, which showed the airline lost $252.8 million, bringing its total loss for the year to $424.9 million.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.

Investors moved to the sidelines in the absence of news and ahead of Friday's release of inflation figures, traders said. DOC.HEAD: Indonesian Airline Orders $1.8 Billion in Boeing Planes
DOC.TEXT: An Indonesian airline, Garuda Indonesia, has ordered 25 Boeing jetliners in a deal valued at $1.8 billion, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group said Thursday. The order includes nine 747-400s and 16 737-300s, Boeing said. Contracts for three of the 747s and eight 737s were signed Thursday. The remainder were ordered last year but not announced until now, Boeing said. The airline plans to use the 737s on routes around the Indonesia islands and the 747s for international routes. The 737s will be powered by CFM56-3 engines from CFM International, and the 747s by CF6-80C2 engines from General Electric Co. The latest order brings to 1,118 the number of all 747 models ordered, and to 2,880 the number of all 737 models ordered. So far this year, Boeing has received orders for 485 jetliners of all types worth a total of about $43 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Production Goes Down This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 193,272 cars and light trucks this week, down from last week's 202,179, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is lower than in the same week a year ago, when 248,603 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 98,740 cars this week, compared with 108,690 a week ago and 133,337 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 58,254, compared with last week's 54,255 and last year's 72,270. Canadian automakers were to build 21,100 cars this week, down from 22,819 a week ago and down from last year's 23,280. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 15,178, compared with 16,415 a week ago and 19,716 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Announces Direct Fiber-Optic Link to Germany
DOC.TEXT: The American Telephone & Telegraph Co. on Thursday announced a plan to build the first fiber-optic link between the United States and Germany. The cable is expected to handle about 100,000 simultaneous telephone conversations between the two countries, according to a company statement. AT&T and a Germany telecommunications company, Deutsche Bundespost Telekom, are scheduled to complete the project in late 1992 or early 1993, said AT&T spokesman David Bikle. The system would allow AT&T to meet a growing demand for overseas calls to Europe, Bikle said.

DOC.HEAD: State Supreme Court Rules for Policyholders in Environmental Clean-up Cases
DOC.TEXT: Insurance companies, and not the polluters they insure, must pay the costs of government-ordered toxic waste cleanups, the state Supreme Court ruled today. The unanimous decision was a major victory for corporate policyholders over insurers, who argued cleanup costs were excluded from coverage. A lawyer for the manufacturer whose waste dump sites were at issue in the case said the ruling would also protect the public. By providing insurance coverage for a company's own cleanup costs in response to government orders, the ruling should encourage ``a quicker cleanup and a less costly one, and the likelihood of a more complete one,'' said David Steuber, an attorney for FMC Corp. Otherwise, he said, companies might wait until government agencies performed the cleanup and sued them for the costs. FMC, a Chicago-based chemical and weapons company, had been sued by federal and local agencies for allegedly polluting the land and water at 79 toxic waste sites in at least 22 states. The costs of those projects have been estimated at $250 million or more. Insurance company lawyers in the case have said more than $2 billion in similar costs was at stake in 17 pending toxic cleanup cases in California. The ruling resolved a split in lower state courts over whether a polluter or the insurers who provide coverage for property damage should pay for the costs of removing hazardous substances from the environment. Standard insurance policies require insurers to cover all costs that the policyholder ``shall become legally obligated to pay as damages because of property damage.'' FMC's insurers argued the policies did not cover costs of cleaning up pollution in response to government orders issued under environmental laws, or costs of repaying the government for its own expenses. The insurers said ``damages'' referred only to money awarded for injuries in a jury trial, and not to remedial costs paid under government order. The Supreme Court disagreed. Chief Justice Malcolm Lucas wrote that ``the plain and ordinary meanings'' of ``damages'' and other words in the policies covered all types of expenses incurred in response to government orders to repair property damage caused by toxic discharges. Rejecting a key argument of the insurers, Lucas said the fact that FMC was a large, sophisticated company did not affect the usual principle that unclear language in an insurance policy must be interpreted against the insurer who drafted it, and in favor of coverage.

DOC.HEAD: Yields Fall on New Bills
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on 52-week Treasury bills fell in Thursday's auction to the lowest level in more than two years. The average discount rate was 6.81 percent, down from 7.01 percent at the last auction on Oct. 26. It was the lowest rate since 52-week bills averaged 6.74 percent on May 5, 1988. The bills will carry an equivalent coupon interest rate of 7.28 percent with each $10,000 in face value selling for $9,313.30. Sales totaled $11.88 billion out of bids of $39.59 billion.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Trade Rep Warns of Tensions if Trade Talks Fail
