DOC.TEXT: U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills warned on Thursday that a failure of world trade talks would increase tensions among trading partners and could even spill over into foreign policy areas. ``We would be headed into a period of much greater friction,'' she said shortly after her arrival in Brussels for a series of talks with European Community officials. She said it would be ``very difficult ... to maintain international cooperation'' on issues ranging from the environment to the Persian Gulf crisis ``if you are at each other's throats over trade issues.'' Mrs. Hills will join U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and other American officials on Friday in a fresh attempt to break an impasse with the European Community over proposals to reduce agricultural subsidies. ``We've got a stalemate and we've got a problem,'' she said. Earlier, Frans Andriessen, the community's top trade official, said the trading bloc's proposal to trim farm subsidies on major crops by 30 percent was negotiable. ``We never said, `Gentlemen, this is the Community's proposal. Take it or leave it.' We want to negotiate. The EC is ready to take these negotiations to a successful result,'' Andriessen told reporters. The offer falls far short of the subsidy cuts being sought by the EC's key trade partners, notably the United States, and has raised questions about whether the Uruguay Round of world trade talks can be completed in early December as scheduled. Andriessen spoke after European Community trade ministers discussed the trade talks, involving 105 nations under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The negotiations, which began in 1986 in Punta del Este, Uruguay, are designed to overhaul the world trading system. The EC wants a 30 percent cut in farm subsidies over 10 years, while the United States and other farm-exporting nations want to slash payments by 75 percent. Washington also wants to reduce agricultural export subsidies by 90 percent over a decade, while the EC has not addressed export subsidies. EC officials sought to play down the dispute on farm subsidies, pointing out there are also disagreements in the 14 other areas under negotiation in the talks. ``Our commitment is to negotiate seriously. What is at stake, economically and politically, is quite a lot,'' said Renato Ruggiero, the Italian trade minister and the meeting's chairman. Otto Schlecht, Germany's deputy trade minister, said ``a successful end of the GATT round is extremely important'' to safeguard an open world trading system.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs Landmark Environmental Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with signing, EDITS thruout. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush proclaimed a ``new era for clean air'' today as he signed far-reaching legislation placing new curbs on air pollution from automobiles, factories and businesses. ``Every American expects and deserves to breathe clean air,'' Bush said, signing the Clean Air Act of 1990. He called the measure ``the centerpiece of our environmental agenda'' and the ``most significant air pollution legislation in our nation's history.'' Bush signed the measure at an East Room ceremony, standing with key lawmakers involved in the long and contentious fight over the measure. ``This is a true red letter day for all Americans,'' Bush declared. ``We begin a new era for clean air.'' ``No American should have to drive out of town to have to breathe clean air. Every city in America should have clean air. And with this legislation, I firmly believe we will,'' he said. ``Mission defined, mission accomplished,'' he added. The bill, 748 pages long, will affect virtually every American. It was approved by Congress easily last month, belying 16 months of debate and long hours of behind-the-scenes negotiations on a myriad of provisions. In advance of today's bill-signing, environmental groups were hailing the bill's enactment. ``The Clean Air Act of 1990 is like a breath of fresh air after a 10-year smog alert,'' said Sierra Club President Susan Merrow. The law will require new pollution controls for automobiles, electric utilities, factories and thousands of businesses. It eventually is expected to cost the economy as much as $25 billion a year, according to White House estimates. The legislation aims to cut acid rain pollutants by half, sharply reduce urban smog and eliminate most of the toxic chemical emissions from industrial plants by the turn of the century. Many environmentalists, although highly critical of the president on an array of issues from wetland protection to global warming, acknowledge the bill would have had little chance of passage without Bush's support. Federal air pollution controls have not been changed since 1977. Over the last 10 years, attempts to impose new requirements repeatedly were stymied by strong opposition from various economic and regional interests and the Reagan administration. Bush changed much of that by proposing in July 1989 a broad rewrite of the federal clean air laws that set the stage for the congressional debate. The act - approved by the Senate 89-10 and the House 401-25 - will require automakers to install tougher emission controls and service stations to sell cleaner-burning gasoline blends; force thousands of businesses and factories to install new equipment to capture smog-causing pollutants and toxic chemicals; and require coal-burning power plants to cut in half sulfur dioxide emissions, which cause acid rain. Some of the new requirements will begin to be phased in within a few years, although most will not be fully in place until the end of the decade. Some cities with the worst smog problems have as long as 15 to 20 years to meet federal air requirements. The signing of the historic bill is expected to do little to help Bush mend fences with an environmental community that has become increasingly critical of the president. Bush ``has yet to prove he's an environmentalist,'' said Mike Clark, president of Friends of the Earth. The clean air bill ``is his one and only significant environmental achievement and he certainly is not entitled to take sole credit for it,'' added George Frampton, president of the Wilderness Society. Environmentalists have been critical of Bush for not moving more aggressively to deal with global warming - an issue the president maintains steadfastly has not had a thorough scientific examination. While many industrial nations have established goals for reducing global warming pollutants - primarily carbon dioxide from the burning of fossil fuels - the administration has refused to make any specific commitments. Environmentalists point to other issues on which, they say, the administration's policies have been a disappointment. They cite the president's strong support for opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska to oil exploration, slow progress in developing a formal policy to protect wetlands, and hints of wanting to re-examine the Endangered Species Act to take economic issues more heavily into account. Last summer, Bush expressed irritation with environmentalists and declared that their ``grading system is absolutely ... absurd.'' William Reilly, a longtime conservationist and head of the Environmental Protection Agency, staunchly defends Bush's environmental record and suggested the critics often judge Bush against an unfair ``standard of perfection.''

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Stage Moderate Comeback, Grains Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Soybeans futures prices staged a moderate comeback Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid rumors of new export business. Grains were mostly lower. Soybean prices firmed as speculation grew that a U.S.-European food aid package to the Soviet Union would come out of President Bush's upcoming trip to Europe. Soybeans futures were boosted later in the day after rumors began circulating that the United States was preparing to offer subsidized soybean meal to Pakistan, said Dan Cekander, an analyst with Rodman & Renshaw Inc. But the gains probably will be only short-term, Cekander said. ``We've had so many rumors of aid, and they never pan out,'' he said. ``I expect to see further liquidation because the market wants to see business - not hear rumors.'' Soybeans continued to face pressure from a government report issued last week that found larger stocks of the crop than had been expected. Follow-through selling in wheat and corn came from Wednesday's sharp losses. Little export activity and bountiful crops were blamed for another session of significant losses. At the close, wheat futures were 8\ cents to 4 cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.47 a bushel; corn futures were 2} cents to } cent lower with December at $2.22 a bushel; oats were 1} cents to 2\ cents higher with December at $1.09} a bushel; soybeans were 4\ cents to { cent higher with November at $5.58{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Commerce Secretary Gets Tough on Canadian Lumber
DOC.TEXT: Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher pledged Thursday to enforce tariffs in an existing trade agreement that helps Americans compete with Canadian softwood lumber producers. ``Events in Canada suggest that the government of Canada may be under increasing pressure to renegotiate or eliminate'' the 4-year-old memo of understanding between the two countries, Mosbacher said. ``We are firmly committed ... and will take any action necessary and appropriate to enforce the terms of the agreement,'' he said in a letter Thursday to Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., chairman of the House Small Business subcommittee on regulation, energy and business opportunity. Canada agreed in 1986 to impose a 15 percent surtax on lumber exports to the United States to help offset subsidies Canadian producers receive from their government. Canada supplied about 28 percent of the softwood lumber consumed in the United States last year, worth nearly $2.8 billion. But Northwest lawmakers are afraid the export duties will be weakened, allowing Canadians to undercut prices for U.S. softwood lumber and eventually costing jobs. Mosbacher said the 1986 agreement has become a ``political target'' in Canada because of saw mill closures, a stronger Canadian dollar and fear of a market downturn. ``It's not a matter of if, it's a matter of when,'' said Steve Jenning, staff director of Wyden's subcommittee's. ``Their political advisers are urging their people in Ontario to take action prior to the return of Congress in January.'' But Mosbacher said in the letter that while Canada's economic problems have an impact on its lumber industry, they don't affect the subsidies the agreement offsets.

DOC.HEAD: Disney-AAA Ad Pulled for Flunking Safety Belt Test
DOC.TEXT: Walt Disney World and the American Automobile Association have pulled a newspaper advertisement that shows a young girl in a car without a seat belt. In the ad for ``AAA Days'' at Disney theme parks, the girl is standing on the front seat of a convertible whizzing past the Cinderella Castle. Failure to wear a seat belt in Florida can result in a $20 fine, according to the Florida Highway Patrol. Disney spokesman John Dreyer said one of his company's art directors allowed the girl to stand because the photograph was taken in a stationary car. A fan was used to blow the family's hair to make it look like the car was moving. ``It was an honest mistake,'' said Dreyer, who said the ad has been pulled. ``We really had no intention of encouraging people to travel without buckling up.'' The ad was part of a campaign to attract AAA members to Disney World.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar inched higher on world currency markets Thursday in cautious, choppy trading. Gold prices fell overseas but advanced in domestic dealings. On New York's Commodity Exchange, where gold plunged $8.40 an ounce in the previous session, the metal gained $1.50 an ounce to settle at $379.10. Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold at $378.75 an ounce, up $1.15. Traders said the market was thin, with most investors focusing on currencies other than the dollar. ``A lot of people were selling (Japanese) yen and buying (German) marks,'' said Gilbert Cisneros, a trader at the Bank of Boston's office in New York. He said many traders were confused and not willing to bet on what direction the dollar might take. The financial markets continue to await signs that the Federal Reserve has nudged interest rates lower in an effort to stimulate a weakening U.S. economy. Lower interest rates generally are negative for the dollar because they erode the value of dollar-denominated securities. Marc Chandler, an analyst with the firm IDEA, said that once the Fed makes its move, traders will begin looking ahead for yet another easing of interest rates, probably shortly after the new year. Some dealers are looking for Friday's report on the September trade deficit to rekindle interest in the dollar. With the U.S. currency trading at depressed levels, most economists expect some improvement from the $9.3 billion deficit registered in the previous month. Also Friday, the Labor Department is scheduled to report on the consumer price index for October. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 129.30 Japanese yen from 129.05 yen at Wednesday's close. Later in London, it fell to 129.15 yen. In New York the dollar closed at 129.69 yen, up from 129.09 yen on Wednesday. In London, the British pound fell to $1.9590 from $1.9615 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.9575 to buy one pound, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.9600. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.4755 German marks, up from 1.4726; 1.2518 Swiss francs, up from 1.2470; 4.9850 French francs, up from 4.9670; 1,113.25 Italian lire, up from 1,111.00, and 1.1624 Canadian dollars, own from 1.1631. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.4765 German marks, up from 1.4715; 1.2515 Swiss francs, up from 1.2460; 4.9890 French francs, up from 4.9585; 1.6650 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6593; 1,112.50 Italian lire, up from 1,109.00, and 1.1617 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1640. Gold prices fell in London to a late bid of $379.25 a troy ounce from $384.45 late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $378.60 an ounce from $384.40. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell $4.43 an ounce to $379.03. Silver prices also fell. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.117 a troy ounce, down from $4.16 on Wednesday. In London the metal fell to a late bid of $4.16 a troy ounce from $4.21.

DOC.HEAD: Embattled Eastern Flying Wounded After Creditors' Attack
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines got a cash infusion that should keep it alive for a few weeks, but the struggling carrier faces another test next month when it tries to persuade a bankruptcy judge to hand out more money. Eastern's fight for survival is made even tougher by wounds suffered in the boisterous battle with creditors who want the airline shut so its assets can be sold off, industry analysts said Thursday. Court-appointed trustee Martin R. Shugrue Jr. agreed Eastern's prospects for recovery had been harmed by a ``reckless and shameful'' attack from the unsecured creditors. They told U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland that Eastern has no chance of regaining financial strength, which has withered relentlessly since a strike and bankruptcy filing in March 1989 threw the airline's future into doubt. But Shugrue said Eastern has a reasonable hope of growing stronger through its marketing of first-class seats at coach-class prices, despite a likely loss of overall bookings following widespread publicity of the creditors' claims that Eastern was dying. ``America loves an underdog, and we are an underdog,'' Shugrue told a news conference Thursday. ``We are the underdog in this indutry.'' Shugrue persuaded the judge during a hearing Wednesday night to keep Eastern flying for now, with an immediate withdrawal of $15 million from an escrow account that the creditors wanted to preserve. On Thursday, Shugrue said he had the court's support, even though Lifland would not give Eastern the entire $30 million it had sought. The judge said he wants to see how well Eastern is doing early next month before it can tap into the account for another $15 million. Shugrue predicted Thursday that Eastern will be able to show enough of an improvement to get the money. But soon, he's going to have to ask for more, with an anticipated request for $40 million coming in late December to be followed by a request for $10 million in early January. After that, Eastern thinks it can turn the corner toward profitability, even though the creditors fear the airline is throwing good money after bad. Analysts also have their doubts about Eastern's future. Raymond E. Neidl at Dillon Read & Co. Inc. said Eastern might encounter troubles just showing the judge it is doing well enough to get the next $15 million. Neidl said that when the judge gave Eastern some but not all of the money Shugrue wanted Wednesday, he may have sent a signal that the airline should start selling what it can before the inevitable occurs. ``It could be kind of a push saying, `Maybe it's time to sell the assets while you're a going concern,''' Neidl said. An active business can generally expect to get a better price for assets than a business forced to liquidate. Creditors said they stood by their view that Eastern cannot become a viable, stand-alone airline at a time when fuel prices seem out of control and the United States is displaying symptoms of a recession. The unsecured creditors, who include banks, airplane companies and labor unions, said they had not yet plotted their next move, however. ``We have some ideas, but the committee will be meeting to talk about that,'' attorney Joel B. Zweibel said Thursday. ``So at the moment there isn't any public statement on their intentions.'' Miami-based Eastern, meanwhile, was assuring its 18,000 workers they are still in business while checking with travel agents to see how much damage the airline had incurred. ``One of the problems we have to address is we did lose a significant amount of business,'' said Eastern spokesman Jim Ashlock. ``We have to regain now that public confidence. It's very difficult to get back cancellations because that usually means they've booked somewhere else.'' Some travel agents say they are advising people against booking flights on Eastern. Others are suggesting that travelers use their credit cards for tickets, so if Eastern goes under the customers can refuse to pay the credit card company. E.J. Breen, spokesman for the Eastern pilots union, said the fatal damage has been done because of the likelihood travel agents will book away from Eastern. ``I really and truly think that this whole process has put the final nail in the coffin,'' Breen said.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Lawyers Withdraw from Eastern Airlines Criminal Case
With AM-Eastern Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers representing most of the defendants in criminal proceedings against Eastern Airlines and several of its managers withdrew from the case Thursday because their clients don't have money to pay legal bills. The lawyers had entered the case believing the air carrier would stand behind its employees and pay the legal fees. However, U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland, who is overseeing the finances of the embattled airline, last week refused to approve the payments. Eastern - which is struggling to regain the confidence of the flying public, especially business travelers - is currently losing about $1 million a day. An Eastern spokesman said the carrier would try to help the employees, possibly using voluntary contributions. ``Whatever we might be able to do at the company to assist them, we're going to explore and pursue,'' said James R. Ashlock, an Eastern spokesman in Miami. ``There's been already a movement to obtain from the 18,000 Eastern employees voluntary funds to underwrite the defense for these people. The employees here do feel an affiliation, and in many respects, what's happened to them is unfair,'' he said. At a hearing Thursday, U.S. District Judge I. Leo Glasser of Brooklyn granted the lawyers' request to be removed from the case. The defendants, who said they would seek court-appointed counsel, were directed to return to court on Nov. 26 with their new lawyers. The lawyers were dismissed hours after Lifland granted Eastern more time and money to show it could recover at least some of its past strength. The airline's unsecured creditors had asked the bankruptcy judge to shut down Eastern and liquidate it. Eastern, once one of the nation's top airlines, was struggling to remain solvent when the airline and nine of its managers were indicted in August on criminal charges that they falsified maintenance and safety records to keep their jetliners in the air and carrying passengers. The 60-count indictment, unprecedented in the airline industry, charged a pattern of pressure and intimidation from the airline's headquarters in Miami to ``keep the aircraft in flight at all costs.'' Two Eastern foremen at Kennedy airport have pleaded guilty to ignoring needed aircraft repairs and then falsifying records to make it appear the work had been done. The foremen, who are cooperating with prosecutors, said the scheme was orchestrated by executives at the airline who coerced them into altering the documents. The highest ranking executive charged was Edward Upton, 40, a former vice president. Because of an earlier agreement, Eastern will pay his legal fees and his attorney, Stephen E. Kaufman, will remain as his lawyer. The law firm retained by Eastern will also continue in the case. One of the former defense lawyers, Edward J. Little, said the trial is expected to last up to four months with legal fees for each of the defendants totalling $300,000 or more. Little represented Jacques Jean, a former maintenance supervisor accused of falsifying aircraft records. The start of the trial, originally scheduled for Jan. 28, 1991, will likely be postponed.

DOC.HEAD: GM to Export Cars to Yugoslavia
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. will begin exporting a small number of Chevrolet, Pontiac and Cadillac cars to Yugoslavia beginning early next year, the automaker said Thursday. The initial order is for 450 1991 GM Chevrolet Corsica, Cadillac Sedan DeVille and Pontiac Grand Prix and Bonneville cars. The order was to be signed Friday in a ceremony at GM headquarters in Detroit. GM also has agreements to establish vehicle and component assembly operations in other Eastern European countries, including Hungary, Czechoslovakia, the Soviet Union and the former East Germany. The Yugoslavian-bound cars will go to YK, a vehicle distributor located in Sarajevo, Yugoslavia. ``Our target is to sell 1,000 vehicles next year from the Sarajevo dealership,'' YK President Sead Dizdarevic said in a news release. Within a year, he said he hopes to expand his GM dealership network from four to 17 outlets. YK estimated that of the 300,000 new vehicles sold in Yugoslavia last year, about 25 percent were imported.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Declines
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply fell slightly in the week ended Nov. 5, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 fell to a seasonally adjusted $3,315.7 billion from a revised $3,315.8 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, fell to a seasonally adjusted $4,084.2 billion from a revised $4,085.1 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $822.6 billion from a revised $820.2 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The growth rate in M2 in the last 52 weeks was 4.7 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The growth rate in M3 over the past year was 1.9 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 1 percent to 5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,316.3 billion, a 4.1 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,090.2 billion, up 1.6 percent, while M1 rose 5.7 percent to an average of $819.9 billion. In other reports: -The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $263 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $253 million the previous week. -The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $318.2 billion in the two-week period ended Nov. 14, up from $317.8 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Campbell Soup Reports Record Quarterly Earnings at Annual Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Campbell Soup Co. on Thursday said higher sales and a worldwide reorganization boosted first-quarter earnings 28 percent for the best quarter in the company's history. For the three months ended Oct. 28, net earnings climbed to $105.1 million, or 82 cents a share, on sales of $1.6 billion. In the first quarter last year, earnings were $83 million, or 64 cents a share, on revenues of $1.5 billion. ``We are pleased with the progress we have made during this first quarter and remain confident about the rest of the year,'' Campbell chief executive officer David W. Johnson said at a shareholders' meeting. Johnson said Campbell's, which has been struggling to improve its sluggish performance in the industry, has turned the corner to profitability. He said the 28 percent increase was the best quarterly performance in the company's 121-year history. ``The quarter was better than expected,'' said John M. McMillin, a food industry analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. ``They certainly got their fiscal year off to a good start.'' In fiscal 1990, Campbell's profits dropped sharply as the company continued a two-year restructuring and corporate makeover. Earnings for the year were $4.4 million or 3 cents per share, compared with a profit of $13 million or 10 cents per share in 1989. The 90-minute shareholder meeting was the first for Johnson, who was brought in last January as the first outsider to hold the CEO position in the company's history. Johnson, who had run Gerber Products Co., was known for turning around beleaguered companies. Johnson announced that the board of directors had approved an increase in quarterly dividends, from 25 cents to 29 cents per share, payable Jan. 31, 1991. The higher earnings were seen as a first step toward pacifying disgruntled members of the founding Dorrance family, who own a major stake in Campbell's and have urged selling off the company. The rift in the Dorrance family and Campbell's depressed stock price had made the company the target of frequent takeover rumors. Campbell North America, the company's largest division, reported a 30 percent increase in operating earnings to $177.7 million, compared with $137.2 million the year before. Strong volume gains in two new condensed soups - cream of broccoli and the Teddy Bear line - boosted sales for the period to $1.1 billion from $1.09 billion last year. Operating earnings in Campbell's biscuit and bakery division were up 16 percent to $25.7 million from $22.1 million the year before, boosted by a strong performance from Pepperidge Farm. Sales increased 9 percent to $212 million from $195 million in 1989. Favorable exchange rates boosted sales for Campbell International by 18 percent to $307 million from $261 million last year. Operating earnings for the quarter were $4.1 million, compared with $2.7 million last year. Johnson said Campbell plans to boost its earnings per share by 20 percent annually over the next few years. He said the company also plans to achieve at least a 20 percent return on equity and a 20 percent cash return on assets.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat Sharply Down; Soybeans Stage Moderate Comeback
DOC.TEXT: Wheat prices fell sharply Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade, plunging to near contract lows on mild weather conditions and a dearth of export business. On other commodities markets, soybeans rose; corn fell; gold and platinum ended slightly higher; silver slipped; and meat and livestock futures were mixed. Wheat prices settled 7} cents to 4 cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.47{ a bushel. ``Nothing. That's what traders are seeing in the way of export business in the grains,'' said Mickey Luth, an analyst for Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in Chicago. Recent weather forecasts predicting above-normal temperatures in the regions where winter wheat is grown also pressured futures prices, Luth said. Soybean prices on the Board of Trade staged a moderate comeback from previous session lows as speculation grew that a U.S.-European food aid package to the Soviet Union would come out of President Bush's upcoming trip to Europe. Soybeans futures were boosted later in the day after rumors began circulating that the United States was preparing to offer subsidized soybean meal to Pakistan, said Dan Cekander, an analyst with Rodman & Renshaw Inc. But the gains probably will be only short-term, Cekander said. ``We've had so many rumors of aid, and they never pan out,'' he said. ``I expect to see further liquidation because the market wants to see business - not hear rumors.'' Soybeans continued to face pressure from a government report issued last week that found larger stocks of the crop than had been expected. Corn suffered from a good harvest and little export activity. Corn futures settled 2} cents to 1\ cents lower with December at $2.22 a bushel; oats settled 1} cents to 2} cents higher with December at $1.09} a bushel; soybeans settled { cent to 4\ cents higher with November at $5.58{ a bushel. Gold and platinum ended slightly higher on New York's Commodity Exchange on support from Japanese buying of platinum and an early rally in crude oil prices. Gold settled $1.40 to $1.50 higher with December at $380.00 a troy ounce. Silver settled 7.1 cents to 5.7 cents lower with December at $4.117 an ounce. Platinum settled $1.30 to $1.80 higher with January at $415.70. Energy futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange slid as traders continued to bet on peace in the Persian Gulf. Light sweet crude settled 10 cents lower to 80 cents higher with December at $31.12 a barrel; heating oil settled .01 cent to 1.12 cents higher with December at 86.67 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline settled .23 cent lower to .60 cent higher with December at 80.16 cents a gallon. Cattle futures prices were mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, pressured by commission-house selling and profit-taking. Hog futures suffered from another round of profit-taking after generally enjoying high prices because of lower-than-expected near-term stocks. Live cattle settled .25 cent lower to .08 cent higher with December at 78.97 cents a pound; feeder cattle was .05 cent lower to .12 cent higher with November at 88.67 cents a pound; hogs were .55 cent lower to .22 cent higher with December at 53.35 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 2.00 cents to 1.92 cent lower with February at 70.12 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: 56 Employees Disciplined for Accepting Gifts
DOC.TEXT: More than 50 New York Telephone employees were fired, resigned or face pay cuts for accepting gifts and gratuities from vendors, the company announced Thursday. The employees were from the company's Buildings Department, which is responsible for construction, repairs, cleaning and routine maintenance of New York Telephone property. The company said the 28 employees who either resigned or were fired accepted nearly $50,000 in cash, gifts and gratuities since 1985. Another 28 employees face fines or other disciplinary action for accepting gifts such as liquor or gift certificates during the holiday season since 1985. The tips violated New York Telephone's code of ethics, said spokesman Tom Pica. Cases involving allegations of criminal activities have been turned over to the Manhattan district attorney's office. Another Buildings Department employee, John Nobile, was indicted June 15 for grand larceny, bribe-taking and other charges. A trial date has not yet been set, said district attorney's office spokesman Gerald McKelvey.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 16th graf to CORRECT S&P 500 composite index figure; PICK UP final graf, The NASDAQ ...
DOC.TEXT: The stock market suffered a moderate setback Thursday, giving up some of the gains recorded in its rally since mid-October. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which had built up a net gain of 71.04 points in the week's first three sessions, dropped 14.60 to 2,545.05. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 591 up, 918 down and 470 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 151.37 million shares, against 179.31 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 182.17 million shares. Oil prices fluctuated through a mixed session, and interest rates rose in the credit markets. Prices of long-term government bonds fell slightly, lifting their yields to the 8.52 percent-8.53 percent range. Analysts said that provided stock traders with enough incentive to cash in some of their recent gains. The recovery in stock prices has been based to a considerable degree on expectations that the Federal Reserve will soon take new steps to relax its credit policy. Some observers believe that any likely Fed action has been largely ``discounted,'' or taken into account in advance, by the market's rise of late. A primary item on the market agenda for Friday is the Labor Department's monthly report on the consumer price index. If advance estimates are correct, the October index will show an increase of perhaps 0.6 percent or 0.7 percent, down from 0.8 percent in both August and September. Losers among the blue chips included General Motors, down | at 39\; International Business Machines, down ~ at 112|; General Electric, down \ at 55, and Philip Morris, down ] at 48{. Bank stocks bogged down as well. J.P. Morgan fell } to 40}; Chemical Banking ] to 12; Chase Manhattan ] to 10}; NCNB 1[ to 23\, and Barnett Banks 1[ to 20{. Monarch Capital tumbled 3 to 2{, for a 54.5 percent percentage drop. The insurance holding company reported a $67.79 million loss for the third quarter, including discontinued operations, and suspended the dividend on its preferred stock. MCA rose 2] to 67~ pending talks scheduled for next week toward its planned acquisition by Matsushita Electrical. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $26 billion, or 0.87 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 1.56 to 173.12. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 3.99 to 371.23, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 3.38 at 317.02. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market dropped 2.41 to 354.46. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 296.69, down 1.18.

DOC.HEAD: Gillette Chairman, Two Other Execs to Retire
DOC.TEXT: Gillette Co. announced Thursday that Chairman Colman M. Mockler Jr. and two other senior executives would retire, paving the way for a succession in leadership at the shaving products company. Mockler, 60, who has also been chief executive officer since 1975, will leave at the end of 1991. Derwyn F. Phillips, 60, a vice chairman, and John W. Symons, 60, executive vice president overseeing the company's North Atlantic division, will retire from their positions by the end of 1990. No replacements to Mockler or Phillips were named. Robert J. Murray, 49, who has been chairman at Braun AG, a Gillette subsidiary, will replace Symons on Jan. 1. The company said Alfred M. Zeien, 60, a vice chairman, was elected president and chief operating officer effective Jan. 1. Analysts said Gillette had been sending signals that Zeien eventually would take a leading role in the company, but they doubted he would succeed Mockler due to his age. The company said in a statement the moves were ``designed to begin the process of an orderly succession in management.'' Mockler, who has been chairman since 1976, said he felt now was an appropriate time to announce his retirement because he is pleased with Gillette's products and organization. ``The company is in a very good position,'' he said. Some analysts said they were not surprised by the announcement, noting the ages of the retirees. But Diana Temple, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, was surprised by the departure of Symons, saying he was a main force behind Gillette's new Sensor razor, introduced earlier this year. Mockler received praise for giving Gillette stability. He helped guide the company through two takeover battles in the 1980s and oversaw a major restructuring. ``He was probably running the company through its most tumultuous time,'' said Jack Salzman, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Co. Under the realignment announced Thursday, the company's four major operating units - Gillette North Atlantic, Stationery Products-North Atlantic, Gillette International and Diversified Operations - will report to Zeien. Mockler said the biggest challenge for the company is take advantage of new opportunities and markets around the world.

DOC.HEAD: Fell $1.23 Billion in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 523 money market mutual funds fell $1.23 billion in the latest week to $417.1 billion, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The decline in the seven-day period ended Wednesday followed a $2.94 billion increase in fund assets the previous week to an all-time high of $418.33 billion,the Washington-based mutual trade fund group said. It said that in the latest week, assets of 259 general purpose funds fell by $153.2 milion to $148.63 billion; assets of 104 broker-dealer funds fell $356.7n million to $164.97 billion; and assets of 160 institutional funds fell $724.4 million to $103.49 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Tuesday to 7.34 percent from 7.38 percent the previous week, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield slipped to 7.40 percent from 7.42 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 49 days, the same as the previous week, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 6.01 percent as of Wednesday from 6.02 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, was 5.08 percent, unchanged from the previous week. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.58 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.60 percent the previous week. Yields were 7.71 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 7.73 percent; 7.80 percent on 2{-year CDs, down from 7.84 percent; and 8.03 percent on 5-year CDs, unchanged from the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Carrageenan Called Revolutionary for Meat Industry
DOC.TEXT: Health experts, restaurant giants and the meat industry are all watching a McDonald's Corp. consumer test of a super-lean beef developed by replacing fat with an algae product called carrageenan. Analysts and industry insiders say if it's successful, the new product could reshape a beef industry often criticized by health experts for its fatty output. ``If it's really palatable, it's revolutionary,'' said Phil Sokolof, a millionaire industrialist from Omaha who ran full-page advertisements in several major newspapers accusing fast-food chains of selling too many high-fat foods. ``We're talking about a complete change in American diet,'' he said. Last year for the first time ever, more chicken than beef was consumed in the United States. A worried beef industry has sought for nearly half a decade to develop leaner beef for health-conscious consumers. The answer may have come with carrageenan, a gum-like substance used to bind ingredients together much as fat would, said Mary Adolf, a spokeswoman for the Chicago-based Beef Industry Council of the Meat Board. ``I think what's interesting about this product is the lean patty itself has a taste and a texture similar to a product that has significantly more fat,'' Ms. Adolf said. ``This product has a lot of potential.'' Carrageenan is widely used in pharmaceuticals and ice cream products, but now is expanding into other areas, including possible use in all processed meats to reduce fat, said Alan Mathis, a spokesman for National Food Processors in Washington, D.C. But national marketing of the beef or any other carrageenan-based product probably is a long way off, said Charles Levitt, a senior livestock analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Super-lean beef is ``certainly not going to hurt beef demand any,'' Levitt said. ``It's not going to change overnight, obviously, and will take time to filter its way into the market, but it's a positive.'' The food service industry is watching to see if the public will sink its teeth into the product. McDonald's said Wednesday it is test-marketing in restaurants in the Harrisburg, Pa. area a low-fat hamburger that has carregeenan as an ingredient. The quarter-pound burger, called Lean Deluxe, and its condiments have 10 grams, or 2{ teaspoons of fat. McDonald's Quarter Pounder, in contrast, has 20 grams of fat. Dieticians recommend that a person eat no more than 67 grams of fat a day. Nutritionists, hesitant to praise the low-fat beef outright, expressed optimism. ``The impact on a nation that loves its fatty hamburgers could be extremely dramatic,'' said Bonnie Liebman, nutrition director at the Center for Science in the Public Interest in Washington, D.C. The Agriculture Department also is considering buying the low-fat beef for the national school lunch program, said Dale Huffman, an Auburn University meat biochemist who helped develop the meat. ``Obviously, if the USDA accepts the leaner meat, it will be a boost. And it would help immeasurably if kids like it, since the majority of hamburger eaters are younger people,'' Huffman said. His research, and that at two other universities, was funded by the Meat Board, which since 1986 has collected $1 per head of cattle from ranchers to find ways to produce leaner beef.

DOC.HEAD: End Mixed After Volatile Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT natural gas price
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil prices finished slightly lower Thursday after see-sawing in brisk trading in the absence of significant news from the Persian Gulf. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the December-delivery contract for benchmark light sweet crude oil swung in a wide range, rising as much as 69 cents a barrel and falling as much as $1.01 before rallying to close at $31.12, down 4 cents from a day earlier. Contracts for later months mostly rose. The market's behavior reflected what traders called an underlying tendency to weaken unless there's a profound increase in Persian Gulf tensions that could provoke a long-awaited fight between the United States and Iraq. The market tumbled nearly $2 a barrel Wednesday as traders focused on the fundamentals of supply and demand, which show that petroleum stockpiles are plentiful. Oil now is nearly $10 lower than the panic-driven highs reached during the tense stages of the 3-month-old Iraqi occupation of Kuwait. ``Basically, what happened today is just a continuation of what we've been seeing,'' said James Fiedler, a broker and vice president at E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc., a New York trading concern. ``Ample supply, falling demand and if there is a war it won't be soon.'' Traders said the market's rebound late in the day was accelerated by short-covering, in which traders who had sold borrowed oil contracts on the mistaken hunch they would fall in price scrambled to buy them back. Some traders said the market's late rally may have been a reaction to a rumor that the United States had formulated a specific attack date to retake Kuwait from Iraq. But others said that rumor was stale speculation and had no influence on prices. Among refined products traded on the Mercantile Exchange, wholesale home-heating oil for December delivery rose .3 cent to 86.67 cents a gallon. Contracts for more distant months also closed higher. Wholesale gasoline for December delivery fell 2.3 cents a gallon to 80.16 cents, while more distant months were mostly higher. Natural gas for December delivery fell .28 cent per 1,000 cubic feet to $2.40. More distant months were mostly lower.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Search for Supercow
DOC.TEXT: Using computers, sophisticated imaging equipment and genetic mapping, university scientists are trying to discover ``supercows'' in the laboratory. ``If you look at genetics, we've made so much more progress in the last 15 years than we made in the last 100,'' said Mike Brown of the National Milk Producers Federation. ``There's certainly more interest in it because it's getting a little tougher to make a living in dairy,'' he said. Economics is a driving force in the science of breeding a better bovine, experts said. ``The quest for the supercow has some real important management implications,'' said William Graves, state dairy specialist at the University of Massachusetts. ``Farmers are going to have to look for alternate ways to try and stay in business and still produce what they produce at less cost.'' At the University of Massachusetts, professors Abel Ponce de Leon and James Robl are mapping part of the cow's genetic package, with the help of a three-year, $210,000 grant from the USDA. The project also is supported by the Eastern Artificial Insemination Cooperative. Using existing studies that showed a variation in DNA is related to milk production, the researchers plan to isolate a particular chromosome, called bovine chromosome 23. ``We are going to concentrate on one chromosome where there is a high likelihood that there will be genes that participate in the control of milk production,'' Ponce de Leon said. ``What we're doing is we're using a direct approach to be able to select animals on their DNA rather than on production traits or physical characteristics,'' said Robl. The advantages of using molecular biology to track down good milkers is that it takes the trial-and-error out of the equation, said Caird E. Rexroad, a research physiologist with the U.S. Department of Agriculture. ``Before we had to depend on the animal's milk production and evaluating the production of the daughters of specific bulls,'' Rexroad said. Other scientific advances in dairy production include the process of selling frozen embryos from high-yield cows to be implanted in surrogates. Genetic research is going on at various laboratories across the country, said Rexroad, who said that Ponce de Leon and Robl are the only team he knows of working to isolate a specific chromosome. ``Probably in the future we will have a few less cows on the farms than we do now. These techniques will make it possible for the most efficient farmers to survive,'' said Rexroad.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Considering Cuts in Benefit Programs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 4 pvs bgng: ``President Bush,'' with 3 new grafs of Bush quotes, picks up 5th graf pvs, now 7th graf: ``In the past,'' also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is considering cuts in popular government benefit programs such as Social Security and Medicare as part of the budget it will submit to Congress in February, an administration official said Thursday. The official, who spoke on the condition his name not be used, said the cuts being considered would reduce benefits for affluent recipients with the savings used to provide tax cuts to the poor and middle class. Such an action ``is clearly being contemplated very seriously,'' said the official, who also stressed that all planning for the new budget was in a very preliminary stage with final decisions a long way from being made. Meanwhile, President Bush received a gloomy assessment of economic prospects from a group of business executives on Thursday. They told the president they believed the country had probably entered a recession. Commenting later, Bush stopped short of saying the country was already in a downturn. ``I'm not an economist but most seem to feel that if we have a recession that meets these technical terms, that it will not be deep and that we'll come out of it relatively soon - six months at most,'' Bush said in an interview on the Cable News Network. In the past, the administration and Congress have both shied away from proposing cuts in Social Security and Medicare because of the firestorm of protests such changes could raise. The benefit cuts are receiving a second look, the official said, because the administration believes that the new deficit-reduction agreement passed by Congress conferred added authority. In the past, the administration shied away from proposing tax cuts and benefit reductions for fear that Congress would pass the tax cuts and leave the benefit levels unchanged. However, the deficit-reduction law passed last month includes a ``pay-as-you-go'' mechanism that will trigger automatic benefit cuts unless Congress reduces benefits in line with any tax reductions approved by lawmakers. The possibility of the benefit cuts was first disclosed in Thursday's Wall Street Journal. In his meeting with executives, Bush received a generally gloomy report on the prospects for the economy with the general consensus of the group being that the country was probably in a recession. John G. Medlin Jr., president and chief executive officer of First Wachovia Corp., a leading bank holding company, told reporters afterward that the general consensus among the executives was that the country probably has entered its first recession in eight years. ``I think there was probably a view that we may have slipped into a recession,'' said Medlin, whose bank is headquartered in Winston-Salem, N.C. ``There was not much argument that we were somewhere in that area between a little growth and a little decline.'' Medlin said the executives, representing banks and industrial firms, noted in particular the problems besetting the construction and real estate industries, which have been hard hit by overbuilding and slumping prices. Besides Bush, administration officials participating in Thursday's meeting were Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, Budget Director Richard Darman and John Sununu, Bush's chief of staff. A White House official, who spoke on the condition he not be named, said the president was trying to decide what steps to take to soften the impact of the current slowdown. Last week, Bush and Michael Boskin, his chief economic adviser, came close to saying the country is in a recession. Bush spoke of ``tough times'' and said he wanted to insure that ``to the degree a president can do something to soften the blow or to stimulate economic growth, that he tries to do it.'' The White House official said Thursday's meeting followed a session Bush had Wednesday with Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan and other top banking regulators. At that meeting, according to another administration source who also spoke on the condition of anonymity, Sununu and Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher talked about a slowdown in bank lending, which they blamed on regulatory overkill in the wake of the savings and loan crisis. Mosbacher has complained for months about a ``credit crunch'' choking off the flow of credit needed to keep the economy healthy. Greenspan and other banking regulators, however, have argued that the slowdown in lending reflects current weak loan demand rather than bank examiners being over zealous. Administration officials have said that the president was reviewing various proposals to stimulate economic growth and would likely submit a set of recommendations as part of the 1991 budget, which he will send to Congress in early February. Medlin said neither the president nor any of the other administration officials gave any hint of what pro-growth initiatives they may propose. ``The president just listened. He didn't give us his views,'' Medlin said. ``He was very sincerely looking for views out in the real world.'' The Wednesday and Thursday meetings were an outgrowth of a meeting Bush had over the weekend at the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md., with Brady, Boskin, Darman and Vice President Dan Quayle. Boskin last week said that ``at best'' the economy was in a lull, which he predicted would last through the first half of 1991. He said that a new administration economic forecast, due to be completed soon, envisioned the possibility of the economy ``slipping into negative territory'' by year's end. Boskin said it was possible that the economic contraction could last into early 1991. The traditional definition of a recession is two consecutive quarters in which the gross national product, the total output of goods and services, declines. The White House refused to release a list of those meeting with Bush, saying the sessions were private. ``It's an opportunity for the president to hear them (the business leaders.) These are listening sessions,'' the White House official said.

DOC.HEAD: Newsweek, U.S. News Announce Ad Rate Increase
DOC.TEXT: Advertising rates will rise for Newsweek and U.S. News and World Report in 1991, the weekly news magazines announced Thursday. The increases, which follow a similar move at rival Time, were blamed on rising costs for postage and news coverage. In addition, U.S. News plans to increase its cover price from $1.95 to $2.50 effective with the Jan. 7 issue, matching the cover price of the other two major weeklies. The advertising rate increases at Newsweek, with circulation of 3.1 million readers, will boost four-color ad rates by 7 percent and black-and-white by 10 percent. Effective with the Jan. 7 issue, the rate for a four-color page will be $108,050, and $69,455 for a black-and-white page. Newsweek publisher Peter Eldredge said advertising linage was off about 5 percent this year, while costs for postage and news coverage, including reporting from the Persian Gulf, have increased significantly. U.S. News, with circulation of 2.3 million, said it would raise ad rates 7.9 percent across the board, bringing the four-color page rate to $72,400 and black-and-white to $48,500. U.S. News president and chief executive officer Fred Drasner said the rate changes followed a year of growth in circulation, revenue and newsstand sales. Carol Welsh, a spokeswoman, said ad pages were off slightly for the year. Officials at Newsweek and U.S. News said postage increases would exceed 20 percent in 1991. Both said they were exploring alternative delivery methods. Time Warner announced on Nov. 5 that it planned to increase its national four-color rate by 6.5 percent to $128,000 effective Jan. 1. The rate was based on a circulation of 4 million readers. It said other ad rates would increase by varying amounts depending on the edition and type of ad.

DOC.HEAD: Advisory Committee Says FDA Needs More Regulatory Power
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 3 grafs edited to CORRECT that committee was formed by industry, sted FDA
DOC.TEXT: An industry committee told the Food and Drug Administration on Thursday that the agency needs more regulatory power over generic drugs, including the ability to ban from the new drug business people who violate its regulations. The panel established by the Generic Pharmaceutical Industry Association also said the agency should extend some regulations that apply to newly branded drugs to generic drugs, and generic manufacturers' trade associations should establish a code of ethics for members. The Blue Ribbon Committee on Generic Medicines was established in the wake of disclosures that some generic companies had faked test results and accusations that some company executives had bribed FDA employees. A new drug, if patented, may not be manufactured by anyone except the holder of the patent, or a company licensed by a patent holder. When the patent expires, however, anyone may make the drug as a generic, and those drugs are generally cheaper than the original. Approval for patented drugs is a long and difficult process that takes years and requires the manufacturer to show that the drug is both safe and effective. Approval for generic drugs is much simpler. The manufacturer generally has to show only that the drug reaches approximately the same concentration in the bloodstream that the original does. In those equivalence tests, some companies did not actually test their own drug, but tested the branded original against itself - a form of cheating practically guaranteed to show what the industry calls ``bioequivalence.'' ``The committee believes generic medicines make a major contribution to consumers,'' the panel of five physicians and two lawyers said in a statement summarizing its recommendations. ``The committee recognizes that its recommendations may increase some companies' costs, but nonetheless believes that the increased benefit to the public associated with a reliable supply of generic drugs justifies the additional expense.'' The summary gave no examples of what the increased costs might amount to. Congress, the committee said, should: -Permit the agency to debar individuals who commit certain offenses from participating in the development, application for approval, manufacture or sale of products regulated by the Food and Drug Administration. -Increase criminal penalties and require a return of profits resulting from criminal misconduct. -Require corporations whose employees are convicted of misconduct in the approval process to prove that their products are still safe and effective. -Give the FDA additional subpoena powers. The committee said FDA should: -Require public disclosure of any financial arrangements outside of fee-for-service contracts between applicants for approval of generic drugs and testing laboratories. -Impose the same standards of responsibility for generic applicants that currently pertain to applicants sponsoring experimental drugs. -Try to identify and resolve controversial issues before beginning review of new generic drugs. -Issue additional guidance to the industry on how to demonstrate bioequivalence.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Airlines Offers $25 Companion Fare
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines said Thursday it will offer low fares to people traveling in pairs, with $25 companion fares for passengers purchasing certain discount tickets. The fares match offers recently made by other airlines and will be available in most Northwest markets in the contiguous United States. Tickets will be available for purchase from Nov. 16 through Nov. 30 for travel through Feb. 28, the Eagan-based airline said. Minimum stay requirements apply, as do blackout periods around Thanksgiving, Christmas and the New Year. Northwest is America's fourth largest airline, serving 135 cities in 40 states, Europe, Asia, Canada, Mexico and the Caribbean.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Outlook: Cost-Cutting, Mergers, Stiff Competition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf to CORRECT spelling of Additional; PICK UP 14th graf, The report ...
DOC.TEXT: Wall Street's struggling securities firms face weak profits and more consolidation in the 1990s as they regroup in an increasingly competitive world market, Moody's Investors Service said Thursday. In its annual report on the securities industry, Moody's said reversing the mammoth buildup in the heyday of big-fee mergers and active stock markets in the 1980s will be the focus of the current decade. ``This overcapacity will take years to reduce, and will put fundamental downward pressure on securities firms' returns,'' said the report, written by Moody's vice president John Kriz. The securities industry has struggled since the October 1987 stock market crash. More than 45,000 jobs have been erased and the key business lines of investment banking, leveraged buyouts, and mergers and acquisitions have nosedived. ``The outlook now is that those three areas will be much, much smaller and in some cases nonexistent,'' said Moody's vice president Christopher Mahoney, who helped prepare the report. ``The Street was subsidizing a lot of growth domestically and internationally from lucrative businesses that are drying up or diminishing,'' he said. Moody's predicted further consolidation leading to domination by firms created through acquisition by wealthy companies. ``Ultimately there may be few, if any, large independent Wall Street securities firms,'' the report said. The power of diversified, strong owners has been a theme of the industry's woes this year, in which several major securities firms have been bailed out of severe financial difficulty by deep-pocketed parents. Most recently, CS First Boston Inc. this week received a $300 million equity infusion from its Swiss parent, CS Holding, which took majority control of the investment banking firm. CS First Boston's main U.S. subsidiary is First Boston Corp. Mahoney said a problem with the trend is that the survival of the fittest is thrown on its head. Wall Street's failed firms used to be acquired by the successful ones. ``One impediment to that now is that a lot of weak firms are owned by strong parents, so they don't die a natural death,'' Mahoney said. ``They're not absorbed by strong firms; they're maintained as independent entities.'' The Moody's report said intense competition, continued overcapacity and the decline in major business segments mean weak prospects for profitability on Wall Street through the end of the century. ``Additional risks are the temptation for managements to ease profit pressure by taking greater risks, and the likelihood of more aggressive involvement in U.S. and overseas securities markets by powerful foreign securities firms and banks,'' Moody's said. The report also cited a recent erosion of the Depression-era Glass-Steagall Act that prevented commercial banks from entering the securities industry. It said several U.S. bank-holding companies, including J.P. Morgan, Citicorp and Bankers Trust, ``are eager to expand further into the securities business, and they pose important competitive threats to U.S. securities firms.'' A similar trend is occurring in Japan, Moody's said, increasing the challenge to U.S. firms' core businesses and markets. Firms across the board face cost-cutting pressures, Moody's said. Likely targets for reductions are reducing the ballooned compensation of the 1980s, eliminating whole businesses and exiting from unprofitable foreign markets. ``The 1980s goal of becoming a global player in a broad range of products is fading for many firms,'' Moody's said. ``Managements are refocusing on core business in which they can build sustainable competitive advantages.'' Mahoney said: ``The Street lost a lot of money in London and Tokyo.''

DOC.HEAD: Claims Against Collapsed Firm To Exceed $20 Billion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs to UPDATE with judge denying government extension; PICKS UP 6th graf pvs, `More than...
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Drexel-S&Ls-List
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for investors and companies that bought junk bonds from Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. filed claims Thursday for well over $10 billion alleging rampant lawbreaking by the collapsed Wall Street firm. The claims in U.S. Bankruptcy Court are in addition to $6.8 billion sought by two federal thrift bailout agencies and by far exceed the amount Drexel can dole out in its Chapter 11 reorganization. Attorneys were still calculating the total, but said litigation claims against Drexel would exceed $20 billion. One New York law firm alone filed 11 cases seeking $9.28 billion on behalf of shareholders and companies that assert they were defrauded by Drexel, the once high-flying investment firm that sought bankruptcy court refuge in February. Thursday was the filing deadline for claims against Drexel. After a lengthy hearing, U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Frank Conrad denied a government request for another 90 days to examine the junk bond holdings of more savings and loans. More than 100 civil lawsuits have been filed against Drexel. Lawyers for the firm, plaintiffs and the government are negotiating to estimate how much Drexel will set aside to pay all the litigation claims. Drexel would use that figure in devising a reorganization plan, and claimants could receive a fixed percentage based on the amount of their claims. A negotiated estimate would be presented to U.S. District Judge Milton Pollack for approval. ``In bankruptcy size frequently prevails over quality,'' said David Berger, a Philadelphia lawyer who is heading a mass of cases against Drexel, its convicted junk bond financier Michael Milken and others. The estimate is not expected to come close to meeting the claims. Drexel has only about $3 billion in assets, plus various investments, and a long list of creditors who might take preference. But the enormous claims could carry negotiating leverage and potentially dilute the pot for others. ``The creditors who actually loaned money and bought ... bonds in what was then a very solvent company - it seems very unfair to them,'' said Steven Felderstein, lawyer for California's Public Employees Retirement System, a large Drexel creditor. ``Everybody sees Drexel as a place where there's a lot of money, and everybody wants their oar in the water,'' he said. Most claims are related to Drexel's 1989 guilty plea to six felony counts involving illegal trading. The thrift claims involve allegations that Drexel ran a corrupt junk bond network that helped push dozens of savings and loans to collapse. All the damages sought have been tripled to reflect alleged racketeering violations. In a 60-page bankruptcy court filing, the federal thrift bailout agencies claimed Drexel preached a ``gospel of greed'' that defrauded savings and loans by peddling inappropriate and risky securities from 1982. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and Resolution Trust Corp. alleged that Drexel made billions of dollars by inducing S&Ls to use their federally insured deposits to buy junk bonds. ``The exposure of Drexel's and Milken's criminality destroyed the illusions surrounding junk bonds that Drexel and Milken had sought to create,'' the filing said. The agencies charged Drexel manipulated junk bond prices, arranged secret securities ``parking'' deals, ran sham transactions, bribed favored customers and controlled a network of S&L customers to sustain a house-of-cards market. The filing presents the most vivid picture yet of allegations of impropriety in Drexel's dominance of the $200 billion market for the securities, which compensated for the risk of default by offering high yields. It lists 41 failed thrifts with junk bond losses totaling more than $330 million and seeks more than $1.25 million more in damages for the lost value of current holdings. Another 18 failed thrifts have separate non-junk bond claims. Institutions from 18 states and the District of Columbia are included. The alleged damages are tripled under federal antitrust and racketeering laws, for a total of $6 billion. The agencies seek $800 million for alleged illegal activity unrelated to junk bonds. A separate claim of more than $4.5 billion was filed on behalf of Columbia Savings and Loan Association of Beverly Hills, Calif., a major Drexel customer, which has not been taken over by the government. Drexel said it was targeted as a convenient scapegoat for the S&L crisis by the federal agencies. Other creditors also said the blame was misplaced and that the government claims likely would face challenges in court. ``The FDIC monitored the operations of all these thrifts while they were in business and did not take any steps to stop it while the actual conduct was going on,'' said Barry Dichter, attorney for one of Drexel's largest creditors.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards $45.3 Million to Lockheed Whistleblowers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Lockheed attorney comment on decision; Lockheed claim that Jones already had decided to retire, hometowns of plaintiffs. Pick up 10 graf, `Schielke, an ...' Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Jurors on Thursday ordered Lockheed Corp. to pay $45.3 million in damages to three former employees who claimed they were wrongfully fired for questioning the safety of the giant C-5B military cargo plane. Lockheed said it will appeal. ``We believe the punitive damages are an injustice and come as a result of appealing to the passions and prejudice of the jury,'' said Lockheed attorney Gordon Krischer. ``The evidence doesn't warrant this verdict.'' The plaintiffs asserted that four C-5Bs built with defective mainframes continue to fly and are currently transporting troops to Saudi Arabia, said Herbert Hafif, lawyer for two of the whistleblowers. ``Our next move is to ask the Congress to investigate this,'' Hafif said, asserting that evidence in the trial proved the planes are seriously flawed. The Superior Court jury announced the award after six days of deliberations and a six-week trial. ``The verdict speaks for itself,'' Hafif said. ``It is the first opportunity that regular citizens have had to speak to the faulty inspections, violations, specifications and other transgressions that permeate this industry and consume so much of the taxpayers' dollars.'' Clyde W. Jones Jr., 62, now of Tennessee; Terrence F. Schielke, 40, of Lancaster and Thomas E. Benecke, 48, of Thousand Oaks said in their lawsuit they were dismissed in 1985 after they wrote letters to Lockheed's second highest-ranking official demanding that the C-5B be grounded until tests could be made. The three said they were concerned about deficiencies in the mainframe of the cargo plane. Krischer claimed that Jones had already elected to retire before Lockheed officials learned of the trio's concerns. Schielke and Benecke were dismissed for circumventing company policies and audit procedures, he said. Schielke, an auditing supervisor on the project, said he repeatedly tried to warn the company that flawed parts were being used. ``The frames were cracked, warped, twisted,'' he said Thursday. ``And instead of scrapping them they went ahead and used them because it would have put them so far behind schedule to scrap them that the Defense Department would not have bought the planes.'' Each plaintiff was awarded $15 million in punitive damages. Awards for compensatory damages and emotional distress totaled $202,065 for Benecke, $91,660 for Jones and $82,789 for Schielke. ``The amount of punitive damages is grossly disproportionate to the actual damages found by the jury and is insupportable factually and legally,'' said the Lockheed vice president's statement. Eric Julber, who represented Benecke, said the jury award sends ``a message that you shouldn't fire people for raising safety concerns.'' He said Lockheed lawyers had informed the plaintiffs they will move for a new trial and, failing that, will appeal the case. ``This could go all the way to the Supreme Court because of the size of the punitive damages,'' Julber said. However, Hafif noted that the jury's award on actual damages was far less than what the plaintiffs had requested. They had asked for about $1.5 million and were given a total of about $376,000.

DOC.HEAD: Government Accepts Private Bids for State Telephone Company Sale
DOC.TEXT: The government received three bids for the state-controlled telephone company on Thursday, the deadline for private companies interested in buying part of Telefonos de Mexico. One bid came from a group made up of GTE, the Mexican stock brokerage Acciones y Valores, S.A. and Spain's Telefonica de Espana, Treasury Department spokesman Pablo Gonzalez said. Another bid came from Southwestern Bell, the Mexican Grupo Carso and France Cable and Radio, he said. Grupo Gentor, a majority Mexican company, placed the other bid, he said. The government kept the amounts of the bids secret. It will evaluate them by Dec. 3, then notify the winners. On Dec. 20, if the investors have paid the guarantee money required, the government will announce the accepted bidder, according to a timetable released in August. The timetable calls for the government to sell 20.4 percent of its shares by that date - 10.4 percent to Mexican investors and 10 percent to foreigners. The overall price will be $1.4 billion to $1.8 billion for 20.4 percent of the shares in the company, also known as Telmex. The government holds more than $4 billion worth of shares in the company valued at $8 billion and plans to sell all its shares within a year. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's administration is divesting itself of the phone company as part of an overall policy of selling off state enterprises, reducing budget deficits and trimming bureaucracy. Prospective investors had to deposit $10 million or prove more than $1 billion in assets to qualify for bidding.

DOC.HEAD: Nevada Regulators Keeping Close Eye On Bally's Nevada Casinos
DOC.TEXT: The Nevada Gaming Control Board has stepped up scrutiny of Bally's resorts in Las Vegas and Reno following word of financial problems facing their corporate parent. GCB Chairman Bill Bible said Thursday the board also has offered to speed up state review of any restructuring or other resolution that Chicago-based Bally Manufacturing proposes. Bible said he met with top Bally executives in late October and discussed the problems and strategies being developed to resolve them. He added that monitoring at the two Nevada resorts was increased to make sure gaming obligations are met. The two properties have cash on hand, Bible said. ``Our primary concern is that there is enough cash to pay off winning patrons and to function on a day-to-day basis. There's no evidence of any cash problems there.'' The monitoring and offer of a quick review are ``the extent of what we can do at this point in terms of the current business problems,'' Bible said. ``From the board's perspective, we're concerned about any licensee, large or small,'' he added. ``We're obviously concerned when it's one of the major players in our industry.'' On Wednesday Bally reported a third-quarter loss of $84.7 million and said it missed an $18.4 million payment to bondholders of its Nevada casinos. The results for the latest quarter include $9.1 million in litigation costs and a $69 million write-off in intangible assets, all related to a missed payment Oct. 15 on $1.8 billion in debt from a restructuring of Bally's Nevada casino subsidiary. Wednesday ended a 30-day grace period for Bally to make the loan payment. Spokeswoman Janie Lewis said the company was still in negotiations with its bondholders' on a debt restructuring plan. Bally operates four casino hotels and numerous fitness centers across the county and also markets a line of gaming equipment and fitness products. Arthur M. Goldberg, Bally's interim chief executive officer, said the company had lower operating results in all three business segments. Under a preliminary restructuring plan announced Monday, the company would hire an agent to sell Bally's Life Fitness Inc., a maker of fitness equipment that had sales of $70 million last year. The company also would scrap plans to sell its Health & Tennis Corp. subsidiary - which operates the nation's largest string of health clubs - and withdraw from an earlier deal to acquire the Clermont Club casino in London for $50 million. For the first nine months of this year, Bally had a net loss of $67.9 million, or $2.66 per share, on revenues of $1.63 billion compared to a loss of $29.6 million, or 88 cents a share, on revenues of $1.57 billion for the same period last year.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Stocks Off Sharply
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with morning dollar, Nikkei
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange plunged in morning trading Friday as a weaker yen, higher interest rates and concern about the Persian Gulf crisis discouraged investors, traders said. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average finished the morning down 557.56 points or 2.37 percent at 22,929.92 points. Trading was sluggish as the Middle East crisis has made market players cautious, particularly before the weekend, traders said. ``It's not that dealers are hoping for war in the Gulf, but there's a feeling that anything can happen over the weekend'' said Yoshiyuki Nishiguchi, a dealer at Daiwa Securities Co. Nishiguchi noted stock prices have been rising at the start of the week recently, then falling as investors try to unload their holdings before the weekend. The dollar stood at 129.68 yen, up 0.38 yen from Thursday's close. After opening at 129.85 yen, morning trades ranged from 129.65 yen and 129.95 yen. In bond dealings, the price of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell to 84.41 points from Thursday's 84.47-point finish. Their yield was higher at 7.845 percent from 7.830. Although the dollar opened higher following its increase on overseas markets, early trading lacked direction in the absence of fresh market-affecting news, dealers said. Minori Takeuchi, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo, said investors were focusing more on German mark-yen trading than dollar-yen exchanges, and purchases of the German currency were indirectly helping to push the dollar up. Takeuchi said some investors are waiting for a series of economic reports that are scheduled to come out Friday, including the September U.S. trade figures and the October consumer price index. But many traders did not foresee a radical plunge of the dollar even if the Federal Reserve makes a long-anticipated move to lower interest rates. A dealer at Mitsubishi Bank noted the dollar's range was slowly rising and probably will hover at the 129-130 yen level. Dealers have put the range at between mid-127 yen and 130 yen for the past month.

DOC.HEAD: Community Newspapers Inc. Buying Back Bonds
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf with two grafs to UPDATE with Jelenic comment; PICK UP last graf, Community Newspapers ...
DOC.TEXT: Community Newspapers Inc. said Thursday it will repurchase a big chunk of troublesome junk-bond debt, which was believed to play a role in the departure of publisher Ralph Ingersoll II earlier this year. The newspaper chain, which publishes three dailies in Ohio, said it had reached agreement with holders of about two-thirds of its junk bonds to repurchase for $130 million in cash a batch of the risky securities with a face value totaling about $240 million. The move is a good one for Community Newspapers because it alleviates the company's obligation to pay the high rate of interest on the bonds, said Ned P. Zachar, an analyst with Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago. Community Newspapers said in a statement that it expects to complete the transactions by the first week of January. The holders of the outstanding 13 percent senior subordinated notes due July 1, 1997, would get $95 million in cash. Holders of subordinated discount debentures would get $35 million in cash. These were some of the same bonds that troubled Ingersoll, a prominent publisher who used extensive junk-bond financing to expand his U.S.newspaper holdings in the 1980s but encountered difficulty making the interest payments as advertising revenue weakened. In July, Community Newspapers said it couldn't make an interest payment on some of these bonds after Ingersoll sought unsuccessfully to repurchase them. At the same time, Ingersoll traded his U.S. properties and their debt burden to investment partner E.M. Warburg, Pincus & Co., in exchange for control of a smaller group of European newspapers. Ingersoll said the deal was driven by a desire to get more involved in European publishing. But bankers and investors said his newspaper buying spree had left him with too much debt. Robert Jelenic, chief executive officer of the Journal Register Co., said Thursday night he was pleased with the deal. ``This transaction is supposed to close in January, and I'll be extremely happy. I'm pleased with the deal as it is structured,'' Jelenic said in a telephone interview from New Jersey. Community Newspapers publishes The Morning Journal in Lorain, The News Herald in Lake County and the Dover-New Philadelphia Times Reporter, all in Ohio.
